And why does he cut his fingers off and make himself incapable of playing the music he wants to be remembered for?3) The character of Dominic was just a complete waste of time.

Colin Farrell is one of my favourite actors and seeing that he was also with Brendan Gleeson (which reminded of the superb film 'In Bruges'), I thought that it would certainly be a great film to watch. Well, how wrong I was!!! There were probably only one or two lines that were funny but the remainder of the film was ridiculous. Who in the world would vow to cut off his fingers if Farrell/Padraic spoke to him again and actually go through with it and cut off all fingers and thumb of his hand??? No way! It made so angry to think that the writer, McDonagh, would assume that he was writing some brilliant script when, in fact, it was absolute tosh! Nope people, very, very disappointing and if you decide to watch it, I really hope you enjoy it as much as I hated it!

reviews.review_title: Only good things about it were the landscapes and animals
reviews.content: Rave reviews by the critics - I should have smelled a rat! Yes it was beautifully filmed and the farm animals were adorable. The donkey should have got Best Actor in the Golden Globes, though(!) Not to say that Farrell and Gleeson are bad actors, but this was shoddy material. The plot made zero sense and was in extremely bad taste, in my view. And now this film was given a Golden Globe for Best Film! This disturbs me in that it could lead to more film makers thinking that they can also get away with such offensive nonsense. If the award was given for the cinematography then OK, well deserved, but of course it wasn't just that, unfortunately. I can deal with depressing films if they have a point and a compelling story. This had neither and, suffice it to say, that this turgid travesty of a 'film' left me in a bad mood.

reviews.review_title: Not as thought-provoking as made out to be
reviews.content: Happy to see this director and our two leads reunited - I loved In Bruges. I was looking forward to another potential dark comedy with poignant themes of humanity. However I thought this was just a bit of a boring downer. I'm sure there's a ton to glean into allegory-wise with the Civil War and the whole "banshees" theme. However, I found myself too bored to care. The story at face value was so simple and straightforward that it just didn't hit me on a personal level. I kept waiting for a payoff that never came and the story ironically just stayed dull. It's a breakup story set on a rural island full of miserable people who are stuck in a depression spiral...yeesh. The acting was good, the setting was unique and the direction was solid. I'm seeing some notes on great cinematography though? I don't really think so. Ultimately, this was a quality-made film whose message is not at all thought-provoking as it thinks it is (from my point of view). People need healthy social interaction. Also, some people are better off living in certain types of communities than others in would likely be happier if they found a good fit for themselves. Like yeah...I know.

reviews.review_title: Tedious and depressing, makes one simple point in too much time
reviews.content: 4/10 very disappointed by this super depressing simple allegorical story about someone who decides to shun their friend, but then harms himself to make a point... and I guess the point the movie makes is that our resentments or self righteousness really end up hurting ourselves as well others. But why does SUCH A NEGATIVE movie need to be made to make such a basic point. The acting was great, but sheesh, I did not enjoy that AT ALL. I would not recommend this movie to anyone as it seems pointless. It is well constructed, well acted, but the metaphor/allegoric vessel is just so ugly and unnecessary.

reviews.review_title: Not funny, not sad, not entertaining.
reviews.content: This movie is not funny. This movie is not sad. This movie is not entertaining. This movie is, quite simply, stupid. Yes, it has great cinematography. Yes, it has a great cast. Yes, the sets are great. But, the 800 pound gorilla in the room, is the script. The script is pure nonsense. In fact, the script is so nonsensical it is farcical. There is no 'art value' in "The Banshees of Inisherin." In fact, there is no value, at all. What a waste of a great cast. The writing is utter nonsense, utter gibberish, utterly pointless. We actually watched the entire movie and can only say one thing positive about it- this movie is the epitome of a "Lifetime Bad Movie."

Fun for all the family! I can see why it came to streaming at Christmas, on Disney+ of all things. I'm joking, it's grim and depressing, as well as pointless and meaningless. The two leads and the writer/director collaborated on "In Bruges", which is superb, and why I looked forward to this film, almost watching it at the cinema. I'm sure glad I didn't. The acting is great all round though, and there are some humorous moments in the first half an hour or so, but then it's downhill all the way. Don't bother, it's a massive downer, all in service of nothing. The music's not bad, and the cinematography is decent.

reviews.review_title: Not fun to watch...even in an ironic way
reviews.content: Every now and then a film comes along that seems to get showered in praise and accolades...and then you watch it and you say, "huh?" That's 'The Banshees of Inisherin.'The Ireland-set "tragicomedy" (is that even a subgenre?) is getting rave reviews for its story of two middle-aged men who have a seemingly one-sided falling out (or "row") on a tiny Irish island community in the 1920s. Okay, sounds kinda interesting on paper. But Martin McDonagh's film is painful to watch.For one, it's hard to find any real humor here. I didn't so much as crack a smile once throughout the 116 minutes. Yes, the story is supposed to be dark, but it's dark in an unironic way. Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson do not deliver memorable performances here - their characters are poorly written, so it's hard for them to bring them to life. Barry Keoghan is also pitiful to watch as Dominic, the island's dunce, although Kerry Condon stands out as Siobhan, the disgruntled sister of Farrell's Padraic.There are also just unnecessarily gross scenes, which are probably meant to be funny...but they do not land. Even though I have Ireland in my blood, I just didn't get the humor here.Yes, 'The Banshees of Inisherin' will go on to win many more awards, but just because "everyone" says a film is good, it doesn't mean you have to like it yourself.

reviews.review_title: Why was this movie even made????
reviews.content: No plot....no point....as boring a movie as you will ever have the displeasure of suffering through. I have absolutely no idea why this movie was made.Ok, they live on an island off the coast of Ireland (we assume) and they are bored to tears although we have no clue what they do for a living nor why they live there. We have zero background on the players and we're never given any. They hate their lives and all we see them do is walk back and forth from their home to the pub or the church. They drink ale and complain about how miserable they are. THAT'S IT.....they have friends and enemies. THAT'S IT.What an ABSOLUTE SNOOZEFEST....there's no reason or point......INCREDIBLY BORING.

Terrible movie with miserable characters in a miserable environment, unable or unwilling to take action to improve their lives.The history of Ireland does wrap around poverty, misery and oppression. However, an important counterpoint is that millions of vibrant and brave Irish men and woman had the courage to walk away and find new and bountiful lives in new lands, including America, Australia and Canada.This utterly depressing movie is the story of those who were too timid, lazy or dim to leave. Instead, they double down and wallow in their small minded misery. I persevered to the end of the movie, walked out being thankful that the movie reminded me that nihilism is a useless and destructive philosophy. The donkey was superb!

The Banshees of Inisherin is the quirky indie darling for the 2023 Oscar season. The ones the critics love but in a few years time, people will be scratching their heads wondering what all the fuss was about.Set in the early 1920s. Ireland is tearing itself apart with a civil war, wanting independence from Britain.In a small island of the coast, Pádraic (Colin Farrell) finds his best friend, Colm (Brendan Gleeson) has made his own bid for independence. He no longer wants to talk to Pádraic as he is a bore and life is short. Colm wants to produce music, leave something artistic behind. Inane chatter is not part of the deal.This comes as a shock to the dimwitted Pádraic. His life in the island is his sister Siobhán (Kerry Condon) his miniature donkey Jenny and Colm.He cannot believe that Colm would abandon him and thinks it is a joke. Colm is not joking and begins to cut off his fingers each time Pádraic speaks to him.This is a black farce. Maybe it is an allegory of the Irish civil war or about mental illness or toxic masculinity.There is a sadistic cop who constantly beats his simpleton son Dominic (Barry Keoghan.) He also picks on Pádraic for giving shelter to his son.By the end Pádraic realises he is on his own. His sister has gone to the mainland, his donkey has died, he finally fathoms that his relationship with Colm is toxic. By which point Colm has no digits left in one of his hands. No wonder he had to give up the fiddle.The film is bleakly funny, the acting is good. It is a small scale film but I felt cut off by it. It had nowhere left to go just like the characters stuck in Inisherin.

I thought that was the biggest load of pretentious rubbish I've ever seen in my life. I stopped watching when the not so cunningly disguised Vincent Van Gogh character cut off his second finger. I couldn't stand it any more. Vincent Van Gleeson sits glowering in a pub for no particular reason. Moronic Farrell character can't understand the whole thing. Repeat many, many times.Never has a director shouted, 'Look at me, look at me, look at me - I'm so clever. I'm doing yer actual ART here', more loudly or more persistently.An absolute pile of steaming cow pat.Total and utter twaddle. Nice Oirishy scenery and music, though.

It's at first boring and dull and then slowly becomes a bit interesting...(the will he or won't he.)But then it's back to the inevitable dull and boring.Then interesting again but less so (the will he or won't he again!)But I loved the Dominic character and the movie kinda runs over his storyline, which is actually the more interesting by the end.And why are most of the villagers just background? No one helps bandage injuries or stop child abuse, or even be at the house at 2pm for the near conclusion when of course it spread to all on the island what was to occur.Did I love the cinematography? Resounding yes.Did I love the acting? Pretty much from all.The directing, very good too.But the story is ultimately what you'll remember and ensure you'll never want to watch this movie ever again. One and done as they say. At least for me.End result...this would never be on my recommended list.

"The Banshees of Inisherin" is a Comedy - Drama movie in which we watch two very good friends in a remote island stop talking to each other after one of them chose to do so but this choice will have some consequences.I have to admit that I did not know what to expect from this movie before watching it so, I was very intrigued to watch it. The plot was a bit bizarre at first but I found it interesting as time passed. The interpretations of both Colin Farrell who played as Pádraic Súilleabháin and Brendan Gleeson who played as Colm Doherty were very good and their combination worked very well for one more time. The direction which was made by Martin McDonagh who is also the writer, it was very good and he presented very well his main characters and the connection between them. In conclusion, I have to say that "The Banshees of Inisherin" is not a movie for everyone so, I advise you to read about it before deciding whether or not to watch it.

Typical Oscar trash. Colin Farrell is not a good actor. Just watch "Alexander" if you don't believe me. This is an unrealistic, gory, gross, disturbing horror movie. There is no comedy. Not one single funny thing about it. I don't know what kind of person writes and directs a ridiculous movie like this, but getting all of this Oscar attention surly won't make him stop.And just a warning to animal lovers, there is a typical movie trope that if a character has a beloved animal companion, that animal will be killed as a plot device.Do yourself a favor and avoid this nonsensical story about insane characters. 1 star outta 5.

reviews.review_title: Meaningless and repulsive - avoid at all costs
reviews.content: Banshees of Inisherin is the most tedious, unpleasant, mindless, pointless, worthless film I've ever seen. It has beautiful photography, great acting, and absolutely nothing to say about anything. It's about horrendously unlikable people, doing horrendously violent and unpleasant things - for no particular reason. And then it ends, making no point whatsoever. You come away nervous and depressed, in every way poorer than you came in.I'm at a loss to explain the critics' view of this as some work of genius. I can only surmise that professional critics have become so wrapped up in their own need to one-up each other, in discovering some kind of hidden treasure, that anything sufficiently 'artsy' starts to look brilliant. This film is the opposite of brilliant - it's dull, miserable, repetitive and above all unfunny by even the 'blackest' standard.I give Banshees a very charitable two stars, one for the acting, one for the scenery. I should probably deduct at least one of those for the gruesome and entirely needless violence, but I don't want to seem vindictive.

Greetings again from the darkness. IN BRUGES is a cinematic litmus test. It turns out, whether someone is a fan of that movie or not is a particularly dependable indicator of similar or disparate tastes in dark comedy material. For me, it's a film I never tire of ... whether re-watching in its entirety or catching just a few scenes while surfing. The plot is bleak, yet we laugh. The characters are sad, yet we are charmed. It's the perfect blend of character, story, and setting ... and proves how exceptional and precise screenwriting can be. So why am I writing so much about a movie from 2008? Well, that film's writer-director, Martin McDonagh, is back, and he's brought along that film's co-stars, Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson.Now don't think this is yet another in the endless stream of Hollywood sequels. It's not. These are (much) different characters in a (much) different setting. What does remain the same is the onscreen magic when Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson collaborate with writer-director McDonagh. It's how some singers are meant to sing one song (Sinatra belting "New York, New York"), or how some athletes are tied to a particular team (Sandy Koufax to the Dodgers). These three talented men are at their best when working together.Padraic (Farrell) and Colm (Gleeson) have been best buddies for most of their lives. Every day at 2:00, Padraic fetches Colm and they head to the pub. One could set their watch by this. That all changes one day when Colm refuses to answer the door when his pal knocks. Later that day, he informs Padraic that they are no longer friends, as he refuses to waste another moment drowning in inane conversation, and instead will focus on fiddle music and living his life to the fullest. Padraic is shook and confused ... as are the bartender and the other folks in this quaint (fictional) seaside village in coastal Ireland. There is a certain symmetry with the civil war playing out on the mainland and this break in a friendship. A crack about not knowing why the sides are fighting in the war adds yet more symmetry as Padraic searches for meaning in the rift.When Colm finally tells Padraic that he doesn't like him anymore and he doesn't want his old friend speaking a word to him, we initially understand and agree with his reasoning, even if it seems a bit harsh. Padraic is a bit of a bore - a man satisfied with his work as a milk farmer and spending off hours petting Jenny, his pet donkey, before blowing a couple more hours chatting at the pub, and ultimately retiring to the tiny cottage he shares with his erudite sister Siobhan (a superb Kerry Condon, "Better Call Saul", "Ray Donovan"). Dull, dim, not a thinker ... all descriptions of Padraic we hear, though his self-reflection finds a gentle, kind soul - mostly harmless and enjoying his daily life. Well, that is, right up until his best friend locks him out.The interactions between Padraic and Colm are fascinating to watch. The two actors play off each other so well, we find ourselves hoping they will be together on screen without a break. It's here where McDonagh's script really shines. Ms. Condon as Siobhan and Barry Keoghan (DUNKIRK, THE KILLING OF A SACRED DEER, 2017) as Dominic both play significant roles (as does Jenny the miniature donkey). What initially seems like commentary on a shattered friendship between two men expands significantly thanks to these two characters. It reminds us that our network, regardless of how small, has an impact on others, even on a remote island in Ireland. The script and actors blend here to drive home the point.Siobhan begins to question her own existence and how she might pursue her own dreams. Local boy Dominic is the son of an abusive policeman, and his troubles seem to run deeper than just being the town oddball. He likely has mental issues, yet occasionally shows flashes of hyper-awareness. He befriends Padraig after the split, and his unconventional personality never quite sits well with others. When Dominic's own dream gets shot down, he doesn't possess the capacity to handle it well. The story and the island sustain tragedies, both small and large, and to top it off, there is a creepy old woman in the village who has visions of death.Once we have settled into the drum beat of the split between Padraig and Colm, McDonagh raises the stakes, bringing an unusual form of violence into the proceedings. This catches us and Padraig and the whole of the village off guard, and makes for a stunning visual and eye-opening shock. There is no way to go into further detail without spoilers that should not be conveyed. What you need to know is that this is expert filmmaking, superb screenwriting, and the best acting of Colin Farrell's career ... leading the way for other excellent performances. Facing one's own mortality is never easy, and we can each relate to Colm's search for meaning as he sees time slipping away. The film also treats us to the best ever confessional scene, and more frequent uses of the word "fecking" than we've ever experienced. The beauty of the island is shown, but never featured. Instead, McDonagh does what he does best - delivers memorable characters and dialogue and unforgettable surprises. He also makes us wonder if our laughter is socially acceptable, causing us to be thankful for the dark theater.Opening wide in theaters on November 4, 2022.

Odd, yes ... this is indeed an odd movie.It starts off brilliantly. It's pretty light and intriguing ... the dialogue and banter is fantastic ... then it gets dark.When the first finger gets cut off ... it was very extreme and not really explained. Why did he feel he had to go to that length? Then ... despite being warned (again!) that he'd cut off more he goes right back at Colm and he cuts every one off!!! I mean ... how stupid is this guy?!?The poor wee donkey dying was the worst bit though ... although it did finally get Padraig to quit being so desperate and needy. However ... he then goes to extreme himself and burns Colm's house down. WTF?Hated the ending as well. One of those endings that isn't actually an ending at all. We're left with the two men left living there and now one's totally got it in for the other one ... who started all this in the first place!It was a strange film that started excellently and then got a bit daft, for me. I don't think I "got it". I'm thinking this is maybe more a critics film - who can analyse the meaning a lot better than I can.Performances and scenery were absolutely fantastic!61/100.

I waited for this movie for a very long time, but the film did not deserve the wait and hope that it will be another masterpiece. A lot of people will probably disagree with me, because the movie is rated really high, but I don't think it's a well done piece. After the wonderful 'Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri', I thought this movie would be just as good, but I am very disappointed.'Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri' was bright, real, which leaves a very big impression, which will not be forgotten for a very long time, that's why I thought that this director would definitely make such an impactful film again.'The Banshees of Inisherin' tells the story of two friends who became angry with each other for very vague reasons and are now no longer friends, but the film does not give a good reason for this anger. The film doesn't catch your interest and the plot is also not surprising as it is not a strong story.All in all, I was very disappointed with this movie, but maybe it was because I expected too much from it, but I didn't see what I wanted to see.

In this worldwide aura of PC, if I were Irish I would be offended by this movie. After all, people are offended every day but considerably smaller issues. That said, I must say that the movie is a huge dissapointment. Apart from the scenery and animals, and in a way Mr Farrell's eybrows there are no redeeming points. The plot is ludicrous and thin as a wafer, the acting wooden and forced, there is no character evolving (or character writing in the firs place), they are all dumb or psychotic, or both and that's that. The movie is too long because after the first 20 minutes, a discerning movie fan knows the outcome, the gimmicks and the message. Maybe the moviemakers of today are dumb or they think their audiences are dumb, but there is no need to be so heavy handed with a message albeit a noble one.

The Banshees of Inisherin is a puzzle to me. I get what the movie is about: an allegorical tragedy about the flailing friendship between two men as a parallel to the Irish Civil War. The cinematography is top notch, the performances from Collin Farrell and Brenden Gleeson are spot on, the atmosphere and setting is authentic, and this movie succeeds in making you feel like you're staring into an Irish island village.I get what this movie is doing. But what I don't get is the high revery for a pretty, but middling movie. What kills it for me is the B.o.I.'s glacial pacing. It is so slow, so much nothing happens and it's so repetitive. When the movie attempted to go weird, it doesn't feel earned cause the level of insanity is never really established. The accents feel way too over the top and heavy, and for a dark comedy, very few of the comedy lands. By the end, I was more bored than I was invested. Not a terrible movie, but not a phenomenal one either.

reviews.review_title: Oscar worthy? What did I miss?
reviews.content: With all of the hype surrounding this movie I expected more. Seinfeld was a show about nothing. Well here's a movie about nothing. (disclaimer, I loved Seinfeld, this movie not so much) The point of this movie may have been over my head but neither my wife or I found much enjoyment in sitting through this one. This film is listed as a comedy. Huh? There was much more sadness than laughter. The story started nowhere and ended the same. The donkey was my favorite part and they choked him to death on a detached finger. Sounds strange right? That's my point in a nutshell. Yes it's easy to see that the actors gave their best and there's some beautiful shots but this one just didn't deliver for me.

What an UN-feel-good movie. Unpleasant. Uncomfortable. Weird. Ranks right up there with one of the worst movies I've ever seen. Sets, scenes, shots, camera work were all very good. Production quality was very good. And there was nothing wrong with the acting. It was simply and unpleasant and very incomplete story leaving you with more questions than answers. You feel CRAPPY after watching this movie. I want the two hours of my life back I lost to this terrible thing! On a 1 to 10 scale, I gave this a 3. I watched it with my wife and 21 year old daughter.. and we all felt the same way after seeing it.

After In Bruges (being my all-time favorite movie) and Three Billboards, I expected another masterpiece.I found satisfying
the cinematographymusicbrilliant acting from Colin Farrell (I hope he gets an Oscar this time)the dark athmosperethe brutalitythought-provoking conversationsWhat disappointed me
poor story vs too long playtimelack of brilliant comedy that I expectedno relief, I left the cinema with sad, depressed feelings, without a single good laughUnfortunately I really overhyped this one to my wife as well who will trust my recommendations less from now on...

reviews.review_title: Over hyped by many to look relevant
reviews.content: Honestly , the response to this film is rediculous, it reminds me of the Irish man , over hyped because of things the actors and director have done beforeIn bruge is brilliant , the guard is brilliant , Calvary is very goodIt is too dark with no real story line or big characters to drag it throughNearly every character is unlikeable, no pleasing story arc , no real endingThere are however lots of hidden messages that I bet the director thinks he hid better than he didThis is a film made by people so they can say how good they are at making films , it is not to be enjoyed by the end user.

I can easily say that this is one of the least interesting & most miserable films I have ever seen & the constant use of the F word is exhausting. The irony of the film being so dull is that the whole point of the film is that a man (Brendan Gleeson) who suffers with depression stops talking to his friend (Colin Farrell) because he says he finds him too dull. Half an hour in, and that's it. Colin continues to speak to Brendan, so Brendan threatens to chop off his fingers if his dull friend Colin continues to speak to him. Colin speaks to him, so Brendan chops off a finger. The village idiot tries to befriend Colin & chat up his sister. Colin speaks to Brendan again, so he chops a load more fingers off. Well that's an hour gone! Colins's sister moves away and his lovely little donkey chokes to death on one of Brendan's discarded fingers, so Colin decides to set fire to Brendan's house the following day, saying that he'll do it whether Brendan is inside or not- which is exactly what he does. The village idiot is found drowned. Brendan leaves the house whilst it is going up in flames, and Colin find him alive and well (well, apart from the numerous missing fingers) the next day. And that's your lot!This was not only one of the dullest but the most miserable films I have ever seen and if it hadn't been for my husband leaving it on until the end there's no way I'd have wasted an hour and a half of my life on this rubbish. On the bright side, the views are superb & the animals are not only cute, but great actors.

reviews.review_title: Dismal, dark and empty and that's just the island
reviews.content: I'm not usually taken in by the hype around a movie but "The Banshees of Inisherin" sounded just so good that I tried many times to see it in the cinema. Luckily that never happened because I would have asked for my money back. Rarely has a film disappointed so hard.The problem is that it offers so much and delivers so little. The core story arc of a lifelong friendship being terminated has so much potential for psychological nuance but not here. Instead you've got one guy saying that it's over and the other guy not getting it. While both start morosely into their pints of Guinness.On the upside the Irish seaside looks wonderful (although I don't know how they managed to find so many days without rain), the dialogue brogue charming and the acting solid. It's just a shame that the film doesn't know where it's going and can't stumble across any sort of conclusion.

reviews.review_title: Not quite at the level of In Bruges or Three Billboards, but very close
reviews.content: The latest film from Martin McDonagh, and given how good his track record has been, I was really looking forward to this one. After seeing it, I think I'd put it a little behind In Bruges and Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri (not by much) and ahead of Seven Psychopaths.Like most of his films, it blends very dark comedy with very heavy subject matter, and here, the two are balanced exceptionally well. The premise is also an intriguing one that despite its simplicity, hasn't been attempted by many other films (to my knowledge). Essentially, there are two close friends, and one of them decides he doesn't want to be friends with the other. The other naturally protests, with the first friend then threatening severe consequences if he continues to try and rekindle the friendship (or even talk to him).There are hilarious scenes, really emotionally devastating scenes, and some scenes that do both at once. I think that overall, the best part of the film is its screenplay, as it balances the comedy and drama brilliantly, features exceptionally well written dialogue, and creates solid characters who you get to know well throughout the film. It helps that the acting is also great, especially Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson in the lead roles.There are a couple of minor side characters whose inclusion I didn't think added much, and the final act is a bit oddly structured. The ending is also one I'll need to sit with a bit, because it did leave me with an unusual feeling.Returning to this film again may well improve it, as despite the simple premise, there's a ton going on here, and a great deal to think about it. The themes surrounding hate, fear of loneliness, a societal divisions, and the difficulty of forgiveness all feel very relevant to the 2020s, even while this film is set in the 1920s. In the end, I'm happy to rate it a strong 8/10 for now, and I wouldn't be surprised if I felt compelled to give it higher if/when I give it another watch.

On a remote Irish island, Pádraic Súilleabháin (Colin Farrell) and Colm Doherty (Brendan Gleeson) used to be best friends. Out of the blue, Colm declares that he no longer wants Pádraic to talk to him. He thinks that Pádraic is too boring and life is too short to waste talking to boring people. Pádraic lives with his sister Siobhán (Kerry Condon).This starts a bit quirky. Then it gets dark. It has some funny moments. Then it gets real dark. There're some more laughs and the darkness never leaves. It's very Irish. Colin Farrell is playing against type and that takes some getting used to at first. All the actors are delivering great work. The dog delivers the biggest laugh. I really appreciate Barry Keoghan who does this sort of character like no one else. It's an Irish macabre tragic comedy.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful acting, beautiful scenery, on point direction. Shame about the story.
reviews.content: I tend to judge a film by the way it makes me feel. A great film will leave me exhilarated, shocked, upset, happy and so on.Banshees just left me feeling nothing. Nothing at all. The film started, mildly humorous stuff happened, then weird stuff happened, then even more weird and slightly shocking stuff happened. I ended up feeling nothing, at all, for any of the characters when the film ended with no real conclusion.Then it ended.Normally when a film finishes with questions left unanswered I wonder or imagine what may happen to the characters involved. I really couldn't care less what happened to Pádraic and Colm in the future. Maybe that was the point but, if it was, it left me cold.A film should tell a story, should make some kind of sense and come to some kind of conclusion. Banshees does none of those things. The story feels like it was made up on the hoof and. McDonagh, either finally bored with it or, possibly, realising he'd painted himself into a literary corner decided to call it a day.Four stars for the great acting, cinematography, location and direction but the most important part, a compelling story is utterly missing,

This is yet another example of nothing being talked into something by critics and the awards establishment just because it's a bit 'edgy' when in actual fact it's boring and unbelievable. The basic plot of two male acquaintances stuck in an isolated rural community off the coast of Ireland falling out and engaging in a dark, macabre and ridiculous feud as presented here is totally unbelievable. Now dark and macabre can work in a setting which is slightly off kilter but this is set in a very real time (1920's Irish Civil War) and a very real looking community so the events just do not work, not on any level. The two principal players give fine performances, Gleeson's is a bit of a riff on his Calvary character, but Farrell makes his character's bewilderment and anger very believable. Fine support is also forthcoming from Kerry Condon & Barry Keoghan but none of this helps a plotline which is totally unbelievable, medically impossible and thoroughly depressing. Much has been made of how this is a parable about the Irish civil war or a commentary on toxic masculinity, it's not, someone came up with a bizarre central theme and then clothed it in normality to make it seem like art. The fact that this is up for awards tells you something about how far from reality and audience appetites the film establishment really is.

I really do not understand the ravings and the high score for this dull dreary and boring film. Honestly, what was in the mind of those behind creation of this garbage? The scenes are great, the music is wonderful, the houses are really beautiful. But, all this does not make a film good. First, what was wrong between these two main weirdos? Whar was the cause of their row and falling out? Where was the movie going? What was the point of the movie? What did the other guy chopped off his wingers? And yet he did not any pain no infection? Was he trying to show his love? Was a masochist? Honestly, I do not understand what was wrong with them and why this movie even was created.Dont waste time on this silly dull movie.

reviews.review_title: A peculiar mix of comedy and drama, but well worth watching.
reviews.content: A very peculiar film manly about two people living in a small isolated rural Irish island community. It manages to deliver laugh out loud comedy and hefty emotional drama intermingled with great scenery and poignant imagery.- - - - - - - - -The acting of the relatively small cast of characters is good, even if some of them are a bit stereotypical, and the detached atmosphere comes across through the characters and the setting. It does struggle a bit towards the end to reach a point, but it's still enjoyable throughout.- - - - - - - - -Overall, I would score this film as an eight out of ten.

reviews.review_title: Wonderful beginning, followed by incredulity and disappointment...
reviews.content: I was really looking forward to this film. I am massive fan of Martin McDonagh's movies.But TBOI left me feeling confused. Was it meant to be a metaphor for the Irish Civil War? Was it trying to demonstrate the effects of life on an island? Or was it all about the complications of long term friendship?Whatever Martin McDonagh was trying to say was very muddled.It started so well. Beautiful music, stunning cinematography, some lovely comedy and an intriguing story about companionship on a tiny island in 1923. Thirty minutes in, I was well and truly hooked. This was shaping up to be a classic.And then....boom! It all gets rather silly. Fiddle-playing Gleason makes a big speech about how important his music is to him, then starts cutting his fingers off to try and stop Colin Farrell from talking to him. Eh? Who would do that? This barbaric self -mutilation would be unbelievably painful and probably lead to a massive infection. But no, he carries on stoically as if he'd over-trimmed his fingernails.Continuing the madness, Colin Farrell still doesn't "get it" and decides to burn Gleason's house down regardless of whether he's inside or not. Gleason miraculously escapes the flames and the two of them mumble some incoherent nonsense to each other the following morning. THE END.What a shame. I looked around the Showroom in Sheffield and there was a lot of head shaking and cheeks being puffed out.Yes, make a dark comedy. Throw in some plot twists. Get the audience thinking. But please, make it credible. The finger chopping rubbish ruined what could have been a really good movie.

Is The Banshees of Inisherin only about a man who no longer wishes to be friends with another? In terms of plot, yes. That's it. Beyond that I suppose one is free to speculate and analyze. Which is probably part of the reason for the acclaim it is receiving. After becoming a Hollywood star and doing all types of movies Colin Farrell has returned to his Irish roots, you could say, in a role he's done to demonstrate his acting abilities.For the majority of the time it tries to amuse you with the most quirky and offbeat humor which like most comedies, some of it sticks and a lot doesn't. But don't expect a conventional comedy. As a matter of fact don't expect anything conventional from it at all. Its bizarreness and idiosyncrasies are uniquely it's own and theres really nothing you can compare it to.Is The Banshees of Inisherin great? I think not. Is it bad? I wouldn't say so either. You can simply describe it as a film.

reviews.review_title: If you're looking for wit Martin McDonagh is known for, you'll be disappointed
reviews.content: As a major fan of 'In Bruges' and 'Three Billboards', I couldn't wait to see this film. Made a big night of it with friends who are equally in awe of Martin McDonagh's work. If you are expecting ANYTHING close to 'In Bruges', you will not find any of that humour here. You will find the acting skills of Farrell and Gleeson again, but you will be left waiting minute after minute for the humour to burst out. It never does.The cinema audience had a few chuckles, which frankly felt forced because we were all invested in making this humorous to justify our love of McDonagh, to validate the hype, to not feel we're missing something. We are all post-graduates so we're aware of our Shakespeare comedies and tragedies (see other reviews) - and we were all left VERY disappointed.This is a mis-billed film and the trailer heavily implies another dark comedy that you'll find once you watch the full film. In reality, it's nothing but darkness, slowness, and a teaser to wrack your brains into working out what the heck the point was.The best I can do is say it's an allusion to rural living pre modern age, when our grandparents would tell stories of their parents and neighbours who bore grudges, and over generations in the pubs the stories became ever more fanciful with the telling, so that in the end we never really know the truth.

reviews.review_title: Depressing, dull and dreary - writer must have has Covid
reviews.content:
I am a huge fan of the Director and thought maybe with two fantastic actors from In Bruges that this could potentially be a wonderful entertaining filmInstead it feels almost like a short film that got turned into a one and a half hour depressing full dragged out idiotic pseudo horror film or maybe the Director was stuck during Covid on some Irish island and someone told him this silly fable which almost forced most of Ireland to commit suicide because it was so bloody depressing of a story. One wonders why woukd such a talented director make such a terrible film.It is a simple story and it is simply never gets beyond
2 dimensional characters that are so predictable and depressing that people were waking out of the theatre pissed off. So do yourself a favor maybe wait for the streaming for free so you can fast forward through it but I have no idea how it got such high ratings as it was mediocre at best.Kudos to both the stars but it always comes down to the script which in this case was beyond terrible and depressing and trite.Three stars for the donkey and dog.

A movie for viewers who need to be hit over the head with direct pointers to social issues, and where setting the movie in a remote location passes for profundity.The two leads clod-hop through the weak script like they are doing an Abbott and Costello performance. Cliches abound and the story plods along telegraphing each coming scene.The setting is picturesque - but it is even when a film crew is not there, so the movie isn't adding to but rather is just stealing from the natural beauty.One Hundred and two more letter are required to make this available. It seems that more effort is required than for the script. But the film didn't need more words, just better ones.

reviews.review_title: Not by any stretch of the imagination is this a comedy
reviews.content: A heavy foreboding hangs over every minute of this tragic story. I was duped into believing there was going to be humour here. I did not find it. I also found the depictions of insanity completely unbelievable. On the plus side there was some gorgeous scenery, and one does come away with a bit of a feeling for the isolated island life, but should we expect everybody on that bloody island to be insane? Another unforgivable piece of rubbish used to support the goofy story is the donkey choking on a finger and that finger being found just inside the donkey's mouth. Why didn't he just spit it out. Lots of emotion demonstrated, but not like that of any human I have known.

reviews.review_title: I feel like I'm taking crazy pills
reviews.content: That's what went through my mind after watching this movie and reading some of the user reviews. I consider myself a cinema fan and I've been watching a large array of different genres from different eras, and I was expecting something much more from a movie that won a Golden Globe. But this one...good God! OK, I understand an absurd situation, I can understand that each of us have our own strangeness and moods, I can accept that Colm just decided to cut ties with Padraic just like that. I can even accept that because of cultural differences and a different mindset in different eras, I might miss some part of the message in this movie. The act of cutting his own fingers, as extreme as it is, represents the pinnacle of the extreme reactions someone might take, a price to pay to be left alone. But at the same time it seems so unnecessary, so pointless, so uninteresting. Siobhan's act of leaving to find a new life, that old crone, the dead donkey...it's all too much.I felt like I was watching something so weird and bad that it makes you want to watch more hoping to find a meaning.It's like a car crash, you can't look away.I get that it's the kind of movie that you either love it, or hate it. I can accept the existence of this movie. But when it starts receiving awards and praises, you start questioning everyone's sanity, your own included. Am I the crazy one, or they are? It's like watching the naked emperor, but you also notice that the emperor also forgot to take his sanity pills.I was reluctant at first at writing this review...but I couldn't help myself. I had to express what I believe.

I am really confused. The movie make me sick. Colin Farrell's performance is amazing, I guess, but there are nothing enjoyable in the whole movie. Literally I was sick when we finally left the theater. Besides, child abused is the worst thing ever. I can't tolerate it even in a fictional situation.The whole story happened in the same location. Pretty photographies, clean water and beaches but was kind of boring.I am a animals lover, I can say his love for animals was the only beautiful things. If the critics say it is a great movie, must be. I will see it again because I have to know why this movie is a "Oscar material. "

reviews.review_title: Boring and pointless pile of madness.
reviews.content: I can't actually belive I sat through the whole thing.Took two days, I really didn't want to watch the second half, but did it thinking there was something more to it. Nope.Just a simple portrait of bored and desperate people on the island. There is no depth to the story nor to any of the characters. Just go do a little bit of work and go drink and share few lines with others. That's their daily life.Counter to what the description says, it's not a comedy by a long shot. Nothing funny, just dumb, really dumb. And, also as it says it gets more and more crazy, it doesn't. Nothing worth my or anyone's time.Save your life and enjoy actual comedy or actual drama!

reviews.review_title: Sadness in the Service of ..... Sadness
reviews.content: 'Banshees of Inisherin' is a sad sad story. Terrible things happen to characters on screen. Characters do terrible things to themselves on screen. Other characters are the victims of violence and molestation off screen. Characters say terrible things to each other for what seems no reason at all. Loneliness is pervasive. Animals die or are endangered by human carelessness. Friendships dissolve. Love is unrequited. And the future is bleak. Like I said, sad.But sadness should be in the service of something more. There should be something for the viewer to take away beyond the fact that life can be, and often is, sad. And I wish that were the case with 'Banshees', but unfortunately it is not. This is sadness for its own sake. Add sad music. Add a rock-strewn island off the coast of 1923 Ireland. Add wind and cold. And what you have is - and excuse the use of this word - a real 'downer'.Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell play old friends who are suddenly, inexplicably, on the 'outs'. And it is this ruptured relationship that triggers a series of terrible events that seems to have no borders, no end. And, well .... that's it.Following the viewing of the film I researched other critics' takes on the production. I could not believe my own interpretation. Was there something I missed? And I'd like to tell you that, yes, there was. But there wasn't.That said, If life is not going great for you and you're in need of a couple of hours of even sadder sadness (to put things in clearer perspective), you might try 'Banshees of Inisherin'.

Don't waste your time unless you like watching mentally Ill people. Few sane people in the leading roles. Should really be classified as science fiction because this stuff is unbelievable. Who acts like this? Who would live like this. Don't say you weren't warned. Waste of good talent. Terrible script. Sane people simply don't behave like lunatics. There is not a likeable character in the whole movie with the possible exception of the sister and the young man (and his plight was so predictable). What else? Oh yeah- no animals were harmed in the making of this movie- only the people who had to see it.

I couldn't Understand The Point of the movie, and the experience was excrutiating. Having read some Critic' Reviews They Got Exactly What I Got, which is for them wonderful and for me dull and sick. If you enjoy the tribulations of a very depressed fellow in a lonely island where nothing happens then this is the movie for you. It tells volume about the current state of affairs in cinema. Seems the director didnt have much of a budget, which I guess went mostly to pay the stars, therefore the crappy script and production. I enjoyed In Bruges but this isn't even close. The director wishes to immerse you in a very sick scenario, and I pity him, the cast, and anyone who watches this film, moreover if they dare find any meaning.

reviews.review_title: In a single word, this film is: AWFUL
reviews.content: I absolutely cannot even begin to understand the overly high ratings on this movie here on IMDB. I wager most of them must come from the writer, director, cast and crew.Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson are two immensely talented and accomplished actors, but this is one terribly stupid, nonsensical, pointless and illogical film. To add to the weakness and irrationality of the story the accents are so thick I actually had to use the close captioning to understand about half the dialog. I love watching Farrell and Gleason together and hope they will appear in another better, more interesting, useful and intelligent offering in the near future. But The Banshees of Inisherin is abysmal trash.

The plot makes no sense at all. I get that life was difficult, tedious and even depressing in Ireland at the time. But none of the characters had the slightest grip on reality, with the possible exception of the sister.The only character I cared about was the donkey, and they killed it off in dubiously bizarre circumstances. I cared nothing about any of the other characters at the beginning of the film, and I grew to loathe them more with each successive scene.If you are thinking of seeing this film because you loved In Bruge, think again. It's nothing like it. Specifically, there is not one shred of levity in it.It was so excruciating, I walked out about 2/3 of the way through it. My wife suffered through it all and filled me in on the ending.If you are entirely too happy with your life and need a massively downbeat experience to balance that, I highly recommend this film. Otherwise, avoid it like the plague.

A very weird story with some charming, Village moments. Definitely not a comedy. Totally overrated to get so many awards nominations. Maybe I don't get it because I'm not white?I suppose the performances are good, for a weird story. The guy keeps cutting his fingers off - why? I didn't get it at all.The Art Direction and period set design and costumes were well-made. But there were 100 other period movies last year.The ads tried to make it sound deep, but it really isn't.They did make the beaches of Ireland look like an exotic, South American destination.Overall, I would have skipped it and would not recommend it. Too much hype.

reviews.review_title: Wish I had not watched this
reviews.content: Free HBO on Comcast this week. Hooray as I could never afford it otherwise. Had heard good things on Twitter about "The Banshees of Inisherin" so watched it last night.It has been nominated for several Oscars. I figured I would like it.Liked the first 3/4 of it or so and was enjoying it well enough until the supposed "comedy" became a horror movie.I now really wish I hadn't watched it.It's really too bad because it is admittedly beautiful and probably has good acting but it's now forever corrupted in my mind.It left me depressed and despairing.Spoiler Alert:I can not abide the killing/death of animals to move forward a plot.

I always rate movies 1/5/10 and this is a 5.How is this movie categorised as Comedy? This is actually a tragedy and for no good reason. If the man wanted to be alone, he could have always left town and got his silence. But no, he chose to stay in the same place and make his silence a spectacle.I completely respect Colm's need to be away from Padraic but to guilt trip him by chopping it his fingers is not helping in any way. If he can cut his fingers off he could very well draw the courage to leave town.I see this movie as a pointless expression for art. Just because you can make a movie you make garbage? There's surely better ways of expressing your creativity. Just because you are depressed don't make the audience depressed. Don't be like Colm. Get out of town if you have to.

Okay, it has 8 stars so it has to be good, right? Star power so it has to be good? So, it starts out slow and boring. That's okay because it's going to get better, right? A lot better. Mid-way through it still boring. But, it's going to get better because, hell's bell's, it has 8 stars. Guess what. It never gets better. It stays boring. What movie were the people who gave this boring tripe a rating watching? It wasn't this one. Might have been Pulp Fiction or Alien but it sure as hell couldn't have been this one. A supposed black comedy but without the black or the comedy. I'm proud that I had enough sense to finally skip to the last 5 minutes which were also boring. You've been warned.

I really should give this movie.9/10, docking a mark for a certain photographic self-indulgence of the Terrence Malick variety. It's debatable as to whether or not the extensvie coverage of the beautiful scenery, lovingly shot by DOP Ben Davis, helps or hinders the film. But, in the end, it is no inconvenience to drink it all in, as the sad story of a failed friendship is played out against the backdrop of an indifferent natural world.So, it's 10/10 for a masterpiece of writing, superb performances, and -- except for those minor Malickisms, tactful and sensitive direction.As the Irish Civil War blasts and rages on the mainland, different kinds of struggle take place in the lives of four islanders. The emotional journeys are charted with exceptional compassion and skill by Brendan Gleeson, Colin Farrell, Kerry Kondon and Barry Keoghan. Farrell in particular, in the role of a lifetime, moves believably and poignantly from skin to stone in the course of couple of unforgettable cinematic hours:The supporting cast boasts several treats, my favourite being the venerable Sheila Flitton, enjoying herself hugely as Mrs McCormick, one of those people we go out of our way to avoid.

reviews.review_title: Everything but character growth and story
reviews.content: Beautiful cinematography, excellent acting, one or two chuckles, quaint Irish dialog and only one character you'll care about (Siobahn). But characters who don't grow, story threads and extraneous elements that go nowhere, and cheap, unsophisticated plot devices thrown in the jerk a requisite tear provide no insight into why this story is being told.I hesitate to even use the term "story" to describe this stream of blather. What does this movie try to say? It doesn't pay to be nice? No matter how you live your life, it's futile to resist being pulled into the social muck? Its message is fragmented, unfocused and hazy.I think the more interesting stories are left untold- what about Siobahn? What's the deal with Mrs. McCormick? The best quotes come from Dominic, but his character simply used as another plot device to evoke sympathy without telling his backstory.This is definitely a one-and-done movie. Watch it once and you'll never feel like you need to see it again.

So, on paper this film has potential, right? High calibre actors, great scenery, an exploration of the human condition... Except it's contrived in a way that you can't just ignore. I was with this film for a while; I could relate to the pain of a friendship ending. We've all been there. We didn't cut all our fingers off, though, did we? And so the contrivance began and never really let go. Sorry, I'm not just going to suspend disbelief and ignore everything I know about people just to humour a film plot. Even the severely mentally disturbed do not cut off their own fingers. And even if they did, wouldn't they get horrendously infected? Or maybe it was all supposed to be deeply symbolic. After all, the film as set against the background of the Irish Civil War. Brother against brother; finger against finger? Perhaps, but I was too dumb to get it. Colin Farrell's eyebrows were great, though. So 5 out of 10 for trying.

reviews.review_title: Just a bit weird - not In Bruges levels
reviews.content: Went into this movie expecting something amazing, as In Bruges - which has the same director, main 2 actors and composer - is one of my favourite movies, as the attention to detail and whole story was fantastic, coupled with the soundtrack. This movie however, was a bit if a disappointment compared to my expectations. My overall thought is just that's it was really weird. At times there were rather comedic moments, which was a nice contrast to the strange seriousness of it all. To be truly honest I do not get the story as it was just one man's complete decent into madness, which has very little explanation, and then the knock on affect on his friend. The overall climax to the movie was also questionable and most of it just felt random and uncoordinated, which resulted in the strange mess that was this movie.

reviews.review_title: The quality of movies has gone so far down...
reviews.content: The quality of movies has gone so far down reviewers and especially critics will laude anything that vaguely resembles what a good film is. I think this is how reviewers keep their jobs.'In Bruges' a film featuring Gleeson and Farrell that came out in 2008 is clearly a better film, yet has a lower imdb and critic rating. Why? Because film is dead now, and all the good stories have gone to TV, or big budget superhero films, which are cool.This film is not a bad film, but with so little to say, it takes long enough to say it. An hour and fifty three minutes to be exact. The location is beautiful and the acting was decent. Life's an existential quagmire. Cutting off your fingers and isolating your friends won't stave off that reality.If you're really jonsin' for this type of theme, may I recommend Lord Jim, or Apocalypse Now!. Good luck.

The cast get full marks for acting their parts. The cinematography is top notch.The plot is where this movie goes completley sideways. Another reviewer said one must be in a certain mindset to watch this film and I have to agree.It's bleak, melancholy and at times, deeply disturbing. Scenes of self mutilation, pyromania and even child abuse are prevalent in the film.What is the source of all these horrible things?One grown man decides he longer wants to be best friends with another grown man. And just like a 14 year old girl, he cuts him off without any warning or provocation.That's it. That is literally the plot.I left this film feeling depressed, confused and irritated. Do not watch if you're in the mood for something uplifting. You won't find it here.

What a colossal waste of time. Two brilliant actors, Colin Ferrell and Brendan Gleeson, attempt to reprise their wonderful chemistry from the excellent 2008 film, In Bruges. Nope.Is this supposed to be Pinter or Beckett? Almost nothing happens, and that nothing is inexplicable. Two friends live in the middle of nowhere in Ireland, and its desolate beauty is all this film has going for it.One of the friends, the musician Gleeson, decides that he is sick of the other, Ferrell, and declares their friendship over. For no apparent reason. That's it, folks.Ferrell mopes his way through the entire film, complaining to his sister, his donkey (who is adorable) and the village idiot. Gleeson provides absolutely zero reasons for his decision other than that Ferrell is "dull".The incomprehensible and gratuitous use of self mutilation is revolting. No set up, no explanation, it is grotesque and pandering.In fairness, Stef liked it a bit more (she gives it a 4) claiming that it is about isolation and how people react to it- some leave, some go mad, and some go silent. But that didn't do it for me.Reading some of the glowing reviews reminds me of another film, The Menu, which is fantastic. That film takes the piss out of the fawning cult of high dining, especially the bread dish with no bread. Charge people enough and they will eat dirt and love it. Unfortunately, the Banshees of Inisherin tastes like dirt, and for me, no amount of critical fawning will save it from its banality and emptiness.

The scenery is amazing and beautiful but the storyline is miserable, lonely and depressing. I would advise there are better things to do with your time than to watch this tripe. Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleason and others do their jobs well but that's it. Genuinely it's one of the worst Irish movies I have ever seen. I was sucked in by all the reviews and I would love to know what people liked about this movie. This review is supposed to be a certain amount of characters and I am struggling. I wouldn't waste my money on a cinema ticket or a Disney Plus Subscription and even if you could watch this movie for free I wouldn't bother.

This movie is just not for me. Also, I'm not sure how there are so many reviews rating it so highly? I get there are people who like the twisted and dark type of movies like this but seems unusually high. Did I watch the right movie? To sum it up, It was very slow to start and didn't really seem to pick up in interest throughout the rest of the movie. I did not find it entertaining in any way the the overall plot of the movie was, how should I put it, extremely odd. The actors did a very good job, I would have given the movie one star had the acting not been as good as it was. There aren't many movies I rate so poorly but this one fit the bill.

reviews.review_title: The In Bruges spiritual successor we needed
reviews.content: Welcome back Martin McDonagh. Despite being a bit hit and miss lately with Seven Psychopaths and Three Billboards despite still being great, The Banshees of Inisherin is up there with In Bruges as a return to top form for the director. An excellent Drama about friendships with well-written characters and plenty of black humour. Nicely shot in Ireland, great performances and lovely music makes this easily one of the best films of 2022. Definitely Oscars worthy for sure. Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson are great together on screen, as well as the supporting roles of Barry Keoghan and Kerry Condon. A must watch and very well crafted film.8.5/10.

Colin farrell and brendan gleeson had already worked together once before. Showing on hbomax, this is a period piece, ireland, in the early 1900s. Co-stars barry keoghan, who had also worked with farrell on "sacred deer". Padraic and colm have been old friends for years, but suddenly, he doesn't have time to be friends with padraic any more. He's gone nuts. And it's driving padraic crazy. It gets pretty dark. Padraic's sister suports him for a while, but realizes he's going just as batty crazy as colm, as the two neighbors carry on their feud. Some intense violence, but we don't actually see it take place. A long, strange story. Written and directed by martin mcdonagh, who won the oscar for "six shooter". "banshees" was just released in november, and is already nominated for nine oscars! Hollywood sure likes those long, strange, weird films. A bit too long and weird for me. Kind of a much ado about nothing. It's okay, but i wouldn't have nominated it for nine oscars.

reviews.review_title: Not a good film. An uninspiring script with no depth.
reviews.content: The fact that the word 'dull' comes up so many times is no coincidence: That's what the movie was for me and my wife. I love the actors and have enjoyed many movies with them. But this just did not work out for me.No background was provided, we did not learn anything about the past relationship between the protagonists which would have allowed us to put what (little) is happening here into some kind of perspective.We couldn't feel any chemistry between any of the actors. The thing with the fingers did not add value to the story at all. The only positive was the filming of the beautiful countryside.

reviews.review_title: This is the gloomiest, bleakest most boring movie I've ever seen
reviews.content: I don't really understand the high ratings here. Is this supposed to be some sort of arthouse metaphorical experiment? I'll sum up the movie for you. In the most boring bleakest of islands one friend unilaterally decides he doesn't like the other one anymore. There's really no plot, no mystery to be solved, nor any sense whatsoever for you to make out of what's presented here for you. Stuff in this movie just happens. For no reason other than to be more depressing and weird by the minute. At the end there's no payoff, no resolution, no real conclusion. We are basically in the same boat as when we started, But an hour and a half has gone by and we have nothing to show for other than maybe a brand new case of the depression after having witnessed this nonsense.

This is not a funny/ amusing film as some would have you believe. It is downright miserable from start to finish.Two men have a falling out for no apparent reason and treat each other appallingly. Meanwhile the local cop is abusing his simple son and the lovely people of the village pry and curse each other. Chopping off all his fingers because his old friend talked to him is the " highlight"/ " lowlight".The one redeeming feature was the scenery on this wild Irish island. Oh and the farm animals who managed to actually steal some of the scenes from the very accomplished cast.All in all, a very depressing movie with no apparent message to its audience that might have balanced some of the misery.

That's the only over riding thought I had continually repeating in my head...
I honestly think that standards have fallen so dramatically when a donkey upstages every single cast member of the film! After his previous films Ihad expected a little more from Martin tbh. This is lazy story telling at its worst. Tierd tedious dialogue that endlessly repeats lines, words and sayings. As if they weren't funny enough the first time around?I wanted to leave the theatre after about ten minutes but thought it must be going somewhere as the premise was clearly spelled out early. But it did not go anywhere? One irish cliche that was missed out: Jesus Joseph & Mary, Saints Preserve Us! Is the phrase that comes to mind with regard to this film!

reviews.review_title: Worst movie I have ever seen
reviews.content: If you want to wallow in darkness, despair and hopelessness, then this is the movie for you. Glimpses of humor, but never funny. It is most definitely not a comedy. The actors are great, the scenery is gorgeous, but the story is beyond depressing.I am so glad to return to the theater, streaming just doesn't do movies justice, BUT, if I had been watching at home, I would have moved on by half time. Also, I regret not leaving the theatre.I don't mind gratuitous violence, I enjoy dark humor, but the gore here is pointless. In an effort towards profundity, they have landed on inane.Three Billboards was so good, Banshees was so so bad-what a disappointment.

Even great acting and cinematography don't save this one. I think it's the most depressing and grisly thing I've ever wasted my time on. That's two hours I will never get back or get out of my mind. I was expecting a light hearted romp across the Irish countryside, after two longtime friends have a falling out, with no explanation. We are lead to believe they will have a drunken brawl, make up, and laugh their way off into the Irish sunset. Once again, we are the victim of manipulative trailers, that suggest a storyline, then don't deliver. Don't go expecting another "Waking Ned Devine". It isn't.

reviews.review_title: Comedy? Sad wierd not in a good way
reviews.content:
They are already telling you spoilers, without saying how it proceeds to the end. I kept thinking, who thought of these plot points. Making this as if it were an allegory of life. No, I don't think so. Wierd, not In a good way. A SAD
picture. A Bored, Mentally unbalanced man, self harms. In an isolated, small island village in Northern Ireland. Colin a nice, simple guy, is left alone, now bitter & isolated. No wife. No girlfriend No women. His loving sister leaves for a bigger life and wants him to join her. Is he too depressed to choose life.Winning Golden Globes as a Black, very black, Comedy.

reviews.review_title: The film is an impossibly boring road to nowhere, without answers, purpose and reason.
reviews.content: I was hoping to see something interesting, as is usually the case in Martin's films, but all I got was the most boring friendship story of a crazy old man and his kind-hearted former friend. All the decisions of the old man are irrational and stupid, the topic of loneliness is not disclosed at all - the whole film Padriac tries to understand why the old man stopped communicating with him, and only at the end you can see a cut of his everyday life with horses in the room, with which he apparently is not so lonely. And why this old grandmother who looks like death and predicts the future? The story leading to nowhere, very sorry for the time spent.

reviews.review_title: Failed to live up to the hype
reviews.content: After seeing the trailer I was really looking forward to this, I was tempted to go see it at the cinema but as it was coming to Disney + I waited until Christmas day to watch it and have to say it was a disappointment.The scenery was fantastic, the acting was superb but the script and story is where it fails in my opinion. Its attempts at comedy fall flat, we have no idea why Colm doesn't want to see Padraic, is he depressed, dying or does he just want an excuse not to play music anymore? What happened to Dominic, was it suicide or an accident?The film is nearly two hours long, plenty of time for these questions to be answered but we are just left wondering at the end, why?

To me, the film is more like a bleak tragedy rather than a dark comedy. Other than the beautiful photography and the good acting, I felt that the film is getting nowhere. Instead, it keeps showing how people can be so insane and life in a small isolated island can be so dull and depressing.I think both main characters are just too weird. Maybe one is too lonely and the other one is just too confused in himself. If a friend decides not to be your friend anymore (although the reason was too mean but it is understandable), you should not keep trying to bug that person anymore, especially when he is crazy enough to cut off his fingers to chase you away from his life. And what kind of person would really do that just to show...I want you away from my life? Only crazy person does that! So, there are too crazy insane men on the island, there is one woman who can't stand the whole insanity of them anymore and move away, there is one poor boy who is hearbroken, abused by his father, and end up dead. There is a witch-like old woman who keeps walking around that saying that the future of the island is bleak. I was thinking...Gosh, what am I watching? And there is no answer, no solution, nothing at the end. The only nleasant thing about the film is that all the farm animals are friendly and the people there treat them so well. But that's all. I don't see any worthwhile theme of this film. I can't help thinking those who love it must have some kind of sarcastic nature or hidden darkness in themselves. The film is really bleak and pointless, although beautifully filmed and greatly acted.

Saw the film last night at the Mill Valley Film Festival and was immediately transported to a different time and place where the people bend to the will of the landscape.It's a lyrical film full of rich language and irony that stays with you. The performances are each and every one remarkable, the cinematography bewitching and the musical score seals the deal.There's a mythological quality to be sure and characters transform unexpectedly in bits of whimsy that suddenly portend a darker streak running through the countryside.Kudos to the director for creating this very Irish (yet universal) story.

Lovely cinematography over desolate landscape - probably the only good thing here. Yes, the actors do a good job portraying dreadful and depressing people. Not a good enough reason to subject yourself to this 'art'. Slam your finger in the car door. It will hurt less and entertain you more. This movie is slower than slow, duller than dull, and completely unbelievable. People are calling this a black comedy??? There is nothing funny at all here, in any shade. Save yourself the two hours and watch something that will make you feel good and happy. In spite of the movie snob nominations, the Emperor has no clothes. It's a study in contrived sadness, there is no redemption.

reviews.review_title: Love these actors didn't like the film
reviews.content: Maybe I missed some hidden agenda or meaning, but this was utterly depressing with no happy outcome. I love these actors, which is why I watched it, but wish I hadn't. I kept going as I hoped the characters would work things out or at least get some answers so efforts could be made to heal the unexplained rift or at least be able to accept the change. Is it possible to love someone one minute then hate them the next for absolutely no apparent reason? On the up side the film is beautifully shot, I have worked in Ireland a lot and the beauty of this country and the kindness of its people is something I will love for ever, this film certainly did show Ireland's stunning landscape.

I found this whole movie to be completely pointless.The only redeeming features - 1. Yes it is wonderfull shot and 2. It is well acted .. but the story is not profound as so many reviewers say it is .. its just completely pointless. If you've watched this movie then the next reference will make perfect sense .. "I'd rather cut off my own fingers than rewatch it.".It is a ridiculously simple premise and it basically never gets beyond two simple characters that are so "just there " i.e they just are basic simple boring people, who do absolutely nothing in a town that has no reason to exist and with a story that goes nowhere over two excruciating hours.Save yourself the pain of seeing this movie and just stab yourself in your hand with a fork it will be more enjoyable than sitting through this inane rubbish.I have no idea how it got such high ratings I absolutely hated it.

I liked this film up the the start of the finger chopping. From then on I was really disappointed. A funny story about two friends, one of whom dumps the other because he's dull, was to my liking. I like stories about eccentric types. The other fellow, the dull one, cannot accept being ghosted by his lifelong friend. Does he take the criticism as something helpful and try to be interesting? No. He becomes annoying.From here on, it was downhill for me. I hate gruesome and I really hate fantasy films. Why fantasy I could not believe that a sane person would chop his fingers off to spite his annoying friend.I could not buy it.It could have been delightful and loony. But, no, it becomes gruesome.

Colin Farrell and Kerry Condon carried the movie for me. If not for their performances I would have turned this movie off several times. Also loved Jenny the donkey.The story was stupid and it just ran itself into the ground. Nothing significant happens other than some fingers getting chopped off.Why the need for extra required characters for a negative review. How many ways can I say I was not impressed with the movie? But since I cannot submit the review without the minimum I apologize that you have to read this extra paragraph. I'd rather watch the donkeys and horses for an hour if I had to.

On a remote island off the coast of Ireland, Pádraic is devastated when his friend Colm suddenly puts an end to their lifelong friendship.With help from his sister and a young islander, Pádraic sets out to repair the damaged relationship by any means necessary. However, as Colm's resolve only strengthens, he soon delivers an ultimatum that leads to shocking consequences......With The Banshees of Inisherin, expect the unexpected, because it slowly begins to boil halfway through the film, and it doesn't let up until the end. It's a simple set up, but in the hands of Mcdonagh, and two amazing performances from Farrell and Gleeson, this is one of the most triumphant films of the year.It starts off simple enough, one friend says to another that he doesn't like him anymore, which is straight to the point, but a little baffling to Pádraic. Even more so when Colm doesn't give him an explanation. And then because their is no real rationale, the tension mounts up, not severely, but there is a hint of an unnerving air about the film, and you begin to dread when the two cross paths, especially considering what Colm will do if Pádraic speak to him again.The tension gets cut up though by moments of pure hilarity, you never thought you'd laugh at the words bread van, but this had me laughing out loud. But it breaks the tension only slightly, because you know that there will be consequences because of the actions.So should Pádraic be at cause rather than effect?You'd like to think so, but in the same breath, you are thinking why should he? The explanation as to why he doesn't want to speak to him isn't satisfying enough for Pádraic or the audience, but that's the only rationale he gets.The film is very touching in places, just because Colm isn't talking to him, it doesn't mean he cares, and this shows in one sequence, and it's a really warming part, to a very cold film.The performances are wonderful from everyone, and this has to be in a lot of peoples top tens of the year, because Mcdonagh has made yet another fabulous piece of work that is warm and funny, but at the same time, tense and bleak, with an air of despair about it.....

I read some of the other reviews and can just say that I've never seen a more grim movie, and at 76 I've seen many films. I sincerely wish there had been a warning online and on the TV ads which even said it was "A COMEDY"!! I didn't need to see it to know about the bizarre behavior of people. And no, I'm not a Disney fanatic. I'm asked to provide a longer review, to what benefit I don't know except for what I've already said. Seriously, people need to be warned, as I could imagine some depressives going in and coming out in bad shape. It's a real downer, no mistake about it. No more I want to say.

reviews.review_title: Without Colin it would be boring.
reviews.content: Interesting is that in the first minutes of the opening the music that accompanies the Irish landscape resembles a Slavic sound, a lot. That was my first impression. However, to me it looks the first time that Colin showed that he is outstanding actor and next to him Gleeson remains in the shadows, nothing special. The story goes very slow and although photography is brilliant, we feel that wet depressed nature of the Irish island. There is some slice of black humor, but mostly all ends tragically, without hope, if not appears some chance of leaving to somewhere else far away for a better tomorrow.

reviews.review_title: How and why did this movie ever get made???
reviews.content:
Let me preface this by stating that I have intensely followed Colin Farrell's career since I spotted him 20 odd years ago in his first and greatest ,movie. Tigerland. It's been a rocky ride since then.Brendan Gleeson is a master of the acting craft.This thing they agreed to do together . IN my humble opinion.Is the WORST thing I have watched on my cable system in years.What possessed the producers and writers to believe this thing
was worth subjecting us to.This movie is a true HORROR show.I play the acoustic guitar for the last 50 years.To see the self mutilation of this character's finger made me sick
to my stomach. Over "NOTHING".To humiliate his friend from the opening of the film had me
trying to find a redeeming frame from that moment on.This film was characterized as "Comedy"???
