The whole cast is splendid and I really liked the way Peadar is performed, as a supposed guardian of the law who happens to be an abusive guy who mistreats the ones he decides trusting that he is a policeman. Barry Keoghan is a noticeable addition that goes beyond the top as a clumsy guy.The plot happens to be empty and absurd and the worst is that it lasts almost 2 hours. There is not a definite point to which the plot can arrive and validate what happens.

Got about 1/3rd through this snoozefest then gave up.No substantial plot, boring, no story purpose, not very interesting to be honest!Great actors doing OK jobs, and great scenery but that's about as far as it goes, the rest is cliched!I didn't see the point of the movie, was it about anything substantial or was it just a chance to let two good actors bounce 'Irish cultural stereotyping' between them?How this gets the nod for an Oscar is beyond me, unless the competition is nowhere to be seen.Not much more to say shoot it, you've probably seen similar plots done better in other movies, so it really hasn't got much to offer beyond two grumpy men, having a falling out in early 20th century rural west Ireland and drinking a lot of Guinness!

Watched this after reading all the rave reviews. I'm a big fan of this style of film and with the writer's pedigree (In Bruges etc), and top drawer actors I was really looking forward to something special. It's not. It's average at best. Pedestrian in pace and much less clever than it thinks it is. Yes, the acting is very good and the scenery is stunning, but the story is just poor. No other word for it. I really wouldn't recommend it - there are just so many better films out there. Why is this film up for do many awards? I can only think.its yet another example of the Emporer's New Clothes...

Unbelievable. This was definitely the WORST movie I have seen in my 71 years. Nothing but gloom, doom, depression, anger and revenge. I cannot believe these two actors read this script at all. No lessons learned, not left with any good feelings. Hopefully, we can purge every memory of this movie out of our minds. I am done with my review but for some insane reason it requires that I type additional characters. Really? The only redeeming quality was the cinematography which wasn't even that great. I certainly will not be rushing over there on one of my travels. Again, acting good but very depressing film. Blah blah blah.

Absolute dumpster fire of a movie. Trash. Faux 'arthouse' made by people with too much money and too much self interest, with actors on too high a wage and too much self interest. Amateur editing cuts, almost broadsword-esque at times with cutting between characters dialogue back & forth robotically, random cuts to an unnecessary close up of a face for 2 seconds then over to another unnecessary shot that brings no premise nor sculpture of context then back to the 3rd or maybe 4th shot choice shown in the scene in totally maybe 10 cuts for a scene lasting no longer than 1 minute, no camera air time to let any scene really marinate, bleh. And was this supposed to be a comedy? Tragic comedy of errors more like. Oh wait! Of course, of course! It makes sense, I should have known... When you have Collin Farell as your lead, a man who's acting could be mistaken for a cardboard sign outside a budget saver store, there is generally only one way the whole vibe of a movie is going to hang it's coating over, that of a self indulgent narcissist who's just vomited over himself and wants you to admire him and tell him how lovely his new coat is, and also give him money for it, because clearly he's so amazing and basically a auteur, with his vomit dripping down from his chin, onto your shoe.Filming an empty bucket for one hour & fifty three minutes with the last minute having someone throwing up in the bucket would be more interesting and artistically stimulating than this film.

Ingmar Bergman's 'The Seventh Seal' looms large throughout this ultra-black comedy set on a fictitious Island in the Irish Sea in 1923.The futile Irish Civil War rages away on the mainland - not affecting our Island community, a community, and indeed movie, that my pal James McLaughlin and I both agree is a metaphor for Brexit Britain - an act of self harm like no other in modern nationhood's history.We cut our national nose to spite our stupid face and that's what The Banshees is about.The title itself is an antonym of the story.This isn't a movie about screaming banshees, it's about silence.It's also about depression and it works as a kind of virtual reality in that respect because the experience of viewing this magnificent beast is depressing in itself.It ain't no In Bruges baby.You won't be holding your sides gasping for air to breathe.You might, however, as I was, be holding your breath still unable to breathe.It's a stifling, magnificent ode to the importance of friendship, to male love (or in Christian terms Agape - the highest form of love, for God) because this film is all about the shattering of a deep, deep platonic love - in an instant - of two men who were as one for many years, perhaps all their lives, for no apparent reason.Just like Brexit.You know who those men are. And they do not let us down.The biggest surprise is the Ursula Von Der Leven-like presence-of-mind and common-sense of the sister, Siobhan, played with grace and skill by Kerry Condon.It's not that funny. It's not trying to be. But it's a fabulous insight into the futility of breaking up with those that were so close to you and the proximity of total disaster that might be the outcome.It's great. (And it looks beautiful too by the way, oh and the music by Carer Burwell is pretty cool too.)

As others have said 'expectations were high'. Far too high. Overhyped by the media and I see by plenty on here. This film is dire. Dialogue is good as is cinematography. But right near the start you think where is this going. Answer :- Nowhere really. Little resolved and very little explained. Disappointment of the year cinema wise. The ''laughs' are very very dark and often at the expense of someone. It really reminded me of the far superior 'The killing of a sacred deer'. Barry Keoghan in that and also in this is the star of the show. He plays Dominic in this brilliantly. I feel this actually started strongly but the final 15 minutes were the worst. Avoid like the plague.

Given the fact that i like both main actors (and normally enjoy Gaelic movies) I have to say that I truly expected to like this movie better than I did, but regretfully that wasn't the case.It was so slow that I fast forwarded thru unspeaking parts that had no visual scenery.I know all movie ending don't have to be a fairytale, "all is good" ending, but this was a waste of my time and made me feel awful to even think people could be so selfish, cruel and cold. If a surprise ending was the writer's intent....well..... let's just say..... he certainly succeeded. I was left with an unrealistic, down feeling. Of course that is just my opinion-though I wish it wasn't.

Apparently I'm missing something. The scenery was beautiful, the acting was done very well, but...the plot- if one can actually admit to one, was diluted and obscure. I'm assuming this movie was a metaphor for the civil war in the backdrop. I want my time and money back - this was painful to sit through, and dark.I was really looking forward to seeing this movie based on the reviews and ratings. I think perhaps it takes a certain type to understand this type of humor and appreciate the symbolic aspects of the film.I hope you have better luck than I did and enjoy it.Go to a matinee or wait for it to come out online.

reviews.review_title: Unique certainly, but Far From Special
reviews.content: Perhaps as an Irish cultural piece this film has some value, but in terms of the actual quality of the story there isn't much there . If I'm really grasping at straws the only theme I found interesting was that of being "nice" and valuing the simplicities in life versus doing something supposedly meaningful or legacy producing and creating internal meaning beyond your reliance on external relationships. On one side of the coin, Padraig sees life's beauty and meaning in simple human connections regardless of how seemingly insignificant they are. On the other, Colm has a midlife/ late life crisis and is concerned he's wasted his life away leaving behind a meaningless life with no legacy to show for it. Meanwhile we see Padraig's sister stuck in this dilemma as well having to decide whether to let her intelligence be wasted away on an island or travel for greater opportunity on the mainland. The characters decisions on how to approach life are somewhat interesting in this sense as many of us in our own lives are conflicted on whether we should place more value on career success versus meaningful personal relationships and whether both are possible.As others have mentioned there are some beautiful shots off the coast of Ireland, although these can also be found by watching NatGeo as well. The acting is quite good, but do not expect to see anything thrilling or even exciting in this film. There is also some weird (physically graphic material) included.Overall, this film is made for a very specific niche audience and therefore I really don't think it should be anywhere near awards such as Best Picture.

I read some reviews that said this movie was a perfect blend of tragedy and "laugh out loud" humor. I don't think I laughed a single time. How could you with the looming threat of mangled fingers being chucked at your door? How could you laugh while you're constantly worried that one of the characters is going to sheet off his own fingers if our MC even talks to him?Sounds like the story is supposed to parallel the Irish Civil War. Why not give us a hint, some context, anything that could help us not feel hopelessly lost in a dark comedy for 2 whole hours?With that said, this movie is visually stunning, with acting to boot.

reviews.review_title: Great performances, interesting setting and premise, unclear point
reviews.content:
By "unclear point" I'm probably being unclear! What I mean is that the two main characters (two friends) fight, get more and more stubborn, get to a very tense point when you expect them to clear thoughts and understand their wrongs, but..
Don't get me wrong, I don't think this is a bad movie, the cinematography is quite beautiful, the landscapes look great on the big screen, and even the indoor scenes are naturally lit, giving a sense of realism to the 20's story setting. It looks great indeed!There're a lot of chuckling throughout the movie, and the animals are lovely and fun to watch as they interact with the characters. It almost makes me feel like going to live in a farm for a while!The performances are excellent all around, the characters are solid and believable while the story unfolds, but then the story's message is unclear to me. I just didn't get anything but bitter sadness and the frustration of two people that won't put themselves in the place of their friend, having things changed or not, I find this pointless and even if not realistic, unworthy of telling as a story.Some may find certain meaning I don't, some may enjoy the setting way more than I do and appreciate details I've missed, but my feeling at the end is of an unsatisfying ending for a story of friendship, which we all have had in our lives.

In Irish mythology, a banshee is a female spirit whose cry heralds death. Therefore, in a country where Spanish is spoken, like mine, it seemed to me that preserving the word "banshee" was the correct option to refer to Martin McDonagh's film, a new contribution to his short but stupendous filmography and his return to British cinema, after doing in the United States "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" in the United StatesRenamed «Lost Souls of Inisherin», "banshee" seems the appropriate term, because it is a film rooted in Irish traditions, based on an exemplary script (written by McDonagh) that contextualizes the story with accurate and scarce data, to gives us the portrait of a society in the 1920s, encapsulated despite its magnificent landscapes, trapped in a country at war against England, made up of men and women dedicated to tasks attached to the land, on the fictional island of Inisherin.Considering McDonagh's extensive and award-winning career as a playwright, it comes as no surprise that he holds our attention for almost two hours without ever straying from the central issue: the sudden break in friendship between two men, when the older man, Colm Doherty (Brendan Gleeson), gets tired of Pádraic (Colin Farrell), who could well be his son. Colm's reasons are simple: Pádraic bores him and he wants time for himself, to dedicate it to music before he dies. If Pádraic insists on speaking to him, Colm threatens to cut off his finger. And in an environment where excessive testosterone permeates every corner, Colm does not take long to do so.The rupture leads to absurdity and violence, sparks mixed reactions among friends and neighbors, exposes the role of authority, and leads Pádraic's sister Siobhán (Kelly Condon) to make a drastic decision, made worse when the enigmatic Mrs. McCormick (Sheila Flitton) announces that there will soon be a death, or perhaps two, on the island. (*)Conceived as the third play in the Aran Islands Trilogy, after «The Cripple of Inishmaan» (1996) and «The Lieutenant of Inishmore» (2001), Irish actors Farrell and Gleeson agreed to act in it seven years before production of the film was green-lighted. Both are formidable and deserve a round of applause for their performances, bolstered by two other Irish performers: Condon as Siobhán and Barry Keoghan as Dominic, the island idiot and battered son of the town policeman. Films so well basted are rare. Recommended.(*) Mrs. McCormick is the closest to the banshees in the title, if we were to interpret it. She is followed in character by the mean village shopkeeper, Mrs. O'Riordan (Bríd Ní Neachtain), and perhaps Siobhán, who, seeing them both, glimpses her fate.

You know, I think I'd rather cut off my fingers than watch this mess ever again. You want I confusing, pointless, boring mess of a film then you have got to check out Banshees. It's about as fun and entertaining as a root canal.. It'll leave you wondering "what the hell did I just watch and how do I get 2 hours of my life back?" . Oh, and the supposed comedy will just leave you sort of confused. The plot is all over the place and the main characters could have fell off the face of the earth and couldn't possibly care any less. Anyway, if you want to check out this debacle knock yourself out. Just remember you've been warned. One lousy star.

reviews.review_title: A slow but igniting take on how the slow poison grows and burns the friends alive.
reviews.content:
The Banshees of Inisherin (2022):
Brief Review -A slow but igniting take on how the slow poison grows and burns the friends alive. The Banshees of Inisherin is getting all the praise from the critics this year for its poisonous take on friendship, which is far away from regular mainstream attempts. The film has a lot of moments for the critics and those who love meaningful and realistic cinema-even if it's slow and exhausting. This film falls into that category. I don't know how many people would agree, but that's what makes it quite boring for mainstream cinema lovers. A runtime of 113 minutes is not long, but here it looks so. Why? Because you don't provide entertainment or engaging elements. We have seen many films made about friendship, sweet and toxic both, but never a brutal one like this. Maybe we have, but that wasn't as subtle or devastating as this. The film follows lifelong friends who find themselves at an impasse when one abruptly ends their relationship. The second one tries to rekindle the bond, but the other goes mad and violent against it. Somehow, this leads to revenge and inner complexity that turn into criminally unjustifiable events. What powers the slow screenplay is the realism and character study. The film reunites Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson, who previously worked together on McDonagh's directorial debut, In Bruges (2008). The performances of both are like a battle of the titans. You get immersed in that face-off, which doesn't have any aggressive scenes; you just enjoy the pauses. Martin McDonagh's writing is a bit dull, but his direction makes up for the loss. Overall, a good watch, but looking at the hype around it nowadays, it seems a bit overwhelming. Give it a watch for the performances and commitment to the topic.RATING - 6/10*By - #samthebestest.

Colin Farrell great actor.Brendan Gleeson great actor.Irish film with both of them in it. Guaranteed winner!Dark films, no problem.This film... Started off interesting, then totally lost its way, got quite repetitive and pointless. Torture to sit through. Some people left the cinema but we stuck with it as maybe there's a big finish, a point, something to talk about. It had none of that. Not even close. "Everything was fine yesterday" until I went to see this movie.Most of the cast have good film backgrounds, but didn't really get a chance to show their acting skills, due to poor character scripts.

reviews.review_title: A Movie Only a Critic Can Like
reviews.content: Whoever called this a "dark comedy" needs a recalibration -- this isn't any kind of comedy, it's not even dark, it is just depressing. Yes, the scenery is gorgeous and you get a real feel for the time and place but that is it, otherwise, it is very hard to watch. This just seemed like a random 1 or 2 weeks in the life of these characters but there was no context, no backstory, I guess the movie is trying to say something about life and relationships (presumably more than just the obvious), but I just didn't didn't see it. No comparison at all to In Bruges or 3 Billboards, both of which were had much more developed story lines and characters (and both in my mind, were more like dark comedies).

reviews.review_title: Searching for a Bit of Peace
reviews.content: McDonagh's latest is his least fussy and most successful works to date, and is more in step with the work of his older brother, John Michael McDonagh, particularly Calvary. Here we find two friends whose lives and relationships are torn apart by a single mishandled decision. There's definitely a heavy sense of allegory here, and you could write of the symbolism for days, but what it has over any similar film studies fodder is a seriously sharp sense of humour as well as gorgeous locations and a flawless cast of characters. I loved it utterly and came away overwhelmed. Up with this sort of thing.

It's rubbish !! Yet again a film that is made to win the minds of only its peers and award judges and not the general public, boring from these 'arty' filmmakers you have no idea what people want to see regardless of how they pay it with hard earned money. This film is a poster for films like this and wouldn't give it a look, if there was a plus point the best came from the donkey in it and the actress who plays Colin Farrell sister. So glad I didn't go to the cinema as would have walked out, maybe I'm being a philistine and like action movies far from it, things like this can be really entertaining but this doesn't even scratch the surface.

Looking at someone cutting off their fingers seems to reveal a serious mental illness with no real meaning or purpose, just pure stupidity of living in a place where there is nothing to do but be depressed. The suicide of another charachter who has an abusive father is also incredibly dark. Overall the only thing good about this film is the scenery. The story offers no redemption nor anything uplifting. I mistakenly watched this to the end thinking there might be at least some kind of meaning but again nothing. Unfortunately I now need to get this movie out of my brain as it diminishes my faith in humanity.

reviews.review_title: boring, slow, depressing, junk, good acting
reviews.content: I give this movie 1 star for the writing and 3 stars for the good acting, so average that out and you get 2 stars. As I have said in my other reviews, there are a lot of movies lately with good acting and horrible writing. This is another example. First of all we have a period piece with good sets, wardrobe, pub, horses, everything, so DO SOMETHING WITH IT ! Whats wrong with you? Those were the most boring pub scenes in the history of film-making! Good acting with nowhere to go. Kerry Condon overacted the whole time, I guess she thought she was still in Hamlet. YOU'RE NOT IN HAMLET ANYMORE, KERRY! Get over yourself.Ok, so the storyline. Guy cuts fingers off for no reason. Ok, brilliant! Holy horsepie, seriously? Seriously. No, Seriously? No. Yes, that is the storyline. Maybe this is Celtic humor, or Celtic horror, or Celtic history, don't know, don't care, never will. Guy burns down house. Holy fire batman, wowza wowza, fire! Fire! Fire! Geez, this is cowpie.The sad scene is when Colin's baby mule Jenny ate an artichoke and died, or a finger, sorry, i think Jenny Artichoke was Irish. See, thats funnier than anything in this movie. Was this a black comedy, nope, was this a drama, nope, none, was this an artsy film, nope, no artistic value or merit, was this a bland non-alcoholic Irish coffee? Yes sir! This is bland non-alcoholic Irish coffee! Not worth the money or the time.Oh, Jenny Artichoke come home to Colin and stop his tears. But wait, hold on, hold on horsey, hold on, this would have been a good 15 minute short film, but not a great one. Edit this beast down to 15 minutes and i'll give it another star.

reviews.review_title: Sad disturbing beautiful pointless and upsetting
reviews.content: Spoilers: The whole premise of this movie is built on an unrealistic insane character who behaves like a psychopath. I can't imagine any backstory which justifies the irrational improbable behavior of Colm. If there had been a purple leprechaun it would have been more believable. Of course the acting was good but I felt at the end like I had been tricked into wasting 2 hours getting emotionally invested in this film which had such a horrific ending. No rational person would behave in this fashion. Not to mention that biologically horses and donkeys can't choke on things. Ridiculous waste of time.

This movie has one truly great star, the landscape. Even great actor such as Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson can't make much of the daft and shallow allegory that Martin McDonagh attempts. It is devoid of humanity and logic. One dimensional caricatures interact in a darkly comic manner with a stunning coastal backdrop. I was beyond unmoved. I was irked. The Irish Civil War and its aftermath was a horrowshow. But the victims were not just the men. McDonagh chooses to ignore this. Wives were committed to the struggle too. They took part in a supporting role. They were widowed if not during, then within a few years after. They raised large families in poverty without the normal neighbourly support. They faced down parish priests who saw slave labourers in their children. This movie is an insult to the people involved.

If there was a full length feature movie entirely about a man taking a dump, it would be infinitely more interesting than this. I'm sure though that someone would praise the man's acting and the brilliant scenery of the restroom. How anyone could get any enjoyment or entertainment out of this excuse for a film is beyond me. There was zero character development or anything that would cause anyone to care about any of the characters outside of the donkey and the dog. The movie was so annoying, I think I will cut my fingers off and throw them at the directors door. Wouldn't that make perfect sense?

What on earth is this about ???? Very boring !!!I'm baffled at the reviews for this. Did we watch the same film ?? Such a shame, I had high hopes for this since their great pairing in In Bruges. Be aware that this is NOTHING like In Bruges and is just a slow boring and dark film all the way through. I was hoping for some explanation of why the friendship deteriorated, but no, none was given. Just a boring storyline, boring scenery, awful houses, boring Neanderthal people, old fashioned and weird, everything rubbish. Just a weird ending to a weird film where not much happens the whole way through.

Colin Farrell was 10!10, but the movie wasn't nearly as good as In Bruges, so I was terribly disappointed. There was funny parts, but the saddest part ruined the entire movie for me. It broke the golden rule of, "don't kill the ____."I almost always really like Brendan Gleeson, but in the movie he was just nasty and crazy. It was okay, but I really expected a much bigger reason behind, "I just don't like you any more." For real, what else was there to do on the island? And the one thing that he could do (sit in the pub and play his fiddle) he robbed himself of doing by his own actions. There he was blaming Pádraic's inane prattle and it probably had nothing to do with anyone else.

I confess that I watched it for the actors and the high score. But with 20 minutes (or less), I was already falling asleep and so was my wife.I tried VERY, VERY MUCH to finish the film thinking there was going to be something good to justify the high rating and all these nominations. And not to mention only bad, the performances were even good, but nothing that justifies this note...I don't know what people are praising and saying so well to be honest.To conclude, the film seems that the main characters are sick - any serious emotional or psychological illness - which is a very plausible and extremely important theme, it would even make sense to me. But the movie is "just" HORRIBLE, without foot or head... Extremely boring.

It's a quiet movie that made me laugh out loud. Honestly did not know what to expect when I went to see it. Did not even Know Colin Farrell was in it. (Brendan Gleeson was big enough for me to check it out). Gleeson plays an old musician living in a small island village who basically realizes his boring friend, Pádraic (Farrell's character) is not worth hanging out with anymore, which he takes hard, because he got nothing else.It's a relatable film if you don't concentrate on the backdrop of Ireland 100 years ago. It's a very small-time folks like movie that I've seen but never in this atmosphere which makes in unique.Plus, it's just really funny!

The scenery of Ireland is just too magnificent to describe. The Irish part of my blood has always regretted not having visited the Emerald Isle.Martin McDonagh has written another winner, although the story is not exactly an uplifting one. Martin seems to have some deeply negative thoughts on human nature.Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell are at the top of their games as a pair of lifelong friends living lives of isolation.Brendan has decided to no longer converse with the Colin character, leading the latter to wonder why this sudden change of their relationship.The second half becomes a bit gruesome as Brendan's character takes extreme measures in order to avoid his former friend.The Banshees of Inisherin is one of the best movies of the year.

Overall I liked 'The Banshees of Inisherin' but I also have mixed feelings about it. Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell deliver strong performances to try carry the film.There is something refreshing about a simplistic setting. The film is set in 1923 on a very simple and laid back island in Ireland. We have become conditioned to seeing CGI and over the top story lines and/or action sequences. So it's nice to see a film that relies on its story and performances. I feel this setup is the reason people have heaped praise on this film, a real story that isn't Marvel or another action/CGI film. The story is also relatable and understandable. One can see how a person might grow weary of a friendship or companion when you had little choice to begin with. They were an odd pairing from the start.My only contention is the story could have delved into something deeper. This simplistic setting could have explored the complexities of the human experience, no matter what the year was, you would find it deeply relatable. It could have been more thought provoking and questioned societies conventions or very nature of friendship, human fragility or something existential. In my humble little opinion this could have taken the film to a deeper level and a higher rating for me.

An artsy-fartsy movie where nothing happens. I'm convinced this is a failed play that they adapted to a movie for fraudulent tax purposes and a trip to Ireland. This is one of those movies that no-one watches and yet it steals best picture of the year. I'm glad I had a coupon for a free movie so I didn't waste my money but I'm upset I wasted it on this.The movie starts out like a Dr. Seuss book and then gets entrenched in mediocre drama. Many plotlines that go nowhere, which doesn't help the viewer care for the "main" plotline. And don't try to say this film is "haunting" or "dark", it's just petty and drawn out. It tries to make the viewer start analyzing it like english literature studies, but there's no conflict or theme worth analyzing. I barely care for the film at face value, why should I give your "deep meaning" the time of day?This year has so many better films that this, save your money.1/10.

This movie isn't funny, it's morbid. I thought I was going to see a comedy but just the opposite. Depressed adults in a malaise living on a small Irish island. I didn't recognize Colin Farrell through much of the movie, he has aged considerably. The movie has some adorable animals in it.This might be a one star movie. I suppose I have a bias for the actors who are very good but the plot isn't. It's bleakness set amongst the beauty of an Irish seaside.It's hard to say what the meaning is. Perhaps that the banalities of life and disappointments of not realizing a lasting contribution as one nears the last decade or so of life can drive some to the extremes affecting the contentedness of those closest. There is a cascade affect that builds to the point of thoughtless, selfish reckless.

reviews.review_title: Sublime Cinema that begs to be seen on a BIG Screen
reviews.content: My Review -The Banshees of Inisherin (2022)My Rating 10/10This is my favourite movie of 2022 for a multitude of reasons .I don't use the word genius lightly but in Martin McDonagh's case I think genius is the perfect description of his talent to write for the cinema beautifully and direct his talented actors to perfection.Two previous films of Martin McDonagh's movies are great all time favourites of mine they are In Bruges 2008 and Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri (2017).It's probably partly my Irish Celtic ancestry because The Banshees of Inisherin joins those two previous Martin McDonagh films and now belongs on my all time favourites lists .I've seen it twice already and as far as character insight ,simplicity of story and the beautiful but austere location are concerned this is the finest movie I've seen since last years Jane Campion triumph The Power of the Dog which also is about a complex male relationship between very two different men.Power of the Dog was about sibling rivalry between brothers The Banshees of Inisherin is about male friendship, loneliness and geographical isolation.I really can't think of any other movie that depicts a non sexual male friendship with the emotional intensity and intimacy that these two polar opposite characters portray.Colin Farrell gives the male acting performance of the year so far as far as I'm concerned cast as Pádraic Súilleabháin a simple gentle sensitive Irish dairy farmer living in a hut on an isolated island with his sister Siobhan plus his much loved miniature donkey Jenny when his sister allows Jenny inside.Colm Doherty played with equal brilliance by Brendon Gleeson who suddenly rejects his friend Colm both actors give Oscar worthy performances.Hopefully they won't both get nominated in in the Best actor category as that would jinx their chances of either winning.These two great Irish actors who also had acting triumphs together in Martin McDonough's "In Bruges "have been waiting 14 years to star together again and it's been well worth the wait .The plot sounds simple but just imagine living on a rural isolated island with a tiny population and the shock and rejection if your best friend who you've shared much of your life experience with suddenly went strange saying "I don't like you anymore " and don't talk to me again .Set on the fictional island of Inisherin in 1923 where Colm can hear the gun shots and conflict from across the bay from the Irish Civil War these two lifelong mates Pádraic (Colin Farrell) and Colm (Brendan Gleeson) engage in a battle of their own after Pádraic is told by Colm to go away and not speak to him again. Pádraic ironically makes a comment as he listens to the distant guns and explosions of conflict " Good luck to you Whatever it is you're fighting about ?Pádraic persists in trying to make amends, meeting resistance from Colm at every turn. The row escalates under the watchful eyes of the entire village as Colm makes good on a gruesome promise.That brings me to the other great characters in The Banshees of Inisherin the village folk who all add to the humour ,charm and magic of this outstanding movie.They include Kerry Condon as Siobhán ,Pádraic's much loved and educated sister who longs for an escape from isolation asking her brother ,don't you ever get lonely Pádraic?Kerry Condon should be definitely nominated for Best Supporting Actress Oscar she is outstanding.As is Barry Keoghan in the role of Dominic Kearney a not so simple minded villager with a monster abuser for a father who happens to be the village Police Constable.Barry Keoghan as Dominic should be among the many Oscar nominated actors in this movie his scenes with Pádraic are truly touching and very funny.The most mysterious character in this movie is Mrs. McCormick played by Sheila Flitton who warns Pádraic that death will come to the island soon as she appears like a banshee which in Irish legend means a female spirit who warns of a death in a house.The threat of death-as if brought by a banshee-falls over the village of Inisherin as no one knows just how far the feud between Pádraic and Colm will go.Colin Farrell and Brendon Gleeson are real life friends who's professional careers merge seamlessly in this film as they did In Bruges their on screen chemistry together and rapport is a joy to behold.The Cinematography by Ben Davis is glorious and captures the wild beauty of Achill Island in County Mayo on the West Coast of Ireland with glorious shots of the sea the fishing boats and the sky at times looking like an artists canvas.The scrupulous attention to set detail by Production designer Mark Tildesley adds to the visual joy of this movie . I read that even The J. J. Devine Public House was purpose-built for the production on Achill Island .in County Mayo then demolished as the Production team had no building permit .Banshees of Inisherin is another movie to be seen on a Cinema screen because of its intimacy and beauty it also has some very funny moments that capture the unique charm of Irish rural village culture and superstition,it's truly a magic movie.Carter Burwell master movie score composer of movies that include Carol 2015 , Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri 2017, The Fargo television series ,Twilight and In Bruges 2008 has added another of his best and most evocative music film scores to The Banshees of Inisherin .

Martin McDonagh turned out fine pieces of work with "In Bruges" and "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri". He has now given us another one with "The Banshees of Inisherin". This tragicomedy focuses on the collapse of a friendship on an island in 1920s Ireland (at the tail end of the Irish Civil War). But as the movie progresses, it turns more and more intense.The movie has rightfully earned a number of Academy Award nominations. Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan put their all into their performances. The cinematography and music accompany the performances to create one of the most brilliant focuses on relationships and despair (an appropriate reflection of Ireland at that time, since it was basically a Third World country).One outstanding production. It deserves at least one of the Oscars for which it's nominated.

Beautiful scenery. Great acting. Lovely little donkey. And that's about it.It seems to be some sort of allegory of the Irish civil war. Where the country is in some way causing harm to itself as it struggled to get out from under the jackboots of the British. But I could be wrong and it might be about something else altogether.It was an acting showcase for all involved. The five main characters did wonderfully well supporting the real star of the show, 'Jenny'. The scenery provided a bleak and harsh but beautiful backdrop to the interplay between the characters.Having seen the trailer a few times I was excited to see the film and was very much looking forward to seeing it. I was disappointed.

Quite literally a waste of your time. The movie struggles to gain momentum or meaning. Associating this movie with "humor" should be a crime. It's boring and an insult to other filmmakers who actually make entertaining content. The only redeeming quality to this movie is the scenery and costume work.The movie has potential to create meaning and emotion yet it seems to sprint as fast as it can away from any point. If it has one it needs to make it or come with a damn flyer that someone hands out before the movie starts.This is clearly someone's pet project that should have stayed in the basement along side their peanut butter fort.

Such a beautiful part of the world, some amazing scenery.Then an ultimately pointless story. It's built up to be some amazing thing, then the end credits came up.It left me dreadfully disappointed. No context as to why, what was it all about?I am finding it extremely difficult to even write enough words to meet the criteria for this review. You have a hapless young man, a hapless older man (Farrell) and a few characters who inhabit the island, but mostly the pub (where they never seem to pay for the pints they order).The story opens lots of sub plots, which all fizzle out, a wizened old crone who shows promise and then fails to deliver.It's a couple of hours I will never get back and wish I hadn't wasted my time.

It is a very interesting film.There is not much action so don't expect it to eventually become faster paced.All the actors are really good.It is a well written film.It's kind of a weird topic and sad when mentally ill people don't get help.It is a long film, almost two hours.I found it boring in some places.The scenery is amazing.What do the people that live there do for work.I'd rent it again but there are a lot of good movies out and this wouldn't be at the top of my list.I'm sure I missed a lot of symbolism.The civil war was mentioned a lot.I had no complaints about the filming, it was well done.

Have you ever had that friend who just one day...disappears? No rhyme or reason for their departure, and no answer will be sastifactory. You can attempt to find out why, but the final outcome remains the same. Picture that, then put them on an Irish island in 1923 in the midst of an Irish Civil War. There is the core of the story and it is a tale you can sense could be told in front of a campfire. If you know any silly stories of Issac Bashiv Singer, you will likely enjoy this film. A film with oddball characters who are so buried deep into their idiosyncrasies you sometimes want to yell for them to get out of their own heads. But in a world where no social media exists and in a town less then a few hundred, it is remarkable that director Martin McDonagh makes this town feel so claustrophobic. This is because this is a place where everyone knows each others business. Questions rise to the top. For instance, Paulraic (played wonderfully by Colin Ferrell) lives with his sister Slobhan (Kerry Condon) and with a close knit donkey named Jenny. One day Paulraic's lifelong friend Colm (Brendan Gleeson) decides he no longer wants to be friends. In any way. Now, in modern days you can move on. On a far off island, it's probably impossible to find someone who you can converse with. In Paulraic's case, it's either Colm or a slow-witted kid who has no filter and is the son of the local constable who has been abusive. Those are his choices. That same fateful moment, Paulraic believes Colm is sassing him with a long running prank. But he means it. The trailer would have you believe a great deal of wild back and forth will happen. Instead, it's a quiet grudge in which both characters do still speak to one another. The story skates wonderfully in that world where you are wondering what frustrations Paulraic could bring his dead old friend. As I imagined, it would be Paulraic making more of nuisance of himself. BUT, that isn't the case. There is a legitimate reason for Colm to ignore Paulraic. And also a legitimate reason for Paulraic to value Colm's friendship. That is remarkable sense of storytelling. An American version would have you feel animosity towards Paulraic.Gleeson plays the Colm character with a great deal of humanity. The man has been feeling stuck on the island. He's suffocating under being irrelevant. Whilst Paulraic is perfectly fine in the mundane world. In Colm's case, he is nearing an age where he feels like he needs to make a mark in the world. A lot of artists feel this way. What legacy can one leave if you aren't married, and don't have children. A world awaited Colm and Paulraic is reminder of an anchor that holds him to the island. In a lot of ways, Paulraic's sister feels the same. It is much too suffocating of a place full of depression where the elderly women of the town live for bad gossip.McDonagh loves his small town stories. No doubt a sense of breaking away from the small world to see the big one. Or at least do the bigger things life should have in store for us.There is no satisfying ending here. Sorry to break it to you. The resolution runs out of gas. There is a glimpse at the end, where you believe it would escalate into two friends physically hurting one another. Instead, it mellows out. Perhaps that is the resolution between two friends. It does leave you wondering how it continues from there.A nice escape from the technology that bears down on us. It's nice to see a movie where there is no smartphones, electricity or even running water. It's just people and behavior.

I love Colin Farrell. I really wanted to like this movie. It's terrible. I like dark films. This is not. It's not a comedy either. Yet it is advertised as both. An equine would never eat a finger. Or try to. They are herbivores. They never eat meat. All the actors are sublime. The problem is that there's just no story. Boring, boring, boring. I wanted some sort of resolution, then it was over. At this point, I need 200 more characters to post and I can't waste more time typing about this tragedy. If you want to watch something good, watch the Australian series Wakefield. It's so good that I bought it on Amazon.

What's the point of telling a story that has no point?They start by setting up a story that seems interesting, funny and maybe even original, then.. nothing! I tried to retell the story to myself or to others and the response always: what's the point of the story?Almost half way through, I thought this is going to be great, maybe even the best movie this year, what a disappointment? I mean, movies like that usually will add a car chase, a super hero a fight scene just to give some form of entertainment.If you watch it, you might conclude it's an autobiography of the director, that dull sod.The world is full of dumb people, nowadays, so a movie like this is nominated as one of the best movies made this year, really?I gave it a 5 because i like the donkey, and the subtitles.

reviews.review_title: Possibly the best thing McDonagh has ever done.
reviews.content: A legend in the theatre, Martin McDonagh's film career has been patchy at best; close to sublime with "In Brughes" and "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" and almost irredeemably bad with "Seven Psychopaths". At least until now, since McDonagh's new film isn't just the best thing he's done on screen but very possibly the best thing he's ever done.On the surface, "The Banshees of Inisherin" is a very simple affair with a plot that could have been written on the back of an envelope. The setting is the ficticious island of Inisherin off the mainland of Ireland. The year is 1922 and the Irish Civil War is raging. Padraic, (Colin Farrell) and Colm, (Brendan Gleeson) are seemingly best friends until one day Colm tells Padraic he no longer wants to be his friend, that he finds him 'boring', and so what begins as a dark comedy worthy of Beckett or indeed the McDonagh who gave us "The Beauty Queen of Leenane" turns slowly but inexorably into a tragedy worthy of Ibsen and dealing with such themes as loneliness, depression, masculinity and friendship and with an ending as sad as any I've seen in the cinema, (though others may see it differently).Of course, it all could just as easily have fallen on its slightly absurdist face. Here is a scenario that could have gone any which way; McDonagh is hardly known for his subtlety and yet he never puts a foot wrong. By the time we get to the last act you could hear a pin drop in a packed cinema.It's also magnificently acted both by Farrell and Gleeson in career-best performaces, both underplaying to the extent that they totally disappear inside their characters and there is a third magnificent performance from Barry Keoghan, (please, just give him the Best Supporting Actor Oscar now), as Dominic, ostensibly the village idiot he may just be the most intelligent person on the island and that is his tragedy; such intelligence can't be contained especially when it goes unrecognized. A masterpiece.

I watched this film last night because of the amazing reviews and the nominations/prices it got. I was really exited to check this one out.For me, this movie is very weird experience. Its supposed to be a comedy but i find it neither funny nore interesting.In my honest opinion, the only good part about this film was the acting and the cinematography (and the donkey). But after watching this movie i just felt weird and a little dead inside.The whole movie is just strange.Idk if this is an irish style thing or whatever but i really wish i hadn't watched this movie.2/10 for me fellas, only because im into cinematography.

THE BANSHEES OF INISHERIN (B+) asks, "Can you just suddenly end a friendship?" The question plays out over the rock wall strewn Irish island (No Man is an Island?) of Inisherin in the 1920's. The inciting conflict is simple, what if one member of a long-time friendship between two Irish men (Colm and Padraic) wants end their friendship. What consequences would develop from that? Colm, played by Brendan Gleeson, one morning decides to stop being friendly with Padraic, played by Colin Farrell. When the two country friends finally sit down and chat about it, Colm opens up, "I just don't like you anymore" and walks off. All of this happens within the first ten minutes of a 110-minute film. We learn later that Colm has been dealing with the meaningless of life, suicide, and that he can no longer put up with Padraic's dull and aimless chatter. Colm wants to focus on making music and being more thoughtful, something that will be remembered past his life. The rest of the film observes the fallout of this relationship that may or may not result in the cutting off of fingers and dead animals. In following this fallout the film explores the purpose of friendship and life. Should friendship be an equal relationship? What should we get out of friendship if anything? What does it do to a person inside when they are denied friendship? What is the effect on society as well? Should life be about friendship or achievement? Do the two need be against each other? I found myself fairly caught up in the story and the questions that arise from it. There's a lot of insight to be had here. Unfortunately, the film lags about halfway through and writer/director' Martin McDonagh's penchant for taking his stories to extremes (which absolutely sank Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri for me) takes the story in directions that just took me out of it. I'm sure others will have different results. It's an interesting meditation, parable like, that is weighed down by a need to shock (if it is just a tragedy) and the lack of redeemable qualities (if it is meant to be more than a tragedy). It's a bummer because the reunion of Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson, and Martin McDonagh, the key trio behind In Bruges, made this one of my most anticipated films of the year.

Yes, the setting is stunning. Yes, the actors are marvelous, right down to the smallest parts and casting choices. But that does not make a good movie.The Producers deserve an award for putting all the elements in place....except a script worthy of 2 hours of your time!This is beyond dreadful, the most disappointing movie I've seen in years. There are a thousand movies that provide a more enjoyable treatise on friendship, isolation and family. This was such a surprise seeing his previous movie '3 billboards....' Was so brilliant. Do not waste your time on this, unless you are committed to watching only the most depressing scripts ever put to film.

reviews.review_title: A parable about the Irish Civil War and The Troubles that lingered
reviews.content: It's a relationship-gone-bad movie set in 1923 on a small island off the coast of Ireland. It follows the deteriorating relationship between two former friends that escalates to a bitter ending.Colm Doherty (Brendan Gleeson) is an older man who lives alone with his dog. He enjoys fiddle music and trying to compose some tunes as he's become more aware of his mortality. He has wearied over time of his younger neighbor, Pádraic Súilleabháin (Colin Farrell). Pádraic is content with his hum-drum daily life with no aspirations to change. He enjoys his farm animals, especially his miniature donkey, and lives with his unmarried sister, Siobhán (Kerry Condon), perhaps the most educated and intelligent person on the island. Another nearby neighbor is the younger Dominic Kearney (Barry Keoghan), son of the village policeman, Peadar (Gary Lydon). Peadar regularly beats Dominic, who is mildly challenged intellectually and has few filters on his conversations.Colm tells Pádraic that he finds him dull and wants to end their relationship in order to spend more time on his music. Pádraic, who is lonely except for Colm, his sister, and his donkey, refuses to accept Colm's request. The tension and trouble escalate throughout the film. Siobhán and Dominic escape in their own ways, leaving Colm and Pádraic in conflict to the end.Some describe this as a dark comedy. That characterization doesn't fit, though there is much humor along the way. It is more of a parable about the Irish Civil War and The Troubles that lingered through the decades. One laughs to keep from weeping about the breakdown in relationships.Gleeson, Farrell, and Condon are excellent in their roles. Lydon also performs well. The Mrs. McCormick (Sheila Flitton) character was an unnecessary diversion in the story, but on the whole, I found it well-crafted. The ending was a surprise, but it made sense. I recommend it.

While the scenery is spellbinding, the storyline is not. If you are squeamish, then this may not be the movie for you. We still don't know what this movie is trying to convey about 1920s relationships. I know that on the one hand it shows animal cruelty, and on the other there is consideration for animals. Overall, the former disturbed both my wife and me.Colin Farrell acts out his confusion very well. Brendan Gleeson acts out the madness his character exhibits to great effect.The island - Inisherin - is in reality a composite of two other islands, and the scenery is stunning.In summary...if this is a 'dark comedy's as the promoters put it, then I am a monkey's uncle.

I've started to avoid films regarded as 'Irish' because the local media and critics are too subjective in their commentary and reviews. The hype machine was all the way up to 11 on this one and it doesn't live up to it unfortunately. If I stumbled on this film on TV one night I might have been charmed more. The accents also grate. Irish theatrical accents are second only to Hollywood Irish accents in their ability to distract from the character. The dialogue was average too unfortunately and included numerous anachronistic phrases. The locations were spectacular and one character does deliver quite a touching moment I must say.

reviews.review_title: "No-one does self-hatred like the Irish" (2022 list excerpt)
reviews.content: Another film I managed to catch on VOD, The Banshees of Inisherin is likely the most personal film that Martin McDonagh has ever made -- if he did indeed base this on experiences of his own; all I know for sure is he's back to his roots, filming in Ireland and reuniting Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson, the starring duo of his In Bruges (2008). It's hard to settle on what exactly to write here, as it's one of those movies where nobody can quite decide on what the film is about.What most will agree on is the following surface-level reading: It is (A) a tale of lost friendship and (B) one of the most Irish movies ever made. (Subtitles are recommended even if English is your first language.)It is also one of those movies that made me want to yell at the screen, and I mean that in the best possible way. It's a film where things progressively get worse, and each time they do, characters will insist on making them worse than worse. We want to clobber sense into them at every turn. However, we aren't frustrated because they're poorly written or too stupid to exist; we're frustrated because we can believe that these geezers are real and that their lives and situations would've led them to a point whereby this makes sense to them.It helps that the actors are absolutely perfect; critic Glenn Kenny remarked that, for all of McDonagh's successful attempts at making films about America, "nobody does self-loathing quite like the Irish". In addition to the transfixing chemistry between Farrell and Gleeson, Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan appear in show-stealing supporting roles.The film also makes marvelous use of the Irish vistas (featuring several memorable shots of peaceful fields lined with dry stone walls and minuscule figures brooding atop the towering coastal cliffs) and Carter Burwell's score is both beautiful and haunting where it counts. And yes, there are many ways to read the text -- the significance of the equids, the cloaked whatever-she-is that lurks about the island (usually before something terrible happens), the possible Irish History allegories to be found, the existentialist question of basing your identity around your relationships (and the self-destruction that may take place once they end)...In any case, it's just a fe*king good time.

reviews.review_title: A Movie of The Dullards by The Dullards for The Dullards
reviews.content: Overall a dull experience. Visually captivating but that's about it. Throw in a load of cliches and a really dumb plot and script (nonsense really) and you have a film that is so overrated it will make some people angry. The lines that try to be witty are, to put it mildly, embarrassing. There is plenty of craft on display: the set, constumes, cinematography, some of the acting; but the raw material is just so bad it is cringeworthy. Is this the visual equivalent of the emperor's new clothes? If you are wondering if you don't 'get it', don't worry, there's nothing to get. This film is proof that no-one knows anything.

... except the point.Great acting, directing, location and characters.. It was certainly interesting for the extent of the run-time, but that was on the assumption that the film would have something interesting to say. It doesn't.This is an example of a movie that gets everything right and would probably have been great if it were made any time before the last decade, but despite being set in early 20th century Ireland, 21st century nihilistic post modernism seeps its way in and the writer/director is under the delusion that the film would be saying more if it said nothing. So really you're just spending 2 hours watching two main characters go through... something.. with no purpose or resolution.It's like one of those splatter painting where the artist thinks it's great if he leaves it to the viewer to see what they want in it. Same philosophy. I prefer a bowl of fruit.

reviews.review_title: Black comedy that misses the mark
reviews.content: It would be easy to dismiss a negative review of this film as "not getting it", but rest assured this is exactly the kind of film I love, and I entirely "get it". It's slow, leisurely in its storytelling, handling despair and loneliness and purpose of life, with a sense of dark humor. And there is plenty of humor, some of it is even funny, but most of it just doesn't land. In the theater where I watched it, only the first confessional scene got any kind of audible response. If it were just that, then the film could be merely passable.But the bigger problem is that the underlying tension is just never terribly compelling, despite some rather drastic events. Dealing with despair and hopes and wasted lives is always going to be a tall task, but I had just hoped for more. As the story slowly unfurled, I hoped it would become a socially kafka-esque tale in a small Irish village, but to no avail. Instead it became a rather familiar, if understated, duel of the spirits.Technically, I think the filmmakers relied a bit too much on setting and cinematography and not enough on writing. There are magnificent shots within the film, which only work to remind the viewer that this is a film, and a visual message is being conveyed. (I recognize the burden is on the viewer to suspend disbelief, but when the sledgehammer comes, it takes a moment to reorient oneself.) And the acting is serviceable. Notably, in a perfect example of a backhanded compliment, Colin Farrell is perfectly cast as a dullard. The role of Dominic was played with vigor, let's say, but it actually starts to grow on the viewer. The portrayal of the sister however, even accounting for dueling defining character traits, was, to be kind, overwrought.It's one of the oldest clichés, but applicable here, that in a very meta sense, this film made me wish I had that time back. Time I could have been doing something more productive, even if it was just watching a better film. That's not just a tired old criticism, it shows that I get the film.

I don't understand why this movie is rated so high. It was incredibly slow and incredibly sad. There were no positive messages. I actually turned it off about 3/4 of the way through. I couldn't handle the sadness any longer. I also thought the story was extremely unbelievable. What kind of person (a musician at that) would cut his fingers off because his ex-friend kept talking to him wanting him to allow his friendship again. And Colin's character only has one friend, his pet donkey Jenny, because of this dark God forsaken island he lives on has very few people living on it. Then Jenny chokes on one of the fingers that were cut off. I had already turned the movie off by that point but a friend told me that happened. I started watching it because I love Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell. But even they couldn't keep me watching.

I've got high expectations going in. This could be dangerous. As Pádraic (Colin Farrell) knocks on his friend Colm's (Brendan Gleeson) door to invite him to the pub, he's ignored and there's an ominous bell toll. This troubles Pádraic. Rightly so. These two it's clear are thought to be best friends and when Colm says "I just don't like you no more", you can see Pádraic's confused heart break. It's a simple world of dry stone walls, rural countryside, log fires, candlelight, Jenny the donkey, fiddles and wooly jumpers. All adding to Pádraic's melancholy. To be honest Colm doesn't seem happy either. Despite all this The Banshees of Inisherin is a comedy. Not the crass stupid blockbuster kind, but the gentle heartfelt kind. Dominic (Barry Keoghan) alone is fantastic, "Pay no attention to wars, I'm against em, wars and soap". Funny as he is, he's no comfort to Pádraic or Pádraic's sister Siobhán (Kerry Condon), who Dominic is chasing... pinning all his hopes on. Pádraic doesn't understand why he's lost his friend. Until Colm explains that he's tired of idling the time away. He wants to be more productive, to leave a legacy. The island of Inisherin off Ireland is both beautiful and desolate. It's a good metaphor for this film, about loneliness and purpose. It's shot through with understated dry effortless humour that warms the soul sumptuously from the screen, but despite Pádraic's best effort to stay away from Colm as instructed. His niceness makes it hard and before long Colm's ultimatum unleashes an increasingly dark string of events. It's the sort of film that cuts deep. Etching something meaningful. It'll stick with me for some time. Expectations met.

reviews.review_title: A tragicomedy that showcases a barrage of emotions! [+82%]
reviews.content: Ireland is such a contradiction, at least in cinema. On the exterior, it has some of the most beautiful landscapes the human eye can witness, yet there's a sense of seeping melancholy and nonchalance that's nearly incomparable. This is the perfect setting to tell the story of best friends Padraic (Colin Farrell) and Colm (Brendan Gleeson), where one fine morning in the island of Inisherin, the latter decides he wants nothing to do with the former - no friendship, no loose talk, no interactions at all. Like any of us, Padraic believes it's all a joke at first, but he's shocked to learn that Colm is taking it all the way.Poor Padraic is told he's dull and not smart enough to engage in any meaningful interactions whereas Colm intends to spend more time creating art (in this case, music) that generations of people can resonate with. This turmoil affects Padraic more than anyone, and losing the only real friend he had is something he finds difficult to digest - Farrell delivers an amazingly vulnerable performance here. One can draw parallels to this with the the faraway sights and sounds of the Civil War that's going on in the Irish mainland, but Inisherin feels like it's cocooned from it. Even the people who reside there barely discuss the war except for a cop. Barry Keoghan, who plays the village idiot (and Padraic's buddy), is sensational. I can see what Matt Reeves sees in him when he's going to take up the role of Joker.Another performance I truly adore is that of Kerry Condon, who plays Padraic's sister Siobhan. She speaks and acts like the only practical person in the whole island, but is downright emotional when it comes to her brother. Then, there's the horde of animals of Inisherin that includes Jenny the donkey, Colm's dog, a bunch of cows and horses, all adding to the silent beauty of the place. Martin McDonagh's film begins as a dry comedy, and it remains one almost all through, even when it embraces its darker (and more complex) sides. The humor itself is well-timed and situational, having you worry less on one hand, and also shocking you just minutes later with visuals of mangled fingers and gory bar-tables.It's all perfect material for theater, but McDonagh's confidence (in the writing and direction) makes it work as cinema. Its central theme is deeply resonating, especially when viewed in an era where ghosting is so commonplace. Ben Davis' cinematography and Mikkel E. G. Nielsen's edit work fully support McDonagh's vision. That's an incredible feat, no doubt!

I really loved this film, the acting, cinematography and direction are just so enjoyable. The bring me back to a time where beautiful film art didn't necessarily involve punching someone in the face.The trailer for this film is great, it gives you a great sense of what kind of emotional treat the film would give, and I was not disappointed. At first I was expecting Colm's motivations to be silly, but his motivations were entirely believable and in fact ever character was so believable, and reminded me of my time as a child growing up in a small town.If you want a film that can evoke a response and stay with you after the credits roll and make you reflect on life and your relationships, then this film is a must watch.

I watched with great anticipation for the great cast, for the Oscar nominations, and after reading the synopsis and thinking that I would have a big surprise that would justify my attention. But, it fits those movies where nothing happens.Maybe I missed something that made me not understand the context of the film, but it's not what it seems, especially when I read similar reviews.It's a totally overrated and monotonous film. You have to have a lot of good will to consider it a comedy. I gave 5 stars for the good performances, but the movie didn't help, hard to stay awake.I was left with a great feeling of wasting time!

reviews.review_title: A poor comedic take off of 'The Field'
reviews.content:
The Field imv is one of the greatest films of all time
This film is a comedy version of it
The Bull McCabe is replaced by a clueless Brendan Gleeson who has fallen our his former friend Colin Farell for reasons we will never find out.The village idiot is played by Barry Keoghan
The comedy is of the Pat Short/Fr Ted type of humour if you like flat jokes
But no drama because we don't even know why they fell out
Endless unrealistic Paddywhackery for someone who knows Ireland
A pub on the edge of a cliff but nowhere near a town etc
A bit of classical opera tries to up the gravity to no effect
I could go on... but not recommended
Avoid.

reviews.review_title: Oh, it's one of those, is it?
reviews.content: Yes, one of those.This review does not contain spoilers, because there's nothing to spoil.The artsy types - believing it to be the highest form of art - will give it high-number reviews and gush about its complexity and nuance, and if you don't "get it" well, it's you who's the problem.And the high-number reviewers seem to think it exists purely for them to write pretentious prose to impress their peers and appear deep.In many ways it reminded me of that other artsy fan club nonsense film from about five years back called "Roma".Remember that? Same thing.And when I say same thing, I mean:camera work/cinematography is more important than storybecause the story is non-existentIronically, as with that one, the "story" has slight references toward a civil war going on in the background, leading you to believe that this would somehow factor in at some point.Newsflash: it does not!You can speak well of the acting. Sure.The fact that actors speak lines in the film whist often (not too often) using facial expressions to express emotion in the lines spoken is there, absolutely.Shocking to realise that actors can act, is it not?And if that impresses you maybe this is the first film you've ever seen, in which case: congratulations!Overall, this film commits the worst crime in film-making: It's uninteresting.Hope you enjoyed this honest review in a sea of drivel.

Terrific actors all; beautiful cinematography; musical score was outstanding... this movie couldn't suck more if it tried. A older man, apparently suffering from despair, decides his younger, long time, friend is to dull to waste time on, so he decides to shun him. The younger man, a "good man" as noted by all, is then driven to malice, cruelty, arson, and attempted murder. How do we get there? Through unbelievable idiocy; insanity not noticed by anyone, thus ignored; and an abused young man, lost in unrequited love, and a monster of a father. The ending, just absurd and insulting. Not a good film. Reviews giving this thing a 10 are beyond nuts.

reviews.review_title: Dull movie of despair leaves movie goers in despair
reviews.content: This was an excruciatingly slow and dull movie. A protracted dull tale about dull people with inexplicable grudges and wretchedly boring lives. We were teased into going to see this because Farrell and Gleeson had teamed up back in 2008 for the excellent "In Bruges". This new movie reunites these two and, similarly, starts off in a slow and moody fashion but just plodded to its tiresome and witless conclusion. The film could have ended at any time in the first 45 minutes and you would have been as depressed as the central characters had you stayed for the full 114 minutes. There is the standard stupid Irish person that you would come to predictably expect. What was not predictable was how truly dull this was. I had been told, in advance, that "If there was an Oscar for landscape this would win". Thankfully there isn't so this will be a forgotten work in moments... with no red carpet celebration.While were leaving the cinema some people seemed to be still in their seats. Asleep perhaps? In spite of some promised, but absent, dark comedy there certainly would not have been any "post credits funny out-takes" to wait for.Finally, there was an obvious goof in the first 10 minutes.... Which makes one think that even the Film Editor had lost the will to live in common with all of the main characters.

Left him alone!!!People are stupid and this movie proved it. Living in such a beautiful place wasn't enough I guess.I can't even write 600 words to describe how stupid people are.This was just a sad sad movie. Full of dysfunction and loneliness and misery.You can't even fathom the depth of irrational thinking portrayed by these characters.If he had just Stopped talking to the guy. Or if the guy had maybe just shot him to make him stop talking to him.Now what? Maybe they will move in Together since the old guy doesn't have a house anymore. Buy a donkey and live happily ever after. No fingers. No donkey. No house.

I was looking forward to seeing this movie. Usually if a movie has Irish actors, among the best in the business, and it takes place in Ireland, I need very little else to enjoy the movie. Given that this one has all sorts of nominations, I am stunned to have plowed through the entire and enjoyed nothing other than the acting & that I wasted money at the movies to see it. Apparently I don't get the story and I certainly didn't get any humor. Was this a comedy? Really? I'm glad Colin Farrell won the Golden Globe. He's a great actor as is Brendan Gleason. However even that it's nominated for best picture is a farce. Don't waste your time.

'The Banshees of Inisherin' is from director McDonagh, he of 'In Bruges', 'Seven Psychopaths' & 'Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri' fame. Unfortunately, I didn't find it as good as any of his previous films. It's good to see Farrell & Gleeson back together again, as well as a predominately Irish cast playing Irish characters. The plot is simple - Colm (Gleeson) decides he doesn't have time to be friends with Padraic (Farrell) anymore, so Padraic, his sister Siobhan (Condon) and another friend, Dominic (Keoghan), try to find out why.Part of the problem is their isolation, living on the (fictional) island of Inisherin off the west coast of Ireland in the 1920s - there's not much else to do or many other people to interact with! There are plenty of chuckles as the news spreads (via refreshing accents not often heard in Hollywood films) and Padraic tries to comprehend what his long-time friend is doing to him. The 1920s era means there's no cars, electricity or large buildings, so the scenery (real-life islands of Inishmore, off the coast of Galway) and sunsets are stunning, almost their own character.The acting's great, particularly Condon, with Keoghan purposefully annoying, Farrell often bewildered and Gleeson adroit. While it's a comedy, it's very dark and bleak - definitely more of a black comedy or "dramedy" than anything laugh-out-loud. Definitely lots to enjoy, but the ending and overall plot left me gloomy, when I was hoping for a little bit of light at the end of the tunnel.

reviews.review_title: What a sad and pointless film...
reviews.content: Top notch actors again in a dreadful and ugly film. We just endured almost two hours of meaningless pain, betrayal and heartache while we all live through individual despair, betrayal and heartbreak in real life as nightly shown on the news, on social media, and sadly, in our neighborhoods. Where is the balance, the hope, or redemption in a cinema that's not continually pessimistic, sexually-driven and often sophomoric perceptive with lame, overworked alternatives. We both continue to be gobsmacked and depressed by wonderful fellow thespians/colleagues in viewed, applauded projects that repel vs compel society to actively push and display hope/change. This is the 4th in a string of deeply pessimistic, sad movies viewed in two weeks, yet many wonder why the public (usually blaming "the pandemic" for the collapse of film houses) has stopped attending film theaters and television/streaming "rules". There are so many possibilities that lie between Pollyanna and pointless despair to attract, inform and still entertain...the hope is a balance in the performing art forms of just that...of HOPE.

reviews.review_title: Sad, anachronistic and the story is punching above it's weight.
reviews.content: Acting was incredible by all involved, but the script was very very poorly constructed. There was comedy added clearly for the sake of it, the two characters played by Pat Shortt and John Kenny were purely there for comedic interlude. The Aran island backdrop of Inis mór etc. Which I know very well is the true hero of this film. Cinematography is superb. Some of the dialog was too modern for 1923, weather also was a fluke - it's always windy here. I was disappointed leaving the cinema as had been looking forward to this all year. It left me feeling empty and depressed. It all felt a bit pointless with no actual conclusion.

reviews.review_title: Try not to think of this as a comedy and you'll be fine
reviews.content: I went into this film not knowing anything about it. I didn't know if it was a drama, horror, comedy, or what it was. I simply watched it without mentally preparing for what I was about to see, and in all honestly that's how I think it should be approached, if at all possible.The reason for this is because it's none of those things, and yet all of those things. To have it lean one way or the other to influence the viewer will do them no favours as it doesn't have enough of the elements of any genre to BE that genre.The trailer makes you believe this is a comedy. I disagree. I think this film represents all the good and bad that can happen in regular life. Sometimes life is funny, sometimes it's slow and boring, and sometimes, it's awful. The angles that the situations these characters go through are unique, but still has a message about what life is like, and perhaps a lesson about the right and wrong way to handle things during the times when things don't go your way.One of the most pleasing things about this film as someone who is not from Ireland, is enjoying the scenery of the Aran Islands. Also charming is the time this film is set in, which is in 1923 when people obviously didn't rely on cell phones and gadgets, allowing them to actually see people in person. This enables today's films that are set in the past to allow characters to knock on doors or meet at pubs to have conversations.The character that is not credited in this film, but should be, is that of Friendship, and how important it is in our lives. Friendship can turn bad making things stressful in every way in our lives, but when it's good, it makes everything worth while. One can't help but reflect on their own life while watching the relationship between Padraic and Colm turn bad. It's hard not to think of the friendships we've all held on to but should have either let them go, or think of the people we let go, but should have hung on to.This film stayed with me for the entire evening after watching it, and all the next day, thinking about the simple things that we can all relate to.Perhaps that's making more out of this film than it really is, but then again, maybe that's the whole point.

This was an incredible watch. Martin McDonagh is simply a flawless and highly underrated director and writer. This film definitely proves it. First of all, the shots in this film are simply gorgeous to look at. The Banshees Of Inisherin is one of those films that you can pause at any moment and it looks gorgeously beautiful. The acting from Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson are fantastic through the whole film. But the best performance in my opinion was from Kerry Condon who through the whole film, gave a very realistic performance. The comedy as well was hilarious and the drama very real. Overall this is masterful work and I highly recommend this film. Definitely one of my favorite films.

reviews.review_title: Save yourself some time and skip this
reviews.content: This is a movie literally about men doing anything and everything except go to therapy...and/or talk about their feelings. It's not funny. It's just another movie about men doing violent things for really no good reason and is some sort of micro reflection on macro events at the time. I really do not understand why the positive reviews and attention this film is receiving as I didn't find it as brilliantly written as some other people. In Bruges was much better and at least had some laughs. This movie is pretty depressing and I realize it was supposed to be dark, but there is no balance or anything to offset, so just know what you're signing up for.

reviews.review_title: Another Film About The Auld Country
reviews.content: As another reviewer said - Super locations. Great photography. Masterful Production design. The acting is world class, supreme. So why didn't I enjoy this film? Because it's been done 100 times before.It's just another film made in Ireland about how the Irish are grumpy, fiddle playing, irascible folk with a penchant for abuse and a love of windy cliff tops. When is my country going to make a film that isn't grim and grey and wet, or doesn't reference the famine, the field, the family or The Troubles??!There's SO much to this country, it's colourful, multiracial and diverse, it's fun and interesting and varied, and yet still we get the same old stuff being churned out because it's what's expected of it, it's what Hollywood will stump the money up for. (I saw a trailer for film about "a moving portrayal of Inner City Dublin" (North Circular). But it's another grim partly black and white 95 mins of misery, "uplifting" music, and po-faced stuff that will make the film critics wet themselves with joy. Ireland has other cities.)I give it 4 simply because the film is by no means bad quality in any way. But jaysus begorra and all that, make a normal happy film.

This movie will stand out in the annals of motion ppicture production as possibly the worst movie ever made. When my wife first told me that she was interested in seeing it I was skeptical.
