I had seen the trailers on tv and they seemed to suggest that the plot was about two Irishmen who had a quarrel and wouldn't speak to each other. I thought,"that can't be all there is to this movie. There has to be some clever dialog or something. Right?" Wrong. The dialogue itself is barely discernible through the thick Irish accents. The plot is non-existent.If you would like to have a better time than watching this film, here is a suggestion: 1. Get a gallon of paint and a roller. 2. Roll the paint on the wall. 3. Watch it dry. There. You will have had a better time than watching "Banshees" and you will have accomplished something useful.To be entirely fair, the scenic photography is gorgeous. If that is enough for you, fine. Other than that, "Banshees" begs the question,"Why was this movie made?"Finally, I watched this movie on HBO. If I had had to have paid to see it, I would have asked for my money back.

reviews.review_title: Actors and cinematographers in Ireland in search of the story.
reviews.content: This was an odd type of film that seemed to have a good concept, actors, beautiful setting but not much of a plot. The concept was to make the audience feel the loneliness and isolation of being In a stunning location in the middle of nowhere Ireland forced to be around the same people for better or worse. To that end it was effective but there really wasn't much of a story to go along with it. The film was slow paced but I never really got bored. That being said It felt like the movie was unfinished or the writers just gave up not knowing where to take it and it just ended. It seems to me that the The Banshees of Inisherin is a film that will mostly only be appreciated by Art film connoisseurs.

There is a lot to like about this film. But in the end, it seemed like another Covid period movie. The reason for the sudden shift and strange behavior is never really explained (for me anyway). It makes no sense that a musician (having found that spark late in life), would do something to mess that up. The reason for the change is the thing at risk here (a strange, nonsensical twist). A better reason would have been to get the brother and sister off the island to experience life. Maybe I missed something or just didn't get it. Everything else about the movie was so great. This is one of my favorite directors.

What is it with Hollywood calling something a "dark comedy" with two main characters suffering from psychoses and neuroses. There's nothing remotely humorous in this story. Fitting I suppose in today's Hollywood it has nine Oscar nominations. Besides the superb acting and cinematography of a bleak part of the world, the story has absolutely no redeeming qualities. Who would dream up such a story. And, I would like to have been a fly on the wall to hear the pitch to a studio that greenlighted it. Very slow, difficult to understand the dialogue because of the heavy Irish accent, this is supposed to be some thought-provoking story about rejection and lost friendships. It's simply bizarre and I wish I could hit the erase button in my memory.

I'm not sure what else I can say without going into spoilers other than what I've already said in the title: bored, disgusted and depressed are the three words that best describe how I felt during and after this movie. The subject matter is horrific: abuse, mutilation, death, suicide... I just don't understand how people can "enjoy" a movie like this. To make matters worse, there seems to be no point to the whole thing. The falling out between the friends is supposed to be a metaphor for the Irish civil war (I read this afterwards) but I don't think that is clever enough to justify what I watched. I honestly feel depressed just thinking about the movie, never mind sitting watching it all. I do not recommend this at all. I gave it three stars because the acting is excellent and the shots of Ireland are beautiful, but they are wasted on such a depressing film.

Big lover of In Bruges. Wasn't expecting this to be the same or as good but it was just so slow and pointless really. Some small bits of humour that remind you of the dark comedy that makes you LOL when watching In Bruges but it fizzled out quickly. You don't tend to develop a care for the outcome of the characters either where as again in In Bruges you do care. The acting was good and some of the smaller characters got the best chuckles.I'm annoyed with myself for comparing this to In Bruges as it's clearly not going to be the same but it's the main reason I went and I just found it a tough watch.

I have read many of the 9/10 and 10/10 reviews and have no idea what movie they must have watched. I am at a loss. The great thing about cinema is that it is like art and music. There is no right or wrong review when it comes to how it makes others feel or how they were possibly entertained. My opinion only matters to me and I completely understand this.Iv'e never posted a bad review. I wasn't sure that a movie could have this beautiful of setting, this beautiful of scenery and have all these amazing actors and be this bad but Martin McDonnagh has pulled it off. What an accomplishment. I honestly would have given it zero stars but that wasn't an option. Just unbelievably bad!

Well shot but very depressing to me. My husband & I found very little humor in the movie although lots of folks around us were laughing. Very early on I felt there was a sinister undercurrent and I agree with Colin Farrell's comments in the Trivia section - especially that this is a movie about "the disintegration of joy". I should have trusted my first instinct and not been swayed by a review that praised the visuals and the music. I found the music minimally appealing - and have since read that the director specified no traditional music. Too bad. Can't think of anyone I would recommend this to.

The acting is excellent and the scenery in Ireland is beautiful, but the story is not. I saw the high IMDB ratings like everyone else so I settled in for a nice movie night. The story starts well but quickly goes downhill. By the end you are asking yourself why anyone would like this depressing dark movie.I kept hoping for the story to change course and for the characters to renew their friendship but it kept going further downhill into a horrible depressing film. There were many opportunities to save the movie but they never materialized.By the end of the film I was ready to chop off my own fingers.

reviews.review_title: I can't believe they made this movie
reviews.content:
After I was done watching it I thought who in the world wrote this trash and really wondered why anyone would make a movie out of it.I have to give props to the guy that can cut off his fingers and then wander around without any bandages on his hand. 😳😳
I kept waiting and waiting for this thing to get to it's point but it never did. I guess the point is that songwriters are true to their word. If they tell you something you can take it to the bank.I've enjoyed Colin Farrells work before but this one is a real dog. I'm just glad I didn't pay to see this garbage in a theater.My god what a horrible movie. I'll never get those two hours back.

reviews.review_title: It has its moments but ultimately falls short
reviews.content: Credit where credit is due. The characters in this movie were all brilliant and felt very unique, much like the story which is somewhat unusual.There were plenty of moments that were hilarious, heartwarming and heartbreaking but in the end the film is very much weighed down by the lack of direction and conclusiveness in the story.The directing is superb, dialogue is quick witted and sharp. It nails all the basics but never really takes off.The film came and went. I had a good time but was left feeling a little robbed as if i almost expected too much from it. At the end, i didn't really feel anything when i felt like i should have...

reviews.review_title: A beautifully begun film, ruined by an absurd horror plot
reviews.content: The premise of this film--that a serious fiddler would cut off his own fingers to make an obscure point--is ridiculous. In addition, this plot point places the film in the realm of horror, not comedy. It's a shame. The film is visually beautiful and begins with great dialogue and lovely acting. Surely there was another way to handle the theme of an interrupted friendship than via such pure and awful nonsense. Perhaps this was intended to be an Irish parable. If so, it fails. The backstory of the Irish civil war of the 1920's is gratuitous. The only character worth following is the sister who leaves for the mainland. I wish the film had been center upon her.

Dumb, stupid movie. The acting, cinematography, and flow of the story were outstanding. The introduction of characters, timeframe, and location were easily understood. The comedy was perfectly placed and timed. I believed everything the characters were saying and feeling.The problem was there was no 'why' to the conflict and the resolution was non-existent. This makes for the opposite of entertainment. Usually, it's the entertainment value that keeps the viewers. However in this case, I stayed because I was waiting for the why that never happened. Then, also lacking a conclusion convinced me I was not supposed to like the movie. I think all the people who gave this movie a good review and high stars are the same people who look at splattered paint on a canvas and call it art.

reviews.review_title: Great start. And then it falls apart
reviews.content: At some point in this movie, featuring the life of three village idiots, one idiot says to the other that he is wasting time by uninteresting conversations. In the end, I wondered if the joke was on the audience, wasting time by idiotic movies.It starts out great. Characters have interesting sides to them, which is never really explored. There are funny exchanges on behalf of village idiots anywhere. Colin Farrell has a moment where he can copy Kevin Costner's Dances with wolves, only with a miniature donkey. There is some horror out of nowhere. And then there is... nothing. The actions seemed pointless to me. Which might be how life of village idiots actually are. So maybe I was unreceptive, but it really seemed like a waste in the end.

Absolute classic.Wonderfully darkly comedic, brilliant characters. Fantastic acting, directing, cinematography. The lucky shamrock of Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson and Martin McDonagh. Moments of concentrated silence where viewers, seated in the dark cinema, tried to stifle their tears, and failed, moments after laughter. An island so beautiful that when we left the cinema we immediately wanted to go live there...or maybe visit. And please, please, see it at the cinema.An interesting 20th century time period - I did not know that the Republic of Ireland was still governed by the British then, so I learned something historic on top of learning something about myself.It's an-anti buddy movie of sorts. Why does Colm now hate Padraic? Colm must hate him, because of the extremes he goes too with his fiddling fingers. Literally as I'm writing this, a couple of weeks later, I'm musing on these two former friends, Pad's sister Siobhan and donkey, the pub; Dominic, Pad's young friend, grown up like the psychological version of rickets from the island-isolation from his own age (covid-lockdown, anyone?) cemented in by an abusive father-son relationship which everyone ignores, and his dazzlingly awkward precursive monologue with Siobhan. And island life - the beauty but how beauty is not enough, not even in the sea and the cliffs and the hills. So much but I won't say anymore because, please see it and let it talk to you, quietly.

reviews.review_title: Totally disappointing, don't bother wasting your time
reviews.content: Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson are both good actors and play their parts in this well enough, but really I struggle to see how this actually got made at all it was that bad. I was intrigued enough at the beginning to stick with it, but I wish I just hadn't persevered as it really isn't worth it. The saving grace for me is the fact that this proves that I still have a future in film making. My next project about a kettle boiling and then making a cup of tea so I can watch some paint dry will certainly be more entertaining. I may struggle to find a dog as good an actor as the one in this film, but then again perhaps a cardboard cut out will do. The Banshees of Inisherin is not a film to cheer you up, and for me it shouldn't even be classed as entertainment.

I definitely went into this expecting more of a comedic tone given the premise and previous McDonagh-Farrell-Gleeson team up. While there are an abundance of hearty laughs throughout this Irish tale, the story has a number of exceedingly dark elements that all coalesce into a bit of a downer ending. Without going into too much detail, this story doesn't have a nice, happy bow tied on it by the finale, instead more of a black cloud lingering above that manages to let in a few streaks of light.Sporting perhaps the best group of performances of the year, Banshees carries some heavyweight awards contenders. The highlight for me would be Keoghan's rather difficult role played to perfection. Farrell and Gleason are the consummate sparring partners and Condon brings some wild, yet sensitive energy to the film. The vistas are simply gorgeous and Burwell's atmospheric score hangs over the film like a hazy fog.McDonagh has crafted another richly compelling film that challenges viewers, yet serves as a rewarding watch for those looking for something different.

reviews.review_title: So dreary, boring and disgusting that I kept skipping ahead
reviews.content: The actors did a great job but the characters they depicted were dull and boring. The first 30 minutes I tolerated -- as setting up the overall context but then it became clearer and clearer that this was going to be a one-note movie (reaction to rejection of friendship). The pace was sooo very slow throughout that I kept skipping ahead. I also kept skipping over the gratuitous and pointless mutilations (which were also unnatural because the victim/perpetrator apparently felt no pain).You have to be a real glutton for punishment in the area of dark comedy to enjoy this movie. Once I find myself skipping ahead more and more then I can't give it a higher review than 3 stars, in spite of the fact that the acting was excellent.

What the hell did I just watch!!! Mislead by the ratings and reviews. I was expecting something like In Bruge but such a disappointment in the end. The story just didn't make sense at all. I really wanted to like it. Alas!The acting is phenomenal by Collin Ferral, but that's all about it. If you like to watch beauty of Ireland, go for it. I wouldn't recommend it at all.There is no resolution in the end too. You just keep wondering about the choices you make in life like watching a movie based on the ratings. May be it has a deep meaning which could be there are things in life that don't make sense and you can't do anything about it!

I tried to watch this about a month ago. I had to turn it off after Colm made his horrible threat. His and Padraic's behavior is inexplicable. I don't need to spend two hours of my life watching them act out their psychotic depression. Now because I'm trying to catch up on Oscars nominees, I made it to the end of the movie, doing some fast forwarding through the long scenes of people staring morosely out to sea or trudging along stony paths.I didn't see any humor in this at all, it is certainly not a dark comedy in my view...it is just very dark. Is part of the theme of the movie that men are inherently depressed, self absorbed, and self destructive? The one major woman character is the only one who has the insight and motivation to change anything for the better and to extend sympathy to anyone. (I do think Dominic cares for others but he is fatally damaged by his father's cruelty and his attempts to connect aren't successful.)The best part of the movie is the scene where Siobhan leaves. That was virtually the only enjoyable thing in the movie to me. Then her brother can't even understand her letter really, won't even consider visiting her.My takeaways from this movie: I will seek out movies/series that Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan are in; their characters seemed more alive than any others. And I need to rewatch In Bruges, which I recall as a great dark comedy.

reviews.review_title: An odd drama with a constant undercurrent of comedy
reviews.content: The trailer for The Banshees of Inisherin immediately intrigued me. And as this movie began, I was quickly enthralled with the look and the characters. This is an odd drama with an undercurrent of comedy. It's a unique mix. It was good to see Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson back together, since I really enjoyed them as a duo in In Bruges. And I thought Kerry Condon did a fantastic job in her role, as well. However, this film digs a hole of intrigue so deep that it's unable to find a way out, so it just kind of ends. I was wanting a little more resolution, and so it left me feeling somewhat unsatisfied.

I remember watching In Bruges and thinking to myself that it could have been a masterpiece if only it didn't go overboard and changed the mood of the movie toward the end. With The Banshees of Inisherin happened the exact same thing. To be fair, Martin' Three Buildings suffered also from the great deal of depressive atmosphere and unlikable characters, so I'm guessing this is just his style - he tells the stories of people frozen in time, without a past, without a future, just lucky to be alive at that moment when we're watching the movie.Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson are fantastic together and their duo's chemistry is palpable throughout the movie, even when their characters aren't speaking to each other but I once again found myself caught between trying to feel their entities and empathize with them and trying harder to find a real purpose of this whole thing as a body of work. The depression and hopelessness fills every corner of the screen and no breathtaking landscapes of Ireland, no occasional jokes (although very witty at times), no eloquent pieces of dialogue and no great acting couldn't let this movie to stay in my heart for a longer time than I was hoping for.Martin McDonagh goes over the top again and expresses a quarrel between friends as something surreal and hard to comprehend. Naturally people drift apart as life goes on, sometimes it even happens in a blink of an eye when one day everything's fine and the next you don't want to see or hear this person ever again but what could've been the best portrayal of human relations turned out to be an exaggerated, bizarre, overbloated (but not in the runtime - two hours go by pretty fast, I have to admit) and not too pleasant experience of a movie that's still better than 99% of all of the movies of nowadays.The banshees of Inisherin is a unique blend of tragedy - when you see people bored to death with their day to day life and how weird they manage it - drama - when those same people try and fail to communicate with each other - and comedy - when you hear what they have to say to each other when they try, - and any other actor or director attached to the project could've ruined it within minutes but Martin, along with Colin and Brendan, make you stay until the end without really trying.

I've just seen this film, and I'm completely puzzled why it is highly regarded. I found it excruciatingly slow, often boring, not very funny, and I struggle to see the point of it. I expected it to be very funny, but all the funny lines had already been revealed in the trailer. I'm not knocking the acting, and the scenery was amazing, and perhaps it wanted to make points about "art" and remote communities and communication, but it was like one of those films that was originally a play, and shows it.I didn't feel that there was any satisfactory resolution and the audience is just left hanging with an uncomfortable feeling of disquiet.It would have been better had I not been told beforehand that it was a comedy, because it's not. Mutilation and death, loneliness and isolation can be funny, but not in this film.

A couple of funny moments and pretty backdrops are the only positive things I can say about this movie. Boring plot. Boring symbolism. Altogether blah.For all the hype, I really wanted to like it. I feel like this is the kind of thing a first year English Major would find entertaining while they learn about allegory. Tolkien was spot on in despising this sort of drivel.I really wish I could have my two hours back. I logged in here and left this review for the first time because I felt the need to share this, even if I'm the lone voice of criticism. My only solace is that maybe this review will save someone else some time.

reviews.review_title: A game of two halves. Miss the second.
reviews.content: The first half of the film was a touching and funny story of two long t term friends where one decides he does not want to continue the friendship. The scenery is excellent and all the acting great. Especially surprising is Siobhon as the sister, previously seen as Stacey Ermantraut in Better Call Saul.There is some real humour in small island life. Some shades of Craggy Island. Although set in 1923 the location gave no sense of era and something the film was an easy fit for viewers.Around the middle it starts to get darker as Bredon Gleeson's character takes some rather bizarre steps to discourage his erstwhile friend. From there I felt the film went downhill fast. There was not only the no logic but some incidental tradgedies that just became a millstone around the audience's neck. The ending was not really an ending. Just a drift off.In short, enjoy the first half then switch off.

In playwright Martin McDonagh's new film the context defines the plot. A few scenes of remote gunfire connote the Irish Civil War in 1923. The Western island setting is remote from the war, with only that occasional aural connection. Yet the village drama is a miniature of the civil strife that erupted after Ireland won its independence. The mainland war replays here as a conflict between two friends.The folk musician Colm is suffering from despair. Sensing his imminent mortality he composes a folk tune to provide some afterlife. Exposing that futility, the song's (as the film's) title just sounds good. It has no reality. There are no banshees there.More damaging is Colm's other resolve. To cease wasting time on his longtime close friend Padraic, who is a standard dumb bloke. But as Padraic's bookish sister Siobhan reminds Colm, all the men on that remote isolated crag are dumb - or they would long since have left. As she eventually does.Like the civil war, indeed like most wars, that small difference swells into a tangle of destruction, both mutual and self. When Padraic refuses his old friend's insistence upon being left alone, Colm chops off one of his own fingers for each day of offence. He is quickly reduced to one fingerless hand. That ends his fiddling pleasure, leaving him to stab his fiddle into the air in mute musicianship. Once he is unable to play his tune it won't outlive him.When Padriac's donkey Minnie (persuasively performed by Minnie) fatally chokes on some fingers, his injured innocence turns mortal. Rejecting Colm's apology and offer of peace, he burns his former friend's home to the ground. Even then he refuses to make peace. They won't be "quits" until Colm dies. "Some things there's no moving on from. And I think that's a good thing." On such stubborn squabbles are most wars waged.The apparently homey little community is rife with aggression. Humorously, Colm disdains of the law: "If punching a policeman is a sin then we may as well pack up and go home." The priest who hears his confession himself erupts into indignant violent profanity. In another family, the father mercilessly beats his wife and son, who drowns himself when Siobhan confirms his expectation that she would never fall in love with the young boy.At the end Padraic, having supposedly won his satisfaction, is left alone. His sister gone, he brings his cows and horse into his house. This is his finally stable relationship. Colm is left with far more isolation than he requested. Indeed the entire community is left - as Colm admits to and suspects Siobhan of sharing - just "entertaining myself while staving off the inevitable."
There is a true serenity and beauty in the island's bleak landscape. And even in this doomed community, a warmth and pathos emerge from the small, tense lives of paralysis and despair.And note this: if a calendar turning up April Fool's Day did not establish the 1923 setting there is nothing in this film's setting, speech and themes that could not represent today. If we don't see ourselves there we're the April Fool.

reviews.review_title: Feels like a classic from 100 years ago
reviews.content: If they're still showing films to kids in high school classes in like 30 years, this is totally one of those movies they should show.This is one you could watch with your grandma and there's a good chance you'd both enjoy it equally.This takes place 100 years ago on the nose. It really puts into perspective how much has changed since then.It's a simple story that is so tightly knit, it feels like a classic fable. Its structure is immaculate and the performances are fantastic - Colin Farrell and Barry Keoghan shine especially bright. The Irish landscapes are beautiful. The whole movie blossoms slowly and seamlessly but it's never dull, and it's very slyly funny. This is a great movie in a very traditional sense. Honestly I hope it wins some Oscars. The year in film needed this.

reviews.review_title: Boring cliché and yet another caricature of Ireland
reviews.content: Have to be honest I found this completely empty and very overrated.Perhaps there is some meaning or substance but it was lost on me and marred by the abysmal script and wildly inconsistent accents. As someone from the west of Ireland it was impossible to see past the poorly approximated Western Irish dialect, which for the most part was butchered by actors who have posh Dublin accents in real life. The fact that we are so misrepresented by our fellow countrymen is disappointing. The most believable performances are by Pat Short and John Kenny who are unfortunately relegated to bit parts with very few lines. Barry Keoghan is the worst of a bad lot, he seems to have a different accent for every word.Again, as someone who comes from the west of Ireland I am very well acquainted with the inherent comedy and humour in our dialect of English, all of which was absent in this films script, the writers instead opted for a kind of hybrid of Americanisms, leprechauns and pirates. None of the idiosyncratic slang or sayings which I heard growing up were used. I was sincerely disappointed to see yet another film that portrays western Irish people as nothing more than bumpkins and simpletons, driving the few marginally intelligent people in their community to desperation and melancholy. Dismal film but 2 stars for the scenery and Brenden Gleesons performance.

reviews.review_title: Great performances - not sure about the final act
reviews.content: This was a really well acted movie. Colin Farrell in particular is tremendous as a guy whose best friend ghosts him and he goes through all of these emotional highs and lows to process the grief and to try and get his friend to come back to him. The scenery and BG are all really moody and atmospheric. The setting of the film in many ways is the star of the film itself. I don't think the film was long enough for all of the characters it established and I would have liked to have seen another half hour or forty minutes or so to really know more about some of the sub-plots. Also, I was not crazy about the end. A little anticlimactic. The film is worth it for Colin Farrell's work and the cinematography.

reviews.review_title: Most over-rated movie of the year
reviews.content: Dumb screenwriting. Great acting. Dumb screenwriting. Great Cinematography. Dumb screenwriting. Great music. Dumb screenwriting. Beautiful locations. Dumb screenwriting. Great costumes. Dumb screenwriting. Great sets. Dumb screenwriting, great sound. Dumb screenwriting. Great production value. Conflict with absolutely no context doesn't work, even if you're trying to make a dark, absurdist comedy. Maybe especially if you're trying to make a dark, absurdist comedy. Sure, some people are going to decide that it felt deep so there must be something there beyond a character saying "what do I have to do to get you to leave me alone?" But really there's just not.

First half is absolutely brilliant black comedy that is, in my opinion, the equal of Mamet or Chekhov as writer/director Martin McDonough cleverly and skillfully "hooks" the viewer by presenting a situation with which we are all familiar but which has not been dramatized all that frequently, namely the precipitate dropping of a friendship, with its concomitant puzzlement, pain, and loss. And the film gains in poignance and interest by being presented through dialogue that is as mordantly funny as it is insightful and a setting that is as starkly beautiful as it is isolated and lonely.Then Colm cuts off his finger and the film takes a lurch from the light/dark to the dark/darker as heavy handed allegory takes over from realism and the film becomes less and less compelling and more and more histrionic. That it survives and still packs an emotional punch by the end is mostly due to the three magnificent performances of Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson and Kerry Condon rather than to McDonough. Give it a B.

Other than the Miniature Donkey Jenny, I couldn't get attached to any of the characters or plotlines.This is the most pointless, depressing movie I have seen in a long time.Portray Irish people as dumb - check
Portray Irish people as drunks - checkKick-off potentially interesting plotlines but do nothing with them - check.There is nothing more I can add to this review except filler to hit the required number of characters for a review.The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog
The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog
The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog
The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog.

Male solitude has been a serious social issue in rural Ireland (where I lived most of my life) and in France (where I now live). I have visited farmhouses where the lone farmer had hanged himself, leaving a cow to die and mummify in the barn. This film trivialises that sad situation.With pretensions of Greek tragedy (think Medea) this film is an embarrassment of fakery. Set in the Aran Islands in 1922, twelve years before Robert Flaherty's famous 'Man of Aran', it is a mishmash of inauthenticity and pointless horror. The script is simply unbelievable, the dialogue completely inauthentic and the indoor décors are about 50 years later than the Irish Civil War, gratuitously referred to. Being a rural Irishman myself, in the 1970s I visited people whose 'humble, thatched dwellings would have been much the same as those in the Aran Islands in the 1920s - apart from the wonderful novelty of bottled gas. I visited people whose sole means of cooking was an open fire, with kettle, griddle and hanging pot - and a collie nearby.When I was a child in the 1940s, it was quite common for chickens (another essential to life) to be in kitchens, but the makers of the movie obviously thought that a pony and an ass would be more of a laugh.'Black comedy' it is not. If it is a satire, it is of the crudest and most pointless kind. Allegory ? If so, impenetrable.Being filmed mostly on the Aran Islands, the 'scenic' shots and backgrounds are wonderful. They would have needed to be in thick fog not to be!Most of Ireland was in the grip of extremely pious Catholicism at the time, so the confessional scenes are simply grotesque. The swearing is not only inauthentic but in-your-face gratuitous. Nobody could have said 'It takes two to tango' on the Aran islands. 'Anyways' is a modern Americanism. No island policeman would have behaved in the way portrayed here; he would have been found drowned had he done so. And that's another huge flaw: there is no mention of the actual and crucial livelihood of fishing, upon which everyone on Irish islands depended. Did no-one associated with this film read the detailed books about precarious life on the Blasket Islands by Maurice O'Sullivan, Peig Sayers and Tomás Ó Criomhthain ?I don't know why excellent actor Brendan Gleeson agreed to take part.The clothing is wrong. The bar very wrong ('whiskey' spelled 'whisky' !). (It is only recently as a result of Anglo-American cultural pressure that Irish bars have started calling themselves 'pubs'.) It was interesting that a postbox changed colour from bright British red to Free-State green during the action. The cottage interiors are far too luxurious. All the décors (and the actors) are far too clean. Most furniture would have been home-made, except of course in the priest's house. The character of the priest is simply a ridiculous New York caricature. As the title warns us, the whole gom film is a cheap burlesque with a good dose of ludicrous horror to increase the takings.

What's the point..? That there is not enough sadness and misery in the world and that violence is the only option..? Thought we got enough of that from Greenblat or Tarrentino.. 🙄 I would gladly leave it here, but more letters are required because like Hollywood more content means more filler in between runs to the bank.. If I didn't know better I'd say this was a laundering situation, but alas I think it's just a sad, boring bit of drivel that serves no good value other then self inflation of ego.. How many slice of life movies do we need..? Where's the storytelling..? Where's the growth of consciousness and evolution of character..? I suppose one could look at it as a reflection of the decline of society, but again, why..? Been there, seen that.. Can't believe this guy got an Oscar nomination over Cameron who offers us something colorful, creative and positive.. This seeping sadness and depressing dark ooze of self indulgence serves only as a paycheck and temporary distraction for some Irish folk too encumbered in their misery to find any light in their imperial drudgery.. I gave it 5 stars because the acting was of course good, the set was fine and outside of the writing and directing it had great potential.. Would easily make my list of top ten worst "well made" movies all time, and I've seen thousands..

You try it. Some of us have personal experience. Are you cruel and mean in using this as a comic foil? Must be.This is not a dark comedy, it is just depressing and sad. There must have been a lot of joy on that island 100 years ago, but all this movie shows is lonely, dead end lives. It also has animal cruelty. So I am just stunned that this has anyone wanting to watch this, let alone nominate it for awards. We have spent three years with covid, gee, let's give people depressing a movie with no reason to appreciate the people or the landscape. Give us clever, thoughtful, meaningful - that is what we want.

Sometimes the simplest of films can become one of the best of its consecutive year, or even an already great filmmaker's finest work. Martin McDonagh is one of my favourite working directors today. Whether you're talking about his excellent and hilarious debut with In Bruges back in 2008, or his award-worthy Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri in 2017, he is a filmmaker that hasn't made a single film that wasn't at least very, very good, at least to me. The Banshees of Inisherin marks his latest directorial effort and arguably his best. It's been a while since I went to the theatre and felt the filmmaking just leaping off the screen, but this one did that for me.The Banshees of Inisherin follows Pádraic (Colin Farrell) as he lives a straightforward life on a small island in Ireland called Inisherin. Drinking at the local pub on a daily basis and only having one lifelong friend in Colm (Brendan Gleeson), he quickly learns that Colm no longer wishes to be his friend. Colm has his reasons, but they really don't make any logical sense, thus sparking Pádraic's confusion and curiosity. Colm's one request is that Pádraic just stop talking to him altogether, otherwise he is threatening to harm himself. That's it, that's the only story to this film, other than the very incredible dialogue that makes it all worth it.This film is a masterwork in how well a movie can work if you have great characters. Pádraic and Colm are both very well written and Farrell and Gleeson both give arguably their best performances here. They both had me laughing hysterically and feeling awful at the same time. There were multiple occasions where the film was too funny to not laugh, but the subject matter was very dark, so I felt bad for doing so, and that to me was the brilliance of this film. The dialogue was the driving force here and that aspect was perfection to me.Martin McDonagh also wrote the screenplay for this film, which really makes me believe he won't ever make a bad movie. He has a knack for writing some of the most clever dialogue out there and his work throughout the years only seems to improve. He can also work exceptionally well with actors, which is why a film like this turns out so well with him behind the wheel. Everything from the camerawork to the subtle score, The Banshees of Inisherin, although dark and funny, is a masterwork of filmmaking, especially when it's such a simple premise. This is also a much darker film than any of his previous work, but that made the final act feel authentic to this story. I really don't have anything to complain about here.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant acting, gorgeous scenery, gothic horror
reviews.content: Someday someone will make a movie with fantastic actors speaking believable dialogue against a backdrop of scenic beauty and historical relevance, addressing the issues of loneliness and severe depression. This is not that movie. Is it a dark comedy? To a point. Then it takes a quick turn into horror, which I realize is all the rage. There are moments of insight, especially with the priest in the confessional, which reinforces the notion that the Church is clueless as to how to help its mentally unstable parishioners. The theme I took: a seriously suicidal older man wreaks havoc on a younger man's live, resulting in both of them being deranged. And the sister would abandon her brother without inviting him along? Impossible. That's when the script failed for me. Granted, the actors are fantastic. The setting gorgeous, but we don't get glimpses of the grinding poverty which was no doubt evident. It's not realistic that the villagers would let an old man walk around with a bloody stump without attempting to bandage it.

I guess this movie is an allegory of something. Despair, perhaps. The plight of the Irish, more likely. Really, what this movie is about is what happens when there is a world where only despair, lack of hope, and lack of Faith in God is apparent. Colin F was AWESOME! When some guy says he will cut his fingers off because his buddy is buggin him the buddy should listen. Colin F got his start in a movie called Tiger Land, a must see flick of epic proportion. Banshees is Colin F's best performance since phone booth. When your 2nd best friend kills your best friend with his fat fingers one should flee to the mainland. Or at least burn his house down. But of course, this movie pales in relations with Megan.

reviews.review_title: It would be funnier pulling your pubic hair out one by one
reviews.content: My wife and I sat down to watch this movie thinking as it has been nominated for awards it must be wort a watch,how wring could we be, I've given up but my wife is going to see it through to the end.What a miserable depressing waste of time , both actors are better than this rubbish warped script , what a fevered mind could conceive a plot line where one friend stops speaking to another for no apparent reason and proceeds to cut of his fingers if he kept on talking to him ,sick isn't the word , described as a comedy only someone very twisted would laugh at this travesty. Did I like it that would be a no from me.

I do not mind being the odd one out here, as it looks like this is being hailed as an artistic gem.From my vantage point this is a vacuous and pretentious film from a director who appears to be resting on his laurels. Hopefully he will not become the Salvador Dali of modern movie-making.The story? Well, a man tells another man he does not like him any more, and that man tries to get him to change his mind. That's it. Now, if you wander through the Guggenheim with the intention of finding art in everything you see, you will find lots of art. If you wander through this movie with the intention of finding art in everything you see you will find lots of art.There is also a negativity about humanity which says more about the director/writer than about the human condition.Perhaps it works as a black comedy. You wish.

Overall, this was a very well-made movie with fantastic acting and cinematrography. I expected it to be weird with dry humor, which it certainly delivered on in the first half. However, the second half was actually quite depressing and at times very difficult to watch. It certainly didn't take the direction I was expecting; not necessarily a bad thing, but I felt caught off guard based on how this movie was advertised. Definitely left the theater in a bit of a melancholy mood, leaving a bit of a bad taste in my mouth. I think it just helps having a better idea on what to expect, as at the end of the day it is not, primarily, a humorous movie.

reviews.review_title: Not quite sure what I just watched
reviews.content: This going to take me a while to digest this movie.If you think this is a surface story type film you are very much mistaken. Everything in 'Banshees' is allegory and metaphor.Sure, the two male leads suddenly decide to stop talking to each other for no reason and the questions, recriminations, violence and escalation begin. Clearly the metaphor here is the Irish Civil War that can occasionally be heard on the mainland.There is smattering of comedy And some religious symbolism with the scene stealing donkey. But the the thing that rescues the whole film is the actual craft of filmmaking. The direction is great, as is the cinematography, but the you must watch Banshees for the acting. All four of the leads are fantastic.You may have to watch this twice to appreciate fully.

Sad and not redeeming whatsoever. Nice photography at least. I think they they were going for highlighting the complexity of friendships and depression. However they missed the mark completely. Not at all insightful into either. The fingers were weird and unnecessarily grotesque. It seems that films such as this are representational without a genuine narrative. I ask myself why this would receive such high ratings. It seems a tired and worn out Irish ballad from the shallow perspective of one who thinks its cool and atmospheric. The main character is well acted with a poor script. You cant help rooting for him though you know he is doomed for heartache.

Why do the critics love this movie? Why it is oscar nominated and WHY does the characters in this movie act as they do? It has nice pictures, very good actors but the story is so incomprehensible. It is not funny, it is not thrilling.If you want to watch a movie that makes any sense, don't watch this one.And at the end, when I thought that there would have been the final escalation, there was ... nothing."In Bruges" was good. This one is not. What is the message of this film? That we should not live on a small boring islands, because we could get stupid and crazy?Oh I know the message: if you suffer by depression get to see a doctor and don't cut of your fingers.

Dark and Troubling; this movie exemplifies mental disease and what a solitary existence can create in a closed society! I struggled through every scene, and the insanity that ensued between the residents on this island was horrifying. Every character had some kind of mental or emotional issue and the twisted nature between them all produced a dysfunctional existence on this bored community. To say the place was creepy and the isolation and rejection was so unhealthy and left me wondering what possessed anyone to film this kind of story!How it garnered ANY Oscar nominations is also beyond comprehension! 😱🤢

reviews.review_title: Most depressing movie I've ever seen
reviews.content: SPOILERSIf you've ever loved an animal, or a friend, or been abused, or wanted to end your life but couldn't do it yourself...don't watch this movie. Performances are good, scenery is beautiful but I really don't get it - a man wants to force his friend into action he can't take himself? Another man is punished for wanting a simple happy life? I really don't understand it. Everyone is miserable and ok being miserable except for the people willing to go to extremes or escape? I mean this place is so bad that someone packs every item they own in a moments notice and just goes? She's the only person in this whole movie taking care of her own sanity. If I think about this movie on too deep a level, I might not get out of bed for a few days.

reviews.review_title: Very well crafted film, amazing acting, about a village in the middle of nowhere
reviews.content: I have to agree with most people that this movie was great. The plot is simple: one taciturn guy in a remote Irish village decides to not accept any contact with his best and oldest friend, with no explanation whatsoever, and the friend can't accept it. It is a deeply sad story, dealing with personal identity, despair, codependence, love - unrequited or otherwise.Like with "In Bruges" before, the triangle of Martin McDonagh, Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson works perfectly. And it feels kind of similar too: deep scenes about people, but not much story. The movie feels like a landscape painting where you admire the care and detail on it, but you don't really care what it is about. And it is about a village in the middle of nowhere, after all.Bottom line: the best film I've seen in quite a while, but it doesn't cover all bases. Nor should it. It's like "In Bruges" had a child with "The Lighthouse". If you liked either of them or both, you will like The Banshees of Inisherin.

This movie was boring and then became disgusting. I can't get over it. I recommend to anyone wishing to absolutely ruin their night, because it totally ruined mine. The fact that this is nominated for an oscar is beyond me. I just can't. I love movies and this might be my least favorite. Ever. Don't waste your time. I came into this without knowing anything other than it's irish and honestly that all you need to know. Now that you've read that you don't have to watch it. You're so so welcome I just saved your evening and possibly the rest of the week you'd have to spend think about how this could possibly impress anyone let alone film critics. If anyone says this is their favorite movie in the future I'll make sure to avoid them, because how.

It's hard to choose any single part of this movie that i like the most but it is a beautifully woven story that is masterfully executed at every level. It is austere and sumptuous, simple and complex, calm and violent, so beautiful and yet bloody, a study in choices and a portrait of inexorable will.The dialogue is exquisite and ripe but never pretentious. Each character is genuine and real in who they are. The existential themes give this MasterClass of filmmaking a timelessness that's is wonderfully reinforced by the spectacular cinematography. Yet there's such a sense of isolation that one almost could image that all the characters are just facets of a single person.It is a brilliant piece of movie making.

Executive Summary: There are two drinking buddies. One decides the other is boring and he doesn't want to be friends anymore. The jilted friend (Colin Farrell) can't accept this. However, to demonstrate his resolve, the aggressor friend (a violinist) cuts off his fingers from his left hand & throws them at jilted friend's house. The jilted friend's favorite pet (a donkey) chokes on the severed fingers and dies. Also the jilted friend's sister leaves him and his only other friend (the village idiot) drowns. Jilted friend burns down aggressor friend's house and he declares war has just begun. The End.Pros: cinematography. Cons: plot (or lack thereof)

The type of movie that doesn't blow your mind or anything of the sort, but it deeply affects you in its themes and in its perfect execution. Here we explore the fear of loneliness. Something we all fear, but something we all eventually have to experience. Everything flows so naturally in this film, the jokes are well executed and balanced. The movie doesn't try to make you cry or make you feel sorry for someone.Synopsis:
Set on a remote island off the west coast of Ireland, THE BANSHEES OF INISHERIN follows lifelong friends Pádraic and Colm, who find themselves at an impasse when Colm unexpectedly puts an end to their friendship. A stunned Pádraic, aided by his sister Siobhán and troubled young islander Dominic, endeavours to repair the relationship, refusing to take no for an answer. But Pádraic's repeated efforts only strengthen his former friend's resolve and when Colm delivers a desperate ultimatum, events swiftly escalate, with shocking consequences.

There is absolutely NOTHING funny about this comedy. Not a single thing.It was actually quite depressing. I am not sure why anyone would think anything about this movie would be funny and call it a comedy.This movie was Dark sad and depressing and weird. If you are looking for a comedy to make you laugh. This is definitely not the movie for you.I watched the entire movie, hoping that I would at least understand what was happening and I just got more confused the more i watched.My husband usually enjoys movies like this and even he thought that this movie was weird.This is 2 hours of my life that I will never get back.

reviews.review_title: Beware: Nothing like In Bruges. Not fun.
reviews.content: This film was not for me and will not be for most movie patrons. I am a big a fan of In Bruges and the guys in general so I was excited to head to the theater for this one. No laughs, no plot, really no fun at all. I wanted to leave early, but I really thought it would turn around. Sadly, did not. I am giving this four stars because the scenery was nice. The shots of cliffs, water, and fields were very cool. Man, I was really rooting for this one to be a hit. My Girlfriend and I left feeling pretty down about the experience. I'd highly recommend skipping this one. I guess I will have to settle for an In Bruges rewatch.

reviews.review_title: Ok I didn't get it, but at least I finished it?
reviews.content: Gosh, someone please tell me what 'The Banshees of Inisherin' is trying to tell? Right after movie, right at this moment I'm writing the review, I'm feeling confused, eerie, and shocked at how many other people look at this film differently. Oscar nomination... Seriously??? I'm really appalled how critics move further away from general public every year. Why does Dominic have to die? Why doesn't Padraic leave the island when he's so bitter? What's up with cutting fingers? So many questions are unanswered because the movie does not give enough justification for characters' behaviour.I guess McDonagh tries to talk about dullness and loneliness of life in Inisherin, but the whole film does not have to be that dull and to leave me lonely and incompetent as heck because I just don't get Oscar nominated movie.

reviews.review_title: Cerebral, gorgeous essay that suggests that EVERY man is, in fact, an island.
reviews.content: If you're looking for a film that's long on action and/or story, skip this, neither of those attributes are to be found.Rather, this is an unusually thoughtful and original examination on the enormous challenges humans face in connecting with others and/or maintaining those connections. Among other issues, the viewer is asked to think about:. What loyalty do we owe a friend who has since become tiresome?. How is it that seemingly unbreakable bonds become broken?. What does it say about people that we often prefer the company of animals versus other humans to avoid the demands imposed by relationships?. Why do we sometimes deliberately "cut ourselves off" to avoid others?. How is it that one's craft/hobby, e.g.- music, art, etc., can provide more companionship than spending time with other people?If these concepts are of interest, you will find them examined and portrayed with magnificent skill in this film. The cinematography takes full advantage of the breathtaking Irish landscape, and it is no accident that the story unfolds on an island off the Ireland mainland; this is consistent with the overall premise that we are all, ultimately, islands unto ourselves, with a gulf between us and the rest of humanity that is often deeply difficult to cross.A final note: while the themes examined here are arguably timeless, the film feels especially relevant today as the current cultural warfare and political environment has resulted in the shattering of many friendships.

I can't believe the hype for this movie. I was a big fan of In Bruges, back in 2008. This, however, is an illogical, scattershot mess, without even a proper ending to the increasing violence experienced as the film plays out. It begins well, with one drinking buddy deciding he's had enough of the other "dull" drinking buddy. But then drinking buddy #1 decides to cut off fingers if drinking buddy #2 keeps reaching out to him? Notwithstanding the fact that #1 is a fiddle player, and his goal in the movie is to secure his immortality by writing a song? And what the heck is going on with the miniature donkey, the weird gut with a crush on #2's sister, and the old lady that keeps showing up? What a waste.

My issue with this film is simply this: you've used all this money and time and energy, used up some top-notch acting, to tell us what? That in midst of this beautiful earth, our petty human grudges devolve into tragedy which always seems to most affect the innocent?At least here in the US, we've seen this play out day by day, hour by hour, for the past seven years. Personal grudges have infected our collective psyche and hurt millions of people in tragic ways, and I, for one, am sick of it.Please - use your talents and your access to such a powerful medium to offer us some hint of how to right ourselves. Even if it's a vague gesture that expiation lies, possibly, in that direction - it's better than being told, over and over, that we're in a dire situation with no one to blame but ourselves. We know we're lost - we are painfully aware. Either give us a nudge toward redemption, or give us the silence which Colm asks for so plaintively, so we can scratch it out ourselves.Gorgeous film, fabulous acting, left the theater thinking, "Yeah? And?"

reviews.review_title: Grim, depressing, pointless waste of talent and idea
reviews.content: Started out great, gritty and funny.Quickly descended into a depressing directionless and miserable mess.Violent and with no resolution whatsoever. The story falls away. Rushed and ultimately worthless as a movie.The hype surrounding this was totally unjustified and actually all you are left with is a feeling of Irish stereotypes and tropes of brutality and stupidity set in a picturesque timeless background.As stated above this started out well, it was funny, Colin was on top form and the role of the sister seemed to be going somewhere..and then...nothing.Just violence and no sense that the writer/director had any idea how to end it.

The acting is ok but the story is awful. Why do I want to watch self maiming?!? Certainly not worthy of any awards, unless the donkey could get one. As a story of friendship, it is an interesting idea, but the development is lousy. Good writers could make this a very powerful story of friendship lost but the characters are not well developed. Side stories of the Irish troubles and police brutality could be developed, but they are only teased. If the Irish Troubles (which is only hearing gunfire in the distance) we're left out, the story would be unchanged. Don't pay money for this, and think hard about watching it when it's free from a streaming service.

reviews.review_title: Fantastically Acted and Surprisingly Funny but Holy Tonal Shift Batman!
reviews.content: I'm going to offer Banshees a backhanded compliment in that they setup a premise and what follows isn't very densely plotted. There are two men on the island of Inisherin in 1923. They were good friends before (or "seemingly" good friends) but one day Colm decides he's had enough of Padraic's boorish behaviour and tells him that he doesn't like him anymore and they are no longer friends. Padraic is flummoxed by this and can't accept that his best friend won't socialize with him anymore. The situation devolves from there. If you add in his smart but lonely sister Siobhan and the nice but troublesome Dominic, that's almost the whole story. But while Banshees doesn't lean on its plot, what it does choose to focus on is the bizarre situation and the eccentric characters that populate the island. Padraic and Colm are complex and interesting even though we know so little about them and I thought the movie did a wonderful job of showing how awkward adult friendships are. This focal point just adds to the subtle but effective dark comedy that is peppered throughout the movie. Other than the villainous policeman, almost every character is engaging on some level and it's a credit to McDonagh as a writer/director for getting so much out of so little.Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson have already paired up for McDonagh's In Bruges and they were a stellar duo in that (I didn't love the movie overall but they're undeniably great together). They're both marvelous in this, I have to credit Farrell first. This character is such a departure from his handsome action-hero persona (it's been a good year for him between this and the Batman). He's an amazing character actor when given the right material and there's a lot of depth and subtlety to his portrayal of Padraic. He elicits so much sympathy for his sweet twit of a character who can't understand why his best friend won't talk to him. Brendan Gleeson is also great as Colm, his character is much more in his wheelhouse. Gleeson is one of the best at playing likeable smarmy jerks and while his character is hard to understand, Gleeson's charm keeps you from completely turning on Colm. His quiet anger is palpable and his madness is puzzling but Gleeson helps the movie make you want to see where this goes next. Many reviewers have justifiably pointed out Barry Keoghan's fantastic work as the quietly sarcastic but sympathetic Dominic. His work in Banshees should garner awards consideration but my favourite supporting performance came from Kerry Condon's work as Padraic's savvy and kind sister Siobhan. Her frustration with Padraic's behaviour is completely relatable and so is her continued befuddlement. Her exasperated scolding of her brother helps contextualize how ridiculous Padraic and Colm's rowing is and she seems like the only normal person in the cast of characters.The Banshees of Inisherin would be classified as a dark comedy first and foremost and through most of the movie, I laughed a lot. The jokes are dropped in a very silent and understated manner but they're simply hilarious. The dialogue is tightly written and the actors deliver exquisitely. At the 3/4 point of the movie though, the story and tone shift considerably however. I still liked the direction it went and I got what the movie was trying to say (it's a metaphor for the Irish Civil War) but it just wasn't as affecting for me as it was for other viewers. It punctuated how dark the escalation of the conflict was and who it affected but I preferred the comedy. The ending tries to leave it open ended and that also was a mixed bag. These changes made the movie feel more like an art-house picture and more geared towards a specific audience. This is all well and fine as it was clearly intended but I wasn't as keen on it as critics were. This shift in the narrative took the movie down a notch for me.I haven't even gotten into how beautifully shot and captured the setting is in Banshees and that's worth noting too. This movie is a well captured and well shot slice of life period piece that is better than it has any right to be. The actors are perfectly cast, the movie wrings interesting moments out of the simplest premise and it feels tautly paced even though the story meanders quite a bit. The climax and the ending just didn't quite work for me as well and that's fine. It didn't knock the movie's grade down a ton but it firmly placed it as an 8 instead of a 9 or a 10. I'd still recommend it however and I'm not surprised at the attention it's getting. It isn't going to be accessible to all audiences but if you're in Inisherin's niche I have little doubt you're really going to dig this movie.

reviews.review_title: A warm story about the ramifications of "unfriending " a friend
reviews.content:
Everything about this movie is top class and it could land up as a frontrunner at the Golden Globes and Oscars. Director Martin McDonagh has turned out a memorable movie and has extracted superlative performances fron Colin Farrel, Brendan Gleeson and Kerry Condon. Its all about two friends, their heartbreak, hurt and loneliness when friendship goes wrong and friends become foes. The movie charms you with a devastating simplicity rarely seen and I don't think it would be right to call it a dark comedy due to sporadic bits of humour. The setting is a less populated idyllic island off Ireland and the period is the 1920s. The friendship of Colin and Brendan is put to a test when Brendan decides to break away as he finds Colin dull, dim and a waste of time
( aimless chatting he says). What follows is tumultuous for both as they take up a confrontational attitude. Kerry ( who plays Colin's sister) turns peacemaker and tries to pacify Colin without success. The scenes are brought to life not only by the superb acting, dialogue and direction but also the breathtaking cinematography of the island's features. While the beach and the greenery around is mesmerizing, the horse cart trudging along, the grocery shop, the bar etc look very realistic. Both Brendan and Colin have given award worthy performances. Kerry too impresses as the affectionate spinster sister. ( Luckily there are no family complications as both men don't have wives and the sister is unmarried.)

Absurd storyline. Essentially old mates donkey dies from eating another man's finger? This sums up the movie for me. Some great acting with a sub par script.Scenery is beautiful, cast is terrific. Story line is terrible. Most of the movie makes no sense. You could say it's an insane movie about some insane people in a village that's insane and a donkey that must be insane as it chokes on a severed finger of a human. Hmmmm. The old Banshee woman wailing about made more sense than the rest of the movie as she had premonitions of the deaths that were about to occur. I'm impressed they actually made a movie go for as long as it did with such a hollow story line and plot.

I personally love dark movies - I love the film where the main character dies at the end, for the unexpected shock factor.This movie sets a very low-n-slow premise: two characters, on one island, in one time, with no disturbances. I liked that; a movie all about dialogue and depth of character. And through the movie it keeps strongly enforcing a potential hit movie.However, the ending is awful, with no satisfactory resolutions to any of the plot lines. Sadly, it reveals the fact that the writers had no end in mind.The movie has beautiful cinematography, fantastic editing, and an unsatisfactory ending; making it a solid 5 in my book.

Going into too much detail on the failings of this dreadful film undoubtedly brings the risk of elevating it to the level of worthiness of criticism.The story is completely nonsensical and reminds me of the times we can all remember when we had to write a story in primary school - made a decent start and middle but rushed a poor ending. Well, the entirety of this film was less inventive then such a rushed ending.The actions and counter-actions of the two main protagonists, particularly Colm, were utterly ridiculous to behold. The two (saving) graces were firstly, the acting performances, particularly of Kerry Condon and the stupendous Barry Keoghan, and secondly, the beautifully-shot West of Ireland scenery. I repeat - those graces weren't saving ones.I sincerely hope, as an Irishman, that the viewing world doesn't make any logical conclusions about the Irish on the strength of this film. Hopefully, it will be seen as some twisted art-house film in Quiet Man clothing.

For the first two acts I enjoyed the simplicity of this story and McDonagh's usual excellent dialogue and humour. The acting is top notch all the way through by everyone and the film looks gorgeous. But when I thought it would build up to a clever ending it actually built up to a really bleak and depressing ending. I mean, I get the point of it all and I appreciate an ending that's different, but I just hoped for a resolution that at least left me feeling I was glad I watched it. In the end I wished I hadn't watched it, which is odd because for the first 80 minutes I loved it.I suppose I just had higher expectations because I'm a big fan of McDonagh, but the ending felt like it wasn't saying anything that you hadn't already figured out an hour earlier in the movie.

When one of two life long friends on a Irish island makes an erratic incomprehensible decision of not being a friend for the other guy anymore, life and soul of the latter seems to be turned upside down. It's 1923, Irish Civil war. Smoke at the horizon, thunder of heavy weapons in the distance. A dark witch-like old woman predicting upcoming deaths. Dark clouds in the sky. Self-destruction as an act of aggression itself is followed by the inevitable irrational spiral of violence, turning into sadness at first and later into madness, not only focusing on the two friends, but spreading out in circles. The irrational demise of this friendship is a clear symbol of what happens to whole nations and their leaders, to their soul and population in times of war, when no-one is able to understand what's going on and why, the so called reasons for this insanity are stupid lies, and hate, violence and man-slaughter continue in unstoppable dynamic escalation.I read in many comments that viewers don't seem to understand what's happening and why. It's War!All around us. Today. We are unable to understand why. And it still continues.Only the animals in this haunting film look at us in deep sadness, as if they knew more about us than we will ever know ourselves.A fine acting ensemble, consequent writing and directing, brilliant camera-work.

reviews.review_title: Look on my Works, ye Mighty, and despair
reviews.content: It's ironic that, when I was younger and knew nothing, I used to imagine Ireland as this merry land of jolly folk songs and people peacefully getting drunk on ale just to sing and dance to those songs, and maybe to write a few more.It's equally ironic to recall how this naive image was shattered. Not through learning the history of English occupation. Not even through learning about The Great Hunger. It was through observing images of those patchwork fields on the slopes near the shore. With nothing but grass around, not a single tree. And those stone hedges that weren't even meant to demark land owned by different people, but rather to protect this already almost barren stony soil from eroding even further and just leaking and blowing into the ocean. It was the epitome of hopelessness and some kind of quiet realisation, that there's no solution here, and this is how things will remain. With no promise of any happy ending, or happy beginning or being for that matter.Those fields. It was enough to have a single look to feel this anguish. Stuff that makes village people drink themselves to death or find quicker ways of reaching the same bitter end.The Banshees of Inisherin manages to do what I didn't think was possible. It amplifies this feeling, makes it take shape, almost turns it into something palpable, and delivers it right into your core so that you shiver even if you're thousands of miles away from those bare windy shores. And it does all that through another unparalleled trick. The vessel that carries this heavy spirit is not some huge riveting conflict. But rather its polar opposite. The most minuscule thing imaginable. A story of one man becoming boring for another one.We are so used to attaching strong emotions to strong stimulation that at first this film feels deafeningly underwhelming. It is so silently uneventful that you might decide that you just lost your hearing. Yet it's through this eerie quiet that we start hearing things that we didn't even know existed. What once looked dull and bleak now turns into a cacophony so loud that one would literally need to distract themselves with pain to stop hearing it.It's not a problem when your friend is dull if you are surrounded with shiny bright sources of cheap stimulation, like all of us are in this modern ever-connected world. But what if your whole universe contracts to a small patch of land with a small group of people on it, desperate for novelty but so used to that desperation that suppressing it becomes a national character? How do you convince yourself that you're still alive, and, even if you are, that your life has any essence and value at all?With only what the life of a small Irish settlement could provide, Martin McDonagh creates something that's at the same time a Boschian pandemonium and a frozen circle of Dantean hell. Where everything moves and talks and bleats at once, but nothing really happens and nothing really matters. In a way, your only hope at sanity is your own blindness and deafness. But once you un-dull yourself, existence becomes a race against time and things that don't push you forward pull you down instead.All this ambiguous and quite nutty complexity is tough to coherently put into words. But the power quartet of Colin Farell, Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan make this almost religious revelation entirely visceral. Through those quite simplistic facial movements these people let us in on the horrors of being trapped inside the routine, feeling brutally lonely while among people, and just suffocating with the mundane and the transient. You could feel it so close that the shattering experience of watching TBoI isn't even in its gory moments (although those are awfully disturbing), but in the despair of sitting next to a person you hold dear - yet knowing that there's a wall between you that can't be overcome, and just crying helplessly.I'm not sure of the film offers any sensible amount of hope at the end. Can redemption be achieved simply via suffering? Does a symbolic sacrifice of one life breathe in life into someone else, so robotic and predictable that they could just as well be dead? And if it does, is there a single chance for this newly found life to have a semblance of, if not meaning then at least value? There's no way to know that. Because, sated with this ritual suffering, banshees are silent now, they sit back, amused, and observe. And all we can do is follow suit.

I liked the wide shots of the Ireland scenery. That's about it. The entire film revolves around an irrational man and an irrational conflict, and by the time it ends you're just left wondering what people enjoyed in this film. The whole experience was so utterly pointless.I think it's trying to be funny? But it really just falls flat. Like those lines of dialogue where they just keep fully repeating the phrase that the other says. Or when the old man cuts off his fingers and hurls them at his ex friends door for no reason.Long story short (and boy does this one seem long), if you enjoy watching contrived conflicts and getting depressed this film is for you.

My topline response to this film is that...I didn't get it. The entire film hinges on the (supposed) friendship between Colm and Padraic, but we never actually see this friendship in full form, and thus we never feel any loss when the friendship is destroyed. I believe this film would have really benefitted from a little more straightforward (some would say cliché, and I wouldn't blame them) Hollywood storytelling, with some more straightforward setup and payoff. The entire time, I really didn't like or care about the sweet, naïve Padraic because I didn't really care about the friendship. I also felt like the tone was kinda weird. Too somber to be a comedy. Too comedic to be somber. I guess this is what a tragicomedy is. Didn't like it.

Dont wish to sound patronising but if any one writes perhaps they missed the point yes ... indeed you did . This is like one of the plays from Samuel Beckett I live so much ... it's thought provoking and is not actually about what your watching ... it's about so much more , it's meant to make you think.and it does just that , beautiful scenery although it doesn't add to their life in any way , it's funny , clever , symbolic, beautiful, sad and just different.... Loved it so much I watched it twice in one day. Acting is superb and I really hope they win something for it ...so refreshing to watch something with some depth.

Some fun scenes, some good dark humour throughout certainly, and a great performance by Farrell, but the ending was deeply unsatisfying somehow. This ending was so unsatisfying that it took the steam out of the rest of the movie, for me. I do generally like movies that find a kind of black humour in the sad absurdity that is this life, this world, but it just doesn't come together into a strong ending, which is a shame. The ending of a movie is important--it is what people remember most, often, and this falls flat.As others have mentioned, the scenery is beautiful (hard not to be, shooting in rural Ireland), and the dialogue is fun and lively.

reviews.review_title: Exposing the Darker Side of a Disrupted Friendship
reviews.content: On the surface, Martin McDonagh's 2022 film about the break-up of a lifelong friendship on a remote Irish island appears to be a comedy that goes dramatically from light to dark over the course of the plot, but there's an implicit reference to the Irish Civil War raging on the mainland in 1923 when allies turned into adversaries over the state of Irish independence. That historic context might have better explained the depths Colm is willing to go to force Padraic to leave him alone. As it stands, the story is triggered by episodes of inchoate male pride that sometimes produce gruesome consequences. Aside from great performances, especially from Colin Farrell as the dim Padraic and Kerry Condon as no-nonsense Siobhan, I was on the fence about this uniquely Gaelic tale as the tragic spirit didn't quite achieve its intended emotional resonance.

Lovely, moody scenery, great acting and a storyline that left me wishing I could get those two hours of my life back. The movie pokes and prods at an island village filled with bored, depressed people. I was thankful for the few laughs found along the way, but this movie went from sad to worse. There was character development but it amounted to nothing really. I'm not sure why someone would write this story let alone decide to utilize 2 fine actors in this downward spiral of despair that, in the end, signified nothing beyond a mid-life crisis driving a man to be cruel to his best friend. As he silently spirals, he does some insane things that accomplish nothing.

I would imagine this bleak, dreary film made about five bucks at the box office. I would b
Never run to a theatre to see this depressing film. Very forgettable and frankly a waste of time. Scenery and acting were great but the story is strange and in the end you have no closure. I'd give it a miss. To be nominated for best picture is really scraping the bottom of the barrel. With all the pain and misery in the world today, why would anyone want to see such a miserable dark film. I certainly wouldn't call it a comedy, but more of a character study. The miniature donkey was the best part of the whole movie, and the border collie.

Great acting, and the background was beautiful. I would say that the director's attempt to highlight stubbornness went straight off the rails into mental health issues. Also, there was an undercurrent that being "nice" makes people "dull." The further the characters veered from everyday pleasantries, the more interesting others saw them as being. Of course,there was the overt "cut off your nose to spite your face." Zero subtlety there. That is one way to demonstrate to others that you are serious. I think a large number of the issues the characters faced stemmed from living in a super small community, and life rarely straying from a predictable, mundane existence.

reviews.review_title: Subversive, off-beat comedy that veers off course in the middle
reviews.content: STAR RATING: ***** Brilliant **** Very Good *** Okay ** Poor * AwfulPadraic (Colin Farrell) lives on a small island off the coast of Ireland in the early 1920's. One day, he calls round the home of his friend, Colm (Brendan Gleason), only to get ignored, before Colm bluntly tells him that he no longer wants to be friends with him in the pub. Unable to make sense of his former companion's stance, and with only the socially stunted Dominic (Barry Keoghan) as a substitution, Padraic tries to pick the brains of his sister, Siobhan (Kerry Condon) about what might be going on, but as Colm's actions become increasingly unhinged, a conflict brews that could destroy everything.2008's In Bruges was a crowd pleaser hit, that generated a cult following with cinema goers, with its jazzy storytelling and severely near-the-knuckle jokes, which may not be tolerated as much in the present climate, but which remained ingrained in the collective consciousness of cinematic memory. Now the stars have reunited with writer-director Martin McDonagh for this more restrained but equally curious offering, which gradually reveals itself to be a period piece (confirmed when a calandar is turned revealing April 1923), when it becomes clear there are none of the trappings of modern times revealing themselves anywhere. This remote, secluded area, is the perfect backdrop for what feels like such a simple, childlike story that evolves in to something more.It's driven primarily by the mystery element to the story, behind what actually lies behind Colm's sudden abandonment of Siobhan and what's driving him to disassociate himself from his former friend, especially in such a dull, uneventful place, with so few people around and the presence of a good friend such a blessing.
