But as it drags on, it becomes increasingly far fetched, and begins to outstay its welcome in the third act, where it descends in to something of a shaggy dog tale, which doesn't leave you with much in the way of a resolution. A shame, since Farrell and Gleason manage the same chemistry and charm they had in In Bruges, if not with the same explosive results, and there is some beautiful cinematography of the Irish landscape.It was always inevitable that everyone behind such a well loved film as In Bruges would try to recreate the magic with a new project, even if we had to wait a while for it. The result is a film that could have been as perfect if it had just stayed on course and not worn the premise out with quite so much wear and tear. ***

This is a great story of friendship, family and ambition. A man so blinded by a desire for greatness that he can actively hurt a someone he called a friend to the point of insanity was mesmerizing to witness at this scale. Colin Farrell is a magnificent actor, and more times than I can count, I viscerally felt his emotions. His face, his body language, his intonation, all of it is spectacular and paints a vivid image of a man, confused and struggling with feelings of inadequacy, being abandoned time and time again. I laughed, I teared up, I seethed at times. The writing and directing was nothing short of spectacular. Hilarious and saddening, heartfelt and disturbing, all at once.

When I'm done watching a movie and the only emotion at the end is regret of even starting I wonder how on earth is this getting such a good rating?A tale taking 2 hours about friendship that didn't last...The ending is just as unreasonable as the is start. You are thrown into the movie without any opportunity to connect with the way of life or characters. The premise of being friends for years but "now it strikes me how dull you are, so don't talk to me or I'll cut my fingers off " is absurd just as some of the dialogs are. You kill my donkey and I'll try to kill you or AT LEAST make you homeless? Really? Theatre of the Absurd at best.Gorgeous scenery, excellent performance and great camera work is the only reason for 4 stars, other than that...not worth those 2 hours.

reviews.review_title: This is film making as it should be
reviews.content: It's not difficult to find some deeper meaning in The Banshees of Inisherin. The story of how two friends become bitter enemies, seemingly for no reason at all, has a universal quality to it. One of them, Colm, prefers silence over chatter, creativity over banality, and playing music over drinking beer. The other one, Padraic, doesn't understand why his friend decides to offend him by making these choices. He prefers kindness over everything else. It's radicalism against pragmatism.If you look at it this way, the film is an allegory for the state of the world in 2023. Radicals are fighting pragmatists everywhere, from the US to Israel, and from Iran to Afghanistan. And the message of the film is clear: radicalism is a short cut to self harm. You'll understand it when you see the film.You can have endless discussions after seeing this film, which is why it's such a good movie. But even better: you don't have to search for a deeper meaning to enjoy it. It's already brilliant as just a crazy story about two people on a remote island off the Irish coast.The great thing about the movie is that it is hilarious at some points, but also very dramatic at other moments. It shares this quality with Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri, the other masterpiece by director Martin McDonagh. The dialogue is very funny, but at the same time this is not an outright comedy, not even a black one. The script is a classic drama, with a good narrative arc and perfectly developed characters. There's no good versus bad in this film. Viewers can sympathize with both characters, because there's something to say for each of their arguments.And then there's one other great thing about the movie: the location. The isolated island and its tightly knit community, where the men gossip at the pub and the women at the grocery store, is a crucial element to the story. But it also adds a layer of pure beauty. The landscapes are nothing less than breathtaking.This is film making as it should be: a good story, great actors and strong direction. Just leave it to Martin McDonagh to deliver.

reviews.review_title: What a fascinating and great film
reviews.content: The Banshees of Inisherin is an absolutely stunning film, boasting incredible performances and exceptional writing that draws you in from start to finish. Every character and every shot in the movie feels essential and well thought out, resulting in a film that is truly mesmerizing.The acting in this movie is nothing short of exceptional. The cast delivers nuanced and layered performances, bringing to life the complex characters in a way that feels completely authentic. The dialogue is equally strong, with every word feeling perfectly placed and purposeful.But the Banshees of Inisherin isn't just about great performances and writing. The visuals in this film are truly breathtaking. The cinematography is both stunning and subtle, with every shot highlighting the beauty and mystery of the film's coastal setting. And the use of animals throughout the film adds a layer of confusion that perfectly mirrors the sense of uncertainty surrounding the human behavior.In short, the Banshees of Inisherin is a must-see film. It's a beautifully crafted movie that showcases the power of great storytelling and amazing performances. Whether you're a fan of drama, mystery, or just great cinema in general, this film is sure to impress. So do yourself a favor and check it out!

One of the worst movies I've ever seen with a bland dialogue, ridiculously boring story and overwhelming level of human ignorance. I've seen plenty of dark movies in my time; but this "takes the cake".The acting was mediocre as I've stated to many - the plot very thin and utterly moronic. I mean mutilating yourself out of minor disagreement and upset on a lonely island as if it were an everyday occurrence? Really now...Truly one of the worst movies I've ever seen and if it has meaning to some? I would submit? A VERY LOW percentage of authenticity to many. I realize the Irish are noted for being "dark and moody" very often, but to the degree that one would live like a manic depressive and not seek joy and fulfillment in any true way is a pathetic commentary that reflects solely on them.

Had such high hopes that this would be a little gem like In Bruges or The Guard. Sadly not, there is next to no story, what there is is completely unbelievable and the movie itself is devoid of any charm.The three main characters try their best but what a waste of their talents.Whatever it is dhat people rave about, i just dont get it, it could have been charming, witty and feelgood but its none of those. Sadly it seems to be a bit up itself with trying to be as drab and depressing as it can all in the name of art. Such a shame when the location and a lot of the drone shots are really quite spectacular.

Then dark and odd. Beautiful & stunning locations. The ending took this masterpiece and tossed it in the fireplace. My review would've been a 9 yet for the finale. I assume the film displays the darkness of isolation and the madness that can accompany it (?). The casting is SUPERB, the screenplay is well written except for the story's destination and the acting is excellent. A balance is achieved between characters you love, like, hate, and admire. It appears the director decided on moments to display Kerry's natural beauty. It is worth the watch yes, but be warned about being left wondering what happened next. It is as almost the filmmaking just.... Ran out of money. ?

reviews.review_title: A test of willpower and strength!
reviews.content: "The Banshees of Inisherin" is one drama filled film a test of relationship, and a look at willpower and determination and it all shapes the eventual fate of the two central characters.Director Martin McDonagh paces the film along well with fine shots and the dialogue makes it really a black hearted comedy. Looking at life, and the relationships of two grown men at odds in a tense and comic like manner.Padraic(Colin Farrell) and Colm Doherty(Brendan Gleeson) two lifelong residents of an Ireland coastal town had a strong friendship however when a fallout happens the two are at odds, and the scenes are timely and tense.The cinematography is fine set in 1920's Ireland with costumes and living quarters taking you back in time, however the chemistry and blend between serious drama and black hearted comedy all lead to an unexpected fate and masterful twist. Overall well done give and take drama.

reviews.review_title: "You are all boring!" shouts Siobhán into his brother's face
reviews.content: The film opens with Colm, a local islander artist, who's had enough of his one and only friend Pádraic, which spends the first hour on screen chasing Colm down the local Pub and back for an explanation. The reason for their broken friendship--we find out ulterior 30 tiring minutes later--is that Colm has changed, and now considers his "dull" friendship with Pádraic irreconcilable with his music writing activity. The last part of the movie portrays their relationship spiraling down, with Colm blackmailing Pádraic with self-mutilation, and Pádraic setting Colm's cottage on fire in revenge of his pet, killed in an accident.The film runs just shy of two hours and mainly portrays the daily walks to the local pub, where most of the action happens, of a handful of characters that are almost unanimously dull, boring, and unintelligent--an exception made for Pádraic's sister Siobhán, which enjoys reading, and leaves the island for good when she gets a chance.Through a sprinkle of unenlightening dialogues happening at lengthy intervals, the audience gets to learn little or nothing about how the friendship Colm and Pádraic was, or the reason why Colm deems inconceivable to be an artist and a friend to Pádraic at once (both seem to have quite some spare time on their hands.) The final dialogue between the two protagonists gives hints of reconciliation, the same way some of their previous meetings followed by gruesome violence did.

I don't understand why everyone loves this movie. I thought it was sad depressing and boring. Basically two 'friends" have a falling out because one thinks the other is dull. Fingers are chopped off, a donkey dies and a house is burned down. Everyone is still sad and lonely at the end. It was very well acted and fun to see the scenery of the island but the story, which I think is trying to be funny, is bleak. I actually think some of these characters need help. I don't understand why he chopped his fingers off. It's gross and sad and makes me feel like he needs help. Then the nicest most innocent character dies at the end. It was all just too sad for me.

reviews.review_title: Can You Find The Love Story Here?
reviews.content: Martin McDonagh's new movie takes place on an island off the Irish coast decades ago, but it could just as easily be in a rural community anywhere. Two middle aged men, apparently friends for years, are going through a mysterious crisis. One of them suddenly refuses to speak to the other, and Colin Farrell can't figure out why his old friend has turned hostile. It's Ireland, so of course there's a pub, a Catholic Church, a hovel where Farrell lives with his sister - and another where his friend Brendan Geeson lives alone. And there are goats, a dog and donkey. For a while the dialog misleads us with its quaint charm and it seems we're easing our way into comical territory. However, Mr. Geeson's behavior becomes increasingly irrational and darkly troubled. Before long Farrell, too, becomes a bit unhinged. It becomes clear that there are things beneath the surface of their relationship that are determined to break through and see the light of day. Only a few fleeting moments hint at their deep feelings for each other, but it seems a subject neither one has ever articulated. The movie is a masterful study of friendship on the edge of becoming something deeper, though the chances of that ever happening seem remote. A beautifully made, immensely moving film that gives both actors the roles of their careers - and us? We get the best movie of the year.

reviews.review_title: Another Irish triumph of a funny, then dark & even tragic dramedy. Superb.
reviews.content: When Irish movies are good, they're great, with none much greater than superb 1923-based dramedy "The Banshees Of Inisherin" (reuniting fine writer/director Martin McDonagh with the stars of his debut ("In Bruges"): Colin Farrell & Brendan Gleeson). Starting light (yet charmingly funny) on a little Irish island, aging but aspiring composer Gleeson cuts contact with his 'dull' uninspiring old friend Farrell, to the latter's confusion. However, as witnessed by fellow islanders like Kerry Condon & Barry Keoghan (both as excellent as the leads) events then turn dramatically darker & even tragic. Brilliantly written and beautifully shot by McDonagh, it's another Irish triumph. Sláinte!

As real people who watch this movie and continue to give it very low ratings as it is no comedy , no farce and not clear in its goal, I hope that the rating continues to fall so that more people are not fooled by the advertising or the BAFTA nominations and spend their money to be so disappointed and disgusted. I am grateful to so many real viewers who seem to agree that the film is not worth watching, should not be sold as a comedy drama and who can't figure out why the cruelty and insanity take place. More confusing are the high ratings but maybe that was required if the entire crew - to write high-rated reviews- in order to get paid ? I wanted to like this movie but won't go see it after reading dozens of RECENT reviews mostly rating it about an average o 2-3 - not the high 7 it currently claims.

I expected this to have mixted reviews, which it does, with critics absolutely loving it and the audience being divisive. It's definitely not for everyone and even Martin McDonagh's fans might not be on board with this one. Everything is very subtle, the pace is extremely slow and it seems like nothing of substance is really happening. I can completely understand why someone won't like it, but I have to say I love the tragedy and the bizarreness of the film. The culture of the film seems very authentic and I love the way it depicted human relationships. It's definitely an interesting watch, even though it falls a bit flat.

reviews.review_title: Ok but not more than ok.
reviews.content: I think there is an argument to say that the love people have for Brendan Gleason and Colin Farrell, the heart stopping gorgeousness of the island setting, the wonderful ensemble acting and the fact that Martin MacDonagh has an almost faultless resume of brilliant films and writing behind him, have given this film more value and prestige than it deserves.Sure it's a strange little tale of abandonment and leaving (a theme in MacDonaghs work) of heartbreak and the consequences of extreme actions (another theme of his) and he captures the twin afflictions of claustrophobia and aloneness of rural village life (neatly contrasted by the wide open spaces of the island) but for me, there was an emptiness and lack of point to the film which made it hard to connect to. I enjoyed it but would never revisit it.

reviews.review_title: Grim drama about friendship and isolation
reviews.content: IMDb headlnes this as a comedy drama. Dramatic, yes, albeit at a slow pace. But comic? Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson play Padraig and Colm, two men in a tiny village on a bleak island off the coast of Ireland. They've been friends all their lives until Colm announces that Padraig bores him to death and he doesn't want him to speak to him ever again; if he does, Colm, an accomplished fiddle player, will start to cut off his own fingers. Since I've questioned the humor of this movie, you can guess what happens next.The acting is impeccable. Farrell, particularly, has never been better. Kerry Condon as Padraig's sister, who longs to escape the island, has the beauty and poignancy of a Thomas Hardy heroine. Delicately written and beautifully filmed, this is a small grim drama about friendship and isolation. But you will not come out of the cinema smiling. Not my definition of comedy.

reviews.review_title: Confusing but silently comforting and beautiful.
reviews.content: My Rating : 6/10It looked good and pretty promising coming from the team behind 'In Bruges' however it is not as good or exciting to watch unfortunately. What shines through brilliantly though is the infinite charm of the leading and supporting actors but is it enough to get it over the line? I guess if you don't take it too seriously and not complain about the overall dullness of the screenplay and lack of any meaningful plot which creates a barrier for the viewer to fully engage and make any real sense about the cause of the impasse.All in all, 'The Banshees of Inisherin' is not as memorable as 'In Bruges' and it seems this kind of comedy drama plays out within its genre peculiarities and does so somewhat well but its convoluted and often boring and unnecessarily existential like my review. Like what's the point? The dialogues are not witty enough at times and seem too simple for a well-made movie.I enjoyed the ending, Colin Farrell's always nice guy character finally answers to the idiocy and that's when finally something normal happens!

reviews.review_title: A well-acted dark comedy that could have been more profound
reviews.content: With films such as "In Bruges" and "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri," Martin McDonagh has cemented himself as an auteur defined by a perversely clever sense of dark humor. I have liked his other films, but not quite as much as some do. Given that I really like Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson, I was looking forward to this film, which is a tragicomic fable about an ending friendship on a remote Irish island in 1923. The film is well-acted and well-made on a number of levels, but it lacks the character development or introspectiveness to make an interpersonal, character-driven film like this truly great.No character-driven film could be strong without engaging performances, and fortunately, "The Banshees of Inisherin" has a few noteworthy ones. Colin Farrell's performance is very strong, portraying an emotional range, whip-smart line delivery, and a deep-seated sense of empathy. Brendan Gleeson is impressive as well, but his character and performance are a bit more one-note than Farrell's. Kerry Condon is consistently excellent as Farrell's character's sister, and Barry Keoghan is sharp as well. With gorgeous cinematography of the Irish coast and a beautifully understated, elegant-but-everyman score, "Banshees" is very technically well-made for a film of its type and scope. Given that McDonagh is especially noteworthy by critics for his showy dialogue, the film's screenplay serves as its most critical component to this film's distinctiveness. This ends up being both a plus and a minus. McDonagh's writing is laced with the type of razor-sharp, profane, caustically-hilarious one-liners that we expect from him. Yet the film could have used a more structured narrative and a genuine plot. While both Pádraic and Colm are moderately interesting characters in the here and now, more sufficient attention to character development and how their friendship was in the past would have been helpful to provide appropriate narrative context across the screenplay more generally. When the film ends, it does feel like the film could have had more to say or a greater point or meaning, and the impacts of feud between Pádraic and Colm do not necessarily feel fully satisfying from a narrative perspective. For those reasons, "The Banshees of Inisherin" ends up being a good but not great dark comedy. 7/10.

So begins his pleading Pádraic Súilleabháin when his life-long friend Colm Doherty told him he wants to have nothing to do with him from now on. Played by Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson respectively, you might think his line is strange. But that is because Colm has no reason to break up his bromance other than the fact that he doesn't like Pádraic no more.Yes, that is the premise of Martin McDonagh's latest movie, "The Banshees of Inisherin". His directing, together with the whimsicality of real-life BFFs Farrell and Gleeson are slowly becoming one of the most complementary trios in the history of cinema: think Scorsese-De Niro-DiCaprio. So, let's start with McDonagh who is slowly molding himself into an auteur of his craft, mainly because of his ability to write characters living on the edge between comedy and tragedy. Sure, Tarantino, for instance, is a better director, but he deals in extreme human beings, outlandish spectacle and the absurd. McDonagh's characters are absurd as well, but they are also realistic. It wouldn't be hard to imagine two friends like Pádraic and Colm could've actually existed, living through the bloody Irish Revolution of 1923.As for Farrell and Gleeson, their chemistry rivals that of the great classic comics like Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy or Abbott and Costello. Farrell, in the performance of his career, plays a simple milkman living with his sister and tending for his animals. Because ignorance is bliss, his incidental pragmatism makes him deal with life as it comes, never thinking beyond the things he sees in front of him, nor he would if he could. He doesn't care. Colm, on the other hand, is a musician and fiddle player who feels death is closing in and only now realizing he's wasted most of his life, so he'd now rather focus on creating a lasting piece of art before he will forever fade. I know, talk about midlife crisis. Under McDonagh's directing, though, "The Banshees of Inisherin" overwhelms its ridiculous and silly characters and transforms them and the movie itself into a touching, shocking take on existential dread and powerlessness in the face of the inevitable. Still, the human characters save it from being pretentions. It's a beautiful balance between the silly and the profound and, honestly, you have to see it to truly understand it. It definitely left a lasting mark on me.If you're curious about the name, "Inisherin" is a fictional island off the coast of Ireland--its denizens isolated from the war happening literally across the pond. Often, explosions are heard, but the inhabitants of Inisherin watch the revolution as outsiders, as if they don't belong. For them, the war is nothing more than an irritating inconvenience. Their lives will go on the same regardless. Which brings me to one of the movie's greatest points: its anti-war stance. McDonagh is all about subtility, so instead of dramatizing the bloodshed caused by war, he imposes upon it the greatest of insults: to be ignored. What would make one angrier other than knowing that he could die in vain, fighting for nothing other than pride? This is the pride carried by Colm, who is so obsessed with his legacy that he doesn't even stop to think whether the victory is worth it. And what would that victory even be? That he might be remembered? It's a noble artistic aspiration but also a hollow one--just like the victory of a bloody war.In all this guy-centric chaos, it is Pádraic's sister, Siobhán (Kerry Condon) who displays genuine wisdom. She is our anchor in the movie, and also an anchor into the outside world, but even she becomes overwhelmed by the ongoing conflict between the two friends in which she often plays the mediator: "you're all stupid" she yells at one point.But the most drastic of all, is Pádric's transformation from the simpleton he is into a man traumatized by betrayal and consumed by loneliness. His break-up from Colm is more tragic than most romantic break-ups, his reactions range from bursting into tears to bursting into Colm's house and the emotional weight is relentless getting heavier and heavier as the movie goes on. After watching it, I got up from my seat trying to make sense of everything I've felt. Even now, I am still trying to.

The worst film I've ever had to see... completely senseless. Only thing touching a viewer would be the death of the only creature Jenny dying whilst chewing fat fingers. I can only see 1 of 10 reviews here which I agree with, but it managed to get 7,8 as a score... this must be a bluff?? No one in their right mind could ever see the beauty in it. There is no point. It has no story. One does not grow as a person watching this rubbish horrible senseless useless sad slow boring
Never ever watch this horrendous I only write this because I have to have enough caracteres to post the thing. Rubbish law.

reviews.review_title: The Full Irish: Funny, Dry and Absolutely Bonkers
reviews.content: Set in the West of Ireland, Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell showcase their acting brilliance in a sensational double-act centred around seemingly, very little.On a remote island off the coast of Ireland, Pádraic is devastated when his buddy Colm suddenly puts an end to their lifelong friendship. With help from his sister and a troubled young islander, Pádraic sets out to repair the damaged relationship by any means necessary. However, as Colm's resolve only strengthens, he soon delivers an ultimatum that leads to shocking consequences.Martin McDonagh directs with such care and consideration for the acting performances of the cast, as well as the breathtaking spring setting of Ireland at its most beautiful. The multiple wide focus angles greeted with little meaningful dialogue, allows the audience to appreciate the cinematography and subtle aspects of the film.The back and forth between Gleeson and Farrell is golden entertainment, the former offering a passive, melancholic presence in opposition to the latter, who assumed an eager and determined characterisation of a desperate man epitomising the difficulties of maintaining societal framework on an island as quiet and close-knit as Inisherin.We are reminded of the values of friendship through the disappointment of Padraig, as well as the importance of family, through his whole-hearted sister Shivon too. For a picture that has lacks a twisting, turning broad premise, there isn't a great amount to review, other than to praise the infectious dry humour, take your hat (not finger) off to the joint protagonists and salute McDonagh for another job well done.

The early 20th century Ireland setting made me pick this out and it didn't disappoint. A very strange storyline but so compelling I needed to see where it was leading. Brilliant acting from the leads and the slow pace of life in such a beautiful remote setting made it an easy watch even if a rather dark tale was at the centre of it. You will feel sorry for some of the characters, dislike a few and be baffled by one of the main characters but understand him more as the film progresses towards it's finale. Were all my questions answered? No - which is not a bad thing because I can decide the outcomes in my imagination.

What a lovely enchanting movie. Colin Farrell is a revelation. Barry Keoghan is a joy. I can always watch Brendan Gleeson. He always delivers. Wonderful Irish cast. It makes a joyous change to hear them speak naturally too. It's a very simple story brought to life by a tremendous ensemble.I enjoyed the innocence of an Ireland in times gone by. However for me the natural beauty of the wild Atlantic way is the show stopper. The beauty of Ireland is breathtaking.I have to say that the lack of traditional Irish music for me is the biggest let down though. I know this was intentional but I don't understand why.

On a small island off the coast of Ireland in the 1920's, dairy farmer Colin Farrell calls on Brendon Gleason every day at 2:00 PM and they go down to the pub together. Only on this day, Gleason does not answer the door. He just sits in a chair smoking in full view of Farrell until he goes away.When they do run into each other at the pub later on, Gleason informs Farrell that he doesn't like him anymore and he is to stay away. When pushed, he explains that a sense of his limited time has started to overwhelm him, and he wants to spend more time writing music (he plays the fiddle) and less time talking to dull men. When pushed farther, he informs Farrell he'll cut off one of his own fingers ever time Farrell bothers him. He is not bluffing.There's a lot going on in this film, and I love that it manages to tackle so much without feeling heavy. It's about male friendship and how bad we are at dealing with emotions. It's about depression and existential dread. It's a black comedy of manners and a pretty serious meditation on the fleeting nature of human existence. It has a really wonderful scene stealing donkey.I really like this film and I suspect I will grow to like it even more on repeat viewing. Farrell and Gleason are as good a pair here as they were in "In Bruges", yet they couldn't be more different. Kerry Condon steals the movie out from under them as Farrell's smarter sister (She has some wonderful scenes that really contrast male and female perspectives on life.) Barry Keoghan steals more scenes as a funny little weirdo.

reviews.review_title: Worse than a waste of time
reviews.content: Beautiful expansive cinematography, artistically laid out shots, excellent acting. But this film burns your soul without any reconciliation.Inisherin has many characters that are full of love for one another. The relationships are close and positive. They pull you in right away with the ridiculous dialogue. However, the further you go down the rabbit hole of despair the more you realize this is no dark comedy. The antagonist is so self-absorbed and cruel in the worst way. He's emotionally torturous to one, which eventually collaterally destroys EVERYONE else. No one takes away anything positive from his destrction.After contemplating this movie for awhile I start to wonder if the characters were built up to make the depressing crash even harder in the end.Cruel, hopelessly depressing, zero redemption.

reviews.review_title: No plot, a disappointing waste of time
reviews.content: A film is more than an actor's performance. But it depends on it.It is more than its picture. But it helps to have a nice one.A film needs a plot. And without one, even the best performances are nothing but cherries in an out of date cake.While the actors where fantastic, I do not remember the last time I saw a movie where I would ask, till the end, when is this going to have a turn, when is it going to become interesting.I can resume the entire film very quickly - a man decides he does not want to be friends with another man anymore. The first insists he wants to be alone with his own reasons, the other is obsessed to be friends again. The End.I'm not even sure if I should tick here that my comment contains spoilers... it contains the whole movie instead!

Well, McDonagh has done it again. Can he do wrong? I'm becoming convinced that the man cannot make a bad movie, or even one that isn't compelling.The characters he crafts to inhabit the lush little island of Inisherin are so distinct, stubborn, and easy to get attached to-lovable, even. The seemingly trivial neighborhood spats that they engage in are absurd to the greatest comedic extent, but the film itself never veers into unbelievable territory.McDonagh's screenplay is bursting with wit and with sadness as his townspeople respond to their social hopelessness with actions that only fuel the fire of their desperate isolation. It creates so many thoughts and feelings in a viewer as they ponder on what each unfolding situation could have been.Despite visual direction that is fairly standard and a couple of dangling plot threads that I personally would have liked to see explored more deeply, the film is emotionally engaging and full of verbal personality to spare.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies of 2022
reviews.content: I would easily put this movie in my top 3 movies of 2022. The landscape of a small island in Ireland already has my heart pounding even before the story begins. Too bad, Inisherin doesn't exist, nor the pub that was built out especially for the movie (and that's a good thing, a pub... 200m from cliffs? That would be a disaster! How many 'hold my beer' moments would happen??). Even though I'm usually pretty good with accents, for this one you definitely need subtitles. The movie start with Pádraic Súilleabháin, trying to understand why his best friend Colm Doherty stopped talking to him (because he doesn't like him no more). The movie is gorgeous in lots of ways, from the cast (Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon, etc.), to the landscapes, passing by all the feelings you go through. It feels like you are on the island with the characters, that you are living Colm's betrayal yourself, and you truly feel for Pádraic. It could have been a bleak picture of a small island where the only distraction is a pub and alcohol, but you very much have this sense of community, where this friendship crumbling makes everyone wonder what happened. A must see.

For me the film was meaningless, nothing makes sense. It's sad, not funny and the scenes with the cut fingers are disgusting- and it does nothing to support the story to show it that detailed, that was just repulsive.I had some hopes for that movie, but still was highly disappointed. The main actors and the team from In Burgess let me hoping to see a strange dramedy. But, a bit but, just to make the characters strange doesn't make it funny, and also, it is not art because it makes no sense. The whole film is sequence of nonsensical actions by the two main characters, which are escalating, but in the end are useless. In the end the only thing that changed is that the sister moved away- so what?

reviews.review_title: How was this billed as comedy?
reviews.content: I am at a loss for words reading the other reviews. How was this billed as comedy? There wasn't a single thing to smile about. It was gruesome, bleak, depressing and incredibly sad. It was also an unbelievable plot with the biggest loophole of all - no one slices their fingers off without serious medical issues. Weird, horrible and I wish I'd never watched it now. Those scenes of self mutilation will never be erased from my memory. Granted there was fantastic acting and well observed characters and the portrayal of life on a remote island in 1923 was both poetic and beautiful as well as giving such a detailed picture of how the minutiae of day to day monotony can wear you down. I will praise the photography and scenery though.

Stop wasting my time. This movie was terrible. Can I have my two hours back and a drink for the bullcrap. Nobody can cut 5 of their own fingers off and no a donkey wouldn't eat one. Sry if I spoiled the movie for you but it was terrible. I still have no idea when it takes place and I still have no idea why the fat one doesn't want to be friends with the skinny guy. Colin give your money back and tell mad eye to do the same. You two are idiots for making this bag of fingers and we would be better off if the writer choked on his. Good luck on the end of a terrible career outside of Harry Potter and The Boondocks Saints. And you both look like donkeys for the record.

reviews.review_title: "It was all going fine till he . . . "
reviews.content: " . . . Chopped off all his fingers," donkey boy says of the local fiddler toward the end of THE BANSHEES. This picture faithfully documents one of the most sordid locales on the planet, exposing the seedy underside of a cursed isle doomed to suffer from an increasingly limited gene pool. The highlight, main occupation and reason to exist for the characters spotlit here is to fritter away the hours guzzling booze in their neighborhood bar. Though some people have menial chores to earn their beer dough, most live amid a boring intellectual vacuum, in which local gossip is considered the pinnacle of higher education. Johnnie Swift suggested years ago that the best outcome for this benighted populace would involve having the sorry sad sacks consume each other, and most viewers of THE BANSHEES will be convinced to agree with Swift's prescription.

The acting for this story was great, the scenery was done well, but the story was so depressing. The secondary storylines were depressing too, but not as much as the main storyline. The "lifelong friends" both had to be mentally ill to do the things they did. I wish I hadn't watched it. It's left me with a sadness inside. It really was very disturbing to think that normal people could act this way towards each other. I think the only thing that could possibly explain this film is mental illness on the part of both of the main characters. At least the dog didn't get killed, although at one point I thought it was going to be murdered too.

reviews.review_title: A Comedy only in the way Lament in Grief is Funny
reviews.content: Banshees of Inisherin is decidedly a dark comedy, focused more on the absurdity of humanity. The film starts as a "slice of life" of an isolated Irish village on an island. The populace is found at the pub, and sharing "news" (gossip) from each village. What ignites the drama in the plot is one friend rejecting another friend, who is considered a dullard. From here, each step triggers another reaction that escalates to the final acts of the film. Along the way, life in the village adds characters and small dramatic points that add to the absurdity and comedy of the film.But, a underlying theme of the film entails the progression of life, the limits of time, and the reality of mortality. Grief and loss are catalysts for introspection and analysis of the relationships in our lives. From this, we are able to see how some will take what life offers to survive, and others just falter and fail. This is where the film shines and dazzles with the storytelling through a simple story and simple folks.All aspects of this film are excellent. Acting, writing, cinematography, music, and direction are top notch. Let the scenes draw you into the story, and open yourself to a slice of life that strikes deeper than we would care.

No pun intended - and that is not me bidding for Colin to become the next James Bond ... though if he gets the role, you heard it here first ... I am kidding of course ... unless this really happens, than I wasn't. Now if you think my thoughts, that are completely unrelated to the movie are funny ... you may have a winner (movie) for yourself here too.Or you may know In Bruges for example and think: I'll love this anyway, no matter what people write. Though to be fair, most do write the bestest of things about this movie. Including it in their top movies of 2022 ... too late for me to do that - but it is an early contender for 2023 for sure. I will keep this in mind and in my list of course. I do do top 20 movies though ... I am certain I will again next year.But there is a lot of time until then - and while I am certain I will still be able to write (with all my fingers, no pun intended), push comes to shove, I could still use voice recognition to "write" things down. About a movie that may have two strong main roles ... but knows that every single character matters ... even the ones that are supposedly less ... intelligent! Touche indeed! No pun intended here either.The movie that is about life, death and our legacy (no matter the century), really knows how to play us ... and the dialog is just exquisite! The jokes can be served cold and dark, but they always hit their mark/spot. A movie that knows what it is, knows how intelligent the audience is that it aims for .... and a movie that is a bit messed up like life ... and irrational too. I cancelled a friendship too when I was younger ... but I did not have the same motives ... it is interesting to see ... and it is even more haunting to experience ... especially going forward to the inevitable ending ... as it seems ...

Banshees of Inisherin is an interesting one, to say the least. It boils down to a feud between two friends on a small island and how that is escalated. At first impression, I love the settings. Beautiful locations with suitable camerawork. I learned later thatthe movie was filmed in multiple locations across the Irish isles but regardless, they made it pretty seamless. I had slight difficulty understanding the heavy Irish accent - probably capturing maybe 7-80% of the lines, which kind of sucked because the movie was mostly dialogue. Felt very play-like given the legendary playwright Martin McDonagh made this movie. I have never heard of him until now but this was certainly a good introduction to him.The writing was top-notch. Introduces the conflict right away. First half of the movie is rather hilarious though it gets darker toward the end. All the performances were amazing. Every single one of them pushed it pretty far. It was also good to see Kerry Condon, also known as Stacey Ehrmantraut in the Better Call Saul universe. She and Barry Keoghan were some of the standout supporting characters in the movie.The movie's main theme is loneliness and mortality. We see how Padraic, who was the typical nice guy, transform into something much darker as he loses everything around him, including his lifelong friend, Colm (entirely by Colm's choice), his sister Siobhan, his pet donkey and somewhat of a friend, Dominic. Loneliness affects people differently and I thought that this film portrayed very well how Padraic handles this. It was also meaningful in that it discusses how one handles the dreadful question of existential crisis, which Colm goes through. The main conflict of the film is that Colm cuts off Padraic overnight because he was too dull for Colm and wanted to try to carve some meaning out of his remaining life. I loved that it was subtly introduced to the audience as the priest asks Colm about how his despair is during his confession.I related to both of these characters quite heavily. Loneliness does sometimes make you angry to the point of no return. I've also had close friends who was very different from me (dull, if you would say) but the circumstances have kept us close. However, there were times where I wanted to cut those kind of friends out from my life just because I wanted to feel like I'm never wasting my time away. So I understand Colm's decision albeit I would probably take a less drastic approach to handling relationships. The irony is that because he cuts his fingers off for the determination that he would make something of his life, he no longer can play music, which seemed like the purpose of his life. Perhaps he will be remembered for his self-mutilation than his music, and that could be why he took such drastic measures. To feel alive and to be remembered.Many often avoid or push away the grim reality of mortality. We all die one day and there will be a time nobody remembers you most likely. How does that thought affect us? How could you find balance between the small joys of life and its overarching goal?Banshees of Inisherin makes you wonder about these questions. And to them I have no answers.

I was enjoying the dark humor, slice of life and remote location of this film. Wonderful acting of a hilarious script. First inclining something was amiss was when the "slow" boy (great performance tho) spouts off about "Touché. It's from the French." He learn that from his copper Daddy? I think not. And in the next scene he's back to driveling again. So which is it, worldly and bright or "village gom"?I was delighted to see animals given such great roles. Animals are often treated terribly in film, starting with the writers. But when something happens to one of them I flipped it off. Don't need another "Balthazar" trauma to haunt me the rest of my days.

Sometimes storytelling is so simple. What if someone's best friend decided he didn't want to be friends anymore? That's it. That is the set up of this movie. No more, no less. And honestly? That's enough in the hands of Martin McDonagh. Because all you really need is a couple characters that want different and opposing things. (Also, some beautiful scenery doesn't hurt.) There wasn't a single point in this movie when I didn't care or wasn't compelled...although I will admit to liking the donkey more than most of the people. Anyway, it is a reminder that stories dont have to be complicated to work.

reviews.review_title: Don't just see it, feel it, live it!
reviews.content: "Some things there's no moving on from. And I think that's a good thing."I absolutely adore those movies that pull the audience in, suck them right into their drama, and you become an active participant in it before you even realize. Martin McDonagh's The Banshees of Inisherin is one of those rare instances where you feel as if you have lived the film rather than just seen it.And when you combine that with wonderful performances and gorgeous overhead views of the Irish Isles, you get yourself a passionate work of art. This brings a certain sense of tranquility to the proceedings, in addition to a sense of poignance that makes you fall in love once again with cinema.

reviews.review_title: Oh no, evil women ruining the peaceful village! ¡Oh boy!

reviews.review_title: A hurtful story about the end of a friendship.
reviews.content: When I read the summary of this movie, I was pretty skeptical, I thought that the premises were not that good. Instead, I was pleasantly surprised. The film is beautifully shot, the plot is captivating, deep and meaningful, the cast was wonderful. Colin Farrel and Kerry Condon were simply perfect in their roles. It is a really sad story about the end of a long lasting friendship, we get to understand the reasons why Colm wants to interrupt this relationship and things will gradually escalate, until the point of non-return. There are some touching moments, where you really get to see the pain of Padraic for this terrible loss, almost like he was mourning the death of someone. I personally experienced the end of an important friendship, I say that the depiction is believable, as a part of you figuratively dies. The sister Shioban, served as some kind of intermediary between the two men. Her strong personality and determination made this whole movie dynamic and well paced. The images of the rural island on Inisherin are absolutely stunning. The representation of the people living on such small territory is likely, especially in a time without the internet. They are simple people that are not able to formulate complex talks, that must be really bored and overall lonely, seeking excitement in the most futile things. It is always nice to see that big actors partake in more "philosophical" productions, bringing in cinemas more people to watch something different than the usual blockbuster.

This film comes with a fistful of Irish stewing. The twists of language, the pints of bitter wit or just plain pints, served at the stroke of two in the afternoon. The tourist board of Inisherin might be overwhelmed with requests, if only it were not a mythical place....a bit of an Achille's Heel for Achill Island.Still the Emerald Isle is magical nonetheless. Some of the drone shots are exultant as are views looking out at the endless ocean. More often though the action is framed by dark, tight doorways. If this were a big budget film, it would be shown in damp-o-vision with humidifiers keeping you and your seat in the mist.Anyways I am always eager to see a McDonagh movie, more so with Gleeson and Farrell in the mix. Had this on tap as soon as it was set to stream. That said my initial review seems to have tickled the censor-bots as I used the more gentle Irish slang for one of George Carlin's magnificent seven words.Anyways, in short and spoiler-free, I felt the film to be more about the loss of innocence, then about the heartbreak of failed friendship or the need for an artist to silently break away from the daily grind binding them.The shots of the various livestock, pets and otherwise, added to the element of innocence watching helplessly. As did Barry Keough's portrayal of Dom. If you found him eerily captivating here and have not seen Barry in Yorgos Lanthimos' "Killing of a Sacred Deer" - please have a gander at that remarkable film.Maybe one word of caution for the film at hand, there are some pretty brutal elements and they tend to muscle out the comedy over time. But there is plenty of both, and tings to tink about too.Ultimately the film left me sad and reflective, kind of like seeing the comments on online videos when my kids were watching when they were seven. I won't expect many to feel that same specific sense of shame in mankind, but maybe the feeling is more akin to forever wars and such. And that is of many topics briefly touched upon in this fine film.Oh one other last minor comment, as a well-lapsed Catholic, I still appreciate any McDonagh film with a confession scene or three in 'em. That and honor among family, very strong here. Got my Irish up to be certain. I've hardly said a word about Kelly Condon as the sister to Farrell's Padraic, but she's more than capable of speaking up for herself.Enough said, I've gone and talked myself up from an 8 to 9 on this and I'm not sure if the director and cast take pride in the double gaussian range of ratings here, but sure and that's a sign of strong, smart and not safe film.Hold such films in the palm of your hand when you can, even if it's a bit precarious to do so.

reviews.review_title: Avoid this god awful film like the plague
reviews.content: Avoid, especially if you are an animal lover. I was looking forward to this as I love the two main actors and the charm of Irish culture. Little did I know that by the end of the film I would fall out of love with both actors and feel dirty and tarnished by the whole exoerience. I urge you to avoid the hype and the film. It is so nasty. I wish I could unsee it' I am a Liberal minded avid film fan and it ajes alot for me to be so dalning of a film, but I feel so strongly about it I want to warn as many people as possible. reviews.review_title: I fear that's where it's all gone wrong.
reviews.content: 'The Banshees Of Inisherin (2022)' is a bleak black comedy about, as star Colin Farrell puts it, "the disintegration of joy" that occurs when a man's best friend decides he just doesn't like him anymore. The picture's overwhelming domesticity doesn't dilute its absolute devastation, instead making it that much more impactful. It's as funny as it is unsettling, an absurdly desperate attempt to prevent the inevitable end of everything one holds dear and preserve some sort of blissful balance. Though deliberately mundane, there is nothing dull about the picture's quaint period setting. In fact, it makes its narrative all the more compelling, taking the kind of feuds normally reserved for much more obviously genre fare and planting them firmly in the milieu of day-to-day life. Everyone brings their A-game here, from the excellent actors to the writer-director to the donkeys and dogs; it represents quite possibly career-best efforts from Martin McDonagh (whose screenplay refreshingly shows a mature restraint often missing from his work), Kerry Condon, Barry Keoghan, Brendan Gleeson and the aforementioned Colin Farrell. Its ending caught me a little of guard, but not because it isn't the perfect place to finish. Instead, it surprised me because I was so involved in the story I could have happily watched it unfold for another hour. Of course, the ambiguity of the ending is key to its success and any further scenes would likely have overstayed their welcome. From the moment it begins, the piece hooks you and doesn't let you go; it's every bit as compelling as any conventional thriller. It's great.

Back in 2008, Writer/Director Martin McDonagh scored an improbable hit with IN BRUGES, a tale of two hitmen "laying low" in...well...Bruges, Belgium while awaiting instructions from their boss. During this down time these two characters muse about the meanings of life and love in a wonderful, Oscar Nominated, character study.15 years later, McDonagh does it again with THE BANSHEES OF INISHERIN.Set in the 1920s in the fictional Island of Inisherin (off the coast of Ireland), BANSHEES reunites Writer/Director McDonagh with his two stars of the previous film - Brendan Gleeson ("Mad Eye" Mooney in the Harry Potter films) and Colin Farrell (unrecognizable as The Penguin in the recent BATMAN movie) - and the resultant character study is just as interesting and intriguing to watch in a setting just as interesting...and breath-takingly beautifully bleak.McDonagh, more than likely, will be nominated (as he was with IN BRUGES) for his screenplay for this film - it IS Oscar worthy - but for me, he was better as the Director of this character study, pointing his camera with a keen eye and surety in what he wanted to show all the while letting the performers and the countryside tell the story.Both lead performers (and the Supporting Actors) are perfectly cast. Farrell, as Padraic,is the protagonist - a simple man who just wants to be able to go to the pub everyday and have conversation with his best friend, Colm (Gleeson) who, one day, proclaims that he no longer wants to be friends with Padraic. Padraic, then spends the rest of the film trying to understand why this is so, what happened and what he can do to make amends.Farrell will earn an Oscar nomination for his portrayal of the simple (but not simple-minded) Padraic who is having a hard time grappling with deeper issues seeping into his simple life. Farrell has really grown into a fine actor and he (at this point in time) has to be considered on of the FrontRunners for the Best Actor Oscar for his work in this film.Just as good is Gleeson as Colm, the recalcitrant, stoic friend who stubbornly wants nothing to do with Padraic. In lesser hands, this character could have come off as "one-note" being, simply, an immovable object in the way of Padraic's irresistible force, but in Gleeson's skilled hands, Colm has layers and depth that seep out through the cracks of his stoney facade. I would not be surprised if Gleeson, too, is nominated for an Oscar (probably in the Supporting category).These two are capably assisted by Kerry Condon (Stacey Ehrmantraut in BETTER CAUL SAUL) and Barry Keoghn (DUNKIRK) as Padraic's sister and a friend of both Padraic and Colm (respectively). Both bring their "A" games to this film and truly show the meaning of the term "Supporting" in "Supporting Performance".Special mention needs to be made for the Cinematography of Ben Davis (GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY) who brings beauty to the bleak, stark and harsh Irish countryside. This cinematography is, actually, another character of this piece and brings strong emotional support to the performances.Not the fastest moving film you will ever see, THE BANSHEES OF INISHERIN is an interesting, intriguing - and beautifully shot - character study that will stay with you long after the film ends.Letter Grade: A-8 Stars (out of 10) and you can take that to the Bank(ofMarquis)

This is a unique and engaging movie that is instigated by the simplest and, in some ways, highly unusual plot. That plot is the spontaneous decision to end their friendship in the 1920's on a remote island in Ireland. Brendan Gleason is the composer who decides to end his friendship with Colin Farrell. Farrell does not understand, or accept, Gleeson's decision and this creates the volatile, tragic, and sometimes laughable chronology of events that unfold in this movie. The movie is beautiful and thoughtfully shot. The small cast is all terrific. Barry Keoghan, of The Killing of The Sacred Deer, steals every scene he is in This is a usual movie that keep you thinking and guessing throughout.

reviews.review_title: Smartly Written - Equally Funny and Cynical
reviews.content: As a huge fan of "In Bruges" and "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri", I was excited to see Martin McDonagh's "The Banshees of Inisherin". The film exceeded my expectations, not only because it feels more mature and focused in its storytelling than McDonagh's previous works, but also because it is more character driven and strikes the perfect balance between tragedy, human foibles, and acerbic, laugh-out-loud humor. This is quite the dark, cynical story to be sure, but at times I was cracking up at the behavior and motivations of the characters.Two life-long best friends, played by Colin Farrell (in what might be his best performance to date) and Brendan Gleeson, live on the small Irish island of Inisherin and hit up the local pub every day at 2 p.m. Life is rather dull and everyone is privy to everyone else's business - you know, the typical small-town mentality and lack of boundaries. When Colm (Gleeson) decides to abruptly end his friendship with Pádraic (Farrell), the two become slowly disheveled and destructive.The movie explores the deterioration of a friendship, but more so the reasons why people will self-destruct, and is a metaphor for the Irish Civil War. I loved the allegorical undertones in the movie such as the personification of Death in one particular character and all of the death motifs throughout. It's a movie that seems simple at first, but once you peel back all the layers, it's deeply poignant, sad, and packs an emotional wallop.

reviews.review_title: Revels in that trademark Irish self-loathing with both funny and tragic results
reviews.content: "The Banshees Of Inisherin" is a black comedy film written and directed by Martin McDonagh ("In Bruges", "Seven Psychopaths", "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri"). Starring Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon, and Barry Keoghan, it revels in that trademark Irish self-loathing with both funny and tragic results.In 1923 in the small town of Inisherin, Ireland, Padraic (Colin Farrell) notices that his longtime drinking buddy Colm (Brendan Gleeson) has suddenly started ignoring him. Confronting his old friend on the matter, Padraic learns that Colm finds him dull and instead wishes to spend his time composing music for something to be remembered by. Shocked by this unexpected revelation, Padraic urgently enlists the help of his sister Siobhan (Kerry Condon) and local man Dominic (Barry Keoghan) to repair this fractured friendship, ignoring Colm's desperate pleas to simply be left alone.With only three prior feature films under his belt, Martin McDonagh has proven himself to be one of the most unique filmmakers working today. All three of those movies provide a pessimistic yet often amusing look at human nature and how we deal with the unpredictable oddities that life throws our way. How McDonagh achieves this is through a signature brand of dark humour that only the Irish could ever manage to pull off. Five years after delivering the fantastic "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri", McDonagh returns to his Irish roots with "The Banshees of Inisherin", a darkly comical tale that contains all the elements of what made his previous work so entertaining in the first place.It is practically common knowledge by now that the Irish have lived through many difficult periods throughout history, ranging from famines to civil wars. Yet, despite all their misfortunes, they have still found ways to find the humorous side to whatever plights they may be experiencing - a true testament to their resilience. What "Banshees" does is apply this to the failing friendship of two longtime friends and deconstructs what caused things to go south so arbitrarily. As depressing a concept as this may sound, here it is treated in such a droll, laidback way that you can't help but snicker at some of the snide remarks that the characters are throwing at one another.For instance, we see that Padraic considers himself a nice guy who is well liked by the town and otherwise hasn't a care in the world. However, when his old friend Colm tells him that he no longer wants anything to do with him, Padraic's perfect vision for himself is shattered. Instead of finding a constructive way to move on, Padraic essentially makes the whole situation much worse by constantly harassing poor Colm at every opportunity in a feeble attempt to return things to the good old days. There's an understandable level of pathos to Padraic's actions, in that while you know he isn't doing the right thing, you get why he's doing it. It is never easy to lose a friend, something I can definitely say from personal experience, so it's a natural human response to try to fix things by any means necessary. Because of that, Padraic is portrayed as both sympathetic and pitiful at the same time, which makes him a much more well-rounded character.It's fun to see how Martin McDonagh uses his clever script to play into the stereotypes of a remote Irish town. Most of the film's humorous moments came from the banal routine the people are following in a place so far away from the rest of civilisation. I found myself chuckling at some of the monotonous and redundant conversations the characters were having with one another, usually over something trivial like where somebody left their pint of beer in the pub. What's interesting is that all of the comedy had an organic flow to it, as in whenever something funny was said, it occurred through an ordinary exchange between people and not a random one-liner inserted for the sake of comic relief. For me, this comes across as a more natural way to do comedy, by making the audience feel like they are watching dialogue between real people, as opposed to an unrealistic sitcom structure where the characters pause for a laugh track to be added later on.Colin Farrell feels right at home in the role of Padraic, and I don't mean that merely because he's Irish. As previously mentioned, there's a relatable pathos to Padraic's character, which Farrell is able to pull off perfectly. Even though somebody like Colm views him as "dull", the audience can see that in spite of the flaws in Padraic's personality, his heart is always in the right place. It's a tricky process to balance pity with likeability, something that most other actors would end up slipping into either/or, but I was impressed at how Farrell was able to achieve it so well. To explain it here wouldn't do it justice so I suggest viewing his performance for yourself to understand what I mean.I also thought Brendan Gleeson did a great job as Colm, complimenting Farrell's role as the antithesis to Padraic. Here is a man whose questionable mental state is made even worse by a former friend who just refuses to take the hint to stay away. Though it is clear that Colm is the one who is in the wrong for starting this entire ordeal, his key reasoning, which I won't disclose due to spoilers, at least makes sense from a logical standpoint. The film's tragic element comes from the ultimate result of Padraic's repeated harassment of Colm, leading to one of the film's saddest scenes.However, I don't think the film would have worked half as well without both Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan in their respective supporting roles. Condon provides the film's emotional anchor as Siobhan, Padraic's sympathetic sister. I really enjoyed her scenes with her brother, particularly the ones where she tries in vein to help him rekindle things with Colm, often indirectly contributing to worsening a situation. Likewise, Keoghan becomes an unlikely voice of reason as Dominic, a local man who ends up as a stand-in friend for Padraic. These two each held their own alongside Farrell and Gleeson, bringing out the best in both the lead performances in addition to their own.As a black comedy, "The Banshees of Inisherin" works simply due to the fact that the Irish are masters of this genre. There's a lot to admire in the way they are able to find humour in even the direst of circumstances, and this film is clear proof of that. Even if you don't find the film funny at all, you can at least appreciate the well-written characters and examination of friendships from an entertainment angle. Just those reasons alone make the film a success in my book.I rate it 8/10.

I'm 25 and I thought I trust the good reviews and go watch this movie with my friends. It was so extremely boring, I HAD TO GO OUT OF THE CINEMA, BECAUSE I COULD NOT TAKE THE BORENESS. I feel like my money was stolen and the makers of these movie were also stealing my time, so basically the makers of this movie are criminals for making such as a bad movie. Why? What do I freaking care about the friendship of some old guy and another guy who is even older in the middle of the Irish nowhere??? I'm not paying an expensive movie ticket to see some boring dialogues and a bit of mountains??? If I want to see nature, I'll watch a documentary or go into nature myself. YOU STOLE MY MONEY AND WASTED MY TIME!

So, this is a strange one. I don't think I really got it. I will probably return to it later and watch it again and see if I understand it any better the second time.For the first half of "The Banshees of Inisherin", I was thinking that it might be the most Irish movie ever. The way the characters talk and behave, with easy familiarity with Irish slang and turns of phrase, makes it feel genuine and you catch up with it immediately. Irish English is like poetry, especially in conversation with others who speak it.At first, what's strange about the movie is that the plot seems to be about something relatively insignificant: a guy's lifelong friend telling him he doesn't want to be friends anymore. It is later in the movie that it takes a turn so bizarre that it made me think of other recent Colin Farrell flicks, namely "The Lobster" and "Killing of a Sacred Deer".McDonagh doesn't normally deal with the totally impossible, however. The gruesome acts of self-mutilation that we see are possible, but also disturbing and unlikely, and most of the characters seem unfazed by it, as though it's not totally crazy.The movie looks great. It's photographed amazingly. And it kept me mostly entertained. I was in it for the dialogue. McDonagh might write the best dialogue in film. I just couldn't swallow a lot of the goings-on in this movie. It seemed too bizarre to care about or take seriously.

reviews.review_title: A good normal chatting would never be pointless.
reviews.content: The Banshees of Inisherin.Two lifelong friends find themselves at an impasse when one abruptly ends their relationship, with alarming consequences for both of them.I'm literally stunned, visually and emotionally after this beautiful and hurtful experience .The banshees of Inisherin is a movie that will stick to my mind for a long long time and I wasn't even considering such a thing !It's about friendship, niceness and ambition.Being ambitious about something shouldn't make you change, being nice is unconditional and friendship is as simple and beautiful as it can be on of the most complicated relationships, because nothing gathers two men, two friends besides having a good normal chat that it would never be pointless .I'm still surprised, a terrific dark comedy and storytelling, everything in this movie was stunning, but when you think about how it started,you may start think it is just silly , yeah you may! I DIDN'T .I was truthfully drowned in every detail of the film, Martin McDonagh and the great dialogs that he wrote, the even greater frames, this man did really a great job .We're not done yet, what about a bunch of unbelievable performances? Colin Ferrell, Brenden Gleeson ,Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan .I won't be happy tomorrow if a single one of these actors haven't gotten a performance nomination at the Oscar nominations announcement .Now, I can confirm that I might have been mistaken, for saying that Austin Butler in "Elvis" will absolutely win the Oscar, I still hope he will, but Colin is as worthy as Austin is ,and I'm looking forward to see Brendan Fresar in "The Whale".The Bar scene though...

The story basically dull .Great cast and area fantastic and director was brilliant but the story guys really got be more to ireland then this

In the pub I thought yes this is changing it course going get great but nope more dullness
Once you hear Oscar contender it never to much to except.On paper I'd think the writer was a bit mad because to read this satire you wonder how it was a film.Fantastic cinematic direction
Brilliantly acted
But don't except to much
Watch with an open mind.

reviews.review_title: It's a movie about human nature, about men
reviews.content: I found it very hard to penetrate what this movie was about until the last act, when it clicks.Martin McDonagh made some of the best films I ever saw. In Bruges is one of my favourites. So when I saw this, I was excited. Why? Because, unlike most movies that hit in something primal with their music, spectacle and awe, his movies hit in some different place, a place where most movies don't.First it's a story about peculiar decisions, seemingly broken friendship, some dark humour along with it. But as it goes, movie turns into something else. It turns into stubborn one sided tug of war, dark humour follows still. But then it turns again, this time, there is no humour, there is only darkness.A spark of despair within any man, some succumb to it, most don't. When they do however, it's not grand or a spectacle, most of the time. But it can be disturbing in how men can sometimes do completely demented things, void of any reason or stops. I've rarely seen this in women, very rare. Men will sit, reason with it and decide the most idiotic stubborn course of action, despite the intellect, social standing or circumstance they are in.Disappointmment in friendship as a concept and time invested in people is also a theme, maybe as a base for all this. Sometimes you just realise things are maybe way worse than you thought they were. And then you find that you wasted time, emotions and maybe took it all too nonchalant and now you have nothing. And it's not easy.Maybe I'm completely missing the point, maybe I'll get something completely different when I rewatch it down along the line. But for now, this is it.Acting and technical aspects of the movie are good, if that's the thing you need to know.I don't know, it's not for everyone but I would also like to recommend it to everyone.

The acting is superb, but that is where the accolades end.This film is boring, dreary and meaningless. The plot is thin, lacks any kind of depth or shape. It is pure Oscar bate.At best it's a poor attempt at an art film, unfortunately at times it's closer to a low budget horror than it is anything Oscar worthy!I have honestly never been so bored watching a film, it is genuinely unbelievably dull. I really wanted to like this film & really tried to see what everyone else raves about. But alas I came up empty. It's awful!If you want a decent dark comedy drama with Colin Farrell & Brendon Gleeson then watch In Bruges. It is infinitely better than this nonsense!

reviews.review_title: Tedious, Cliched, Gratuitously Violent; A Disappointment
reviews.content:
Terrible. Don't waster your time. The setting and cinematography were good. The actors did the best they could with what they were given, which wasn't much. It wasn't funny (except for a handful of lines), deep, coherent, interesting, had no believable motivations, had offered nothing about the human condition. The writer seems to fall back on shock and clichés (especially about Ireland--I have family there and have spent time in the rural West) to wake the audience up and be of the moment...child abuse, the gay (as implied) Catholic priest, the bullying cop, the cute farm animal who must suffer, the drinking of booze or beer every single day from early afternoon onward, the frustrated young spinster, the enigmatic musician, the enigmatic crone, the pitiable orphans, the village idiot,
etc., etc.Dull, depressing, boring, and gratuitously violent. After a half-hour or so I couldn't believe how bad it was. The production values were good and the writer gets off a handful of witty lines. But nothing happens except trips to the pub or village store and back home, a lot of whining, a few violent episodes attempting to wake you up.Because this movie is so strange and random and offers nothing uplifting during the current difficult times, it will probably get a bunch of awards. I give it two stars for the scenery, the sets, and several leads' (wasted) acting abilities.

reviews.review_title: long time ago on a small island by the ocean
reviews.content: Well it is a good watch...but is it new?...in bruges was new, original and sincere...this one lacks those features...a beautiful setting but almost too beautiful and somehow far from the problems of the mainland...main characters appear one by one...actors act professionally, no problem doing their jobs...both gleeson and farrell top notch...but the script misses to explain why the characters take the steps that they take?...what is the reason for the conflict and solution...after all a big disappointment...feels as mcdonagh took the easy way and stuck to the tested formula that brought him success.

I am very confident that I know how this movie was written. In a detention class full of potentially sociopathic 12 year olds; one took a piece of paper wrote a paragraph, then passed it a long to the next and then the next until they arranged the basic plot of this film. The writing was then taken to a script writing class at a local community college where the professor asked their students to polish the ramblings into a movie script that symbolized a civil war that occurred 100 years ago. The worst one was chosen. Superb acting though. And beautifully shot. It makes me want to drink stout beer.

The cinematic double act of Irish actors Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson returns after several years in a sometimes tragic, with elements of black comedy and acts of depravity including finger mutilation! A story of male friendship set in a 1923 Irish, island off the mainland fictional environment where the simple locals don't often have such experiences. 1923 was a period of civil war in Ireland where once friends became enemies, a forerunner of the plotline?Farrell plays a likeable character Pádraic Súilleabháin who is bewildered one day when a supposed best friend Colm Doherty (Gleeson) just blanks him and makes it clear he wants their friendship to come to a parting of ways as such.What follows is an hour or so of dark comedy as Colm threatens and goes through with a threat to remove his fingers one by one each time Pádraic attempts any kind of contact.Director Martin McDonagh brings some of his stage writing and production of The Aran Islands Trilogy to craft a film that gives splendid material for the cast rightly earning several Acadamy Award nominations for their performances.The photography of the fictional island of Inisherin reminded me of films like The Wicker Man (1973) and Local Hero (1983) with its photography and production design, the crew upping the ante of the film.Some scenes are simply gross and add to the black comedy providing supporting actors some input into the film. These include island 'dullard' Dominic and his drunken police officer dad who masturbates into the night, yes you read that right.Excellent support is also given by Pádraics sister Siobhán played by Kerry Condon. More intellectual than her brother and planning on moving to the mainland.Conclúid is the Irish meaning of conclusion. The film ends with near tragedy and a questionable ending as old wounds are barely healed. Revel in the film, you won't regret the journey.

reviews.review_title: Superb Acting in this Dark Comedy
reviews.content: Odd and offbeat, The Banshees of Inisherin is an excellent tale of lost friendship. Slowly paced at times whilst still entertaining in its calmness, each main character is developed well and justified in their own actions. Sharply turning the theme into a darker context as the film progresses, it may not be a film for the squeamish, but the emotional arcs and connection created with the island's inhabitants keeps the audience engrossed in the conclusions of a bittersweet friendship/rivalry.The acting throughout is superb. Farrell is perfect as the somewhat simple, yet loyal and kind, Pádraic. His emotions shine in such an endearing character as the film follows the highs and lows his friendship with Gleeson brings. Keoghan is also brilliant. No doubt some audiences will need subtitles to follow his dialogue, but his challenging character is another who invokes strong fondness. The whole cast are great, and it's good to see real accents portrayed.Visually the film is stunning. Captured by the mood of the plot, the Irish island can display beauty and despair. This is well accompanied by the soundtrack.Offbeat and equal measures of dark and comedic, The Banshees of Inisherin is an artistic joy.

reviews.review_title: Amused & disturbed at the same time
reviews.content: Nobody does black comedy like sir martin here. The plot may have seem rather simplistic and yet I cannot peal my eyes away from the screen the entire time, that is also attributed by the stellar performance of the four main cast. I think this just became my favorite Colin Farrel movie, his portrayal just shines so much here. What started as an amusing comedy who then turned slightly disturbing and later on verging on horror (at least for me) this is one of the best drama that came out in 2022. Absolutely love the cinematography of this movie, the rich rocky landscapes of ireland and the colouring is done so beautifuly. This movie deserves all the awards, truly bravo.

OK, so as many other reviewers have said, there are great performances, and beautiful scenery of this imaginary island, but boy YAWN it is slow. I immediately had two problems: What do these people do for a living? The pints are flowing but I never see money change hands. Other than the two jugs of milk, does everyone make money ofd fishing? Why not show more of it. Sevindly, there's the the self injury Colm does. With sheep shears? Really? And it apparently didn't hurt very much or bleed much, like he was trimming his nails? I would have been laid up for weeks. That part could be the comedy of it all.

reviews.review_title: Dont lose your kindness (niceness). Metaphor for war
reviews.content: Wow. The performance in this film by all the actors in phenomenal. Wonderful beautiful visuals. The landscapes of the island are too beautiful and it hands a hold on you, like the way water has on an island. The story and its parallels with the war. The fight on nothing and it costs both sides a great deal of pain and misery. Additionally, someone totaly innocent gets in the crossfire. This is the same what happens with the fight of two best friends. It doesnt matter, who wins, or not. It is the friendship, honesty, trust, niceness we lost. Sometimes I think it is streched a bit but then so are the wars. So it is a perfect metaphor for that. The dread of not becoming known, successful or someone who will remember you after death. It is real. But to have a frightening thing to guide you to reach the goal. We forget, it is the journey that matters not the destination. The sisters story is having a great arc. Knowing you want better for your life. But to leave the homeland you have to left somethung behind. Even if it is something you love. Highly recommend this to my film mutuals. Not for everyone though.
