reviews.review_title: Talent galore in front and behind the camera make a marvelous film
reviews.content: A film that is funny, moving, sad, shocking and unusual is not your average film and this wonderful film isn't. It's beautifully filmed, written, acted, photographed and scored. We all know the basic plot. A best friend (Brendon Gleeson) of another (Colin Friend) who have lived their entire lives on a small Irish island no longer wants to retain this long friendship. He says he doesn't like him anymore because he's dull and boring, but my take is that is just not true. He does still like him, though he might indeed find him a bit boring, and he certainly cares about him, but the character Gleeson plays is getting old and he wants his life to mean something and he doesn't want to spend the rest of his time on earth doing the exact same thing day in, day out and it's near impossible to change this routine on a remote island in the 1920's. I get it. He might also be going a bit mad. The acting in this film by everyone is perfect, but we have four principles who will just knock your socks off. Colin Farrell gives one of the best performances of his career, if not the best, and he will break your heart a little. Brendan Gleeson, always excellent, plays his role perfectly. Kerry Condon as Farrell's intelligent sister is a kind and wonderful force to behold and very funny at times. And then there is the always interesting and very unusual Barry Keoghan who just about steals every scene he is in. He is a marvel to watch here. I loved In Bruges & enjoyed Three Billboards, but this might be Martin McDonagh's best film. This is an extremely talented man.Is there anything I didn't like? Yes. I would have liked to have known more about one of the principle's deaths. It was barely touched upon and just passed by quickly. I have my own take on this tragedy which is different than the slight one mentioned, though I've no idea if I'm correct, but I will choose to accept it. Make of the ending what you will as it's up for debate, but I loved this film flaws and all.

reviews.review_title: Cannot stop thinking about this film.
reviews.content: Was COMPLETELY UNPREPARED for the emotional heft of this amazing, original film. Colin Farrell, Kerry Condon and AMAZING Barry Keoghan are phenomenal. It's Joycean, Beckettesque, very sad and deeply moving. It's probably an allegory about Ireland. It's about friendship, personal knowledge, small community, the intellectual life, the value of art, guilelessness, and the terrible paradox of knowledge of the human condition. I desperately want to see it again *for the first time* but if I watch it again I will cry from tbe beginning. Jessie 💔. Dominic. 💔💔 Padraigh 💔💔💔 Stunning writing and acting.

I love Martin McDonagh. In Bruges was one of the best movies I've seen in the past 20 years. Then he makes Seven Psychopaths (which is my personal favorite of his.) which technically wasn't better written or acted but drop dead funny and very clever. Three Billboards Outside Ebbing Missouri was the film that put him on lists with the Tarantino's and the PTA's of the world and deservingly so. That film was brilliant but also just a little off. It was realistic of the American south but also surreal and fantastical.You add all these aspects up into his 4th film, The Banshees of Inisherin. Clever writing, wickedly hilarious dialogue & on of the best acting ensembles of the year make up one of the best films of the year. Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson & Kerry Condon are absolutely brilliant and i can't picture any other 3 actors being in these roles. They were absolutely perfect from beginning to end. The story itself, again as with McDonagh is surreal yet grounded. The dialogue maybe his funniest of his career while also being his most serious. Also mostly his best directing work of his career.Now you may be asking why this review is getting a 7 and i can only tell you that by the films end I just didn't feel good about what i watched. This is a depressing film no matter how much it made me laugh. Something was keeping me from loving it. And the ending didn't do it any favors. It mostly fizzles out with the last 10 minutes. It was building the entire time to something amazing. I thought it was going to be a masterpiece until the 3rd act. It just kind of ends with nothing being resolved.This movie is absolutely one of the best of 2022 and i hope it's a big awards winner especially for the actors and Martin McDonagh is now in the top 5 filmmakers working today. I only wish the 3rd act could've wrapped up what was a masterpiece. Please Martin, don't make us wait 5 years for your next film!

reviews.review_title: An Allegory for the Irish Civil War
reviews.content: I don't think Banshees holds a candle up to In Bruges or even Three Billboards, on either the comedic front or the emotional front, but it definitely feels like a more intellectual and allegorical piece than anything McDonagh has done (or maybe it's just more obvious here than in his other works). As I mentioned, it was great seeing McDonagh, Farrell and Gleeson teaming up again and I sincerely hope it's not the last we see of them together. Banshees has some definite awards contenders for acting and writing, but as a movie as a whole it didn't wow me as much as I had hoped. I'm sure multiple viewings would help elevate it for me, but it's also not a movie I'm in a particular rush to go back and revisit. I give Banshees a solid 8/10.QyrosMovies.

reviews.review_title: An excellent cinematography that lacks poetry
reviews.content: A film that doesn't even deserve an Oscar nomination. Way too much praise for a cinematic achievement that says almost nothing interesting.The only really successful part is the cinematography, it's excellent. The acting is good, sometimes theatrical, forced, mostly everything feels unnatural. The script is full of gaps, you don't understand who comes from where, what their past is. Some dialogues have interpersonal relevance, they say something about friendship, about bad attachments and about the relational falsity between people.It is a strange film that does not deserve its praise. It's worth seeing once for the cinematography and that's it. A forced film that definitely does not say anything special. Too technical, lacking the essence of cinema. Mediocre to boring.

Martin McDonagh's latest film is a tragicomedy set on a island off the coast of 1920's Ireland, that can be both sharply witty and humourous and also very bleak and depressing. Like his last movie Three Billboards, 'Banshees of Inisherin' doesn't fully explain or resolve certain aspects of the plot or characters, rather leaving it to the audience to think about and derive their own meaning. I believe this to be wholly intentional on the writer's part. So don't go in to this movie expecting to understand everything by the end, or you may leave disappointed.Although this film doesn't reveal everything on a first watch, don't think this is some artsy-fartsy, metaphorical slog to sit through. I found this to be an absolute blast, with well-written and interesting characters, great humour and a plot that always kept me guessing and on the edge of my seat to see what happens next. There are plenty of laughs to be had, but as the narrative continues it takes a rather dark turn, with major consequences for certain characters leading to a few genuinely heartbreaking scenes.The acting in this movie was honestly flawless, I believed every single character in this movie -especially Colin Farrell, who maybe gave his best performance yet. Believe the Oscar buzz. The chemistry between his character and Brendan Gleeson's stony-faced and troubled Colm was brilliant, they both played off each other extremely well and as the stakes rise and become more desperate you can really feel for both of them and understand both their motivations. The script is sharp and quite detailed, as an Irishman myself I think McDonagh nails the banter and dialogue down to a T.I genuinely feel like this is one of the best movies of the year, and although I didn't quite understand it fully by the end, it was still an absolute blast and an emotional rollercoaster and left me with a lot to think about to form my own conclusions. If you go in with ZERO expectations, it's a hell of a ride. Would recommend.

reviews.review_title: If you don't get the Irish
reviews.content: For someone born in England, Martin McDonagh writes a brilliantly observational movie that cuts to the heart of the Irish people and culture - their propensity for love, their ability to hold a grudge, their wont to fight each other in absence of anyone better to fight. The humour is understated and an aside to the tribulations of the characters, even though it reflects the very best of why we love the Irish.The drama and tragedy are very real and wholly relatable to those who have, or are experiencing, mid-life existential crises - who am I, what have I achieved, what is my legacy? All very real questions that are brilliantly played out by Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan.A mixture of craic tempered with a healthy dose of real life are a winning formula.

I'm a big fan or Colin Farrell - he acted well in this but there was no plot & extremely slow - 2 guys not getting along isn't enough of a premise for a movie - I was bored to tears - the landscape was beautiful but certainly not enough to carry a very basic story - I was very disappointed.Why the hype & high scores on here - I have no clue? I have no idea what people would have seen in this movie that I didn't? What were their expectations - perhaps they look for dull & uneventfulI watch a lot of movies & expect quite a bit more - often times hard to understand the Irish accent - that's not the issue here though.

reviews.review_title: Great acting, fine script and awesome scenery
reviews.content:
Am a McDonagh fan, loved Three Billboards! Was hoping I wouldn't be disappointed with this new film, and thankfully I wasn't. It's was a great movie. Dark in spots , some humour and insight into Ireland of years gone by. Great ensemble cast.Farrell is superb, deserves an Oscar nomination at least. Gleeson always underrated. The rest of the cast are excellent - particularly Keoghan. The locations are beautiful , but then I'm biased, being fro the West.This a real movie about real people, not like most of the stuff we see in the cinema. Underwear inside their trousers ! 😀
Go and see it! Thought provoking is my final comment.

reviews.review_title: Not what I expected at all!
reviews.content: So having seen the trailers for this you could be forgiven for thinking it was a straight up black comedy revolving around a pair of 40/50-something Irishmen and their devolving dysfunctional friendship.Having now seen the film, yeeeeeeees, that's what it's about... sort of, a bit.Without applying enough spoilers to warrant the tag, what you actually get is part black comedy, part social commentary with a little bit of harrowing despair thrown in for good measure. Sadly, the despair is what I took away from this, and what I remember now while the black comedy elements and at the time genuinely funny situational jokes have faded into the background noise.I enjoyed it while I was watching it, but it's not a feel good romp, it's not even really a comedy and there's parts of it that still make me a little sad thinking back on it 24 hours later.Would not recommend if you're expecting to be amused. Would recommend if you want a film more akin to Three Billboards or In Bruges.

Why? If the writer and director wanted to show how sad, futile, and depressing life is in this film he succeeded. But why? Why use such a beautiful natural setting? The contrast of the beautiful scenery and the despair in the characters is profound. More then profound it is disturbing. Why show heart breaking characters that just wander in and out of each other's lives exposing each other's flaws, weaknesses and hopelessness? There are no good characters with redeeming qualities. So what was the point? There was nothing comedic in this film. It is just a dark fatally
flawed look at life that has no redeeming qualities.

This is one of the worse films I have ever watched. It has absolutely no redeeming features it is unbelievably sad and pointless. I thought the scenery was nice but it soon paled against the ridiculously stupid plot and story line. I've seen many films in my time but this ranks among the very poorest. I strongly recommend that if you're considering watching this film you should seriously consider washing your car with a toothbrush or cutting your lawn with nail scissors, either would be far better uses of you time and energy. My other half has gone to bed and as soon as I have written this review, my first, to hopefully help others, I shall follow.

reviews.review_title: A curious allegory of human relationships
reviews.content:
Set on 1923 on a fictitious island near the coast
of an Ireland gripped by civil war, this is the story of the disintegration of the friendship between dim, dull Padraic and fiddle-player Colm. The latter unilaterally instigates the split as he is fed up with Padraic's banalities and wants to concentrate on composing music. The consequences of his choice comprise most of the film.The actions and behaviour of some of the characters are not realistic. This film makes more sense as an allegory on the fickle nature of human relationships, and the futility and slow collapse of society. Hence the several references to the ongoing war across the water, the most profound of which is by the island's policeman, who is confused as to what the conflict is all about.The cinematography is superb, the film is very well directed and the acting is top-notch from both leads. Kerry Condon is very good as Padraic's much smarter but disenchanted sister, but Barry Keoghan is superb as Dominic, the village idiot who is abused by his policeman father.Where the film falls down a little is in the script. It bounces around from slow, tedious and repetitive at times to moments of inspired observation. There are several attempts at humour thrown in for good measure, but only some succeed. Overall the narrative is inconsistent and has a somewhat childish overall feel about it, which lets down an otherwise beautifully crafted film.

Love both actors, but did they have no input with writers or directors? I'm being generous with 3 stars. No one behaves this way in real life! Loved "The Bruges", so I thought I would watch this. Without Colin, I wouldn't have made it after 30 minutes. Started to read reviews and realized it wasn't going to get any better. People don't watch movies to be more more depressed. They watch to feel better. Every time a director takes a bad/dark turn it never goes well, but they continue to try, and fail! "It's a Breautiful Life" was a great movie until the end. Never watched again!!!! Depressing, bad!! :(

This film sort of ruined my night. I was going to catch up on some series I had saved after watching this. But I couldn't watch anythng esle afterwards. I was comletely sated. And grateful. This is one of those films that makes me marvel at the power of cinema. And great acting. A perfect blend of humor, drama and tragedy. This would have been a 10 but for the very last segment which, while I get it and understand it was a necessary part of the story, sort of detracted from the dramatic impact of what I thought was the conclusion. No spoliers but those who aready saw it know what I mean. Gratitude to all who were involved in this amazing piece of work.

reviews.review_title: Irelands and islands, and the people on them
reviews.content: "The Banshees of Inisherin" is a fairly new movie that comes close to the two-hour mark and here we have a co-production between Great Britain, the United States and Ireland. If you look at several factors from the production of this film, the Irish impact is really dominant here. This includes the cast, includes where the film is set, includes the man who wrote and directed the film and includes the heavy accents you hear from beginning to end. This is one of the biggest awards players this season. It won over 100 honors, was nominated for over 300 more, so it comes close to a total of 500 nominations and maybe it will even exceed this magical number at some point. It scored nine Oscar nominations and not winning a single Academy Award seems highly unlikely. Especially the screenplay has a good shot and I think the supporting actress category is now maybe a 50-50 thing between Condon and Angela Bassett, but we will see. Whoever wins the SAG Award is surely the frontrunner then. Colin Farrell won a Golden Globe, but he may have a hard time at the Oscars against Butler and Fraser. Keoghan's BAFTA win came a bit out of nowhere really and we will see how it goes at the Oscars then. I still feel like the clear frontrunner so far will not lose to Keoghan or anybody else. If anybody had predicted this film to win said category, I am sure Gleeson would have been the odds-on favorite. I am not super surprised though. I like Gleeson a lot, but he has several better performances, still cool that he got in at the Oscars. McDonagh always has a talent to direct his actors to Oscar nominations, maybe even wins and four people being nominated again this time is surely evidence of that, even if one win would already be a nice achievement. No easy frontrunner here like McDormand and Rockwell, but again he got two males nominated in the supporting category.I like McDonagh, he has a pretty great body of work and I must still say this film here, his newest, is not even remotely close to being my favorite of his. Of course, given all the Irish impact here, it has to be a very personal project and I am glad it got made and I am also glad I saw it today. The one thing he always succeeds with is dark comedy. There were some laugh-out-loud moments here in the first half really from this perspective. Also some in the second half, but there it got a tad more dramatic. I mean one character cutting off all the fingers from his hand is telling enough I would say. Or a really awesome donkey dying. Jenny would definitely have been nominated for an animal Oscar this year. I just wanna hug her. But I am a huge donkey fan anyway. It is a good year for donkey movies for sure as "EO" a bit surprisingly to me also found its way to an Oscar nomination in the foreign language feature category or whatever it is called nowadays. In addition to this, it is a good year for Irish films as there is a film from this country in the same category as well, even if it is maybe the least likely from the quintet to win. Still a huge success if we see over which films it got in there, for example a new Asian film by a very renowned director. But back to the Banshees now: I already talked about the comedy here and I feel kinda bad for people who did not find any of this funny, the ones who go down to the basement to have a laugh as we say in Germany. Sad creatures. So I hope you will smile at least while seeing this film, but here and there you actually have to laugh I am sure too. McDonagh is just really great in terms of situational comedy and dialogue writing. Always has been, always will be. I could give you a double-digit number of examples, but I will just stick to one now and that was when Farrell's character enters Gleeson's character's home and says he is not here for lickin' when the latter's dog approaches him and licks his fingers. This scene, however, also results into some of the biggest drama because as a consequence one character cuts off all the fingers from his hand then and one of them is eaten by the aforementioned donkey, well not eaten but he dies from trying to eat it, so tragedy galore there. Of course, the parallel between fingers being licked and being cut off is also a fairly dark one.As for the dog, that one was also really amazing of course. It had its moment when it tried to carry the scissors away from Gleeson's character. That was one tough bloke though. He seems to feel no pain after cutting his fingers off. I did not even know you would not bleed to death then literally, but he seems alright. They also put away the idea that he is dying or that he is depressed, even if there were in a way mentions of the latter when he was talking to the local priest. Overall though, there is no fake melodrama in here and McDonagh made this clear from the very start. It seems as if Gleeson's character really just thinks about his life not being fulfilling and memorable enough and that is why he has to cut ties and focus on creativity, music in his case really. Still, honestly, when he is there towards the end with the other musicians and he has no fingers any more, but still makes wild gestures, you could wonder if he had really lost his mind. In the end then, when Farrell's character takes revenge for his donkey, it is all about the question if Gleeson's character will leave his home or not. Is he ready to die? The solution is that he is not, but that the two are then in a way enemies, even if one is always ready and willing to look after the other's animal. Maybe it was these events that had to happen for Farrell's character to be really ready to let Gleeson's go then. These two actors also starred in "In Bruges" together, a movie that got also made by McDonagh and that one I liked more for example, but only because it was quite great and this one here is just good. It did not suck or anything. McDonagh has worked with both actors on other occasions like "Seven Psychopaths" or the short film that was his first work almost 20 years ago, a movie with Gleeson in the lead, that won McDonagh a short film Oscar.As for the title of this new film here, I am undecided. Inisherin is a location where the cliffs and the sea are as rough as the people, but with Banshees I just don't know. I thought from how the word is used in a video game that it would describe death fairies and that would fit at least one mysterious character we see on a few occasions, but they just translated it with "ghosts" here. Perhaps not so perfect. Anyway, back to the cast: Farrell and Keoghan also worked on a film together, one without McDonagh, that one turned into a success, so even for them it is a reunion. Keoghan looks so young anyway, I would not have thought he is over 30 anyway. His character then towards the end becomes tragic and before that he is referenced mostly as the village idiot and this twist then, fueled by his violent police officer dad, shows us that there was more to the character than we thought. He was disappointed in Farrell's character, he found out that the woman he likes (okay, he likes many) is not romantically interested in him and also he had to constantly face violence at home. There is far more to this young man than comic relief. Nice to see the BAFTAs recognize it. How he went though, I think we can say it was most likely suicide with the story his dad tells us and the nosy store owner earlier. As for Kerry Condon, I liked her character a lot. I thought she was smart and also pretty and it is nice she managed to get away from the island that held her back and had a future on the continent then. Maybe she will meet her brother again, maybe not. I feel like there will be a reunion. I also thought it made sense that he did not write her about the donkey's fate, on the one hand because he was still hurting and on the other hand because he did not want her to worry about him as she knew how much the animal meant to him. He was happy for his sister to have made that big step and did not want her to take it back, even if he was clearly missing her. And surely he was not the smartest fella as we see when he does not know the word "touché" or when he tells Gleeson's character what he did to his new friend. Definitely not a smart move. One with drastic consequences then.The aforementioned police officer is a very violent man as we see from his actions when he punches the protagonist and hear from his words when he talks about an upcoming execution. One that is politically motivated and he does not even remember who kills whom. But this was surely interesting because if you look at the gunshots being fired in the distance there towards the end, you can absolutely make a connection between the two main characters and the two political groups fighting each other. The comment about how things were easier when they were just fighting the English can be seen as a parallel of struggling with life as a whole, but the more specific mention of the Irish groups can definitely be seen in a way as the fighting between Farrell's and Gleeson's characters. It is also debatable if Gleeson is really supporting. He is on the edge of being a co-lead. Does not have to be a lead as significant as Farrell in here. Another thing that came to my mind is that perhaps McDonagh started enjoying burning down things as fire towards the end already played a big role in his previous movie and also there was a key character in danger of dying in the flames and here it is the same. Still, the one thing that hit maybe closest to home for me was the idea of getting stuff done during your lifetime, the late-life crisis if you wanna call it that, that has so vividly left its mark on Gleeson's character. The elaboration on musicians being remembered centuries later was extremely well-written and also a bit funny again with how he gets the century wrong. That is all then. This film gets a thumbs-up from me, which was never in doubt. I recommend watching "The Banshees of Inisherin".

reviews.review_title: I know very little of the Irish but I like this.
reviews.content: That poor little friendly fellow and his poor donkey. Really there is no good reason for that to have gone down like that.Having gone into this without any idea what to expect was definitely the right call. I had no idea this was set in Ireland until I realized I could barely understand what anybody was saying. It wasn't long until I realized this was not going to be about some random guy and his donkey.One thing I really wish I had was a more expensive knowledge with the Irish Civil War. But it really is nice to get this perspective on it.This story takes place during the Civil War and it involves two neighbors that had been getting along just fine until one day one of the guys just decides he is too good for this friendship. Having had no good reason for cutting contact, of course the other neighbor wants to hang on to the friendship that obviously meant so much more to him. Increasingly extreme measures to separate leads to bloodshed and thus a lifelong rivalry is born out of the stubbornness of the two. And the movie ends with the implication that the two can never be friends again.If you come out of this film thinking it is a good idea for these neighbors to continue being enemies then you don't deserve an opinion.One of my favorite metaphors put to film. True mastery.

Be prepared for a character study that focuses on poverty, despair, friendship and its dissolution, social isolation, leaving home and family, and late blooming ambition.Also be prepared for drop-dead gorgeous photography, terrific music, and world-class acting.Colin Farrell, in my opinion one of the most accomplished actors working in film today, plays his complex role with amazing subtlety. Brendan Gleeson provides another example of his impressive versatility. Kerry Condon portrays a balanced view of the long-suffering sister who must choose between her own needs and those of others.Given the time (1923) and the setting (isolated island off the coast of Ireland from which gunshots of the ongoing civil war can be heard) there are many directions the film could have taken: social commentary, black comedy, farce, cute rural adventure, broad Irish stereotypes, etc.Writer/director Martin McDonagh instead focuses on individual characters as opposed to all-out social or political commentary. Gleeson's character one day decides he doesn't want to be friends anymore with Colin Farrell's character. The results of this falling out take a tragic turn that many will find neither entertaining nor appealing (and certainly not funny).Some might call this a "black comedy" but that's an overly simplistic label. "Tragicomedy" is probably more accurate. I did find myself laughing in a few spots, but these are few.This is a character study that lays bare complex human relationships set against a time and place whose impacts are still rippling today.Were I to compare this film's emotional impact to others I would probably select Paul Schrader's FIRST REFORMED or some of the films of Yasujiro Ozu, but BANSHEES OF INISHERIN stands on its own.

In a day and age where it seems like studios won't get creative anymore this one stands out. It's all about two men who live on a secluded island with not many people around and their relationship. The two are best friends. That is until Brendan Gleeson's character decides he no longer likes Colin Farrell's. He didn't really explain why until he was pushed enough to do so which is really hard for Colin. He's overly nice and he just doesn't understand how their bond can be broken when he didn't do anything wrong. It's a movie most can relate to as they've had to end friendships or just stop talking to certain people to move their life in a better direction. This one takes a sinister twist though so it's worth a watch at least once.

reviews.review_title: Excellent Film and Oscar Worthy for Colin Farrell
reviews.content: Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson star in this tale of what happens when one friend decides he no longer wants to talk to another. This is a very original story that keeps your interest and has great performances, especially Colin Farrell, who plays the hurt and disappointed friend. He is very confused, lonely and frustrated as to what to do about it. While there was offbeat, matter-of-fact humor and was at times very moving (Brendan driving Colin home after Colin had been beat up), this was also very frustrating for me. Why couldn't Colin get the message? He was being accused of being boring. I don't know, but he did seem to be what you would call a simple man and at times seemed a bit dense to the serious situation. On one hand, I could see simplifying your life and separating from things that don't matter, but not at the expense of hurting others. Why did Brendan have to be so cruel and extreme? Why didn't Colin just leave him alone? Also, it seems like their roles had somehow reversed by the end. You feel for Colin when Brendan won't have anything to do with him. But by the end, after Colin get a little extreme, you sympathize for Brendan. I'm not sure exactly what to make of their last conversation and if they are done with each other or not . Having said all that, looking back on it, it seems like a parable or a fable that a parent would tell their child about what not to do in life and to their friends, making this story/film to be a lesson learned for others. This film was successful on many levels, because it makes you think of your friends, your own life, and what you would do in this situation. This was a very deep, thought-provoking, humorous and rewarding film experience, and I have thought of it almost everyday since I saw it. I recommend this for those who like Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson. Austin Butler as Elvis had better watch out for Colin Farrell, who may give him a run for his money and win his first Oscar.

I haven't seen many films that deal with the break up of a friendship, which can be just as devastating as a romantic one. At least not good ones.This latest film by Martin McDonagh is perhaps his quietest and more brooding film to date, and probably his best. Set in a small Irish island during a civil war, Colin Farrell's character cannot understand and is unable to accept the fact that his best friend, Colm (Brendan Gleeson) refuses to speak to him. "I just don't like ya no more." he says. And because of Padraic's persistence at wanting to speak to him, and Colm's fierce and repeated rejection of him, things basically go from bad to worse for the two of them.The great thing about this film is that you can feel very deeply for these two flawed men, and really sympathise with their predicaments, while at the same time shaking your head in disapproval at the things they do. McDonagh has always had that impressive ability to perfectly balance tragedy with comedy, making laugh out loud one minute and reduce you to tears in the next.Because I've also experienced a terrible friendship breakup when I was younger, as well as being an aspiring musician, I could really relate to Farrell's character, and to another extent Gleeson's. It's also an exploration of one friend wanting you and other things to stay the same, while the other is looking for change in his/her life, and therefore is interested in other things, leaving you behind.It is 100% a tragedy, but is also very common in life.

Why are critics praising this film? Have they lost touch with all viewers? Let me guess, like Babylon, this is such a wonderful artistic view of life that the mass audiences are just suppose to appreciate it like a Van Gogh piece of art? A few good shots, some good locations, and Oscar nominated actors doesn't just make a good movie. This was a horribly under-developed story with utterly lacking characters.There are so many ways to show the devastation of the loss of a close friendship, this is not one of them. This film just made me feel like I was watching someone being bullied. I'm not your friend because you aren't as smart as me and now I'm going to mutilate myself because you won't leave me alone. Oh, and to boot, I'm going to destroy your marriage and kill the one thing you care about. And then have a teenage suicide to show that living on an island is hopeless. Funny? Dark comedy? Or just cruel?

As soon as I heard there was a new film out with the duo of Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleason, I knew I wanted to watch it and I knew I would like it, whatever the synopsis was. I love their previous work together (In Bruges) and that is with great credit to director Martin Mcdonagh who has only directed 4 films and all four are amazing and unique. (This, In Bruges, Seven Psychopaths and Three Billboards). Really talented trio who know how to make a proper film.It's also a fresh synopsis. A fresh idea. Best mate decided to one day just try to cut his other best mate out of his life, a situation I myself have unfortunately found myself in, so I can understand the stages of grief and despair that paddy feels and goes through. It shows how quickly something can snowball and although Colm was just trying to make something of himself and his life it has bigger consequences. Gutted Jenny the donkey died but relieved Siobhan and Colm's dog got out unscathed. Don't have much time for the creepy Mrs McCormick and got to feel for the hapless poor Declan.Probably the best film of the year, and it's still January. Deserves all the praise in the world.I feel there is a balance in life, you want to make something of yourself and be remembered but there's no saying you can't be nice at the same time.

Most of the movie audiences around the world think that British, Scottish and Irish actors are American because they know them through American films.While the British should take a lesson from this, many Scottish and Irish actors and actresses in English cinema and theater are thought to be British.Because they cannot use their own colors to match the work presented.But an American actor is always an American.For example; DiCaprio of Italian/German origin, who played the Irishman in the movie Titanic, etc.Fortunately, there are still filmmakers like Martin McDonagh who have made a career by sticking to their roots, but we can watch different stories from the voices of the people who own those stories.That's why each of the actors and actresses in this movie performed well enough to give a masterclass on this subject... They didn't have to get into another role first to get into the role.Although the cinematographer of the movie, Ben Davis, often worked on CGI-filled works (especially Marvel movies), he did wonders in natural light for this movie.Even in the first 5 minutes of the opening of the movie, there are at least 10 scenes that will not look like Rembrandt paintings.Martin McDonagh is a name I fell in love with after watching all his films in the cinema many times and also bought DVD/blu-ray editions. While there is a continuity problem in the success of many of our favorite names in our time, Martin McDonagh raises the bar every time.

Ireland 1921. On a remote island off the mainland two old friends unexpectedly fall out, with very alarming consequences.From the start I knew I was in for something special. This is a story about male friendships, remote places, and the weight of expectations and history. As with McDonagh's previous film, the wonderful 'In Bruges' there's plenty of dark humour here, perhaps though darker than the earlier film. As with the (I think) overrated 'Three Billboards' it's also a quirky tale that takes its time to reveal its full drama, though it does it far more effectively than that film. Colin Farrell is simply brilliant as is Brendan Gleason, and there's a great supporting turn by Barry Keoghan. McDonagh writing and directing is masterful, and manages not to descend into Irish cliche or too much that's folksy, though it does edge close at times. I loved it all, and although the more eccentric plotlines and the odd mildly gory scene might displease or even confuse some, this film worked well for me - I think it's one of the years best.

reviews.review_title: Cinema Omnivore - The Banshees of Inisherin (2022) 7.6/10
reviews.content: "That said, the best among the crop is the lesser-known Kerry Condon, who plays Padraic's long-suffering, spitfire sister Siobhan, and makes her both an exemplar to instantiate that there is a way out of the soul-destroying insularity and monotony, and a contradistinction to Padraic's shiftless trivialness, self-centered neediness and almost reduces him to a regressive man-boy. Condon fires on all cylinders, stunning viewers in every scene with an unmistaken attitude, she is the heart and soul of the film. Then, on a lesser extent, Barry Keoghan is also commendable as Dominic Kearney, a dimwitted boy who steals our hearts for his unexpected acumen and self-knowledge, Keoghan is remarkably touching and mutable here, but if you have watched THE KILLING OF A SACRED DEER (2017), then it would not be a surprise, he has done it before!"read my full review on my blog: Cinema Omnivore, please google it, thanks.

This is a very depressing movie. I just watched it and I really wish I had not. It starts sweet, and then gets darker, and then gets utterly depressing and sad, and then it ends. I still feel ill after watching it.We saw the good reviews, and of course the Oscar nominations, and the great actors, and the beautiful setting, and we were pretty sure it would be good. And it started nice, very funny characters, great acting, beautiful cinematography, and a kind of cute story about a break up between a couple of old friends on a beautiful Irish island. But it gets sad and depressing and ends very sad and depressing. If you don't want a huge drag of a movie crawling around in your brain I strongly suggest you pass on this thing. I sure wish I did.

The Banshees of Inisherin is the best written of Martin McDonaugh's catalogue of films. That's because it reads exactly like his plays. The magic is in the script. No flashy set pieces in this one, unless you consider the dreary Irish coast a flashy set piece. I applaud McDonaugh for making such a moving story based off of so little. It's just about two men. One tells the other that he doesn't like him anymore. There, off to the races! This is a story about agony, that is, the agony of the unknown. You can feel Padriac's agony as he struggles to understand what he did wrong to make his friend suddenly dislike him. Colm, on the other hand, suffers a serious bout of depression, but as a man in old word Ireland, he's unable to address it. Farrell and Gleeson are pitch perfect. Their chemistry, as always, is unmistakeable. If you are looking for the perfect slow burn of 2022, look no further.

reviews.review_title: One of the best feel-bad movies.
reviews.content: Banshees of Inisherin features moments of sadness, humor, and melancholy. Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson re-team with director Martin McDonagh since In Bruges. From the painterly landscapes of the island to the intimate character interactions, Inisherin makes the viewer part of its story. Some viewers might be looking for a more complex plot. Inisherin doesn't do this, instead it focuses on the failing friendship between two men, and they lengths they go to understand one another. If you are a fan of In Bruges' humor, then you'll be happy with Inisherin, some of the scenes had me dying of laughter due to how they're filmed. Overall, if you are looking for a slow - often humorous - look at fragile friendship, then Inisherin should suffice.

'The Banshees of Inisherin' is Martin McDonagh's fourth feature film and the first to be set in Ireland. In fact, it could be an adaptation of the third play in the 'Aran Islands trilogy', of which the first two plays have already been published and staged with considerable success. The third, however, the Anglo-Irish dramatist considered insufficiently good to see the lights of the printing and the stage, and its finalization was postponed. All the characteristics of the previous works of the playwright and screenwriter Martin McDonagh are here: strong and tense conflict, few and well-defined characters who are pushed into borderline situations, a pessimistic view of the world and society. To these 'The Banshees of Inisherin' adds an Irish theme - both as a profile of the characters and as reflections of a difficult history characterized by conflicts and internal rifts that are difficult to reconcile and overcome. As is the case with many good films, this one can be interpreted and explained on many levels - as a personal story, as a parable with biblical resonance, or as a metaphor for historical conflicts.The story takes place on an (imaginary) island located a few kilometers off the coast of Ireland. Whoever can crosses to the 'mainland', that is, Ireland, another island, much bigger, where the civil war haunts, but where life is more interesting and the opportunities are different. Few remain. The community they live in probably has a few dozen houses and families, a pub, a policeman, a shop where basic goods are bought, where mail is delivered (sometimes after having been read by indiscrete eyes) and where rumors are circulated. Everybody knows everybody. The heroes of the film, Pádraic and Colm, were, until the scene that opens the film, two good friends. Every day at 2 o'clock they met to go to the pub together, until one day when Colm decided he no longer wanted to talk to Pádraic. Colm is a musician, he plays the violin and because he wants to leave something behind he composes a song whose name is also the title of the film. Pádraic is a very good-hearted boy, but a bit boring, and Colm feels that he has no time for him. Siobhán, Pádraic's sister, tries in vain to reconcile them. She herself, already past the age of marriage, dreams of leaving the island, perhaps to find a place where she can use her passion for reading. Pádraic's insistence and Colm's stubbornness will gradually escalate the conflict to unpredictable extremes.The film benefits from extremely well written dialogues and an exceptional cast. In this film, Martin McDonagh brings back in the main roles the two actors who 16 years ago ensured the success of his most famous film, 'In Bruges'. It's hard to believe that Colin Farrell, who plays Pádraic, could miss the Academy Award for Best Actor this yeat, but Brendan Gleeson isn't far off either. Outstanding supporting roles are also played by Kerry Condon (Siobhán) and Barry Keoghan, who plays Dominic, the son of the island's policeman, a victim of domestic violence, who has become a kind of fool of the island. In less than two hours, McDonagh creates an entire human universe that absorbs viewers. The meanings of the text, however, go beyond the ambitions of a simple domestic drama. Banshees are female embodied spirits that can foretell the future. There is one character who fits this profile who also appears in key scenes, and her omens are grim. Death lurks around every bend in the paths or on the high cliffs. The dialogues include a wealth of allusions to life and death, kindness and loneliness, hope and despair. The most obvious metaphor, however, is that of the island. Inisherin is a small island next to a mainland towards which the dreams and aspirations of the inhabitants are directed. There, however, haunt conflicts, wars, and other evils of large societies. The ratio of forces and sizes recalls Ireland's destiny relative to that of Great Britain or the United States, to which the population of Ireland has been emigrating for centuries. . The misunderstandings and conflicts caused by the very nature of people, however, do not bypass even small communities, and inevitably the accumulated passions will erupt into violence. The outbreak is ugly and hard to understand, like in a horror movie. But what are the ethnic or religious conflicts that we live in so many places of the world but horror episodes? We all live on islands, bigger or smaller, and hate is everywhere. The final scene may indicate hope (the violent outburst is over, not before causing casualties) but also an uneasy coexistence with unresolved tensions in the future.

I go to the movies as such rarely, I leave it for something worthwhile (last one Bladerunner 2049); and I wasn't disappointed, yes I like this director's body of work but yes they are movies you see only once, the tropes are such that once seen you know exactly what happens next. Some movies you can re-watch -as you can't even remember how it ends. As a screenplay goes, however I note yes beer was poured only from bottles in 1923 but some dialogue is from the modern idiom. No-one said wank in 1923, or the phrase (Doesn't) time (be) fly (ing)s? When you're having fun and I am not sure whether "So move on," was in current use then, as well. The simplicity of the script and the limited area the characters live in - is brilliantly projected by the cast. Brendan Gleeson, Colin Farrell, Barry Keoghan and the lilting voice of Kerry Condon.So, apart from these complete minor flaws only a linguist would note. And in my opinion little Jenny the dwarf donkey, Minnie the miniature pony; as well as the trap horse especially in the last few scenes not forgetting the brilliant performance of Colin Farrell are all Oscar worthy. Don't Vote it only encourages them. Don't buy advertised products it encourages them even more.

Every year, there are "Oscar" films that critics love but that I can't understand and find overrated when I watch them. I was biased towards this movie. But it's not such a movie. It's sure to be an award-winning movie. The director did not many movies but all of them were very good. It's a metaphorical movie. I gave a lot of meaning to the character of Colm. Sometimes all you want is silence and solitude. But most people don't understand it. I empathized with the character of Colm. Yes, it did not seem absurd to me to give up even one's fingers for this request. The acting in the movie is excellent. Colin Farrell was amazing. He put on one of his best performances, perhaps his best. The place where the movie takes place, the music, the poetic dialogues were all very good, I think. Most viewers wrote that the movie was suffocating, but I liked that part. It's a very good movie.

I am not going to agree with some who say this is the best film of 2022. But I am going to say it is a fabulous film in terms of acted story.The story has a few threads, but the one relating to Padraig's sister is unexplored and comes as a bit of a surprise.The one relating to Dominic is not a surprise, but a very sad one. Barry Keoghan is going to win an award one day. He is incredible to watch in everything he does.Brendon Gleeson needs no introduction.I could go on but the short version is there is not a badly acted scene in the entire film. Not one. Every single character plays their part well.Thee sets are impossibly authentic and the videography close to perfect.So what spoils it? The story. It's silly. It's saved because the dialogue is impeccably delivered and it just shows how a poor story can be elevated if it is delivered correctly.It's not the kind of film you will ever watch again, but I enjoyed the time I spent watching it. I gave it a seven for the acting and production, even if the story is silly.

reviews.review_title: Grips loosely and strongly at the same time
reviews.content: The Banshees of Inisherin is a movie that begins with steady and subtle storytelling. All the characters that get thrown at us, pull us into the void with the beautiful performance from the actors. The amount of grip this film gets on us only with their characters is harmony on its own. The story that gets played in front of us seems sluggish with not much to offer but as it moves forward it manages to open up and throw some spice in the pot for a small amount of time. Director Martin McDonagh, with everything combined whereas most of it is the sheer performances of the actors has created a harmony that blooms quite a bit but not too much overall. All in all The Banshees of Inisherin offers a story that fills you up with appetizers and leaves no room for anything else.

I was privileged in seeing this movie early at the SCAD Film Festival and it was absolutely amazing. Martin McDonagh absolutely knocked it out of the park again. First off, the performances here are some of the best of the year. Colin Farrell is so far my pick for Best Actor this year. His performance here is absolutely amazing and heart wrenching at points as well. He does an amazing job at embodying this character and all his little quirks. Brendan Gleeson did an amazing job as well. He did a great job at being the foil to Colin Farrell's character with his more serious attitude. Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan did a great job as well with Barry Keoghan delivering probably the best performance of his career by a country mile. One scene from him in particular is heartbreaking. I keep mentioning how this film is heartbreaking and heart wrenching but this film is absolutely hilarious as well. Almost every joke here is very well written and incorporated into each scene and they are just funny in a dark way. This definitely falls under the black comedy genre. McDonagh does an amazing job at directing and incorporating the mix of dark comedy and drama tones together in a way that doesn't feel jarring. The film starts out being funny but the end you're definitely feeling emotional and sad as well. The story is really interesting. It's fascinating watching Colin Farrell try to get back under the good graces of Gleeson's character and all the incidents that follow that. The cinematography and music are both breathtaking and easily some of the best of the year. Every shot feels picturesque and the music works incredibly well at bringing up the jokes or bringing out the seriousness of a scene. As much as I love this movie, I would say that McDonagh's previous film Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is just slightly better than this. I would highly recommend watching this when you get the chance of you want a slow burn comedy/drama.

reviews.review_title: How Many Fingers Am I Holding Up
reviews.content: The Banshees of Inisherin is an odd bucket of fish! I don't think I've seen another movie quite like it, which is a good thing :)The acting is spectacular, whereas the story is just so so strange.There is essentially no point to the film, with some happenings that just meander across the screen until the end credits roll by.There are some terrific moments and the donkey is a real champion of the show.This film will bore the cr*p out of a lot of people and greatly entertain others.For me it was an intriguing ride of lunacy and genius that had me quite gazumped at the end. Did I like it. I dunno :)

reviews.review_title: Allegory for the troubles in Ireland
reviews.content: Banshees is a fairly simple tale of friendship and how friendships can end and troubles can arise.Set on an island off Ireland during the Irish Civil war of 1923, a war that that started 100 years ago in 1922 and to this day hasn't really ended.One man Podraic suddenly finds that his life long best friend Colm doesn't want to be his friend anymore. The despair and confusion of this situation escalates over the films nearly 2hr runtime.This really is the modern Brothers Grimm fairytale that will tell the story of the past 100 years in Ireland. The story also focuses a lot on loneliness and despair and the confusion that surrounds this. Which can ultimately leads to anger and pain.The film is shot beautifully from the vistas of the Island to the Animals and its surrounding nature.Everything is well kempt but of its time while also looking rather like a glossy fairytale picture book, a reminder that you are watching a film not a documentary. There is a lot of Irish humour within this tragic tale and at times it may seem like a comedy.I think you can take a lot from this film without comparing it to the last 100 years in Ireland but ultimately it makes a lot more sense and there being too many references to Ireland troubles for it not to be a direct Allegoric story.By the end the bloodiest moments had passed but it seems that some are not willing to let go.9/10.

reviews.review_title: Dark and sombre tale of human tragedy
reviews.content: Dark and grim but a wonderful movie to watch. What started as a simple village life story slowly and absorbingly turns into a dark and grim study of human behaviour and its effects on our fellow humans.A simple story of two lifelong friends; the older one gets this idea and chooses to do something great in his life. So that he can be remembered. To achieve this; he makes a life-altering decision that he won't speak to his best buddy, a simple man from the village.As we journey through this, it becomes clear that things are complex and get bloodier with every passing day.This makes an impact on everyone involved.The music in this film is outstanding. It helps to create a powerful atmosphere and adds a great deal of emotion to the story. The actors all deliver amazing performances, making the characters very believable and compelling. The cinematography is beautiful, providing stunning visuals. Overall, this is a great film with excellent acting, music, and cinematography.The movie is a dark and sombre tale of human tragedy, but one that is also full of hope and possibility. It is a movie that is worth watching for its thoughtful examination of human behaviour and its consequences.

I kind of had high hopes for this as I settled into an evening viewing. Wine ,check , G&T for the wife ,check , ample crisps and snacks , check , award winning film waiting for a check , well not so much.First of all I'm not sure what I was expecting . Maybe an , In Bruges , on steroids. If that what you are expecting then disappointment is honestly just a few screen credits away.Ok the good points . The acting is really good and there is some funny yet subtle one liners. There are some interesting secondary characters the scenery is magnificent bleakness. The animals are great, you know when you use the animals are great line you are searching for something to really like about this film.Alas, the whole films concept is fairly flawed at its genesis. Its just not well written. If you are one of those people who can look at this and say its a metaphor for depression , maybe even madness a groundhog day with no happy ending or redemption , then maybe , just maybe you will finish this and say, yes I get its deeper meaning what a great film. Sadly, as a mere mortal you finish it thinking this is very over hyped and nowhere near as good as it is touted.

reviews.review_title: It's a small, intensely personal story that sticks in the mind
reviews.content: On the face of it, Banshees of Inisherin is a story of two Irishmen (Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson) competing over who can be more stubborn and prideful (i.e., pigheaded). That's not wrong, but of course there's much more to it than that. The time and place are the end of the Irish Civil War in 1923, on a tiny (fictional) remote island off the coast of Ireland just big enough to have one pub and one general store. It's kind of a statement of their relative importance that the pub is spacious while the store is barely big enough to turn around in.Some other reviewers are calling this film a comedy or at very least a black comedy. Yes, it's got some good, funny dialog built on inimitable Irish personality and turn of phrase, but that's just a side element. At its core this really seems to me to be a tragedy. Not a Shakespearean one in style, but still a tragedy. The conflict between the two long-standing friends comes right off the top and seemingly out of nowhere, and builds from there to a story of how fairly normal human impulses can turn in an astonishingly self-destructive direction. In other words, 'conflict resolution' isn't exactly their strong point. Padraic believes, for a long while, that he can change his friend's mind, while Colm can't see past his own priorities. Even if we understand both of them much more by the end, it's still a head-shaking adventure. And in fact I guess maybe it's a lot more Shakespearean and more universal than I originally suggested -- i.e. Relentless stubborn pride (see above) isn't just the property of giant figures like Lear or MacBeth or Coriolanus.The acting, dialog, and cinematography are uniformly great. Kerry Conron (playing Padraic's sister, ultimately the only character who has the sense and intelligence to take herself out of the whole situation) and Barry Keoghan (playing Dominic, a friendly but odd local youth) are spot-on as well. One of the strengths of "Banshees" is that these two side characters have stories that are almost equally fleshed out, done very economically and tellingly. Dominic is living with troubles that are more serious than anything Padraic and Colm are fighting over. That is, an even bigger tragedy is happening on the sidelines that is sadly going unrecognized by everyone until it's too late.There's an intriguing mirror symmetry in the story. In the first half, Colm is resolute and unyielding while Padraic is baffled and contrite, but without knowing why. In the second half, Padraic has hardened into resolution while Colm has become sad and contrite. Sow the wind, reap the whirlwind. They're both to blame, and neither.

Having seen the trailer for Martin McDonagh's "The Banshees of Inisherin" and being a big fan of "In Bruges" I was disappointed when I didn't have a chance to see it at the cinema, but it landed pretty quickly on Disney Plus where I took my opportunity. Though I have .... thoughts .... about the ending, generally I enjoyed it.On an Island, not far from the Irish mainland, Padraic Suillebhain (Colin Farrell) is shocked when his closest friend, Colm Doherty (Brendan Gleeson), tells his that he no longer wishes to be friends with him. He struggles to determine what he has done to drive Colm to this decision, which he is adamant about. Padraic's sister Siobhan (Kerry Condon) tries to repair the relationship, but she has distractions of her own and, every so often, the sounds of gunfire come from the mainland.I haven't done much supporting reading for the film, so my assumptions here about what the film is about may not correspond with what McDonagh had in mind. But I saw the film as an allegory for the Civil War that was taking place in Ireland, in 1923 - and perhaps even for wider civil wars. A trivial annoyance is escalated through poor communication and then taken to extreme violent lengths. All the while the participants ignore a bigger problem, that they're aware of, until that reaches catastrophe.I know the "Black Comedy" description has proved divisive, but I did find the film regularly funny and thought the performances from the central four (the three mentioned above and Barry Keoghan) were excellent. I couldn't help but feel that the ending was somewhat of an anti-climax though, specifically in the very final scenes, rather than the surprising ones that proceed it. I don't have a better alternative in mind, but it ends with a whimper, rather than a bang.I had my issues with "Three Billboards" but for me, this was a big improvement.

reviews.review_title: What's the Irish Word for Disappointing?
reviews.content: I had such high expectations for this film, given the actors, setting and premise. It is beautifully filmed, with the sea as backdrop and the fog setting the overall tone of loneliness and loss. In that way, it's a perfect pandemic story, but that's also what makes it such a disappointment. It's just too sad. Despite the many touches of dark humor, the narrative lacks direction and motion - there's no story at all, really, only atmosphere, and one that is just too dark and heavy to raise the film out of the bog from which it originated. Enjoy the cinematographyand the vintage simplicity of a poor, remote village. Just don't get your hopes up.

The Banshees of Inisherin is the tale of two old friends, one of whom stops their relationship without a clear explanation.The movie offers strong performances, and not only from the two main leads, who indeed steal the spotlight. The side characters are also excellent and aid a lot to the creation of the right atmosphere.The cinematography is also spot on, moody, cloudy and melancholical. The ptopts and costumes support the era in which the story takes place as well.However, the main plot leaves you with the feeling that something is missing. It doesn't feel wholesome. Rather, it's like a snapshot of the two friends' life, which makes you want to know more about the outcome.

reviews.review_title: neess to be your cup of tea for you to enjoy
reviews.content: It may be a small surprise to many that The Banshees of Inisherin chalked up 9 Oscar nominations, nearly half of which in the acting categories. The "many" alluded to above most likely (95%) have not seen this movie. Nor would react to the name of director Martin McDonagh. Those who are brought to understand (as I) that he also directed "Three billboards outside Ebbing, Missouri" would immediate raise their eyebrows (I did). Best vintage. He gets nominated for both directing and writing. The four acting nominations are Best Actor Colin Ferrell, Supporting Brendan Gleeson (well known), Barry Keoghan ("The eternals") and Kerry Condon ("Three Billboards..."). Best Picture, plus Editing and Music make 9.The plotline, if you can call it one, is simplicity itself, a scrapbook of ordinary life in a fictional island Inisherin off the shore of Ireland during the civil war of the 1920s. The persona of the main character Padraic is not unlike that of the portrayer Ferrell, but without the sophistication, a cheerful happy-go-lucky cow herder. Loving his donkey and other animals, Padraic does not have many real friends, his sister Siobhan, played by Condon, obviously, being his keeper of sorts, emotionally as well as pragmatically (she cooks). He does have a friend, fiddler Colm (Gleeson). The entire plot rests on this strange friendship. As Colm is taciturn, brooding and quite a bit older, it may not be that easy to explain how the friendship of this odd couple started. It is not explained.The abrupt ending of this friendship is explained, but that does not mean that you can understand it. I cannot, from a pure rational, logical perspective and therefore simply accept it. Colm simply tells Patraic that he is tired of the latter's conversation, which has become a waste of his time, which could be used to do something really useful, such a creating music. Patraic doggedly persists driving Colm to extreme measures. His way of protesting is bizarre and gruesome to the extent that may turn off some in the audience. Colm does nothing to Patraic though. Just to himself. But that indirectly kills Patraic' most beloved donkey. I'll stop here.While this movie is listed as "comedy" and does generate dry chuckle and laugh-out-louds it is really in a territory of different viewers may feel different things. Gleeson's role could justifiably get a co-nomination with Farrell as Best Actor. On the other hand, some may feel that Keoghan's role does not quite justify a nomination, albeit as a Support. Condon well deserves her Best Supporting Actress nomination.

reviews.review_title: Not funny, but enjoyable and thought-provoking nonetheless
reviews.content:
Set on a backwards island off the coast of Ireland, our main character's (played by Colin Farrell) best friend abruptly ends their friendship for no apparent reason. From there things turn dark and weird as Colin tries to figure out why his best friend doesn't want to spend his days small-talking at the pub anymore.I liked In Bruges, so I figured I'd give this a chance despite the plot sounding dull. It took a bit of patience, but was an enjoyable watch once I let myself get into it. It's more tragic than funny. It might have gotten two slight chuckles out of me.The plot is easy to follow, as opposed to other more abstract movies in the genre. There is depth to be found, if need be, but the plot works even without looking behind the surface.The movie is set during the civil war, but historical context really has no bearing on the plot. The fact that I know nothing about the time period didn't subtract much from my viewing experience.Like In Bruges, Banshees of Inisherin gets carried by a few interesting characters and great performances. It's bizarre and tragic plot will make you reflect deeply on something or other, while guessing at what comes next.Negatives:
Parts of the plot are unbelievable, even within it's dark comedy setting. There are too many unnecessary lines. Some have commented on the dialogue not sounding authentic irt the time period. While I can't comment on historical inaccuracies, some dialogue just didn't come off as believable, and I didn't think the movie gained enough from being set in said time period. Also, it could've been funnier without having to compromise on it's dark tone - the "comedy" label will leave a lot of people extremely disappointed.Worth a watch. However, If you aren't fond of so-called dark comedies, you likely won't get much from Banshees of Inisherin.

There's an Australian metal band that have a song titled "In Misery There Can Be Comfort" - a sentiment that echoes particularly true in The Banshees of Inisherin. Martin McDonaugh's latest is a melancholic slow burn, a poignant and strangely soothing meditation on friendship and family that can be both tranquil and agonizing. Yet for all its gorgeously evocative scenery and career best performances from its two veteran star, it's as likely to make my "Best of 2022" list as it is to make my "Best movies I never want to see again" one. Which is a compliment more than anything - its emotional weight makes the movie stick with you long after the credits (and a couple fingers) have rolled.

I didn't know what to expect going into this movie. I just knew it was winning a lot of awards and I'd better see it soon.This was like watching the War of the Roses between two men friends. Not that extreme, but one of the men wants a divorce and the other doesn't.When Brendan Gleeson tells Collin Farrell, I don't like you anymore. OMG, that hit home because I'm going through an analysis of my friendships. And realize there are some folk I don't like anymore and won't socialize with them. What happens when you tell someone who thought you were friends that it's over? And that person won't let you be.Colin Farrell is probably giving the performance of his life because you can see the sadness and confusion in his face when his so-called best friend doesn't want to be around anymore. And there's nowhere these two can go. They live on a remote little Irish island where everybody knows everybody, sees everybody all day and knows your business. You would have to leave the island entirely.This movie made me laugh, made me think about relationships and understand about loneliness and isolation. It was sad in a lot of ways.Not to spoil anything, but the friend who won't let go goes to extremes with his anger and confusion.I didn't understand some of the Irish brogue and words they spoke. You have to listen very carefully.

The Banshees of Inisherin is a phenomenal film, brilliantly executing its genuinely exceptional screenplay. McDonagh's direction is impeccable, building an atmosphere so lived-in and rich with emotion. This undoubtedly starts with the amazing location the picture was shot at, which allowed for such outstanding cinematography. The music throughout doubles down on the continuous sense of dread and, especially, isolation. As this environment is well-crafted, so is each character. Every role feels tightly connected and purposeful to the overall story being told, captivating the audience despite a slower than average pacing. What happens simply feels so real, reflecting on impactful ideas like loneliness and friendship while simultaneously producing a beyond intriguing story. Aiding this is one powerful performance after another from the star-studded cast. These actors and actresses are able to seamlessly blend comedy and drama, delivering great dialogue with sincerity that both fills the audience with laughter and moves their hearts with emotion. Ferrell and Gleeson highlight the film, sharing a chemistry onscreen that leaves the audience at the edge of their seat until their respective characters meet again. Condon and Keoghan are great, as well. Altogether, then, this film is almost flawless. More could have expected from the third act, possibly, and what happens is admittedly not the most exciting story out there, yet the small feel of the movie may just be its charm. The Banshees of Inisherin is ultimately worthwhile for most.

"The Banshees of Inisherin", the Last Melody of Colm, is an intimate movie that talks about the ending of a friendship that lasted for many years. The two main characters, Colm and Padraic, are two fragile men with different perspectives on the definition of life.Padraic does want to live his life with his friends and Colm, but the character portrayed by Brendan Gleeson doesn't want to waste his time speaking with a "boring" man talking about non-sense. This movie is really heartbreaking, during the almost 2 hours of length of the movie we see how the relationship between the two starts to corroborate itself, with the ultimate act which is very powerful and astonishing. In the background, there is the character of Dominic, an Irish boy who can't escape from that little village in the Highlands and he has to live with his drunk and violent father. The character of Barry Keoghan really delivers its job, portraying a sense of malincony and sadness when we acknowledge what happens to him. In conclusion, this movie is a really particular one, with twists and death all around the corner, but it will surely affect you in an interesting and unexpected way.

It's hard to put into words how much I truly liked this movie - nay, loved it.The cinematography, acting, story (as you will) and theme - all came together to make a truly enjoyable viewing experience.It's one of those few movies that will actually stay with me for a while - something like those inane Marvel movies never will.10/10. Well done.It's hard to put into words how much I truly liked this movie - nay, loved it.The cinematography, acting, story (as you will) and theme - all came together to make a truly enjoyable viewing experience.It's one of those few movies that will actually stay with me for a while - something like those inane Marvel movies never will.10/10. Well done.

I am bit confused about calling this the best film of 2022 though unarguably this is definitely one of the best film of 2022. This was entirely Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson show as the director brings out the best chemistry between them as Pàdraic and Colm with Kerry Condon playing a strong supporting character Siobhàn. All of a sudden Colm decides to ignore Pàdraic ending their decades long friendship which disturbs Pàdraic. Further Colm exaggerates his decision with a threat of cutting off his finger if Pàdraic ever tries to speak to him again. The drastic results that comes out of their current predicament while Pàdraic's unmarried sister tries hard to play the peacemaker forms rest of the story.The beauty of this story is how well the characters are etched out apart from the commendable performances. Instantly buying these characters aside, even the story is worth getting hooked on. The life that Colm seeks for the remaining years and the life Pàdraic is used to living, the change one so harshly seeks while the other is disturbed to the core to latch onto the existing life is beautifully captured on screen. Especially those moments where they both care for each other despite the fallout is sheer brilliance.Strongly recommended.

Moon goes first usually, but THIS TIME I WILL REVIEW THIS FIRST.BIZ REVIEWNOW LOOK HERE. I LIKED THIS MOVIE. Aham. Sorry about the capslock. I really liked so much about this movie. The acting. The view. The music. The dialogue. Everything, except the vibe. Except the ending. Except THAT THING that you can't put in words. I just expected something else, I must say. I saw In Brudges and it's my fault for thinking that this will be like that. Well, it really wasn't. And because I went with different expectations, it disappointed and left me with a rotten pizza taste in my mouth.6/10 for me, WITH A LOT OF EFFORT. More like 5.5/10Pass it over to Moon. Thank you Moon.MOON REVIEWOk. So. This movie was very, in my opinion, bleak and it portrayed a.... aa.... sad part of the human condition. It felt a little bit hopeless and it also felt very very close to the truth. A. I can't say I liked the main characters but I did like how they acted, but I just didn't like the main char who they were in the movie. That's all.6/10 for me too.BIZ REVIEW AGAINLet me say, just one more time, that I am just angry. Angry at myself that I couldn't enjoy this movie. Clearly it's a great movie and I will not recommend it to friends. DAMNOVERALL RATING: 6/10
SHOULD YOU WATCH IT: Yes, just don't go with expectations.WITH WHO? Not with your mom.

The Irish really are an island unto themselves, and that may be the point of this movie. Loved and despised in equal doses, "The Banshees of Inisherin" nevertheless is rewarding cinema. Set solely on the gloriously green rolling knolls of a cute island (sit down tourists, no such place) where the rain only sprinkles at night, the muffled sounds of revolutionary shots fired are at a safe distance on the mainland, and the locals gather daily at the local pub. All seems idyllic in the charming farming community, until a long-standing friendship is suddenly disrupted. Forget small town, this is a small island, where everyone not only knows everyone, but appear to have no will to escape.The break-up, abrupt, congenial, silent, eats away at a confused Padraic (Colin Farrell and his expressive eyebrows). A simple man, his confusion and childlike determination to mend matters with the stoic and complicated Colm (Brendan Gleeson) is rife with comedic tension, until, well, until things get way out of hand.The battle of wills takes on an unsavoury, physical bent that becomes the knife twist in the film. One which tests an audiences' mettle. An allegory for the warring factions on the horizon, the odd couples' relationship runs the gamut of absurd to horrific. A tragic comedy that delivers more victims than victors.Farrell and Gleeson are superb, bringing plenty of grand ideas to the table - the regiment of life, the role of friendship, reinventing oneself, the cuffs of relationships, unrequited love, vengeance, and mortality. Plus a bunch more. Sunny yet dark. Do a favour with a viewing.hipCRANK.

First Impressions:
A long friendship between two men was suddenly threatened when one of them decided to end it. This movie captured a relatable, at times funny, and often heart-wrenching series of events that portrayed a fraying friendship that seemed doomed to end. Don't be put off by the odd title, there's more to this dark comedy than meets the eye.The Crew:
Martin McDonagh wrote and directed a winner.Carter Burwell's musical scoring was amazing.Ben Davis' cinematography was stunning.Mark Tildesley's production design was great.Art direction and set decoration were noteworthy.Editing and sound effects were superb.Hair-makeup and VFX were great.The stunts team did admirable work.Eimer Ni Mhaoldomhnaigh's costume design was quite good.The Cast:
Colin Farrell as Pádraic Súilleabháin was excellent.Brendan Gleeson as Colm Doherty was captivating.Kerry Condon as Siobhán Súilleabháin was superb.Barry Keoghan as Dominic Kearney was exemplary.Sheila Flitton as Mrs. McCormick was notable.David Pearse as the priest was good.Gary Lydon as Peadar Kearney was great.Plot Summary & Analysis:
What happens when one best-friend ends the relationship while the other tries everything possible to repair it? That was the simple premise that inspired a range of complex and deeply meaningful sequences in "The Banshees of Inisherin".The story was set off Ireland's west coast and on an isolated island in that region. Pádraic Súilleabháin (Colin Farrell) and Colm Doherty (Brendan Gleeson) were the lifelong friends at the heart of the script.Colm is the one who chose to end the bond, which saw Pádraic doing whatever it took - despite Colm's self-mutilation ultimatums - to heal the rift between them. Before long, the gloves came off - or rather, the fingers.The only explanation for the apparent tiff between the men was Colm telling Pádraic, "I just don't like you no more." Plenty of suspense revolved around this line and what it implied. Colm's later explanation about time slipping away from him and his urgent need to do something more useful with his life than waste it indulging in dull conversations with his bestie made a dark sort of sense.Colin was so vulnerable and innocent, it truly made me feel sorry for the man. That side of the actor was great to see, though. As for Brendan, his sincere performance made it a challenge to refute his reasons for leaving Colin's character in such a loop.The scenes between Pádraic and his sister Siobhán (Kerry Condon) added to the flow of things in "The Banshees of Inisherin". I also loved watching what Barry Keoghan contributed to this movie as Dominic Kearney.Also in focus was the magnificent Irish countryside. The landscape was magical, almost like something out of a fairy tale. I'm sure the cinematographer had a heckuva field day shooting some of the outdoor sequences.Around that time the Irish Civil War was also in full swing, adding to the movie's passive thrill.
