I liked how they wove elements of that historic moment into the plot, perhaps mainly to balance things out. But they barely gave it any real attention, which was good. The main plotline lay elsewhere.There was also a "nice" - those who've seen the move will catch the reference - philosophical leaning to the story.Final Notes:
Remarkable performances and outstanding timing set high tones in this dark comedy about a friendship gone wrong. The sheer not-knowing-why angle was delightful to watch as it played out.Tender moments were also present, adding to the captivation and warmth of this story, which I'm sure is going to stay in my mind for months to come.The movie aligned perfectly with the spirit of the genre. It took a simple storyline and lent it a world of gravitas that was timeless and relatable. I'd call this movie a work of genius, but many before me have already started appending that honour to it.

BrilliantIt starts of so awkwardly funny and then gets a tiny bit darker as it goes on.It is always funny, the locations and the camerawork are beautiful. The characters are quirky and the plot is ridiculous.Brendan Gleeson decides he no longer wants to be friends with Colin Farrell because he feels lifes to short to waste talking to a man he finds dull despite being friends for a long time.Farrell cannot work out why he doesn't want to be friends no more and keeps pestering Gleeson.Gleeson then tells him for each time he speaks to him from now on he will cut off one of his fingers.The Island of Ireland in 1923 is an excellent setting.The supporting cast are also excellent.The best film i have seen from the 2020's so far.

reviews.review_title: How can this possibly be labeled a comedy?
reviews.content:
It's a dark expose into depression and self-mutilation. It should've been marketed for what it is an intense fly on the wall experience of life in a stagnant world, where hope is only to be found elsewhere.. the characters were very interesting. The performances were all outstanding, and I believe deserve. Oscar nods for the performances that picture of the year nominee ? You've gotta be kidding me
Beautifully filmed, incredible natural settings, offset the bleakness of life, lived by these characters who are locked into a system that is brutal and harsh. It seems that human interactions bring less joy than the animal ones do. And the upside down society allows authoritarian police to be abusive and no one bats an eye? A lot of sad commentary on the social situation at that time in history, and to see from whence our current day struggles have sprung....

reviews.review_title: Who doesn't love laughing about heartbreak?!
reviews.content: I love the films of Martin McDonagh, and "The Banshees of Inisherin" is no exception; I'd even go so far to say this might be his best film. It is a richly layered and brilliant film that is both darkly hilarious and tragic at the same time. Frankly it is a masterpiece, and will certainly be one to watch for in the Best Picture race! This is a gut-punch of a comedic drama like only McDonagh can make it - expertly toeing the line between laugh out loud funny and heart-wrenching melancholy. I laughed throughout the film, and yet it struck me so hard emotionally by the end, leaving me with a lot to think about and ponder. The film is a finely-crafted feel-bad treat, and the more I think about it, the more I love it!This is easily one of the most remarkable films this year, and yet it may be one of the more small and subtle premises of any film in 2022. I loved how simple the premise was; it is really refreshing to see a film do so much with such a subtle and human premise. The film essentially follows a "break-up" between two friends, as we see how far one is willing to go to fight for their friendship, and conversely how far the other will go to block him out of his life. By the end of the film we really come to understand each character's point of view, and the reasoning behind their occasionally extreme actions. Brendan Gleeson's character, Colm, has motivations that I found quite interesting - especially because we can fully see where he is coming from, but also see the pettiness behind it. Without giving away too much, I loved how it touched on feelings of running out of time in life, and picking exactly how you wish to spend your remaining time, as we all only have a limited amount. The thematic writing in this film was especially strong, McDonagh excellently explores themes of fate, friendship, loneliness, life and death. All these themes are touched on, and what I found most interesting was that in a way each character represented one of these themes in one way or another.This film is very thought provoking, but it doesn't always have the easiest answers. It challenges the viewer to think about the content of the film on deeper levels. And yet... it really cannot be overstated how hilarious this movie is! If one describes the film as only a dark comedy that is concerned with loneliness and existentialism, one would be painting a different portrait of the film, because this movie has big laughs throughout! It is very funny and has such clever, well-crafted jokes. McDonagh is a master of this type of dry humour and wit, and really knows how to play the audience. The editing also really helps, as the editor has a strong understanding of comedic timing, knowing exactly how to cut and time the jokes. Every single joke and funny moment landed perfectly, I was dying laughing at times! While it is quite funny, it does also make you feel sad at times too, as overall it does tell a story about the loss of friendship between two men. The tone is a dramedy, as funny as it is don't expect this to be a slapstick comedy flick, and McDonagh balances the two tones extremely well. One scene you could be bursting with laughter, and the next you are deeply emotional and very resonant to what is going on. It never compromised either tone, instead letting the comedy build on the emotional scenes and the emotional scenes build on the comedy. It was just this perfect balance you rarely see in film; something I love about McDonagh's filmmaking style!One of the most outstanding aspects of this film is the incredible acting on display. The film is a fantastic "In Bruges" reunion, reconnecting stars Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson with McDonagh, as well as adding in some great talent in the form of Kelly Condon and Barry Keoghan. This could easily be Colin Farrell's best performance to date - and he has given us a lot of good performances over the years! This one, however, is pitch perfect. He's hilarious in it, especially as his character is almost never aware of how he is being funny, instead is very hurt and offended at the things we are laughing at. He is a master of comedic timing, nailing every comedic moment his character gets. There's a lot of face comedy in his performance as well which was wonderful, Farrell is very good at acting only with facial expressions - even his stares communicate so much. It is a very subtle and nuanced performance, I could see a best actor nomination coming out of this! I really loved his character, Pádraic, and how his identity was so rooted in how nice he is (even if he is intentionally a bit dull). He has quite the fascinating shift in how he sees himself and his life as the film went on. I really loved this performance and character. Brendan Gleeson was also perfect for his role and so good here. He doesn't have as much to do as Colin does, but it is so great seeing his character's gruff persona bumping up against Colin's nice guy persona. Gleeson really embodied his character, delivering a performance that felt very lived in and natural. Kerry Condon was also fantastic, and had some phenomenal moments that really stand out. I loved Barry Keoghan too, he was hysterical playing the town idiot, and somehow fit the role perfectly!I loved the setting of the island off the coast of Ireland! The location really felt like a character in the film, as the setting informs how the characters make their choices and who they are as people. It actually informed a lot of the comedy too! Plus... the landscapes look stunning! The cinematography is outstanding, not just in the way they gorgeously capture the Irish hillsides (which have some natural beauty), but even the interiors were shot beautifully too. It felt like they were shooting with lanterns and natural light. I loved that they let the setting be filled with darkness, which made it feel more authentic. The use of focus pulling was also quite excellent here too, especially when it came to using this to only show silhouettes in the background. I didn't expect such lush cinematography from a comedy! It found it quite interesting how shots/setups would mirror themselves throughout the film based on the current state of the relationship, for example you would see one shot with Gleeson sitting outside and Farrell inside, and then 45 minutes later the same shot but reversed. McDonagh's visuals have never been better! I also really thought Carter Burwell's score was quite fitting for the film!The standouts here really are the writing, directing and acting, but overall this film is so well-made in every area of production. It may not be my personal favourite of McDonagh's, but it is one of his strongest directorial efforts to date. It's essentially flawless in my mind, there is not much to criticize at all. While it is a very unorthodox film and has a very small scale plot, it is a must see for this year and is a top contender for the Oscars! Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson are excellent here, proving that whenever they work with Martin McDonagh the result will be perfection! This is one of my favourites of the year, I loved it! Who doesn't want to laugh about heartbreak?

reviews.review_title: Perpetuating stereotypes only Gleeson can overcome
reviews.content: This was a lovely film about the hardships of growing up outcast from society and struggling with friendship. It centers around the titular islands off of Ireland, during their Civil War. Not many will realize after watching this film that Ireland boasts one of the most thriving modern economies, and that despite the border which enshrouds its legacy there are only 18% of the Irish counties within that district which rebel against the Christian doctrine. My aunt and uncle are members of a local traditional Irish music band and play at bars frequently within the area. Directly from them, I learned about Riverdance and the culture of Gaelic traditions. My uncle plays the Irish flute, and my aunt plays the fiddle. The problems with this movie are major, however. The violence with Gleeson really overshadow the meaningfulness which was intended for the film. They could have done away with some of the violent imagery. As a fan of horror movies, even I was taken aback by the scenes when they had very little payoff and even smaller plot building around them. Other parts of the movie remind me of Terrence Malick's Days of Heaven, but with even more authenticity. Also subtracting from the film were superstar Colin Farrel's spray tan. How could a man on the islands of Ireland use so much spray tan? His performance was on par, but his often-confused facial expressions did little to enhance the script. Barry Keoghan was underutilized, I thought, yet brought a lot more to the movie than Farrel and his overutilized sister. The movie perpetuates myths about Ireland which could have been chiseled away at, I thought. However, it was an enjoyable, lighthearted movie with its hands just on too many deep pockets of emotion to hold together perfectly. Had it been a little simpler with violence, and a little less overacted by Farrel, it could have been golden. Also, I thought there were supposed to be banshees? Where's the banshees?

reviews.review_title: Good film, let down by poor dialogue
reviews.content: Overall, a very good film. The story, the acting, the setting are all great. I wouldn't be a big fan of Colin Farrell but he gets it exactly right here. I've seen his accent unfairly criticised by some but for me, he gets it more or less right. (Note for the non-Irish reader: Ireland has many, quite distinct accents, and that is not Farrell's real accent, even though he really does have an Irish accent, so what I meant is that he gets the new accent right, for me.) Gleeson's accent was more of his own, and slightly out of place, and Keoghan's accent let him down in an otherwise excellent performance. Kerry Condon was flawless.The story was odd but still believable. The distant backdrop of the civil war rang true. Pat Short played the character he always plays but it worked well here.The only real issue is the dialogue. There were too many instances of characters saying things Irish people (especially Irish people of that era) wouldn't say, and while McDonagh usually gets Ireland right, here, he's betrayed by his London upbringing, I think. It affects the suspension of disbelief, to someone actually genuinely familiar with Ireland.That being said, non-Irish audiences will miss most if not all of that, and the film is great otherwise, so I could see some awards coming. Keoghan and Condon have to be dark horses for supporting actor/actress Oscars. Well worth a watch.

reviews.review_title: Masterclass in acting, writing and direccting.
reviews.content: A beautiful, sad and funny movie about the loss of friendship and what can cause this in a person. It is a very rich film that deserves all the applause it receives and it is a pure masterclass of acting.The funny thing is that it seems like Martin McDonagh made kind of a prequel to "In Bruges" with Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson portraying similiar characters (yet in different circumstances) and show off the same dynamic. It feels like the film portrays the great-grand parents of those two In Bruges' characters. The environment of course is different and extremly unique in its own way. Colin Farrell surely gives one of his greatest performances and this is the film he will most likely be remembrered forever for. He was brave to show all kind of different emotions that he hesitated to show most of his film career. Brendan Gleeson is simply terrific. Finally he gets the recoginition he is overdue for a long time already. Its such an interesting character and constantly unpredictable. Then you have Barry Keoghan who hits the final straw of becoming one of the respected actors of his career. He really has the most tragic charaxcter of all and he masters it marvelously next to the two more famous actors besides him. Kerry Condon also gives an extremly beautiful performance full of strengths. From that perspective the film is already a winner but then we also have a very well balanced direction by Martin McDonagh and an extremly well drafted screenplay by him. Thi sin addition to a fantasic cinematography and great score makes this film a true masterpiece of the year. The ending was a bit bleak but I think that will grow on me on future encounters with the film.Truely one of the best of the year.

An allegorical story of the civil war that destroys the country, set on a small Irish island where everything is going equally wrong, despite the apparent routine calm.Life is made of social bonds, some good, some bad. You have to accept some to be able to enjoy the others. This is true both at the individual and collective level, in friendship as well as in community and national relationships. Severing these ties leads to mutual destruction, loneliness, and death.Instead of revenge and blackmail, only mutual acceptance and cooperation can lead to the development and fulfillment of individual and collective aspirations.A beautiful film, profound, poetic, beautifully photographed, set to music and performed.

As a devotee of McDonagh's previous work, In Bruges and Three Billboards Outside Ebbings Missouri, my expectations were high but still tempered with some trepidation....everyone is due a fall eventually! This was another success.McDonagh again uses a mundane setting to construct a narrative around human relationships wherein a complexity of attitudes, values, behaviours and needs unfold. Dark humour is juxtaposed against profound tragedy; absurd incidents are aligned with banal events to resounding effect. The dialogue is both comedic and poignant.....you are invited to laugh and then subsequently cry, as used to meaningfully in 3 Billboards, but again exercised here with a deft touch.The film is rich and layered, enabling personal interpretation, the ending being a superb example, where actions can be read as metaphors. The Irish setting of the time, with the significant sinister presence of the civil war, is perhaps being played out in microcosm within this isolated community...?? The characters are maybe symbolic and representative of any community and thus depict the tensions that can exist therein.....if we dont talk and listen, bad things can happen! The portrayal of the police officer is a case study in itself.The cinematography adds as a constant backdrop to this enigmatic tragicomedy. The development of Mrs McCormick as a the "banshee" heralding death grows with the tonal transition of the film....from cliched old lady to quirky harbinger of doom.The acting, and its direction of, is excellent...kudos to Berry Keoghan especially!A thought provoking piece of art entertainment which should be watched again and again. Thankyou once again, Martin McDonagh.

I paid good money to see this film, I'd pay the same (or more) to remove its memory from my Brain.Great cast, director and location but all seemed intent on making something so unpleasant for no apparent reason. There were times in the film when it seemed things wouldn't be so bad and then they just got even worse.I'm done here, but just like the film I'll repeat myself for no apparent reason!I paid good money to see this film, I'd pay the same (or more) to remove its memory from my Brain.Great cast, director and location but all seemed intent on making something so unpleasant for no apparent reason. There were times in the film when it seemed things wouldn't be so bad and then they just got even worse.

reviews.review_title: Where is the comedy in this dark comedy?
reviews.content: I'm leaving this review as a warning/heads up, primarily for other viewers like myself. If you have past trauma or fear around social isolation and/or suicide ideation, I'd take a pass on this film. For me this film was overwhelmingly bleak and lacking in comedy. The beginning was fine, but before the first hour was up the comedy seemed to have disappeared. This movie somehow seemed to touch on underlying themes of some of my worst memories and some of my worst fears. I love a good dark comedy, but for me I couldn't find this film comical. This film left me with hopelessness and dread in the pit of my stomache.Beyond the content, however; I can acknowledge that the acting, cinematography, dialog, filming location, and many other aspects of the production were top notch. Especially the acting. Colin Farrel, Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon, and Barry Keoghan all did fantastic jobs.

Besides the lovely, brooding cinematography and good performances, there is little to recommend this dreary tale of loneliness, despair and self-loathing.In this tale of whoa, all the elements, from the foggy, damp and chilly weather, to the slate grey, forbidding ocean, to the rocky and treeless landscape, segmented by crude granite walls and dotted with bleak, forlorn, nearly windowless dwellings, seemingly conspire to suck the life from the inhabitants of this melancholy Irish island. There is even a banshee-like crone who appears periodically and speaks only of doom and sad tidings. The gloomy atmosphere pervades even the pub, where smiles are absent, and mirthless fiddlers play without emotion.The characters are as follows:
1. The protagonist, Padraic, a simple but well-meaning "good" man, who loses what cheerfulness and happiness he has when his only friend 'unfriends' him to pursue music seriously through his fiddle. With the death of his donkey, he turns bitter and hateful.2. The friend, who mourns a life of idle pursuits, and ends up cutting his own fingers off to spite Padraic.3. The policeman, who sexually abuses and beats his dim-witted son until he commits suicide by drowning.4. The priest that hates his job.5. Padraic's sister, who escapes the island to take a job on the mainland.We never learn anything endearing about these characters and I saw no humor in their dilemmas.

One can easily experience or feel pull over emotions,surely not everybody's cup of tea...coz of Colm Doherty could have one valid reason for not to patch with pardraic would have convinced to connect audience a lot...
As my prediction i strongly believe Gleeson could win an Oscar for this role whose performance is arguably the best...
Despite having a futile role Colin Farrell couldn't match Gleeson ability when it comes to deliver...
Martin does get a golden opportunity for the Oscars to be won under best director category..
The film skillfully toggles between tragedy and realism to manage this timeless classic...
Overall a thought provoking fable about two men whose relationship goes wrong shot with gorgeous visual grandeur does stay in ur mind for sometime.

reviews.review_title: Adult children crack under the weight of the evil of Christianity
reviews.content: There's a moment in this dreary talkathon where a character notes that people around him are acting like "12-year-olds". That says everything about this monotonous, pretentious tale. Sure, the acting is fine. And yes, the scenery is at times wonderful. But the characters? You could place this story in a teen movie from the USA or anywhere else in the world, replacing religion with abusive parents or school teachers. There's an ugliness that permeates every scene of these adolescent, dull people. They're awful. There's no other way to put it. What a waste of some fine acting talent. Playing children is never easy.

reviews.review_title: Good actings and some sharp writing
reviews.content: Two women in a general store: Ever hear the one about the two best friends who got in a feud years and years ago?! Such a row!One could imagine such a conversation taking place on the (fictional) Isle of Inisherin today. Back in 1923, the pair, Padraic (Colin Farrell) and Colm (Brendan Gleeson) are drinking buddies. Every afternoon after he's attended to his flock of animals, Padraic comes around Colm's humble home near the coast and they head to the local pub. That is, until one day when Colm decides he's heard enough of his friend's stories and just wants to be left alone with his fiddle, which completely flummoxes his pal. Padraic lives with his spinster sister, Siobhan (Kerry Condon), who unlike her brother, is well read and curious of the outside world. Unable to keep his mouth shut, Padraic only antagonizes Colm further and further until it's a full on feud.Inisherin is just off the Irish coast, so close, that the locals can see and hear the sounds of battle raging during the mainland's civil war. The people of Inisherin enjoy being on an island to themselves, even if that isolation is as much of a burden as a benefit. The local half-wit, Dominic (Barry Keoghan) is abused by his father (Gary Lydon), who happens to also be the only cop around. The local Priest (David Pearse) can be as foul-mouthed as his Parishioners. Lurking around the fringes of the land is a real life Banshee in the form of Mrs. McCormick who is always spreading her gloom and doom about town.Writer-Director Martin McDonagh writes sharp dialogue, often tinged with a caustic humor. As with IN BRUGES and THREE BILLBOARDS OUTSIDE EBBING MISSOURI, that wit presages darker turns. The Irish Civil War is clearly used as a metaphor for the feud. Colm searches for more meaning in his life through music, while Padraic is content with leading his simple existence. They are like brothers, but, the friction only grows. It's "war".Farrell and Gleeson are very good here. Their real life friendship adds all the more realism to the battle of wills that ensues. Condon is in many ways the conscience of the movie. She loves her brother and Inisherin, but, she too needs more out of life. As fine as all the cast is, McDonagh never quite manages to fully explore his symbolism. The pub is sparsely attended, and most of the other locals only seem to interact when its convenient for the story to do so. One never gets a true sense of community. And, in that vacuum, the Padriac-Colm skirmish comes off as bitter if not outright nasty - it ends up feeling more mean than meaningful. McDonagh is trying to exposie a dark hole in the soul of the Irish people, but can't quite bring it off. Still, it's hard to criticize a movie for ambition, especially one as well-crafted and performed as THE BANSHEES OF INISHERIN.

reviews.review_title: Crazy Alone and Needs of (Brotherly) Love
reviews.content: Its a somber slice of life about two friend who just stopped being friends. Its gets really worse for those involved.Farrell and Gleeson take center stage as the two friends turned enemies who's odd disposition is really difficult to write into words. Its a bit of complexity that shockingly is better left watched. Barry Keoghan also hold himself as a satyrs lost and wayward with the increasing isolation he is feeling with his father's abuse and everyone's disgust of him. Kendon, whose portrayal of straight act of the film, is also noteworthy. The film together with its masterful script really is sight to behold. That script is practically the one of the wittiest film scripts I had watched in while.Overall, this film is a such a shocking delight. I have a really hard time pinning what I felt about this film but the funny moments and ultimately its darkest compliments each other in an operatic way. Its just works AND its makes sense EVEN with all the craziness. Would rewatch in the future.

reviews.review_title: A Really Great Dark Comedy Film
reviews.content: I found The Banshees Of Inisherin quite silly at the first 45 minutes because of you know, reason of the main story, but it's not bad at all, and i ended up found that The Banshees Of Inisherin as a really great dark comedy film with incredible performances by all the cast and the sillyness of the story ended up to be a really really great fascinating amazing story, i was really investedly growing to the story throughout the time, while not emotionally in the characters i still found it great, it is entertaining, engaging, partially funny and mostly depressing, The Banshees Of Inisherin was surely something special, it's nothing i've ever seen and it's incredible!

reviews.review_title: Minimalist, effective, fun, brutal. The best of 2022.
reviews.content: When a movie has an original script that seems to be taken from a book with the status of a classic of universal literature, you have no choice but to surrender to each and every one of its details.The Banshees of Inisherin is minimalist and austere in many of its resources, but they are used masterfully. The locations encourage some of the best cinematography in Ireland, which is more than achieved in this film. The best of all, after the script, are the performances. I would venture to say, knowing that this is very rare, that the entire cast has been simply phenomenal, from Colin Ferrell to the lady who ran the bazaar.Overall, it's a funny but sad story. Innocent, but brutal. Minimalist, but ambitious. It is definitely one of the best movies of 2022.

reviews.review_title: Rather perfect cast...wasted on a perfectly bad film...
reviews.content: Slow, and sad, eventually winding down to - no point. Possibly one of the worst films I have seen in years.Great cast, horrible script & directing. The story starts with a nice Irish guy on a small Irish island - and gradually devolves into the depths of depression, mean-spirited drama and down right irrationality. No epiphanies along the way, no enlightenment - and then it was over.I usually trust IMDB ratings, because they are based on normal people, with common-sense tastes expressing their views.These movie ratings are abnormally high. And with all the "red carpet oohs & ahhs" I have been seeing about this film, I have to suspect the professional critics have been on-board, skewing the numbers.Because I NEVER trust critics - they are too full of themselves and have little concept of what the public needs, wants or likes.And I rarely trust the Academy, because they are too busy selling the agenda-du-jour, as seen from the streets of Hollywood.This happens close to the Academy Awards - the oddest, darkest, most twisted films are touted as the best & brightest. I suspect that's what happened with this one, they are schlepping it around town all polished up with BS - to get an AA.Don't waste your time folks. You will burn a few precious hours - and feel a lot more sad by the time its over. But very glad it was done!

reviews.review_title: Great Acting In this Existential Play In Film
reviews.content: Colin Farrell really hit the nail on the head with his performance . That is his portrayal of this Irish country man is nuanced and very thoughtful .Gleason is also grand in his portrayal of the friend of Farrell's character .The two at lager heads for some unknown reasonOne is serious not to talk to the other but the other maybe a bit slow on the up take .This is about life , death and depression . It's about isolation and friendship . It's many things . It's also dark , violent , and tragic .Their are moments of humour but they punctuate the scenes that flow to a dark and end with really no resolution .Watch this for the performances and the dialogue . It is a great Irish movie .

reviews.review_title: Thought-provoking and dark drama with comedic moments
reviews.content: Technically it's a good movie with superb performances, but what makes it stand out is the message director Martin McDonagh is trying to convey. While comedic moments are sprinkled throughout the movie, they are quite rare. It deals with a heavy but interesting subject and it's likely sadder than you'd imagined. Colin Farrel explained "In Bruges" as a comedy with dark moments and "The Banshees of Inisherin" as a drama with comedic moments.Everyone on the small island called Inisherin is miserable. Only a few hundred people live there is not much to do. Every day is like the last one. It's a recipe for madness.Gleeson's character does not want to be friends with Farrell's character no more. Gleeson wants to focus on his music and find peace in his life. He is not very nice to Farrell and when Gleeson is questioned by Farrell, Gleeson makes the point that being nice will not make people remember you. Farrel then says how he remembers how his mother was nice. So what is more important? Being remembered or being nice? It's very thought-provoking and interesting.This is a strong contender for the Oscar. Farrell and Condon both have very good chances of winning. They are the pillars of this movie. A movie about loneliness and depression.

reviews.review_title: Surprisingly comedic and full of depth
reviews.content: What an odd duck. Yes I mean duck autocorrect; I don't use that other word 😇. This is a story where two friends have an inexplicable falling out. One wants nothing to do with the other, and that animosity, because of the toxic masculinity each possess, festers, boiling over into a modern day comic tragedy. It's genuinely funny and fairly subtle with its communication of themes, some of which I thought resonated even more with me, living in a small town where I know no one. Great performances, great shot compositions. I can see why it's already a darling. The stupidity of men on display might be exasperating for some, but at least here they primarily hurt each other. I'd be sailing away too.

reviews.review_title: The overlooked and under appreciated message of this film
reviews.content: I've seen a lot of negative reviews here but it seems like the underlying concept has gone over a lot of people's heads.The movie paints a very realistic picture of slow, Irish country living; the script, the characters, story, and imagery portray a true Irish charm, and a dreariness that depicts the 1920s in Ireland as it really was.The main character's actions are seemingly nonsensical, which is unsettling and confusing to watch. But as the movie progresses, the absurdity of the characters' actions suddenly begin to make sense; we are eventually supposed to realise the symbolic connection between the absurdity of the Irish Civil war and the absurdity of the characters' actions.At the end of the movie, when the two men stand on the beach and talk about the Civil war coming to an end, suddenly so much makes sense.If you think of the two main characters in this movie as a representation of the two sides at war in Ireland in the 1920s, it becomes a deep and meaningful message delivered in a very powerful way: Just like at war, the men fought with each other for what seemed like absurd, unjustifiable reasons, they harmed themselves, and their stubbornness just caused greater destruction. And just like in times of war; the woman left, and the young man died. I think it is especially powerful for the Irish who were affected by the Civil War in recent history.This film was incredibly acted, beautifully pictured, and the subtle meaning behind the confusing and unsettling storyline was all the more powerful because it was so elegantly hidden in front of our eyes the entire movie.

The symbolism in the Banshees of Inisherin (2022), is everywhere. The whole film feels like a commentary on loneliness. First off, the film takes place, exactly 100 years ago, on a tiny island, off of the coast of Ireland. The sparsely, small population, moving about, around this island, either walking, riding a bike or traveling in a horse cart, also have access to the mainland, via boats, at their tiny island port. But, the isolation is felt, all throughout the film. This isolation is the island itself, which enhances the loneliness, but maybe the isolation is a good thing, as the explosions of civil war are heard, just over the hills on the mainland. From here, the loneliness moves further into the story, as we meet our two main characters, Colm (Brendan Gleeson) and Pádraic (Colin Farrell). Colm is a musician, who lives alone with his dog. Pádraic is a boring milk farmer, who lives with his bored, lonely sister, Siobhán (Kerry Condon). She definitely needs a change of scenery. The loneliness carries over into the supporting cast, as evidenced by Pádraic's friend, Dominic (Barry Keoghan). Dominic tries to help Pádraic's situation with Colm, while struggling with his own, dead-beat father, the island policeman, Peadar (Gary Lydon). Their tragic, complicated existence takes place, in another lonely house.Whenever the plot takes you into any of their homes, the mood feels lonely and isolated, in every scene. One day, Colm decides he doesn't like Pádraic anymore and ends their long friendship. Of course, this makes no sense to Pádraic and our story turns into a complex character study, as we try to unravel why their friendship is over. In-between funny situations and banter between the characters, the plot gets even more, shockingly interesting, as Colm has to increase his threats, because Pádraic won't stay away from him. The cast in this film does a brilliant job with their performances. It's no wonder this film was nominated for nine Oscars. Four of those were for cast members. Farrell and Gleeson, both deserve the Oscar nod, with their totally believable portrayals, of the two sides of this story. The calm clash between these two forces, is ever so incredibly polite, yet you literally feel things, unraveling even more.This film is a comedy-drama, but it does get serious in places and sometimes does teeter on the edge of fantasy too, especially when we see the image of the island elder, Mrs. McCormick (Sheila Flitton), who resembles any of the classic gypsy-women or witches from Hollywood's past. It's also the ultimatum, Colm gives to Pádraic, that is carried out to its shocking, unbelievable conclusion, which enhances the fantastic angle of the film. This film is well-shot and the island's pale, chilly, isolated loneliness, is still depicted as respectful beauty, because of the excellent cinematography. The mood is represented just right. I totally agree, that the Banshees of Inisherin (2022), deserves its Oscar nods, but what keeps me from giving this film a 9/10, is the lack of a soundtrack, which hampers the pacing of the film, making it slow-down a little, but I did enjoy this film a lot.8.7 (B+ My Grade) = 8 IMDB.

This film was magic.The setting, costumes, music and screenplay were stunning, really capturing a place and time - made me feel as though I were really there.It was truly hilarious in parts, gruesome in others and harrowing.Colin Farrell's eyes could have told the story on their own - his performance was outstanding, I felt for him so much.Barry Keoghan's character was heart breaking, he played it so beautifully and of course, Brendan Gleeson was wonderful. I had never seen Kerry Condon before, but she was amazing, she showed so much - her character was so tender and kind.A lot did happen in this film, but it somehow felt very simple and understated, and it was beautiful in this. I felt as though it really captured feelings of depression and longing and frustration, and a desire to be remembered.Feeling very grateful to have seen such wonderful film making, and in knowing that this film is out there for me to watch again and again.

Having recently watched Andrew Haigh's brilliant indie "45 Years", what struck me about "The Banshees of Inisherin" is how similar the two films are thematically, exploring the tension naturally borne from man's vainglorious obsession with creating a lasting legacy for himself (once he reaches a certain age), which results in an inability to appreciate the relationships he's formed in the past, consequently neglecting them in the present in a self-centred attempt to influence the future. Therefore, although lacking in anything particularly original to say, creator Martin McDonagh brings to this familiar concept a totally different (comedic) tonal approach (which differentiates it from the rest, gifting the piece with a quirky personality), effectively doing justice to the tragedy of the tale (depicting how pathetic it is, in the grand scheme of things) whilst humorously coming at it from a totally unique angle, inventively using the period & isolated location to poetically reflect the fact that although the islanders are separated from the war playing out across the water on the mainland (seemingly spared from the horrors taking place elsewhere), they are equally at odds with their own enemies (within) which manifest themselves physically in lands closer to home - & thus, despite the naive perception of peace surrounding them, equal amounts of destructive conflict are erupting at either side of the ocean between those in one location & the other (juxtapositioning the visual tranquility by holding a true mirror to the character's behaviours, in the sea which divides the two).Plus, the film acts as a social commentary, chronicling the inevitability of bloodshed when communication breaks down amongst those who have a disagreement (regardless of how petty), which is often exacerbated by toxic masculinity & an unwillingness to simply talk about one's feelings with other males. That point is only reaffirmed by the fact that the only individual who actually seems to get through to either side is Pádraic's sister, a woman - residing above the behavioural limitations imposed by their socially incompetent gender.All of this nuance is carefully embedded within a seemingly light hearted flick, enriching the viewing experience all the more further & I feel as though I haven't even scratched the surface of how deep this plunges. That's how good it is.

Really one of the worst movies I have ever seen. Absolutely loss of time. Go better to have a good dinner with your partner, instead watching this movie. Of course Colin Farrell performs very good but it's still not worth watching this movie! You are excepting all the time a intelligent or a exciting message or just something during the movie but unfortunately until the end NOTHING! We were thinking to go home in the middle of the movie but we thought we give this a chance, but nothing until the end! We regret to loss our time and money that bad movie. Again, spend your time somewhere else and don't watch this movie!

As a black comedy, you'd think there would be some levity. The darker it gets, the more revolting it is. Really one or two laughs early on. But the context generally was sickening. And the senseless of it was terrible. Why make a film this disgusting and disturbing? I see few redeeming factors.The photography was wonderful. But, portraying this kind of mental illness and moronic attitudes is pointless. I feel very sorry for the actors that participated.Senseless sadness topped with useless ignorance. Heartbreaking, of course, but also so far from any reality. No redeeming value in my opinion. I'm apparently in the minority. So be it.

reviews.review_title: Such a simple plot but the execution is sophisticated
reviews.content: Seeing Colin Farrell in this film is treat enough for me as I am a fan of his work. Then we get the bonus of Barry Keoghan from "Chernobyl" and also "The Killing of a Sacred Deer," and Kerry Condon from "Better Call Saul" as Mike Ermentraut's daughter-in-law. I am not familiar with the older actor Brendan Gleeson but he is also outstanding. The other two standouts from this movie are the breathtaking landscapes and the fascinating Irish dialogue. Altogether, we have a unique film injected with dark humor and piercing sadness all in one. The pace is just right, luring you in, following along to realize some of life's deep existential philosophies. Quite a feat for a movie with the most simple plot to come around.

reviews.review_title: Too much moral view at stake.
reviews.content: As I come from a culture that many things and problem could be solved by some good will discussion, it was quite difficult for me to understand and enjoyed the story. Too many "why not this, and why not that" questions pops out in my mind.I got into quite a heavy argument with my wife just to find the answer of the most common thing when we watch a movie: "Who's the bad guy? And what is the motive?".The argument got a little bit tense so I ended up by shutting my mouth.That's how interesting this movie is, and of course by Farrel's act that might made you to would be having a wild respond to loneliness, confusion and desperation.

reviews.review_title: I knew it but watched it anyways
reviews.content: With a great cast I had hope although I had it pegged from the beginning that this wouldn't be my cup of tea. And it wasn't. I wanted to get pulled in by the characters but wasn't and didn't really care what happened to them or how it ended.I can't think of anything in real life that is so off kilter and how stupid both their characters are. From one that is crushed when his life long friend tells him to leave him alone to the other character who starts chopping off his fingers every time the crushed one talks to him. I mean who does this. I guess I was looking for some connection to reality but both lead characters are insane.That said, I give high marks to Colin and Brendan for their portrayal. Takes a dark mind to write this script and call it a movie; but then there is a lot of 'stuff' out there parading as a movie.

reviews.review_title: If you didn't get the film
reviews.content: This is a really deep film about the Irish. You need to dip your toes a bit into Irish culture and history to be able to fully enjoy/understand it. The Irish Civil War happened exactly 100 years ago. This movie is a tribute to it.The two protagonists are the metaphor for the war. Best friends turning against each other for reasons only they think make sense. For everyone else it's just madness. This is civil war, right? I'm right, you are wrong. Yet we are still friends hurting each other.One of them just want peace and want to be left alone. After the war of independence the Free State just want peace and recovery. Turn to something meaningful. Trying to achieve something instead of wasting time. (on fighting and chasing a dream)The other one wants the old times back and sees this "peace" a betrayal. The things that made them, the bond that made the pair was the fight for independence. The Anti-Treaty IRA wants to keep on fighting to achieve full freedom. At all cost. It made sense when they fought together, why stop now?

Don't do it. Preposterous and just plain boring. Tha Academy will love it, which is all you need to know.If this is genuinely considered entertainment then I totally understand why our children are enthralled by their hand-held digital thingys.The parts are well acted, the scenery is authentic to the storyline, it has very mildly amusing moments... But... The plot if that's what it is, will leave you begging for the end to put you out of your misery. I watched this on a TV streaming service saw numerous good reviews. What were they truly enjoying? This film makes Power of the Dog dynamic. Actually, no it doesn't.

This movie was terrible! Cannot believe it was nominated for all those awards. I was waiting for it to get good but it got worse and worse and worse. I will never get back the time I wasted. Run. Do not watch this.This movie was terrible! Cannot believe it was nominated for all those awards. I was waiting for it to get good but it got worse and worse and worse. I will never get back the time I wasted. Run. Do not watch this.This movie was terrible! Cannot believe it was nominated for all those awards. I was waiting for it to get good but it got worse and worse and worse. I will never get back the time I wasted. Run. Do not watch this.

reviews.review_title: An Amusing Film but Odd Slice of Life
reviews.content: The leads have fun with their quirky scripted dialogue and relationship. With some quirky island residents and animals as supporting cast. No one ever behaves like this place in real life. Maybe it's meant as a metaphor on the Irish people themselves, they can be "nice" but prone to self-hurt, despair and nonsense combat, like their civil and Protestant/Catholic wars, with 2pm pub time and fiddle music. The sister gets frustrated with the menfolk and actually does something does something constructive, similar to the way the Irish women forced the end of the IRA wars in the 1990s. Jenny the mini donkey steals the show.

I love Irish movies because I get to use the word fek in my review. Hey, if it's good enough for the Irish, it's feking good enough for me.First of all, my feking wife made me watch this horrible feking movie.I should have known it was going to be feking horrible, she has no feking taste in movies whatsoever.At the end of the movie I asked myself "what the fek did I just watch?"
I rated it 10 stars because otherwise I knew nobody would ready my feking review.If you like movies that have lots of weird stuff that makes no sense then this feking movie is for you.Did the person who wrote this script take some feking drugs? I'm pretty feking sure he did.Sure the acting is good and so is the filming but I think the actors will someday look back at this one and ask themselves "why the fek did I do this one"?And one last thing. Why did the feking cute little donkey have to feking die?F count, 14. Or was is feking 15?

reviews.review_title: Grateful Films Like This Still Get Made
reviews.content: The Banshees of Inisherin is a superbly-made film. Sorry folks, no superheroes or fantastical, sappy love story here! Just very good, original storytelling of the sort that you've never seen or heard before, and a fascinating study of relationships, people, and life in a beautiful, natural setting.I'm a lifelong lover of movies and of the potential they offer to tell riveting stories of value that keep you thinking long after, while transporting you into somebody else's life experience for two hours, and that's what this film is. The Banshees of Inisherin is the type of movie that is sorely lacking in today's lineup of offerings, having been overrun by huge, money-generating, bubblegum junk, featuring grown people dressed in ridiculous costumes doing ridiculous things very seriously.Don't get me wrong, I enjoy a good superhero movie now and again. But in a healthy and sane world, I wouldn't have to sift through 9,000 of them in order to find a single quality film, more anchored in real life, that doesn't rely on CGI to sell itself.Many of the other reviewers complain that this movie is a waste of their time and it is disgusting and horrible and blah blah blah. You're right. For you, you're right. Go find something different. But I for one am very grateful that movies like this still get made. Yes, there are some really curious decisions and actions made by some of the characters in this film. That's part of the humanity of it that gets your mind asking questions like: Why? What must be going on inside of that person? What are they feeling? What's going on in their heads? Are there any situations where I might find myself thinking and feeling in similar ways? How would I hope to handle it? Ten Stars.

I am pleasantly surprised with how much I liked this movie, I watched it Christmas Eve and then again Christmas Day with family and on the second watch I really fell for the movie.In the beginning the hype hearing it was the best movie ever kinda took me out of the movie and my expectations were too high, on the second watch my mindset was for pure enjoyment and that's what I got from it !!Many scenes were actually really funny and the story itself starts somewhat normal and goes mentalI'm not sure how the world will take this movie or even understand it, it is so Irish, it's classed as a black/dark comedy which it is but it's 100% Irish wittiness start to end and I really liked it, I hope other countries will enjoy your dry humour too.Definitely a must watch, don't go in with the mindset of the best movie and fast paced, it's not, just go into it with an open mind and for a laugh.

I really wanted to like this movie but as it went on it got more and more depressing and bizarre. Made my stomach turn. Wasn't expecting a comedy to be so tragic. The scenery was beautiful and the actors were excellent but the story was so over the top weird. I couldn't imagine this chain of events to be a plausible plot. Such a shame that it went so very dark and disturbing. My husband got up and refused to watch the rest of it. I continued on but then I just had enough and turned it off. After reading a review which told me that things went continually down hill and got even darker, I'm glad that I ended my distress. I had been so looking forward to seeing this movie.

Absolutely loved this movie. Watched due to Colin and Brendan working together again. I wasn't t disappointed; in fact I was absolutely delighted to watch a movie that had this level of greatness. Perhaps an over the top comment but there hasn't been a lot of decent movies for some time. Seriously. Easy to predict with bad acting and writing. I had lost all hope. Luckily this gem was made; involving people who know how to act, write and direct.It's brilliant, funny and incredibly sad. Island life is not easy; friends and family are everything. And your pets. Jenny the wee donkey stole the show. Highly recommend.

reviews.review_title: Terrible, only watched until the end because of high ratings.
reviews.content: This was a sad excuse for a movie, not to mention, Nominated for "Best Picture".Who are they Kidd here, when all you learn or glean from this movie is that one or both men are Mentally Insane, which is very obvious with the older man, who self-mutilates himself without any regrets.To be labeled as a Drama/Comedy is another part of the Insanity, as it is barely funny at all and the story simply doesn't work.I gave 1/2 a Star for the Dimmest Character who had to act challenged as though he were trying to be star in the movie "Rain Man".I only watched this all the way the through because of the Oscar Nomination and high ratings, but the Professional Reviewers in this World must be part of the "Dumbed Down" movement!The actual "Best Picture" winner should be "Top Gun Maverick", which is so well made with Filmography that is cutting edge and has never been done before, as well as the fact that the whole Family will enjoy it and it has the quality and story that makes you want to watch it over and over, which is a must quality to seriously be considered for "Best Picture or Film".I will add "Avatar: The way of the Water" as the only other competition for the Best Picture Award, in my opinion.

I love the cinema and go often. I recognise and experienced all the emotions that this spectacular but quiet film has aroused in me personally. I just want to say I have never left a cinema feeling how I did this afternoon. Just go and see it. Best film I have ever seen. I see I have to put another 296 characters to be able to post this review. I can't do that. This film is so personal. I don't want to comment on the cinematography and the stunning location, the acting skills of everyone in it, I don't want to say it's going to win every Oscar going. It's a quiet contemplative personal experience.

reviews.review_title: Turned it off, pile of poop
reviews.content: That's not my summary of the film, it's a friend. Excitedly went to see this at an early screening at the cinema and was sorely disappointed. I understand it is based on an early piece of work by McDonagh and for me that came through. The nuance and polish of In Bruges for example was missing.Supremely disappointed and I did feel that it was just me, given so many people and the reviewers are so positive about the film. However, as the title of my post suggests it's not just me.Barry Keoghan was stand out in the film, I have to agree. Farrell and Gleeson didn't hold the film together. Give it a miss and watch The Menu, a far superior film.

reviews.review_title: Civil war across the water, and in ourselves
reviews.content: Complete with an Ancient Greek Tragedy chorus of one, who is presumably the main Banshee, with Kerry Condon, Colin Farrell's "sister" groomed by happenstance to possibly become her successor if she does not get away, The Banshees of Inisherin feels, in fact, closer to a Greek Tragedy than a Shakespearean one. In either case, the movie, a community isolated in more ways than one across from a civil-war-ridden mainland, is to be taken as a metaphor. Taking it literally would simply raise the question of why not commit Gleeson's character to a mental institution and ultimately would ask whether this experience of just under two hours is the purpose of Cinema? So, I will see the whole thing as metaphor.The performances genuinely showcase the craft of these actors and are worth the viewing just to watch them, especially Barry Keoghan. The photography, the sets and overall look and feel are truly inspired and without a blemish.This movie is truly an experience and if one refrains from asking "so what?" or pointing out that in two hours the audience deserves at least one moment of feeling good, and if one simply accepts that life is hard and then you die, then, this is a masterpiece in explaining drifting apart, alienation and the frequent inability to find anything positive to hold on to and overcome one's own demons as well as the inevitable.

This is a movie about the human condition. It's about 2 best friends one of whom simply one day decided that he had more important things to do in life rather than "wasting" any more time with his best friend. And the story just gets more depressing from there.What gives it a real sense of depth and feel is the acting, you really needed 2 actors that could pull it off beautifully, and the supporting cast did their jobs perfectly. The sister for example was fantastic. The animals played a great part in this entire endeavor as well. All in all this was a masterclass in emotion and humans being left to their own devices.7/10 so why only 7? Because despite it being fantastic in both acting and feeling, it was one of the most pointless movies I've ever seen. You could best describe it as boredom personified.

I'm giving this nine instead of ten because I never trust tens, they always seem to be generated by bots promoting dross, but this marvellous movie merits top marks. Variously poignant and hilarious, every performance is a delight. I can't understand anyone who gave a poor rating to this film. There was so much to enjoy, I can see myself watching this over and over again, and the films I could say that of don't come along every day. Colin Farrell was fabulous, but the real standout for me was Barry Keoghan. Beautifully and sensitively played by the young man, well deserving of any awards that come his way.

reviews.review_title: Dumb and Dumber in Ireland make a beautiful looking film
reviews.content: The first thing to say about The Banshees of Inishirin is that aesthetically it is one of the most beautifully shot films I have ever seen. The cinematography is really amazing. You should watch it for this reason alone. The scenery, choice of locations, the wide shots and the camerawork make this truly a feast for the eyes. Just breathtaking.The story of this film is basically two grown man on a sparsely populated Irish island who decide to behave like 6 year olds and take it to it's ultimate conclusion. I know while watching we should look for themes like friendship, loss, mortality angst etc,, but ultimately I felt I was watching nothing more than Dumb and Dumber, where one decided he didn't want to be friends no more and the other could not accept it. Does this make it a bad film? No, the story is unusual and original and engaging enough to keep you watching. Also half way through the film takes a dark turn and you are not sure what is going to happen next. The acting was really great, but I would not have expected anything less with this great cast of actors.So is this a great film? No. Whereas in a hundred years time we will still be watching Brendan Gleeson and Pat Shortt in The Guard (2011) and Barry Keoghan in '71 (2014), both truly great films that you can see over and over again, I would be surprised if anyone would watch The Banshees of Inishirin again after seeing it once.

reviews.review_title: Solid performances but the story lacks aim.
reviews.content: After watching The Banshees of Inisherin i have to say i am a little on the fence with my thoughts. The acting is 10 out of 10 there is no doubt about that, i can sense some Oscar nominations to be on the way. Same goes for the cinematography, somewhat throughout the movie i felt like i was watching an old film. The story is set in the 1920s so it makes sense to film it that way, cold and gritty. Writer/Director Martin McDonagh does an excellent job on the movies overall tone. Not a tone we tend to see much of nowadays it's all superhero films and big blockbuster action films. It's nice to see original small story classics making it to the screen again.Then said, i'm not sure on what i feel about the story. The main plot is decent enough and captures the real loneliness a person can go through when feeling alienated, and the depression civil wars can have on friendships. I actually got glued into the story for 3/4 of the film. Although certain plot points started to drag on for too long and others made no sense nor were they resolved or even explained. The old lady with the stick made no sense as we didn't get enough detail on her reasons. The end of the movie just has you sat on a fence trying to make sense on what you've just watched, near to the end of the film i started to scratch my head wondering where the plot was aiming to. What was the aim? I get that people go through this type of stuff and Director Martin McDonagh probably wanted to make the movie as real feeling as possible. It ended up being confusing, but i'm not saying the movie was bad, i really enjoyed the acting and overall tone. I just feel like i've missed something?

reviews.review_title: Humor and drama in the right measure
reviews.content: "Inisherin's Banshees" is a peculiar dramatic comedy, with a touch of English humor and taking place on the Irish coast of the 1920s. His cinematographic style, a mixture of the Coen brothers and Yorgos Lanthimos. The film is well directed, with bluish photography and a soundtrack that guides the feelings on screen, it gives a certain warmth to the cold composition of the scenery, the script is "strange", we have a weak beginning that begins to deepen in several layers and expose some feelings, mainly loneliness, depression and purpose, but this is diluted in its third act, transforming what we saw into a dispute of egos, could this be a criticism of how shallow human beings are? You can, but I don't buy that idea so well. Artistically, what attracts me the most is not its beautiful centered direction or the beautiful long open plans, but the performances, all the actors are impeccable, with emphasis on Kerry Condon, Brendan Gleeson and Brendan Gleeson. "Inisherin's Banshees" received extremely strong favorable and unfavorable reviews, I don't agree with either side, its melancholy and exaggerated humor attracts me, and combining this with beautiful performances, good direction and an irreproachable authorial touch by the director, they form a set of factors that make me like the film, despite its slow pace. Note 8/10.

The Banshees of Inisherin (2022) follows two life-long friends continuing on their lives after one of them chooses to end their friendship. This film has a simple premise that's executed very well and it's understandable as to why this it gets so much praise. It's perfectly acted with subtle cinematography and a brilliant score.The film is visually very subtle yet works well alongside the minimalist concept. It has a beautiful setting, and the set designs have great attention to detail. Every shot is well lit and the colour palettes are bleak and really capture the tone well. The camerawork includes plenty of long shots with good framing that linger on the characters to really bring across the emotion.The movie has nice sound mixing and precise sound design. The score itself is very fitting and quiet, yet really adds a lot to the experience of watching the film. It's extremely mysterious and immersive.The acting is great all around, and the actors have a lot of chemistry with each other which makes their interactions feel very real. Colin Farrell is perfect as Pádraic, he's very likeable and interesting to watch whilst also being strangely relatable. Additionally, Barry Keoghan is brilliant as Dominic and is especially loveable. I was completely heartbroken when he died! These great performances are paired well with the fast and snappy dialogue that carry the film.This movie absolutely nails the tone and pacing. It's a consistently slow and steady film, that builds up the story well and is consistently engaging. It has a very melancholic tone and plenty of shocking and unpredictable moments that really caught me off guard! I like the ending too and feel it ties the story together well.

A loving, attentive pastiche to a specific time and place. It's completely uninterested in anything beyond being an intimate character study, which won't be enough for those who are looking for more bells and whistles.If you're looking for masters in their respective crafts to play in a sandbox for about two hours, you'll find a lot to enjoy with this one.//JUSTICE FOR JENNY AND DOMINIC. So you're just gonna off the only two pure souls on this island? Rude.This film does for cozy navy cable-knit sweaters that "Knives Out" and Chris Evans did for cozy, cream cable-knit sweaters, i.e. I WANT.Jesus Christ Colm, go to therapy already.

One of the great favorites to win the statuette for best film of the year and, frankly, it has plenty of merits to win this recognition. Director Martin McDonagh once again sets precedents as one of the great British directors of the moment and one of the most interesting directors in the industry. After his stupendous Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri in 2017, the director offers us his fourth feature film that once again positions him as one of the great favorites for the awards season.A little masterpiece.We are in the presence of a surprising film thanks to the cunning of a director who writes and directs a film that takes us through black humor, drama and violence in such a consistent way that all you have to do is enjoy a proposal different from what you we are accustomed that it is simply a pleasure while we watch the screen.Interpreted in a brutal and honest way by its cast in which if justice exists they should go as strong candidates for the awards season, especially a Colin Farrell who gives us the best interpretation of his career. The actor is a naturally gifted, but playing Pádraic Súilleabháin he has brought everything to perfection. An interpretation that cuts deep due to its intensity and its uniqueness that is totally hypnotic to the eye.As well as Farrell we cannot leave out Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan who are also brutally inspired that they follow the same rope on the way to the nominations.The wonderful landscapes of Ireland are portrayed by a wonderful photograph by Ben Davis that places us in the solitude of a town where the dissatisfaction of his characters is wrapped up as a great contrast on the screen.A film that tells us about something more than enmity.The intelligence of his script is to take us from a simple premise like enmity for no reason to realize the depth of a script that tells us about the passage of time and all its consequences.It is a film that hides in its black humor a strong drama about how we have lived our lives and how we have wasted time falling into a routine from which we often do not realize how we wasted our opportunities to do something different.Loneliness is also present and the dependence on the lives of others, being routine people in our lives.ConclutionDefinitely, we are in the presence of perhaps the best film of the year or the strongest candidate to stay with the greatest recognition in the industry.A visual and interpretive delight that thanks to its wonderful script we face a film of emotions and sensations about the passage of time and loneliness.

I was initially quite excited to see this film after the good reviews I had seen. I am sorry to say (in my own opinion) it wasn't standout amazing. I am an Irish person living in the west and was utterly distracted with how wrong they got some things. The main story, that two men could fall out over such a thing, is totally okay in my opiniom. I really understood Brendan Gleeson's frustration at his life and the desperation of his situation. Very well done indeed. I don't however appreciate how they portrayed the islanders as being ignorant, strange and completely disconnected from Irish politics. Some of the characters don't feel quite real. For example the pub owner seems a bit like a characture rather than a person. There are stupid mistakes in the setting like when they say "it takes two to tango", nobody in Ireland would use that phrase in that time period. In fact I think they depicted the time period completely wrong overall. It drags on a small bit, there are way too many quiet scenes (but of course others may see as an emphasis on how quiet their lives are). I was looking for a more satisfying ending aswell, it just sort of ended on nothing. It does have it's moments but they are disjointed and too unbelievable. I feel that nothing actually 'happened' and that I could predict where most situations would end up too easily. I think of the movie more as a poem than as a story. In the end I just didn't get it, which is fine. I would still recommend it because most other people did get it, just not for me.

The movie "Banshees of Inisherin" is another excellent film by director Martin McDonagh, who wrote the script and directed it. He returns to the theme of communities that live on the margins of society. This time on an island, where everyone knows each other and tolerates each other. The key player in this movie is the dialogues, McDonagh is an excellent storyteller but the dialogues here are perfect and in tune, with the right amount of comedy and drama. The movie is about friendship, loneliness, tradition, community, and time. Colin Farrell is spectacular, superb as Pádraic Súilleabháin, a lonely man who accepts his fate on the island. It feels like the role was written for him, he is solid and embodies his character with such fluidity and lightness.The movie "The Banshees of Inisherin" is an amazing movie to watch, both visually with beautiful cinematography and traditional Irish ballads.A must to watch!!!

reviews.review_title: Interesting, different, I think I liked it.
reviews.content: It had me captivated the whole way, the premise of the film is so simple but the resolution is hard to fathom. What do you do when someone just doesn't want to be friends anymore but they're all you have? I was so curious how they would tie up the ending. It did a lot of unexpected things, Gleeson's character starts off as relatable, he wants to create a legacy in music and he doesn't have time for his friend but then in avoiding the friendship he's being unintentionally nasty. In response Farrell is spiteful in return but this just leaves them both depressed. In the end Gleeson character realises he is depressed with life not his friend and his friend gives him the option to die and he doesn't take it, in essence Farrell cures his depression, he realises all that matters is being nice to others and his friendship inspires him to make a new song. Unfortunately though Farrells character can't let it all go he loses everything and becomes toughened by it all, but he is nice still in the end offering to look after the dog. So my takeaway was that life is more than what you leave the world after you die but being nice to those around you while you live. The subplot of his sister leaving was sad too for Keoghan character dying but I feel that was more reflecting on the themes with the Policeman, he was also self loathing and taking it out on others around him but losing his son who he treated badly made him have the same realisation that you only have the good deeds you do while alive and the people you help. So in a bittersweet ending they all realise they only have themselves to blame for their different versions of despair but living alone to avoid being hurt by anyone isn't an answer, kind of like no one remembers those who only serve themselves.

reviews.review_title: Laugh Out Loud & Cringe at the Same Time Like
reviews.content: My goodness...just watched this movie last night on my funny cable and I don't know what to say about his gem. How a simple premise can be transformed into an Oscar-worthy movie can only be attributed by the Oscar winner for best actor Colin Farrell and his buddy Mr. Brendon Gleeson, winner of best supporting actor.Jenny gets a nod for the best supporting actor for having no dialogue.The characters' dialect makes it a must to stay focused, but even if you miss a few words here and there like, it's OK like. You know like?There are no Banshees in Inisherin, but I guarantee you there will be some Oscars.

A read a critic's review that this film would appeal primarily to art film audiences. Those audiences must be small and certainly not understood by the likes of me. It must be appealing to some level of sophistication unavailable to the masses. The movie could have been really interesting if it stuck to the exploration of a relationship complicated by an aging partner who suddenly realizes his looming immortality and his younger friend who simply can't conceive of the mysterious motivation for the breakup. I guess the sophistication enters when the aging friend and fiddle player resorts to self-mutilation of his left hand in order to prove his iron clad commitment to ending the relationship. And he's able to accomplish the self-mutilation with little pain, minimal bleeding and infection free self- care. Now that's sophisticated!!

"The Banshees of Inisherin" looked funny and had the promise of being a sort of dark comedy "In bruges" reunion. So a group of us went to see it, and it's a decent movie.If you've seen the trailer there isn't much of a story. It's basically about a guy (Brandon Gleeson) who decides he doesn't like his pal (Colin Farrell) anymore. But that being what it's about in itself is funny and it's beautifully made until it gets deliberately darker than you'd have first thought.It's a funny movie because of its great writing and Colin Farrell is really good in the movie as he struggles to understand what's up with Gleeson and himself. A bizare film but parts of it will stay with you in a way the latest superhero film won't.

reviews.review_title: Great message and acting, but slow and boring
reviews.content: I had high expectations, they weren't met. It seems like it's a movie for those fancy film critics. But not the general public. Nothing really happens in the first 2/3 of the movie and it's just starting to get 10% interesting in the last 1/3.After leaving the cinema, I could appreciate the message but during the movie I was bored and couldn't wait for the movie to end.I almost fell asleep several times during the first half and didn't miss anything.Nevertheless, I like the message as said above. When relationship end and only one party contents with it, how does the other react? Especially in a village of 20 people. There are a lot of parallels that can drawn to today relationships.

The banshees of Inisherin is testament to how an excellent writer can take even the most basic of ideas and turn it into a full and entertaining 2 hour film. The idea of 2 men falling out doesn't exactly scream excitement and thrilling but the excellent storywriting and the characters managed to keep me thoroughly enjoying every minute of it.However it's a tale about much more than two men who have a falling out. It clearly marks the importance of friendship, dealing with loneliness and depression, the impending loom of death and the use of comedy to ease the tougher moments in life. The writer deals with incredibly dark topics like a Father abusing his son, a war that's literally on your doorstep, Suicide, and losing the people you love the most. It deals with these matters eloquently and leaves nothing to the imagination, it clearly shows you a simple man's life and the things that happen each step of the way that cause pain, suffering and confusion.It manages to weave the perfect blend of sadness and comedy into the story that keeps you watching eagerly and always wanting to see which path it takes next. I simply loved each of the characters quirks and behaviour and you can just imagine that a little island somewhere in Ireland still has people just like it to this day."It takes two to tango"
"I don't want to tango"
"Well you danced with your dog"
A line that is hardly a stand up comedy zinger but I couldn't help but laugh out loud at Colin Farrells perfect delivery of the last line. This sums up The Banshees perfectly. It's subtle humour and thoroughly thought provoking moments leave an impact on anyone who takes the time to sit down and really focus on the film, and it's a excellently written, directed and acted movie that contained every kind of emotion making it one of the best films I've seen all year."Yeah maybe there are banshees, I just don't think that they scream to portend death anymore. I think they just sit back, amused and observe"

reviews.review_title: Thankfully there are more Siobhans than shopkeepers now!
reviews.content: The confusion, the cruelty, the stubbornness, the intractability, and the futility are a large part of the point, not a flaw but the feature.A conflict between friends: Gleeson (pro-Treaty) and Farrell (anti-Treaty). Gleeson cuts off his fingers (what may THEY be I wonder) and Keoghan (the 'casuality') abused by his father (I have to wonder again) and then disillusioned by Farrell meets an untimely demise. Farrell's donkey, a love, is dead, Gleeson's house, a possession, is burnt down, the two men are left standing, but the conflict is unending.Is it not apt, if not a little disappointing, that Keoghan and Condon (the voice of reason) have won BAFTAs for their roles in this film if nothing else.I don't understand (in particular) the Irish reviewers who have deemed it pointless, boring or having nothing to say (even if they were not to agree with it).Regardless of this specificity, for its applicability to conflict in general, for its musings on the human condition (stubbornness and niceness), and for the performances and cinematography perhaps above all else, I think it would be well worthy of winning the Oscar for Best Film. And who knows, the voting body may be more amenable to Farrell winning Best Oscar.The recognition of Condon has occurred long after it should have been, and pleased for Keoghan and McDonagh too. Great filmmaking and at such a timely moment in history!

reviews.review_title: No message I want to receive
reviews.content: I was anticipating something a little more uplifting. Something, anything that gave me some hope for the future. Here was a film made in a beautiful location with wonderful actors but it fell flat for me. In the 1992 film 'Bad Leutenant', Harvey Keitel plays a very corrupt police officer. His character was a representation of the depths to which society had fallen and yet, in the end there was a glimmer of light. A signal that there is still something to believe in despite the depravity.Here there is nothing. The message I receive is 'You know everything is totally miserable? Well guess what? It's going to continue being miserable. There is no hope and no future'.Well who on Earth wants to watch a film that revels in utter misery? It may be arthouse to remind us all that times are tough but surely the role of cinema is to take us out of our mundane and difficult lives and show us that there could be a better place?Yes, I get the black humour but I found it a pointless film and not particularly enjoyable.

I love the characters and acting, but the plot is about... nothing.How to say it... If I asked my wife, or my father to watch this film together, I would drop myself in their eyes.The moral of the film... is the pointlessness of rural life. Filled with stereotypes about the deep countryside, and Ireland. Don't know about Ireland, but if you want stereotypes, see Whisky Galore. And you will find a great meaning there. Here I see no meaning but self-mutilation only...But the worst part of all IS THE SET! It is a cheap one-room small theater play with a deep insufficiency of decorations change. You may find there just 3 decorations, and no specific logical or emotional insight into overall environment. It is even hard to guess what characters do or how they live behind the main line, which is the only line in this play.If I missed some hidden line there, or some ethnic hints...
