Well you have to be a 109 level {elf} Irishman to get that probably. Not for culchies.

I was really looking forward to watching Banshees of Inisheran, but unfortunately, it fell short of my expectations. The storyline was confusing and disjointed, and it felt like the movie was trying to be too many things at once without fully committing to any of them. The pacing was slow, and the characters were underdeveloped, making it difficult to connect with them emotionally.Moreover, the acting was subpar, and the dialogue was uninteresting and lacked depth. There were some beautiful shots of the Irish landscape, but they couldn't save the film from being a disappointment overall. The music was forgettable, and the sound design was inconsistent, taking me out of the story at times.In conclusion, Banshees of Inisheran was a letdown. I had high hopes for this movie, but it failed to deliver a compelling story, interesting characters, or engaging dialogue. I wouldn't recommend it unless you're a die-hard fan of the genre or have a lot of time to spare. An inexplicable turn on a friendship; never explained; and never resolved.It seemed more like a play to me than a film. Wondering why this film has received the good reviews.

Alright who would've thought this would by far be the weirdest movie I'd watch in a year EVERYTHING EVERYWHERE ALL AT ONCE came out! The best way to describe this movie would be that its like THE LIGHTHOUSE, extremely well made, unsettling which you liked but don't know if you should've or suggest it to someone with confidence. Extremely well acted, breathtaking vistas, ethereal music and a supernaturally absurd yet simplistic plot would still leave you completely unsatisfied with its conclusion and even more confused of the events that transpired or even ushered it.Its the type of movie to make you feel absolutely gobsmacked.(Please dont mistake it that I didnt like the film, I absolutely did but its not something I'd recommend even to myself, let alone other people.It will most definitely come off as stupid, as intended by the director but if you're an artist or a content creator undergoing depression and identity crisis it will most definitely intrigue you.You have been warned)

I don't say this lightly, this was one of the worst, poorly acted, poorly written movies I've watched to day.It was almost embarrassing to watch.Other than beautiful views of Ireland,
I couldn't find a mere echo of praise
I saw in the reviews.The plot was weird, made no sense,
Made no point. It went on and on, only to
Become more and more obscure and stupid.The whole movie felt like a fluke.The acting was especially bad.Colin Farrell was downright unbelievable,
melodramatic and flat.The dialogues were painful.It's not every day that I see a movie so utterly misreviewed. I just finished and thought it was so awful I had to write this review immediately in order to vent for the two hours of my life I would like back.

This movie is sad and heartbreaking within minutes of watching the opening credits. Movies are meant to teach and uplift. This movie made me want to go home and kill myself. It's a story of how kindness and niceness is not enough and is likely to be stamped out and replaced by meanness. At a time when we all have dealt with death and destruction constantly, it feels irresponsible to have created such a depressing and isolating story. Two best friends, one simply decided one day he no longer likes his friend and then threatens to self mutilate if the friend so much as speaks a word to him. Then when he does and the friend cuts his own fingers off and he throws them at his ex friend's door and the friend's favorite pet donkey eats the finger and chokes and dies. WHAT? Why? This breaks the friend utterly breaks him. And there's more... it just gets worse and worse...don't waste your time or your heartache.

reviews.review_title: A folktale that stayed with me
reviews.content: On a remote island off the coast of Ireland, in a small rural community, Colm (Brendan Gleeson), an introspective compossor, suddenly and without explanation, terminates his long-time friendship with the island's happy-go-lucky nice-guy Padraic (Colin Farrell). Wounded and bemused, Padraic is unable to accept Colm's decision and pursues answers. The Banshees of Inisherin will not be my favourite film of the year but it has stayed with me, randomly coming into my mind in the days that followed. The film felt like a folktale as I was watching; there was a kind of unrealness to it even though it seemed very grounded in reality with bleak scenary and every-day-life quality to the story telling. There are broad sweeping themes of legacy and seeking meaning from life which are spelled out and the more dramatic events are bold and symbolic, again, adding to the folktale feel. There is a lot of dry humour spliced in with the drama and I did laugh in some places but I found the humour was sometimes used as a pallet cleanser to the tragedy to keep the audience on board with the film, rather than being integral to the story. The cinematography is fantastic, despite the overt bleakness, there were also beautiful landscape and low-sun shots Overall I would say that it wasn't the most fun cinema experience but I found it surprisingly dreamy and thought provoking.

reviews.review_title: This is what moving pictures are made for
reviews.content: Namely a fine tale to tell, with all the ridiculousness and stupidity and tragedy of life, the ideosyncracies, the incomprehension of other people's decisions, love and goodness in between.A parable, a history. A mystery.True characters. Blue characters. The cards lefe dealt them.And a pet donkey.I mean, what else do you need?There's action, there's blood, there's nakedness - if that's what you need.There's life. On an Irish island 100 years ago. Imagine. No, look, it's all there!It's just a story, but a very unique one for sure.And stories are our lives, we are our stories.Some things, in love and life and fiction, you cannot forgive. Some things turn a nice man mad.What a delight of a film!

The trailer for this movie made it look like a fun but quirky comedy with maybe some sadness but also some levity. The first third of the film is slow but it does have the makings of a good indie film. Slowly the film degrades into a dark pointless pit of sadness with no comedy and no cheerfulness. I understand that it's kind of the point of the movie and probably exactly what the writer/director was going for but it really seems like a waste. The actors did a fantastic job, the scenery was amazing, the writing was well done, which is why I give this a 4 instead of a 0. It's sad to see a film with so much potential take such a turn into hopelessness. I don't get why it has such great reviews, I guess a lot of people aren't depressed enough? I would only recommend this movie if you were super happy but you didn't want to be. So if you're looking for something to ruin your day, give this movie a go.

Colin Farrell plays Padraic and Brendan Gleeson plays Colm two life long friends. One day Colm just suddenly decides he doesn't want to be friends with Padraic anymore. Not for any reason just that he thinks he has become dull. This leads to Padraic trying to everything to win his friend back. The rest of the film is populated with interesting characters. Padraic has a lovely dotting sister named Siobhan played by Kerry Condon. She showed a lot of range in the film. She is funny, heart breaking and very warm. There is Dominic as well a dim witted young man who his friendly with Padraic. This film has some very funny dialogue and dark humour. The film also has some great Irish scenery. The film deals with themes of death and the consequences of actions of one person on the characters around them. This film has some many great moments in it. It will make you laugh and cry and be shocked as well. It is the best film of 2022.

reviews.review_title: I walked out and so should you
reviews.content: One of the worst and darkest and most pointless movies I've ever seen. I walked out after 1hr and 25 minutes and I do not do that. It is more than depressing. It has absolutely no redemption and no redeeming points. Even Colin Farrell's good looks can only last so long amidst the dreariness. Can you handle extreme mental illness, cruelty, beloved pets dying and endless desperation? If that's your idea of intellectual and emotional stimulation, you'll find this fascinating. I guess Zi was looking for a little Irish charm and actual humor. Both of these elements are missing in spades. I just cannot figure out why it got good reviews.

Ireland is a bittersweet island. Genuinely funny everyday craic is salted with the sadness of unresolved issues from the past and the present. This film captures the nature and depth beautifully. A dispute with no real cause reflects the confusion of the Irish Civil War going on in the background. The policeman the priest and the old woman each demonstrate their power over the village life, as the bleakness of life in the west unsoftened by the beauty of the scenery. Poverty, boredom and a tiny island population all push people together, compatible or not. The story captures all of this with an understanding of the Irish use of English, the wit and tension of the bar where the drink can result in laughter or a right hook, and the sadness of women who live for the local news and not much more.All round a superb thought provoking film about an Ireland that few not native understand
.

reviews.review_title: Best Film I've seen In years.
reviews.content: I am not a movie critic though I've watched many films not many have compelled me to make an IMDB account for for the sole purpose of giving it a high rating, It was a rollercoaster of interpersonal conflict, paired well with good cinematography and a hard dose of irish culture, I had a hard time bringing myself to pull my eyes off the screen when I had to head the bathroom because I wouldn't forgive myself missing a second of this film. I hope you find this review insightful and if your going to watch it yourself take it with a bit of skeptism as it may not be for everyone. Also I think the charachters have a ton of charm and personality.

Going through the interviews of Gleeson and Farrell, one thing the latter says perfectly sums up the transition between Martin McDonagh's debut and this last masterpiece of his.An unexpected friendship blossoming from a tragedy vs. A decaying one through a tragedy...What was so impactful for me was how Ken seen good in Ray which led them to have this beautiful yet, not long lasting friendship.Though in here, it was the other case. It was the goodness (not sure it sums it right) that separates the two. It is actually interesting how a whole another story is emerged through little flick in the main theme of the logline.As always, McDonagh perfectly blends the comedy with dark themes while taking us back in time to Inisherin.Plus, it is always such a great experience to see yourself in characters and their actions which led me thinking if I'm more like. Padraic, Colm, Siobhan or Dominic. Cause, even though some actions of the characters seems surreal it is actually very authentic and familiar on its core...

Just saw this one today. Way different from In Bruges their last team up but a better film i reckon. Big themes here even though it starts with one old mate not wanting to be a mate to his old mate anymore. Very great acting by all and just a great mix of comedy and melancholy which is best done by the Irish. Kerry Condon is the most beautiful i've ever seen her in this. And is she maybe a Banshee too or is it just the old girl in black with the pipe? It is plural-Banshees. A mad ending too and i like how the Civil War is part of the story too. I could happily watch it again so i'll have to get the Blu Ray to watch this gem again when it is released.

reviews.review_title: You didn't do anything to me. I just don't like you no more.
reviews.content:
Overall: 8.97Summary: A beautifully shot comedy/drama with elements of dread and deep sadness from Martin McDonagh. The look of the film and breathtaking shots of the island off the West coast of Ireland are breathtaking. The film is expertly directed and crafted, with great lead performances and exceptional supporting roles for Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan. The film feels as though it is an allegory or fable akin to the Irish Civil war at the time with Mrs. McCormick (the old lady in black) serving as it's oracle or ultimate observer of events through time. The tone is difficult to adjust to at times, and the humor is very dark, but that is what you can come to expect from a Martin McDonagh film. Some scenes will leave you in absolute awe, like the one with Dominic and Kerry by the lake, but the movie overall lacks a bit in structure and lasting impact.Setting, Conflict, Character, Dialogue, Theme, Plot, and Climax: A-Runtime: 1:54Audience Engagement (do you feel runtime): NoTop Genres: Comedy, Drama (Fiction)Genre(s) rating

reviews.review_title: The hidden message behind it all
reviews.content: Great performances, photography, script... yes, yes, we love the film, Ireland, and everything about it, who doesn't.But something was odd about Colm's behaviour. Amputating one's fingers is not normal, even less for a fiddler, and surprisingly he is not even suicidal.At the very end of the film both the Irish civil war and their relationship completely ends. We can then realise of the synecdoche behind it all.Two friends: one of them suddenly asking for complete independence, another does not understand. The one not understanding will try to kill the one requesting independence.A war inside Ireland, two men at war in a small island.PS: Thanks Charlie Kaufman for the training in spotting hidden messages in movie plots!

Off-putting, bleak, & strangely captivating. The dark comedy is dry, hilarious, & works incredibly well due to the lead actors' chemistry. Gorgeous scenery & score that set a baren yet bittersweet tone..
..
Off-putting, bleak, & strangely captivating. The dark comedy is dry, hilarious, & works incredibly well due to the lead actors' chemistry. Gorgeous scenery & score that set a baren yet bittersweet tone..
..
Off-putting, bleak, & strangely captivating. The dark comedy is dry, hilarious, & works incredibly well due to the lead actors' chemistry. Gorgeous scenery & score that set a baren yet bittersweet tone.

I'm not quite sure where to start with this review - so I'll start by saying that this is a movie that is so real and compelling it's hard to imagine that there is a camera and crew there at all. That's not to say the cinematography isn't up to snuff, quite the opposite, the cinematography is beautiful and makes the most of its locations.Rather, the movie is so intensely personal, and the actors, all of them so focused and concentrated, that it's easier to believe that the camera was invisible and that the whole thing is completely real.The viewing experience is completely enthralling and takes you on the full gamut of emotions - which means that at times it's hard to watch and will pull at your heart strings.Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell are extraordinary - intense and fully immersed, two quite breathtaking performances - but the entire ensemble deliver at the highest level , portraying a well realised and convincing character, warts and all - and there are plenty of warts. Kerry Condon playing Farrell's sister and Barry Keoghan playing the troubled son of the local policeman also stand out with magnificent and emotionally challenging performances (for the viewer at least).I feel like I've just been snooping on people's lives. Hell, even the animals put on a good show!Martin McDonagh, who wrote and directed this, deserves some serious accolades for his efforts - he has produced a seamless encounter with island life and eccentricity, a life that is both beautiful and terrible.

Ok, so maybe this movie turns out fine, maybe the acting is pretty good or there may be some deeper sense to it but for the first time in my life I left the cinema before the end, actually after only 20 mins of the movie. I just couldn't take it anymore.Seemed like a nonsense and it was just going in circles, all dialogues were almost the same and the plot just doesn't seem believable. I was interested in scenery, Colin's acting and Irish accent a bit. And was I disappointed.I knew it wasn't gonna work for me when I heard this quote: "Look at this I found. A stick with a hook. What would you use it for, I wonder. To hook things that are the length of a stick away?"..and this wasn't a joke.

reviews.review_title: A fantastic film about violence and its consequences.
reviews.content: What on the surface seems to be a tale of two men, whose friendship has ended, slowly descending into hate and violence, is actually a metaphor condemning violence, war, and conflict.Set against the Irish Civil War (1921-1922), when an Ireland recently united in a War of Independence (1919-1921) turned on itself, The Banshees of Inisherin is the story of Colm and Pádraic, part of a tiny community on a small island off the Irish coast, who likewise end a long friendship and turn on each other.Colm wakes up one day feeling that he needs to leave a legacy to the world, but his friendship with Pádraic is getting in the way, so he ends it, offering no real reason why until pushed.Pádraic can't accept this, continuously pestering his former friend who just wants to be left alone to create a musical legacy to leave the world. It's a decision that ultimately leads to madness and violence that both men inflict on themselves, each other, and the community around them.As with war, sectarian violence, and conflict, ultimately it's the community and innocents around the warring parties who suffer the most.Both Gleeson and Farrell offer fantastic performances, their genuine lost friendship is clear in the loss both men suffer, and there is a spectacular supporting cast helping writer director Martin McDonagh bring the film to life. The most compelling performances though (aside from the two stars) come from Barry Keoghan as Dominic, and Kerry Condon as Pádraic's sister Siobhan.It's a fascinating and fantastic film, the parallels to the internal conflicts that have left such visible and lasting scars on Ireland are clear, but it's the wider condemnation of war and violence that lifts this. Combined with a self important Church, and a corrupt Police, both representing Government and social structures that hinder, ignore, and exacerbate the violence through self interest or a refusal to intervene, The Banshees of Inisherin is a film that will leave you thinking for a long time after its finished.

reviews.review_title: An Amazing Movie for Mature Viewers
reviews.content: I went into this movie not knowing anything about it's category. It's true, as many other reviewers have written, that this film doesn't make you laugh often. However, what other reviewers aren't noticing is that it rarely tries to make anyone laugh. It's a rather dark drama that focuses heavily on the falling out of two friends. The characters manage to make themselves feel real while simultaneously engaging in the kind of brash and irrational actions that perfectly symbolize the emotions that come with loosing a friend. As others have mentioned, it also draws an excellent juxtaposition between its friend vs friend plot and the backdrop of 1920s Ireland. For anyone that loves Celtic culture, you will be completely drawn in by the cinematography and bits of everyday life depicted. Yes, it's long and it's not action & comedy packed, but know that if you like mature movies that make you think deeply about the lives, thoughts, and emotions of the characters involved that you will love it. It's fantastically acted, beautifully shot, and very well written. It's without a doubt the best thing to be released on HBO max this whole month and deserves a watch.

I honestly don't know what I felt after watching this movie. The emotions are so conflicting that they don't settle. Not sure they will, have to give it more thought. But for now, it's all surface reactions.Most people at some point wonder and feel a deep longing to try a life on a beautiful, lonely Irish island. Especially if your DNA is primarily Irish (or Welsh, Scottish, Celt etc). And we all know that it would mean lots of alone time, lots of quiet, lots of walking, reading, looking at the ocean...every bit making it all the more delicious.What might not be so obvious is how crazy that might make us become.At first, I was positive that Colm was the terrible one. In the end, I wasn't too far away from that idea still. But in the meantime, it also came to light that pretty much all of them have foibles that, good or bad, might twist a person. But it was their interactions that caused so much of it. The poor schmuck Dominic was off because his policeman father regularly beat and "fiddled" with him causing him to be drunk 24 hrs a day. The policeman father was a sick pedo so his position of power allowed him to be evil without repurcussion until Padraic said it out loud at the pub.Paidraic was never going to be able to move forward with any kind of REAL life because there aren't any available women there to marry, have kids and a life with. Colm has let his never being a successful artist warp his actions out of frustration to the point of madness. Why else would he be willing to mutilate himself just to punish someone else he suddenly feels he has to control? Honestly, I think he came to hate Padraic because he, Padraic, was content and happy living a truly simple life on Inisherin. It made his own frustrations even harder to bear in the end.The only regular person there was Siobhan and the secondary characters who just went about their day like regular folks or looking for a way to have a fuller life by getting off the island.This wasn't much of a comedy, but it did have some funny moments. There were some truly sad moments that made me want to cry (but not in public). Poor Jenny, just a big sweet donkey that acted like a dog but she died because of what was happening. And Siobhan leaving her brother, knowing he'll never leave but she has to. And Dominic, his drowning after realizing he'll NEVER get a woman of his own. Truly heartbreaking.All in all, glad I saw it, but it definitely wasn't what I expected based on the clips or promos.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant and it doesn't look what it looks like
reviews.content: It's about 2 lifelong friends that abruptly end up their relationship. WRONG.It's about many things and the friendship is the less important thing.The movie have beautifull pictures, is well directed with a great environment and a small historic context.Humans are social animals and the social interaction on an island or closed space have mental consequences over the decades.Cutting fingers is a beautifull metaphor for the degradation of human mental social behavior in a closed space when persons only see the same people over the years and go to the exactly same places over and over, talking the same subjects as usual, we are nomads in our genes.This movie talks also about growing old and the changes that the human brain suffer through our life. What individuals achieve in life and what they didnt.We see the contrast beetween the young and the old.The "burden" of mariage and coupling is also slightly shown with influence on human behavior.The autority sickness that hits all men with some kind of power is personified in a policemen that is also in a closed space or environment.There is a mysterious old woman that "could" be explained as "the life experience" and somehow is feared becouse every individual after some time thinks it knows everything but when look at her: hum.. maybe not.Extraordinary performance of all actors with special regard to Collin Powell that made the best performance of his career so far.Some actors make performances so big that make some films oscar winners, this is almost one of that performances and the movie is already a winner.Outstanding job.It's oscar winner material.

reviews.review_title: a gruesome tale about the horror of living!
reviews.content: Martin McDonagh never fails to leave me speechless. He literally had me in this one, making me re-watch the movie the day after I first watched it, simply because of the complexity of all the characters and the plot itself.If can sum up the whole movie in one sentence it would be (The possibility of human insanity and choosing malevolence over goodness). And I've actually seen the story from this perspective the first time I watched it, but it took me multiple viewings to grasp what the story is all about.Domonic's character must be the center of attention in the whole story; He lives a tragic life, searching for love, meaning in a bleak island, he gets beaten by his own dad, yet no one gives a damn about him, the whole island is concerned with a stupid quarrel between two adults, That shows how society exactly works.I've admired Barry since Dunkirk, He's one of the best actors of his generation and probably with the highest potential. Such an outstanding performance he delivered in this beauty. SPOT ON.

2020 to me, was one of the most disappointing years for movies. 2021 was a good year, but outside of Licorice Pizza & Coda, no film became a treasured film of mine. Yes, there were many other fantastic films, but I would only go to bat for those two being masterpieces. This year alone, I have over 15 films I would have put in my top five. So making an actual list was nearly impossible. While I decided on my picks eventually, this film, in particular, could have easily been top 3 or even top 2. It's that good.The setting, characters, and story are all excellent in the film. When a movie can tackle such complex human relationships and individual characteristics you know it's going to be a moving piece of cinema. Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon, and Barry Keoghan could be nominated for their excellent performances. Gleeson deserves his praise, but Ke Huy Quan will win for supporting actor. Farrell, on the other hand, has a good shot at winning his first-ever academy award for one of the top performances of his storied career. It has that feel of a close nit-community that you just don't see anymore in movies. Yet it's the haunting feeling of the story that makes your eyes never want to leave the screen. This is a hard movie to swallow, so if you're not looking for something with tons of emotional weight you might want to skip this. But if you are looking for something emotional you may have found your film of the year.10/10 A pure masterpiece. Words cannot describe the feeling.

reviews.review_title: Some humour underlines a dark tale of male separation
reviews.content: The Banshees of Inisherin is one of those films about male friendship and what happens when one of the party decides that they no longer want that friendship to continue. In some ways it's heartbreaking and also not well understood.Brenda Gleeson plays the older party of the friendship who decides for whatever reason that he's bored with his friendship with Colin Farrell's character. A number of reasons are speculated but the truth is, no-one really knows.The pair live on an island off the west coast of Ireland. The island life produces the room for eccentric behaviour with its rugged beauty, beaches and hard going roads. Both men live separate to each other. Colin's character, Padraic lives with his sister. Brendan's character, Colm lives with his border collie for company and also his music.The two's separation affects the entire community and it also grows, until the party who instigated it considers quite an extreme act. Once this begins, things go from bad to worse.This is not a film for the faint hearted. It also gives an insight into the Irish/Gaelic culture with its religion and superstition moving beside each other, sometimes at odds. Other brilliant performances come from Kerry Condon who plays Padraic's sister who is looking for a different way of life from the one offered on the island. Also equally superb is Barry Keoghan, whose performance is a delight.

reviews.review_title: High potential but it didn't click
reviews.content: "The Banshees of Inisherin" surprised me for everything, except for the only thing I was expecting it to shine: the screenplay. The acting performances are great by all the actors, the direction is well thought, the cinematography is gorgeous and the score is also very good and it conveys perfectly tension and emotions. I have to point out these merits because they are absolutely there and I actually think that for the things cited above even some Oscars would be deserved. However this movie didn't "talk" to me, I was enable to empathise for the characters or feel emotions for what was happening. And it was strange because the themes touched by the movie are actually something that in some capacity I've dealt with recently, but I got nothing from it. In the first part I was enjoying it but the second part, especially from the "finger affair" (and not only that), brought me outside of the atmosphere. In the end I was totally indifferent to "The Baneshees of Inisherin". Maybe it's only my sensitivity because some good elements are there, or maybe a poor screenplay. Who knows? But still it is suggested, because if it clicks it has the potential to be a film that is loved.

reviews.review_title: A Movie For A Mature , Intelligent Audience
reviews.content: If you have known pain, loss, sadness,isolation, grief then you will understand this well written and well acted film. The musical score along with wide shots of the landscape transports the viewer back to 1923. A simple but rugged people on a rugged island are; a beautiful and desolate area with obviously no modern amenities makes the need or desire to chat at the pub necessary and basic; or so it seems.It is the chemistry that really endears me to these two fine actors as well. Their on screen relationship is so real and genuine. I think these two are already legendary together in some ways.The supporting actors in the film make up the townspeople and bring to life this sleepy or quiet town that is full of mystery, folklore, secrets and beauty for sure.

Those of you confused about this review's title will understand when you watch the movie and likely laugh your arse off like I did. The only thing I didn't entirely love was the directions taken with our protagonist Pádraic's character. I understand why the changes were written in as they were even foreshadowed and reflective, but it made my heart sink a bit. The film ended well out of context, I just wish it would have been under different circumstances. And it isn't to say I don't appreciate the film's darkness because I truly do, but I wish some of it would have been eliminated as it would've made for an even stranger and more ambiguous feel. Of course all of its technicalities were great and I look forward to its Oscar wins. It is highly entertaining, and not in the mainstream, "I need action, explosions, and excessive CGI," way, but in the way when a movie sways you on the inside like a song; when it captivates you and holds you. That's what Banshees did for me. Beautiful landscapes, wonderful directing and cinematography, charming writing and characters; it's virtually perfect! It's safe to say I highly recommend The Banshees of Inisherin.

reviews.review_title: A Beatiful Tale about the Awesome Stupidity of War
reviews.content: Going into this film I had no idea what to expect. I don't like watching trailers or reading premises, and as often as I can, I go in blind. All I knew and needed to know was that it was a Martin McDonagh written and directed film. This man always finds a way to enthrall and amaze with his trademark of poetically comedic misery.So at the very least, I had the expectation of walking away from this cinematic experience satisfied and happy to have been there, which I certainly did.The story revolves around small conflicts on a small Irish island in the 1920s, with the Irish civil war rumbling in the background. Indeed it's a tale of how misery only leads to more misery, the value of kindness and being simply nice.By presenting this very small scale story with these larger than life characters The Banshees of Inisherin becomes a greatly relatable (fairy-)tale about the way war and other mindless conflict only hurts everyone involved. No matter who's in the perceived "right", in the end everyone suffers and no-one wins.While the subject matter is certainly quite depressing and often bizarre, it makes the contrasting comedic moments all the more potent and truly hilarious. The emotional journey is everything but spelled out, and the film doesn't attempt to cheaply manipulate the audience's experience at all. The balance between the wonderfully organic escalation of events and it's awesome theatrical presentation is spot on.Technically the camera work, the location, the editing and basically every little detail shown on screen is a feast of epic proportions. Martin McDonagh's directing and dialogue is incredibly charming and purposeful.The accompanying performances are utterly superb, especially Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson and Kerry Condon. Barry Keoghan also manages to pull off a type of character, who could easily feel forced or obnoxious to near perfect endearment.I'm happy to once again having the privilege to see such a different and unique film, by a cast and crew who clearly gave it their all.Thank you! This film is a masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: Excellent film that stays with you
reviews.content: This has got to be the craziest film review I have ever written on here.I saw The Banshees of Inisherin yesterday in a Parisian cinema and I haven't stopped thinking about it since then, but I can't possibly tell you why.Sure, the acting is absolutely top-notch (not only the four leads, but even the minor characters, like the actors playing the policeman, the grocery store manageress and the local "witch" (I don't know what else to call her), all of whom did their acting job so well that I wanted to get up and punch each of them in the nose (luckily, one of them does get just that punch from one of the leads) but that is true of many other films.Nor is it the plot of the film itself, which may be a fantastic metaphor for the Irish Civil War but makes little or no sense if taken literally, and even if it did, the dénouement of which is entirely illogical, although not unexpected in the context of the film.In fact, I simply cannot put my finger on why I found this film to have such a dramatic effect on me, but it did.I encourage you all to see it and make up your mind for yourself.

reviews.review_title: A 'Very Nice' Award-Worthy Film - but it is dull...
reviews.content:
On a remote Island off the coast of Ireland a tiny community scratch a living as best they can. Two long time friends suddenly have a falling-out that leads to ever more desperate reactions by the two protagonists... Brendan Gleeson is Colm, who has abruptly made the decision to disassociate himself from his long-time friend Pádraic - Colin Farrell - who is, needless to say, utterly confused as to why this has happened. Despite attempts by Pádraic to mediate the situation, Colm resorts to increasingly drastic measures to keep his old friend away from him, which ultimately leads down some dark paths.Firstly, the cinematography and look of this Film is wonderful - the opening shot of falling out of the clouds to suddenly see the very green fields below us is a superb opener and the locations chosen really do place the viewer firmly in the remote Irish setting.The Acting is on the money by all of the major players - both Gleeson and Farrell, who played so well together in the directors previous In Bruges, again show their acting chops and the supporting Cast, especially Kerry Condon, all bring something to the roles.However, the Film unfolds at a glacial pace and almost all of the characters seem to be suffering from boredom or depression.Colm's reason for ditching Pádraic appears to be because he now feels he is just 'dull', prompting Pádraic to keep asking all and sundry 'Am I dull?'
He receives a back-handed compliment that he is a 'nice' person but Colm merely scoffs that nobody remembers 'nice' people..
Pádraic on the other hand, seems to misjudge his dealings with Colm, even when it is plain that he really needs to stay away. The way the two central characters seem to have no idea what they are doing, or why, is a flaw in the Film.The only character with any spark is Kerry Condon's Siobhan, who recognises the sheer drabness of the place and takes firm steps to get away. It is she who confronts Colm about why he has taken this action against Pádraic, to which he again mumbles something about him being 'dull', to which her exasperated response - Your ALL dull' - kind of sums up the film.For me, the central 'feud' between the two men doesn't ring true and the we never get to know why Colm has acted this way in the first place. The Film really seems to meander looking for a resolution.Banshees is a very well made film - beautifully shot and acted - BUT the dramatic thrust seems to go nowhere. It is a 'nice' award-worthy Film....but it IS dull and nowhere near the masterpiece critics are saying it is.

reviews.review_title: Martin McDonough has done it again
reviews.content: The banshees of inisherin is a sad, lonely film, about a man unable to cope with his friend breaking up with him. Inisherin feels like it's own character. An isolated island both full of peaceful beauty and haunting loneliness. The film is very philosophical without beating you over the head with it's message. It's hilarious without taking away the dark, depressing tone of the narrative. The acting and screenplay is practically flawless. So many nuances and unforgettable moments. The story is deceptively simple, yet endlessly rewatchable. I love this movie to bits and it gets better on every rewatch.

I've always been a fan of Martins work. Same with his brother. Their dark comedies are usually great. However here I'm not sure what to think of it. I understand there are some films that are meant to be arty or dialogue heavy. But even most of those films hold your attention because of the dialogue. There didn't really seem to be a point to this story. I know it's part of a series of plays but honestly I think it should've stayed there. Idk why critics gave this such a good rating. It didn't entertain. At all. I thought there would be some type of pay off or a deeper reason why Colm didn't want to be friends with Colin's character anymore. But there wasn't. Like I said, I understand Film is an art. However it's meant to entertain and hold your attention as well. Took me three tries to finish this. I just got bored. Performances were great as usual but that wasn't enough to save it. Kind of disappointed to be honest. "Three Billboards" and "Seven Psychopaths" were phenomenal. Same with "In Bruges". Honestly if you're into the whole art of film more than you are to have a great story and excitement then watch it. If not you'll feel empty when it's over because it doesn't really give you anything.

Just wow!This instantly became my favorite film from 2022 so far.Also my favorite film from director Martin McDonagh.Just unbelievably beautiful on so many levels.This type of very dark and maybe even quite cold comedy is just my type.I laughed in very many times to this film.Some really smart comedy that isn't overdone at any moment.But then this film also manages to be very melancholic and absolutely heartbreaking.This all definitely made me cry quite a bit.In heart of this story is very much about loneliness.Really unique study of different human relationships.We can see that two main characters once were great friends, but that has already changed when film has started.Really great brother and sister relationship too.And stories about multiple outcasts on remote land where love doesn't live.So well crafted characters with unique personalities.This screenplay is just wonderful.It pulls just right strings at right moments.Absolutely wonderful performances from Colin Farrel, Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan.And of course that donkey that just adds suprisingly much heart to this story.Visually stunning film.So beautiful cinematography.Beautiful use of nature and setting of this film to really bring it alive.I really can only hope that this would win as many Oscars that is possible.This definitely woul be my pick to best picture so far.Just beautiful.

The cinematography is stunning. I have been a fan of Colin Farrell since his early days on Ballykissangel. He is underrated and deserves the awards for this performance. This was my favorite movie of the year---the subtle intricacies, the angst, the depth---is amazing. Finally a gem for the viewers who do not watch the superhero movies, the horror movies, the teen nonsense fare. In the same vein as Three Billboards, Outside Ebbing, Missouri, Mcdonagh once again weaves a visual, dramatic and emotional tale clothed in a painful beauty. The cinematography, pace and acting in Nomadland had similarities which made it a Best Picture (2020) and other awards. The intricacies of friendship, aging, loneliness affect everyone and one needs a "quiet" and introspective beauty to witness it. The continual parade of buddy movies, gun violence, gratuitous sex, and commercial schlock is tiring but movie companies have to pay the bills.

reviews.review_title: Suitable to watch individually and think
reviews.content: Likes - Perhaps a contrast to the badness of how people live in the island. But the scenery is just breathtaking to watch.Focusing on specific characters and the interactions between them, the character building is solid and profound.It should help us revisit how important the background is around us and how we should get out of it to give us a chance to be individually satisfied. I am also rethinking how I dealt with some relationships which didn't go well in the past.Dislikes - The movie is spiced up with some humorous lines, but the overall tone is gloomy and sarcastic. It's a way to create some kinds of emotion to moviegoers, but gloominess is perhaps not the only solution.Summary - Not for entertainment but for someone who gives himself a chance to reflect his relationship and living environment.

reviews.review_title: What a fantastic movie carried by pure acting
reviews.content: Like the title says, this movie is a wonderfully crafted work of art. It is a simple script, simple concept, simple locations, everything is very simplistic, but what sets it apart is that it uses dialogue to tell the story. You feel you are there listening to the characters as things unfold and you get the complete sense of their emotions, inner state and even desires.The small town rural irish dynamics are captured well enough as well giving the movie a bit of an exotic feel because the culture is depicted so well with so little effort. This is a movie that is all about dialogue and acting and the cast nails it. I cannot find a fault with any of it, every line and scene fits and makes sense.As a very adult movie, it will require you to pay attention and listen to what is being said; cannot skip or fast forward this one. If you are looking for mindless action, you will not like it. If you want a great acting based movie, this is it!I did not give it a 9 because i wanted a little more closure at the end....

reviews.review_title: A true masterpiece because of its simplicity
reviews.content: Knowing very well how everyday life and mentality looks like in a remote small village in rough rural area I have to say this movie is spot on and closest to perfection as it can be. To create the atmosphere of the place, to make it alive with the language and the everyday life of Irish rural people a hundred years ago takes really a master work. You could see the slow life, what's important and how everyone details with it. Also the belief system was different and I loved everything about it. The scenery where every second is a postcard, a music score that is truly perfect and then the amazing but simple plot and the story. I can't really see how this movie missed rewards in Cannes and Venice if it was even running there in competition. I can't write a review here and not mention the most amazing movie duo today that should work much more together, Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson. It's so good to see them together again and they truly came as a cherry at the top of this masterpiece. Hats down to all actors and lastly the director Martin McDonagh. You can see clearly that he can't miss and is making movies that only rare few are able to do on that level. He's the reason why the movies as an art form are still alive. This may not become a cult movie but for me it's not only the best movie of the year by far, but top 5 in last 10 years or more. Even though I'm not fr Ireland but knowing how this kind rural, tough and raw life looks like and how they made it authentic in the movie on so many levels the rating should be 8.8 or but for me it's a 10.Now a spoiler part of what I see the reason of brilliance of this movie. People don't get why they stopped being friends and why on Earth on of them would go so far and cut his fingers just to make a point that he doesn't want to be friends anymore. So living a slow and routine copy paste days in a island village where nothing happens a hundred years ago simple things can stir up complications. So being seriously depressed to the point you only want to leave something behind that people will remember is not easy at all. Especially if you have that but of an art flick in you. And to leave a memorable thing means you have to go extreme in an environment that knows only boring routine. So to cut ties because you overgrew someone who's only in the way of your only life goal but you meet all the time and can't avoid on a daily basis makes you go desperate in your depression. All that just to make the simplest things respected. In this case that ment cutting you own fingers so your best frend comes to understand that even if you didn't have any disputes you don't want to be friends anymore at all. If your friend disrespects your decision and your efforts that repeatedly drain your anyway low energy, you're walking that line of going completely mad and the only thing keeping you away from it is being alone, which you can't have. On the other hand the good-hearted friend suddenly lost a friend who was his world, because of what he is and he simply can't accept that he's the main reason for being friends and for stopping being friends. It's contradictory for his mindset so he tried to make sense and pursuing the contact hoping it's all a bad dream or a small, passable thing. Brilliant and even though simple in context many people can't get a hang of it why. The Banshee, Irish myth of a lady spirit that comes to someone's home and signals the death that's coming is the old lady in the movie. Did she cause the change of behavior or just a tough and depressing life that craves desperate for a gossip or that only local pub meetings can ease up leaves open doors to conclusions. Brilliant.

reviews.review_title: Wow wow wow, best Drama of the year
reviews.content:
May be this movie is the best in this year ,
the magical touch of (Martin MaDonagh) appears here , like in (Three billboards outside ebbing missouri) you can feel niceness , passion , simplicity , depression , anxiety , guilty and darkness in the same time , this how the humans feelings and personalities can turn up quickly and unexpectedly , this exactly drama movies that i like.I think that everybody in this island was crazy somehow in different ways .Colin farrell (as always) was amazing and deserve the oscar for this great audition.You have to watch this movie if you like Elegant dramatic movies.

The Banshees of Inisherin is an allegorical tale of friendship and feud between two intellectually different individuals. Set in the backdrop of the Irish Civil War, the story, even though told in a simple manner, reflects the underneath tension of the concurrent political imbroglio of Ireland. In his latest offering, director Martin McDonagh continues his predilection for his favorite stars Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson, the first of whom maintains his superb form from the earlier outing of the trio 'In Bruges'. Even though it is being lauded critically across the globe for its metaphorical approach of storytelling, 'The Banshees...' somehow failed to impress me with anything new apart from Farrell's brilliant portrayal as the naïve and unimaginative Padraic and soothing scenery of an imaginary Irish island called Inisherin. However, this is absolutely my personal opinion and many may rate this as a masterpiece. Life is all about personal choices when it comes to art or entertainment, isn't it?The narration is slow paced and follows a definite pattern of the Irish plays. There is simplicity all around. There are lonely people. There are petty talks. There is naivety and there are aspirations to be immortal through one's own creation. One of the friends - Padraic is unambitious, dull , unimaginative yet possesses a good heart whereas his friend turned foe for apparently no solid reason Colm represents the higher, more talented, more ambitious echelon of the society. There is an eerie and obnoxious presence of Mrs. McCormick who foretells about imminent deaths. She represents the banshees of the title. There is Padraic's sister Siobhan who chooses her own independent path amidst the feud and bitterness all around. Everything and everyone portrayed represents one thing or the other of a civil war. Destruction for apparently no reason. Middlemen profiting from the destruction. People suffering and losing their loved ones. And there are people migrating for peace.The cinematography is exceptional and it is one of the strongest points of the movie. The serene landscapes of the imaginary island called Inisherin mesmerize us throughout the duration of the movie. Farrell' acting is topnotch and he is definitely a strong contender along with Brendan Fraser to win the Academy Award for the Best Actor of the Year. Kerry Condon as the caring sister of Padraic is scintillating and her screen presence is one of the factors keep you glued to the screen. However, there is nothing special other than the points I mentioned and the acting of the rest of the cast including Brendan Gleesan seemed prosaic, insipid and lacks vigour. Storyline as I mentioned already is simple and even though it is metaphorical to the civil war, at times it is difficult to digest a thing or the other. Colm's hyperbolic behaviour at times was irritating and monotonous. Even though it has already bagged 9 Oscar nominations and definitely is poised to score big in the Academy Awards, it may not go down the history as something immortal like the tune Colm was creating in the movie. It's a good movie with some very high points but offers nothing new to be a pathbreaker. On any given day, I would rather prefer to watch Martin's previous work 'Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri 'My rating 7 out of 10.

See this film in a theater for the beautiful landscapes and cinematography.The plot revolves around the sudden end of a friendship. The friend who ends the friendship is deeply depressed but still goes through the social motions of pub drinking and playing the violin. The spurned friend is deeply hurt and perhaps humiliated. They both act out their feelings of helplessness and loss of control in ways that are visually shocking. They are unable to escape each other because they live on an island off of Ireland, in a claustrophobic small town culture despite the stunning ocean vistas. MIrroring their enmeshed relationship and escalating hostility is the Irish Civil War in the background. A supporting cast of characters include a sort of village idiot with secrets, the spurned friend's sister who is a voice of reason, a vicious police officer, and a mysterious elder, witch-like woman (the Banshee?). Is the film a psychological drama or a metaphor?

reviews.review_title: A Witty Walk on the Bleak Side
reviews.content: Ihabitants of a dreary Irish isle infect each other with the venom borne of loneliness, disappointment and despair. Like drowning men they pull those trying to help under. Finally the able minded abandon the rescue and swim away, leaving the stricken to their fate. Brendan Gleason, Colin Farrel and Kerry Condon are simply magnificent leading a particularly nuanced cast. Martin MacDonagh is a master of dialogue and direction. The green gray Irish West coast is beautiful yet bleak like a striking woman with a crooked smile.This movie is full of wit, but its austerity and despair are overwhelming.

As someone who is Irish, it is very pleasing to me that an Irish film is getting a lot of attention for the right reasons! This movie is right up my street - it's hilarious, dark, unhinged. Whatever you expect the movie to be going in you will have a different perception going out of it.In terms of acting there is not one bad performance in the film, even the donkey and the dog are great in it! The cinematography of Ireland is stunning too, no surprises there. The best thing about the film though is that there are so many different takeaways at the end - me and other people who watched it had different takes of why all the strange events went down and I think we're all right.Needless to say I will be jumping on the Banshees Academy Award hype train, I hope awards will be flying out the door.

reviews.review_title: I'm not sure I've seen a movie quite like this
reviews.content: This is quite an unusual film, which I mostly liked. You think it's going to be very slow and small, just about these two guys working out their friendship (or lack thereof). But it goes in very interesting directions. I could sympathize with Colin Farrell's character, but at the same time I kept wanting him to just leave Colm alone. His stubbornness is really his undoing. You really get a great sense of how isolating this island is, and I enjoyed just seeing the characters walking from one place to another. I wish the ending had gone a little further. It felt like it was leading to one of the characters (if not both) dying, but to leave it on an ambiguous note left me a little disappointed.

A strange movie. I think around 2 thirds I was laughing out loud and the other third almost depressed. The funny bits were so typically, what I think of anyway, Irish humour. The characters were amazing and so well played, especially Colin Ferrel.The island is very claustrophobic, so few people to interact with, everyone knowing everyone else's business. But the real story is when someone has a mid life crisis leading to depression etc. They take it out on their nearest and dearest, in this case their best friend. What happens when it goes too far? The ending of the movie was quite bleak leaving us with 2 completely fractured lives, hurting each other so much that it can never be resolved.

Sometimes I measure a movie by the reaction after it's been viewed. After we (my wife and son) watched this, we were talking about it for some time. It was a superlative tragi/comedy. The performances from all involved were amazing and captured both the bleakness and warmth of the island of Inisheran. The two protagonists did, in our view, deliver the finest performance ever. The despair of Colm coming to light in the confessional. The sadness of Pádraic who is unable to comprehend the actions of his best friend. For a low budget movie, this truly deserves to be up there with the greats. The background civil war between the IRA and the new Irish Government never seen but somehow there. The unrequited love Jonjo has for Siobhán is both touching and amusing until tragedy strikes and you realise the depth of the writing and acting. I would happily watch this again and again.

Written and directed by Martin McDonagh, The Banshees of Inisherin tells the story of Pádraic Súilleabháin (Collin Farrel) is left perplexed and devastated after his lifelong friend, Colm Doherty (Brendan Gleeson) unexpectedly puts an end to their relationship. As he tries to rebuild their relationship, Pádraic is faced with shocking consequences for both of them.Having this on my watchlist, Though i don't know what to expect to see going into this movie. But i am pleased after the movie ends. You'll be laughing and shattered at the same time because The Banshees of Inisherin dive into the meaning of life, friendship, the emptiness of solitude, and loneliness of oneself. Colm simply doesn't hate Pádraic, he does what he did just because he feels that his time is running out and chatting with Pádraic is a waste of time. He rather fills his time building a legacy for himself, composing a piece of music. It's not a movie for everyone, some might be bored with the constant slow pacing.Martin McDonagh manages to perfectly blends sadness and comedy in an excellent script. Performance from the ensemble cast are powerful in an emotional way, as well as Farrel and Gleeson's chemistry. Also from the supporting role of Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan. One thing I adore from this movie is the cinematography by Ben Davis, what a gorgeous scenery of Ireland.

Having seen and loved Martin McDonagh's "The Lieutenant of Inishmore" on Broadway a few years back, I had high hopes that this film would feature the kind of outrageous irony and societally comic darkness he wrote with there. Sadly, not really the case here. While the acting is solid and the cinematography is lovely, this deeply depressing tale of the end of a friendship misses the mark as a "black comedy.". The main characters are tragically sad for very different reasons, and the lengths they go to inflict pain on each other are brutally needless.There are lessons here for sure, but I'm not certain they survive the disturbing plot. Padraig IS dull and needy, but a kindhearted twit who means no harm. Colm is a depressed artiste whose attempts to suddenly and dramatically sever ties with his old friend lead to unnecessary emotional and physical torment for both and for those around them. It becomes just a sad story of aging and loneliness in a beautiful setting with a miserable present and a bleak future. While I appreciate the work that went into this film, the ending was unsatisfying at best, and the entertainment value was minimal. I feel sorry for every miserable character here... except for Siobhan, who was lucky enough to get out before it all ends.

Is this the quintessential Irish film? Sentimentality and savagery living side by side, deep and dark, poetic and philosophical, tender yet rugged. For two-thirds of it you're chuckling almost like it's Father Ted, then suddenly it takes a dark turn and the last half hour is like a horror show. The civil war makes a good backdrop to a friendship on the rocks but it never directly impinges. A few forgiveable cliches, or maybe they're just tropes (e.g. A sibyl straight out of Macbeth). Fabulous to look at, tours de force from Gleeson and Farrell, as well as a meditation on the meaning of friendship and the purpose of our existence.

Firstly, I am a massive fan of Martin McDonagh's films, as well as the even more Irish films of his brother John. I was very excited about the re-casting of Gleeson and Farrell for this one as their chemistry in In Bruges is undeniable, and plenty of that is still here - there was a genuine sense of these two blokes having spent the larger part of their lives together on this agrarian island. The idea of this lifelong friendship coming to a holt for seemingly no reason at all seemed a bit unjustified but I felt it feasible more in a relationship sense where you all of a sudden realise you can't stand your partner at all...
As the resulting stalemate unfolds into self-mutilation, loved ones dying and homes destroyed I was expecting / hoping for things to really spiral out into some wild antics (perhaps like the unhinged relationship in Lighthouse) but instead it sort of just simmered away at a steady pace. I think the commentary on male stubbornness, the lack of enterprise and inspiration in rural settings and the female voice of reason that is forever ignored were decent enough traits for exploration, and perhaps the civil war allegories were lost on me a bit - I watched with my Irish friend who came out of the cinema feeling a 9+. Acting and cinematography are incredible and really carry this piece.

Took me a while to work out what year we were in. In Ireland, especially Achill Island, one can still find oneself, entering homes, pubs and environments, such as those portrayed in the film.The performances were so good, you really believed in Pádraic, Colm, Siobhán and Dominic and got immersed in their world.It was a combination of funny, whimsical, sad and mystical.Pádraic's confusion, when his best friend, Colm, will not speak to him anymore, is wonderfully played out. Siobhán's frustration with the pettiness and grinding loneliness of the island is palpable. Colm's mindset was a bit of a mystery to me, but his actions are the pivotal force in the story.The wonderful portrayal of Dominic by Barry Keoghan was a joy to watch. So subtle and understated. Dominic; dim-witted or savant?.He certainly had some of the best lines and the poignancy of his circumstances filtered out over the course of the film; one simply fell in love with him.A film to be savoured.

As usual, I went into this one blind. "Two friends quarelling" was all I knew, and good gravy was it interesting. First off the tone was very strange. At first I wasn't sure where the story was headed. It's a simple, grounded, and very very human story that doesn't try hard to make you stop and think, although I felt it was quite existential. Everyone played their parts perfectly, with true abysmal Irish cadence and gossip. I didn't expect as much humor in it, but it really made for a very special experience, especially when the movie starts to, how should I say, go in its own direction. I'm definitely going to be thinking about story elements of this movie for a long time. I would like to see Brandon Gleeson winning an Oscar for this. It really is a memorable performance, to say the least. I recommend it if you like a good old fashioned film with lots of undertones. Put away your phone, shut off the lights, light a candle and sit back. It's a good flick.

This movie has it all - original story, great acting, animals, setting, surprise and probably a lot of other things. A great story to remind us how different we all are. I thought the underlying story line of a simple but for some the non-rewarding existence was brilliant. The local pub and the ability to cut through lonely times, connect to the others in the simplistic manner was a great center of the various plots.There were times I thought wow that was a jarring jump in scenes, but each scene was superb. The pacing and editing I am still not sure about, it was ok. Where it shined was in the individual scenes. The actors were so good. At the end it was hard to decide who carried the movie. This would be a good movie to ask people what your favorite scene was. I bet there would be many differing opinions.It is a easy watching, maybe slow at first, but well worth it. Lot oof things to think about when one gets done watching it.

Friendship is one of the basic human traits that have been cultivated in us ever since we as a species have step foot on this planet and losing it can sometimes cause a heartbreak even greater than any of the deepest romantic relationship a person can have, because true friendship is complex and an immensely rare thing to have and find. This complexity is put on the screen with vivid cinematography and expressive and eloquent acting in The Banshees of Inisherin by director Martin McdonaughSet against the usual precedent of fast paced films that dominate the modern cinema landscape, The Banshees of Inisherin is laid back and a calming viewing experience. Sit back and enjoy the delightful Irish landscapes and a pastural lifestyle accompanied with a pint and melodious violin. It's a shame that this had a limited theatrical run and only in select theatres cause oh what I would give to be able to experience this on the big screen.Colin Farrell is the star of the show. He shines in every scene he is in and his splendid expressions are the driving force of the storyline. I would be surprised if he didn't win Best Actor because if there was ever a performance you could look at and say "That deserves an Oscar", it would be this. Apart from him, everyone does a near perfect job with other amazing performances include those of Barry Keoghan and Kerry Cordon.Another key aspect of this film is the metaphors and parallels that are sprinkled thoroughly throughout this immersive cinematography and photography. The themes revolve around that of Christianity and the Civil War (the period where it's set) After reading through some post film discussions, I'm tempted to see those metaphors for myself. This film is recommended for a second viewing as well.All in all, definite top 5 film of the year. Highly recommended.

I can see why this film might be a bit marmite, I wasn't desperate to see it but I'm glad I did. I watched it a 2nd time 2 days after seeing it. It's very good and as they often say, not the kind of film that gets made much these days and certainly not the kind of cinematic event punters flock to see on the big screen.The two leads are excellent and the script is brilliant. It's sweet, funny, somber and thought provoking.Hopefully it will win lots of awards and get some
Oscar nominations.I'd like to see more from Gleason and Farrell as they make a great pair, we need at least one more with these two as leads to complete the trilogy, lolIf you haven't seen it give it a go, I laughed a few times but I was w compelled by this film. It's an odd one but a great one!

It's a strange little film great actors great location I liked it but it was odd I shouldn't have liked it
It was thought provoking and some comical bits and quite a few wtf moments
I won't watch it again
All the cast were great
Very scenic location
Expected a bit of a twist it wasn't there
It's simple film surprising it was so long
It's crazy in parts
A story of two friends and one no longer wants to be friends for no apparent reason but goes to very odd lengths to stop the friendship
Maybe he is crazy
Watch it if you like slow pace scenic movies
Both main characters played by top actors who do a grand job.

reviews.review_title: Banshees might not be what you expect
reviews.content: Plot-driven viewers seem to have a tough time with this movie. Everyone looking for a pay off gives me a giggle. This film is outstanding in the way many classic pieces of literature are despised. Enjoy the acting, scenery, dialogue and voices. Accept that not every writer/narrator is obligated to give you a profound happy ending. Although we are given exactly that -- a profound happy ending for those willing to step out of their own safe, oblivious perspectives, and into the dark, stubborn human condition.I wish I didn't need to write three hundred and fifty more characters to post this review.

Firstly I didn't know what to expect at all from this & went into it with that intent because I hoped for something more like a previous film I watched with Gleeson & Don Cheadle "The Guard" which I have to say was far funnier & superior to this filmSo definitely check The Guard out more than this one,
That being said I suppose my primary take is that the acting is superb Farrell,Gleeson,Keoghan & Kerry Condon are the only reason I finished the film, exceptional Irish talent & that's a compliment straight from an Englishman right there, the story is limited & centres on Farrel & Gleeson through out but who cares to be honest is the overriding feeling I had, Has to be said Farrel has come a long way since the phone booth his turn at the Penguin amongst other roles he's excelling & showing true development as a great actor aside from the acting not sure why this film is getting so much love,
WATCH "THE GUARD" INSTEAD.

reviews.review_title: About what I expected, was hoping for more
reviews.content: An interesting, unique take on friendship and the hardships that can come with it. I think what I liked the most is that sometimes relationships end, whether it be abrupt or a falling out over time.The movie was fairly decent, but I missed the wow factor that many have been boasting about. It kinda reminded me of The Lighthouse without the isolation and madness that comes with it.I was surprised how long the movie was, though with a slow pace, it didn't really drag. By time it was over, I could not believe two hours had already come and gone. I do not know how anyone could understand this film in a theater without subtitles.

reviews.review_title: A great film that gets even better with time
reviews.content: Martin McDonagh is now officially one of the best directors working today. His latest piece, The Banshees of Inisherin, is a complex and layered work of art that makes you think and then makes you laugh. It is one of those pictures you can't stop thinking about long after you've seen them, you just keep liking it more by the day.The movie deals with a plethora of themes. Padraic (Colin Farrell) is a character study, and an excellent one at that. Through Colm (Brendan Gleeson), McDonagh makes us wonder about decisions we take in our lives and the way we choose to spend our time. He also explores relationships between friends and siblings. While coming to grips with Colm's decision, Padraic tries to find the answers with his sister Siobhan (Kerry Condon) who is the heart and soul of this story. And there's also Dominic (Barry Keoghan). I can't remember the last time I saw so many phenomenal performances in the same picture. Both the main and the supporting cast do outstanding jobs, and the writing and direction are spot on as well.The setting for the fictional Inisherin, while picturesque, is perfect for the overall heavy atmosphere as it gives additional credibility to the actions of the actors. It also makes for some beautiful camera shots.The film should speak to anyone who ever felt or feels lost, melancholic, to the ones who dreamt of leaving their small town to escape lethargy and apathy and doing something with their lives. I would recommend it to the people who like dark humor too. If you liked In Bruges, chances are you'll like this one.

This was a job well done. The movie is a beautiful one to watch as the background and cinematography are simply gorgeous. The acting is flawless. The plot is unique and engrossing but simple to the point where if you explained it to someone they would probably be confused as to how a movie could be made out of it. My one issue with the film was the ending. I'm all for ambiguous endings because I think they lead to contemplation and are more reflective of real life than a finish which is neatly tied up in a bow. This ending, however, felt rushed and too undone for me. Otherwise, a terrific watch.

The Banshees of Inisherin is set during Ireland's Civil War and is a clear metaphor for the conflict between Colm and Pádraic. Legacy vs Morality is the biggest question addressed as our main characters circle this issue. The best aspect of this film is the acting from the duo of Collin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson to the supporting cast of Barry Keoghan and Kerry Condon. McDonagh gives the audience a great deal to consider and he serves up the questions with great comedy at a satisfying pace.Plot: 8/10
Acting: 9/10
Cinematography: 5.5/7
Score: 3/5
Enjoyable: 1/1
=80/100Favorite Character = Pádraic (Colin Farrell)Favorite Scene = Confession of SinsFavorite Quote = "We haven't been rowing. I don't think we have been rowing. Have we been rowing?" - Pádraic.

Martin McDonagh's "In Bruges" is one of my favorite movies of all time, and in this film he brings Brendan Gleason and Colin Farrell back together again in a poignant, heartbreaking story that is in the absurdist tradition of Samuel Beckett. In fact, without the splendid Irish coastline vistas and verdant countryside, you'd think you were in the theater.The acting is superb overall and the severed relationship, broken without a cause, at the center of the story elevates this film to a metaphysical exploration of friendship, boredom, aggression, ambition, family, loneliness, hope, and despair.With a backdrop of the 1922-23 Irish Civil War, this is not a movie that will make you feel particularly good, but you can't ignore it either. It's an artistic revelation.

The Banshees of Inisherin is an intriguing watch despite the lack and scale of events. The events that do occur throughout are merely social ones, which is no surprise following the isolated setting adding more weight to characters choices and opinions.The moment in which intrigue begins is when Colm (Brendan Gleeson) ends his friendship with Padraic (Colin Farrell). The film follows Padraic who's core interest is behind wanting to understand this decision. As the film moves forward this becomes partly an open ended choice for the viewer. Whom decides who really was at fault. As you lean in to the themes however, you will discover that there is more to Colm's sudden turn in attitude. The themes explored and their ties to the narrative are very interesting and dealt with immaculately.Sadly, I believe the film misses out on character building prior to Colm's epitome. It is hard to imagine this character any other way than displayed in the film, which is described to be much different compared to his older self. That, as well as the damming tone of the film serve as imperfections. It is not the most enjoyable watch and its comedy is witty at times but lacks control over scenes. This is likely the intention as comes with the design of dark humour but i was expecting a comedy listed film to have brighter moments. Having that said, despite being an enjoyer of dark humour, i hardly found myself creasing the ends of my mouth.A great encapsulation of isolation but not for the lighthearted.

Expectations were so very high after watching the trailer. However, it isn't what you may expect. It won't leave you feeling giddy or glad. It will leave you a bit frustrated, perplexed and maybe a bit sad as hopes for a reconciled friendship slowly fizzles.The acting is perfect, cinematography is great and the story is unique. This story seems to be a metaphor for something deeper. There are clear references to the Irish Civil War. This is at the heart of the story and most likely inspired the film. Watching this casually I expected a well acted dark comedy, but this is not what you will get, despite the trailers promise. However, it is worth a watch, just be prepared for sad story with subtle hints at more.7/10 but the more I think about it the more I like it.

Everything about this movie is simply brilliant, at it's core it is such a basic movie premise, one friend suddenly wants nothing to do with his other friend, but at the same time the movie was so incredibly deep with many subtleties. The movie was also very funny and entertaining in an almost satirical fashion if you aren't familiar with this kind of Irish culture but then you realise it is all very serious, the authenticity of the film is also another reason why i loved it so much.Of course it can't go unmentioned but i am sorry to have to repeat it. The performances by every single member of the cast is outstanding, the relationships between the characters are captivating.The sound and cinematography emphasise the authentic feel as well as cementing the scale of the island and the 'loneliness' of the characters. The occasional references to the main island give you these moments of self reflection which to me were very powerful when they happenedConclusion is that this film is somewhat of a slow-burn but massively amusing despite that, you just don't want to stop watching. Also the accents are very entertaining of course.

reviews.review_title: Love It, I Can't Stop Thinking of I
reviews.content: Every single actor in this film, deserves all the awards In the worldA brilliant dark comedy.Martin Mcdonagh directing is brilliant - wow - a tale about friendship and loneliness.He Banshees of Inisherin is the best movie of the year. Every scene has a visual landscape setting and colour tone is completely balanced.The movie revolves around 3 arcs and all the 3 have their perfect conclusions and intersect cleverly. It's one of the best writing you will ever see. There is a perfect blend of humour and tragedy. The stories revolve around Colin Farrell coming to terms that his best friend doesn't want to do anything with him, his sister played by Kerry Cordon trying to find the ultimate purpose in her life and Dominic played by Barry Keoghan, who is living a worst life possible.Colin Farrell - great acting.The Banshees of Inisherin deserves both commercial and critical acclaim. Very rarely movies that satisfy everyone are made, this is one of them.

This movie is f amazing. It's hard to be fun and deep separately, but The Banshees of Inisherin manages to be both at the same time under a rhythm that flows like the cleanest river, and that isn't afraid to slow down when's necessary to penetrate sufficiently into certain ideas.I believe that the uncertainty about the correct use of time is a problem that concerns all of humanity; there is no individual who escapes this elemental doubt. Wanting to make sense of our actions and trying to leave something behind; that our name has meant even a small amount, not even progress, but a simple contribution to the species, is something that directly contrasts with the simple fact of living. There are individuals more predisposed to the present, as well as others with more abstract inclinations who set their eyes on the future: Pádraic, unintentionally, interferes with Colm's "intellectual" activity, and that dichotomy creates a gap in the friendship at least unilaterally.More than one will be able to recognize and see themselves denounced in this film: I separate certain people for the sake of a greater search, for an end that matters... or maybe I'm just being a petulant f assh*l*. The answer? That's the dilemma.PS: The performances are just outstanding; everyone, from its protagonists to the people with two seconds at the bar. The ridiculously good actor that Colin Farrell is, here continues to shows itself. And the photography of the film is just beautiful, but, I mean, it's Ireland.

reviews.review_title: i'll remember this movie by the end of the decade
reviews.content: The Banshees of Inisherin is definitely one of the movies that will make you just "think". We are presented with Farrell (Padraic) and Gleeson (Colm) experiencing interpersonal conflict as friends, and the sole reason for that is Colm is reaching the end of his days, and doesn't want to spend the rest of his days with Padraic, whom he sees as dull, monotonous, a waste of time essentially. He believes the rest of his days should be spent playing music, or playing music with others. The conflict here is that Padraic is not able to comprehend the fact that Colm can just leave him like that. They were friends, and suddenly Colm just drops him.
