Honestly, if someone just dropped me like that I would also go a little bit wacko, you dont drop someone like that, and if you was friends for years???? Yeah oh hell naw.Martin McGonagall I meant McDonagh went absolutely ASTRONOMICAL in every aspects of this movie lets appluse for the sound mixers the lighting crew the elderly man who sew those sweaters and all the other crew. Let me first of all talk about the setting. Some Irish island and wooow it so beautiful but like cinematography gives it the cream if you know what I mean. The use of wide shots - e.g. In the bar is used carefully in the sense that we can establish comfort when Colm plays for the other people at the bar but we can then see the contrast in Padraic, the despair in his facial expression is encapsulated PERFECTLY. Like, I dont know about you but I felt actual emotions watching this and if you didn't probably seek a therapist or something /s.Secondly, sound mixing SAY WHAT??? Lighting SAY WHAAAAAT? Ok, sound mixing like woow everything sounds right uhh i know nothing about sound mixing but it feels right so um yes. But lighting, CAPTURE SUNSET SUNRISE THANK YOU. Capture the dark gloomy ravenous overcast day to signify character depression thank you yada yada yada.Just watch this movie honestly its very difficult to not enjoy it but everyone has their own subjective opinions of course !!

I enjoyed the film and the actors were very good but cutting your fingers off to make a point is ultimately unrealistic. No one would do it. Delving into the nuances of friendship and the unseen compromises and resentments that exist in most friendships was intriguing and a very difficult task but wrapping up the story in a satisfying manner proved too much for the writers. Barry Keoghan was quite exceptional and along with Farrell (whose sadness at losing his friend and being thought of as being dull was beautifully acted )deserve the accolades. Even with its glaring faults it's certainly worth watching.

A smart, poetic and taxing black tragicomedy from the often brilliant mind of Martin McDonagh (In Bruges, Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri), set on a sparsely populated fictional island off the west coast of Ireland in the year of 1923. The premise is a budding conflict between two former pals (Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson), backdropped against the Irish Civil War, which is seen raging on the mainland. McDonagh's usual quirky dialogue and small shifts in tone help create a playful atmosphere despite the material's inherent gloominess. You'll likely find yourself chuckle your way through this slowly wounding downward spiral. McDonagh touches upon timeless, universal aspects of humanity during this dissection of a friendship gone awry, but despite powerful themes and wonderful acting, the film retains an academic quality throughout which keeps everything at a certain distance. It's in its depiction of the bond between the people and their animals that The Banshees of Inishering is at its most poignant. And there is also a magnificent supporting performance by Barry Keoghan as the dim but highly acute village idiot.

Three and half times watched, and I find more to like in each viewing. The true test of good acting is when you don't think of someone as acting but as the character they play in the film. This happens to me once in a while. "Oh wait....he is acting, he is an actor." In the scene where Dominic gets rejected by Siobhan. The performance by Barry Keoghan is so good, so heartbreaking, He shows so many emotions with his facial expressions, his movements, those sad, searching eyes, the words, the look back as he walks away is crushing. For that scene alone you should never miss this movie. Also, Colin is spot on with his "dim" and "dull" character, since Colin is Irish, he has probably known people just like his character.It took me a while to figure who the why of this story. Why would Colm do such a thing, and what was his point? It was for selfish reasons. He wanted to be famous for something after he dies so once he finished his song, he wanted to make sure it became famous by making it his one and only composition and then attaching an unforgettable fact that he cut his fretting fingers off on finishing it.I recognized beautiful Keem Beach on Achill Island in West County Mayo, Ireland as the location of Colm's thatched home. I spent a beautiful sunny afternoon there about 10 years ago. Not many tourists make it out there, but it's worth the trip.

This one came out of nowhere. I'm a huge fan on the director and Brendan Gleeson and Colin is a generational talent. But the entire cast was awesome. What I was most impressed with was the tone of the film. It managed to be hilarious almost throughout but still had this looming sense of danger and dread. It was totally unpredictable and kept you guessing to until the very end-- "How is this thing going to be resolved". I know some people have complained about how it ended and DON'T WORRY this review contains no spoilers. I however thought the ending was brilliant. A perfect close to what just may very well be the best film of the year.

The Banshees of Inisherin is the best film I've seen in years. Most unusually, there is not one point that the captivation lapses, even for a minute.Starting off as a relatively gentle, humorous plot, it takes a turn into dark, macabre territory. Personal relationships and tensions pushed to the limit.The scenery throughout is breathtakingly beautiful and astonishing, colour & content. It must have been a joy to make this movie. Not least interacting with some lovely animals, an added bonus.The performances are top class, not one character lets the story down.It's funny, sad and thought provoking, and clearly the actors (all of them) have such chemistry between them that the viewer is treated to 2 hours of magic: time that passes all too quickly.

reviews.review_title: Wonderful in many ways, but loses its way in 2nd half
reviews.content: There's so much wonderful in this movie. The acting, of course, esp the 4 leads. Some fantastic dialogue with that Irish mix of sad, humorous, and poignant. Wonderful scenes esp in the confessional, shop, and, of course, pub.Starts with Gleason telling Farrell he wants to end their long friendship because Farrell's to dull and dim. E.g. Farrell recently going on for 2 hrs on what he found in his donkey's droppings (would prob do it for me too). Unfortunately it just loses its way about half way through and suddenly becomes a movie about someone with severe mental illness.Much less interesting than where you think the areas the movie could have been heading to.

It's an absolute joy to watch good actors delivering on this many levels. Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell are always brilliant but the synergy with the rest of the cast makes this movie very special. The dialog is expertly delivered throughout and coupled with the setting, cinematography and storytelling this movie is close to being a masterpiece. I watched it, then I watched it again and my second viewing was as enjoyable as the first, despite knowing the plot. The vast array of emotions this movie provokes is truly outstanding. It's a deeply sad story on the base level but it has hilarious and absurd moments to. Highly recommended!

We watched this hoping for a "Waking Ned Devine"....ah no. This is no Sunday night 'sit by the fire' type of Irish delightful movie. We had heard the hype of Awards and had high expectations of a quirky art house movie with some Irish quirky natured laughs along the way.The little house on the water and seaside village was the only similarity. Acting and scenery, tick. Theme was dark but please don't expect a comedic finish.Still visiting these little coastal villages is on our bucket list for an Ireland trip. I want Guinness and oysters!We both couldn't sleep after this movie. Disturbing content.

reviews.review_title: This movie will stick with you
reviews.content: I honestly don't know why I love this movie so much. It has great acting, extremely likeable characters, a world 100 years ago that is fascinating. Maybe it's the simplicity of it. The story just seems so relatable. It might be one of my favorite movies of the last few years. It does what a good movie is supposed to do. It took me to a simpler time, and made me ask myself questions about myself. What kind of friend am I? What do I like about my own friends? Am I the stoic jerk who cuts off his best friend, or the fool with a good heart? I think we are all a little bit of both!Bottom line: excellent movie and even better performances! Loved it.

There are many negative user reviews on this site for The Banshees of Inisherin. I can understand that. If you require lots of action, thrills and special effects this ain't your picture. But there's an interesting strain that runs through many of the harshest user reviews. They praise the acting. For me that was the point of the film.The story is slight, to the point of diaphanous. Overlaid on this translucent structure are the amazing performances of the cast. Gleason and Farrell carry the brunt of it but, up and down, I couldn't find a single false note from any of the cast. This was an amazing piece of work.To any aspiring movie actors, on your list of acting classes and getting an agent and composing resumes, make sure to include repeated viewings of The Banshees of Inisherin. It will teach you how to give an effective and powerful performance without chewing scenery.

I'd give this film 9/10 or 10/10 for the first 95% of the film but they really blew it with a terrible ending. Up until that point I was marvelling at the script, cinematography, humour, acting and uniqueness of the whole thing. However I was really disappointed with how it finished, absolutely no end of the story arc whatsoever. It just felt unfinished. Such a shame. They could have either done a reconciliation ending (maybe the boring option), or killing each other, or them writing music together, or fighting with each other in the civil war. Any of these endings would have been better. Such a missed opportunity.

I found this movie deeply disturbing to the point of almost being farcical.Maybe the word I am looking for is "far-fetched".It's well worth a watch considering I've never seen anything like it before.Collin Farrell did a pretty good job considering he just wanted answers. It's never fun when friendships break up. I think most people actually just move on. This movie gave the friendship duo almost a "fatal attraction" vibe but there was nothing sexual about it.I will say that I knew two friends who went their separate ways. One friend owed the other money and refused to pay it back. What he did for the next six months to drive his friend crazy would be a movie on it's own. The second friend learned a hard lesson about not paying someone back and the aftermath of cheating him was not worth his sanity!

Presumably the falling out of friends Colm and Padraic is a metaphor for the Irish Civil War. The behaviour of the two seems to me arbitrary and at time inexplicable. The narrative has no great pull and no plot devices. It strikes me as deliberately 'Irish' and so quite unconvincing in its mise en scene - characters too clean, costumes too bright and fancy, extras too many and too choreographed. An Irish west coast island in 1922 would have been poor and grubby. Some characters - the old crone and the nosey shopkeeper - were straight from central casting. The colour was pumped up to make the film look artificial. I didn't care about any of the characters, except perhaps for Dominic (Barry Keoghan) abused son of the brutal island policeman. I have to wonder about the judgment of professional critics who claimed to find this film 'hilarious' and 'shot through with humour'. Similarly I can't understand the high praise for the cinematography. Very disappointing.

Two friends separate apart with the backdrop of war. This film is an amazing black comedy. The score is amazing. The editing is some of the best editing I've ever seen in a film. And the framing of the shots in it is both haunting and outstanding. It deserves the golden globe. It's one of the greatest of 2022. Colin feral is great in it. With Brendan Gleason being snubbed at the golden globes for best supporting actor. And the production design is beautiful. I would go as far as to say this is up there with visually stunning films with Spirted away and 2001. I want to move there after watching this. And some of the twist this movie makes. A+

reviews.review_title: The Banshees of Inisherin: Movie Review
reviews.content:
Synopsis: The life of two long-time friends takes an unexpected turn when one decides to break all ties with the other without specifying any reason behind the decision.On one fine beautiful day in 1923, on an Irish island, Pádraic Súilleabháin (Colin Farrell) visits his friend Colm Doherty (Brendan Gleeson) to call him to the pub just like any regular day. There he comes to know that Colm doesn't want to be friends with him anymore. Clueless Pádraic didn't understand the reason behind such a massive step and tries to dissolve the situation by apologizing and talking to his dear friend. Contrary to his efforts, the more he tries to talk to Colm, the more the situation worsens, and that further leads to devastating events in both of their lives.The Banshees of Inisherin is an extremely beautiful film, both from a story as well as a scenic perspective. The screenplay is so smooth that one doesn't even realize the passing minutes of the runtime. The cinematography is brilliant. The wide-angle shots of captivating landscapes with cloudy sky and seashore give a soothing experience.McDonagh's direction is top class and he has masterfully created a mesmerizing world around us in this film. On one end, the story's simplicity gives a touch of authenticity to the film; on the other hand, the diligent character development & careful writing, make the characters more real than fictional. Every moment and conversation has been used efficiently to develop the story and take it further. Everything happening on the screen makes sense. Since McDonagh himself has written the film, he embraces the characters with the utmost care, and it's evident too, throughout the film when as a viewer we can relate to the characters and the situations. Even smaller role characters are written with interesting character arcs.When such a talented cast is onboard, you can expect top-notch performances. Colin Farrell once again gives an Oscar-worthy performance with an extremely powerful portrait of his character. You can literally feel his anguish and emotions. Brendan Gleeson is equally outstanding with his marvellous dialogue delivery and character portrayal. Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan are the scene stealers and make their characters memorable even with limited screen time.This comedy-drama, under the carpet, is actually more of a tragic tale. There are metaphors, but one doesn't need to dwell too deeply to understand them. They have been laid out in simpler ways here. There are plenty of scenes that would make you laugh, but at the same time, there are many that would make you sad. The film explores various underlying themes like loneliness, sadness, love, and friendship under the umbrella theme of human relationships.At the end of the day, I see The Banshees of Inisherin as a film that everyone would appreciate in one way or the other. It's smartly written, brilliantly directed, and passionately portrayed. It's a fascinating piece of cinema and every frame in it is simply admirable.Follow me: on Instagram: m_movie_reviews
Rating: 8.3/10.

It's hard to stomach or appreciate how despairing and lonely life in such an isolated hamlet of a place at such a point in time would be. This film manages exceptionally to convey in brutal comedic darkness how uneventful & limiting remote living would be. Grudges, gossip, misery, & sheer madness driven from boredom. Slow moving but perfectly threaded and perfectly endearing. You are engrossed in every character. With sympathy for their humour &suffering. Where Sunday church is a staple of connectivity and drinking from 2pm a ritual to create and confront. Is the rift driven by sheer boredom to force change? If you only have one life and everyone will forget you anyway, wouldn't you want to at least live a good & kind life to the people you share it with? Barry Keoghan is simply magnificent beyond compare. This movie deserves all the awards thrown at it.

reviews.review_title: Existential dread wrapped in history, lore, and humanity.
reviews.content:
"The Banshees" is a film that touches on themes of friendship, nothingness, and pessimism. It harkens to the styles of Oscar Wilde, James Joyce, and even Shakespeare.This movie is modest, humble, and nowhere near pretentious as this review.The acting was superbly executed. Thoughtful,
emotional, and darkly funny. The wit and love over time and study that went into this film is lost in a time of instant gratification and self satisfaction.The character development is at a perfect pitch and even-keeled.Farrell and Glisan are an excellent match who have authentic chemistry together.Kerry Condon is as gracefully beautiful and talented as always. And Barry Keoghan captured his character with perfection.This story encompasses grief, loss, angst, and despair during a time of just that in the "Emerald Isle"- The Irish Civil War.This isn't your Americanized, scooby-doo version of a banshee. "The Banshees" interweaves Irish folklore into the drama with precision, not straying away from what an actual banshee was told to be.Beautiful imagery, intelligent, darkly funny, amazing acting, great nuance in writing, and vision is why I give this Film a 9/10.

I never give any movies or any shows 10. But I'm going to give this one a 10. Both of the leading actors are spot on and very engaging with every line that they give. The music and the scenery is a 10 plus. The following actors each and every one of them are also a 10 plus. They're acting is spot-on and I'm only guessing because of the writer allowed them to be. I can't say too much about this movie without giving away the amazing storyline, but I am going to say that this is probably my best movie in the last few years. I am a huge series watcher, I don't really care for movies anymore as they are such a big letdown. And I feel that watching six to eight series allows a good storytelling. But this movie reaches beyond that and tells such an amazing story within a short amount of time. I would highly suggest this movie to everyone that loves an amazing storytelling. I have watched it twice in the last 2 days with family. I wish I had more words to describe how amazing the story, music, visual, this movie. I am sure that it's going to win lots of awards. I hope.

reviews.review_title: So funny. So sad. So beautiful.
reviews.content: What a pleasant surprise! I enjoyed watching the trailer, did not really know what I was expecting and therefore, surprised with this beautiful and shocking movie.The scenery is just astonishing. The thick green landscape and well placed pictures of this beautiful country are more then worth watching on a big screen!The acting is just impressive. All of them doing such a fine job. The emotional variation of Farrell is Oscar worthy for sure. Some of the best actors of their generation!The music, which is well integrated in the story, makes atmosphere just perfect. The scenery and music give a well round concept.The story is devastating, but told in such a funny way. I laughed so much during this movie. The laughter definitely balances the rough message of the movie.

reviews.review_title: It literally happened to me after watching it
reviews.content: This is the best movie there is about ghosting and what insane chaotic sad emotions this creates around people who really care for someone. A story told in the past but so actual. People keep doing this for the most absurd reasons ,hurting and getting hurt. A simple question could make one think about it with a higher perspective: What if the one you ghost would suddenly die tomorrow?Well, almost nothing I just described is part of this moving story pictured here, but it could. If you are sensible, emotional and have a heart you will enjoy this movie. If you lack adulthood, if you are a troll and lack intelligence to understand something as simple as this story tells, then you will not enjoy this masterpiece that predicted my future somehow.I wish life was not has cruel as this story tells us.

Here is the review everyone has been waiting for, as it's the most accurate and best opinion out there.This film is brilliant from start to finish, every performance is spot on and keeps the movie on track.A powerful and unique drama that has aspects of comedy in a classy and well timed manner - some say tongue in cheek, I'd say proportionate and very well thought out.Absolutely the best film of the year, possibly even in the last two which totally blows Belfast out of the water for performance, production value and narrative.In my opinion the best contender for the Oscar's in 23, id be amazed if it gets outshone by any other picture this year.Bravo.

reviews.review_title: An absurd play that actually hides a deeply philosophical fable
reviews.content: If it were not a philosophical allegory on the nature of Man, The banshees would probably only have for him his photography and his acting. Fortunately, the film offers a fable, that of the conflict between Man in his natural state embodied by tradition (Padraic) and civilizational Man embodied by music (Colm).Rousseau could have seen his most fundamental reflections there: The amoral goodness and naivety embodied by Padraic the animal lover - who seeks only to reproduce the tradition day after day without worrying about the next day, by going to drink his beer at the pub with his friend - represents the good savage, the pre-civilizational man, the one who does not care to write and mark history. His friendship is shattered one day by this new Man, the Man so decried by Rousseau, the modern Man, the one of civilization, the one who wishes to leave a trace in history through "the sciences and the arts", by composing a piece for violin: Colm. For Colm time counts and is counted! No more "hollow" conversations with the naive Padraic. He wishes to leave a legacy to civilization unlike the good savage for whom time and history are irrelevant.But Padraic doesn't understand. For him, this desire to leave nature, tradition has no meaning. He wants to understand. But Calm wants to do something with his two hands, the tool that allowed Man to found civilization. By trying to understand this divorce, Padraic will cause Colm to cut off his fingers. And these are the same fingers that will kill Padraic's donkey. What meaning should be given to this scriptwriting choice that is a priori absurd and wacky? The fingers of Man allow him to found civilization and to leave the state of nature. By preventing Colm's will to rejoin civilization, Padraic takes away his tools to achieve it. And the fingers of modern man will end up killing what matters most to Padraic: his donkey, which represents both nature and naivety, simplicity.A bit of ecology in this fascinating fable: Padraic, the Man who embodies nature in all its simplicity will want to take revenge on Colm, the man of civilization, destroyer of the environment.In this confrontation between what Man may have been a long time ago (Man in the state of nature has probably never existed, it's a philosophical concept) and what he has become ( the one Rousseau calls "Modern Man"), death lurks in the distance, armed with his hooked stick (the scythe) and seated on Colm's rocking chair. She patiently waits to know which of the man in the state of nature or the man of civilization will prevail to know who she will mow down.

reviews.review_title: Colin Farrell is Brilliant in BANSHEES OF INISHERIN, a Film about the Need for Human Connection
reviews.content: The latest film, THE BANSHEES OF INISHERIN from writer/director Martin McDonagh (In Bruges), sees the re-teaming of Brendan Gleeson (Colm) & Colin Farrell (Pádraic) in a dark comedy set on an isolated island off the coast of mainland Ireland at the climax of the Irish Civil War in 1923. Colm's abrupt decision to end his friendship with Pádraic starts a series of events and creates upheaval in the otherwise ordinary lives of several of the islanders. Gleeson and co-star Kerry Condon (Pádraic's sister, Siobhán) give strong performances. But, it's Colin Farrell as Pádraic who steals the film, brilliantly conveying BANSHEES themes of kindness, fear of change, isolation, grief and the importance of human connection. Features cinematography by Ben Davis, shot along Ireland's west coast, equal parts bleak, ominous and breathtakingly beautiful.

reviews.review_title: This is a history lesson of Irish v English conflict
reviews.content: I think it is a reference to when Ireland and England were friends.... One decided to pick a fight, then it morphed into Irish fighting Irish for independence (movie set in 1923) ..... the cutting the fingers off is representing 'cutting your nose off to spite your face' no one wins and all you did was hurt yourself.Then it escalates from there.Hence reference many times to 'the bombs and their still at it' on the main land of Ireland.The you boy that drowns is symbolism for the youth of Ireland.... Young / silly / naive..... all had hope..... then gave up when told there was none.The police officer represented England.... They should have protected Ireland.... But did the complete opposite.My synopsis of the movie anyway.

What a strangely hauntingly beautiful moving story of the ways of old times which were brutal but honest. I loved everything about this movie from the acting to the animals and cried at times. The scenery was absolutely spectacular. The old ways of getting the boats out of the harbour was amazing as was the scene on the cliffs from both angles. I wonder how many people back when this was set used to regularly house their animals inside the home with them. The music played back then was beautiful. The 5 main characters, the 2 blokes and their beloved animals and the long suffering sister, stole the show as did the "young lad" another main character whose life was one of horror too much for him to bare. I would recommend this beautiful movie to anyone who asks.

We watched Banshees of Inisherin. Out to lunch on this one. Funny, tragic, angering and quite disturbing.Anyhow, the acting , screenplay and cinematography were exceptionally good. The story, not so much. The movie centers around the (rapid) deterioration of a relationship between two friends who live in a small community on an island off the coast of Ireland during the early 1920's during a time of significant civil unrest. The extreme behaviors and events which follow are anything but friendly.If you haven't watched already , 'In Bruges' is another black comedy pairing the 2 gents for the first time and with the same director. I loved this movie and found it the better of the two. Like Inisherin, I laughed my butt off until I couldn't.. To note, it is a disturbing flick, too.

I walked into this one, clueless! But came out with my heart heavy and my head full. There's something about it that creeps up on you especially as it begins as a straight up comedy but ones the camel's back is broken, you keep hoping for the best resolution but it never comes.I walked into this one, clueless! But came out with my heart heavy and my head full. There's something about it that creeps up on you especially as it begins as a straight up comedy but ones the camel's back is broken, you keep hoping for the best resolution but it never comes.Kudos to everyone involved in this masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: "Nine fingers is the epitome of mental."
reviews.content: Martin McDonagh is one of the finest screenwriters of today and this film continues his fantastic run. I will say, I don't think this film is on the same level of brilliance as Three Billboards, but they are different films and both have much to like about them. As far as Banshees goes, it is the acting of the 4 leads that really stood out to me, Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan, all 4 were terrific and I could see them pulling out an ensemble SAG win despite it being a smaller cast. I personally think The Fabelmans is still the Best Picture frontrunner, but I could see this picking up some individual wins for screenplay as well as possible supporting acting wins for Gleeson and Condon, maybe even a lead actor win for Farrell. The writing was just so well done in this film and I always found myself intrigued as to what would happen next. This is shaping up to be a great award season for film and I am excited to see where Banshees stacks up against the rest.

reviews.review_title: Sad, lonely, and a terrific black comedy film
reviews.content: The plot focuses on three arcs, each having a great finish and elegantly intersecting. Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson are mates who have a falling out because one of them no longer wants to be friends with the other. Why? He doesn't want to waste his time with dull guys because he's realized how rapidly his life is passing him by. Obviously, Collin (Pádraic Súilleabháin) takes offense and begins attempting to win the other back until his friend's stubbornness leads his boiling resentment to boil over.Colin Farrell gives one of, if not the, greatest performances of his career, with his adorable naivety gradually transforming into a blazing rage. Brendan Gleeson is amazing because of his continually calm demeanor and ability to humanize his character despite his severe decision.The film is brilliantly shot, perfectly reflecting the natural landscape. The excellent costume and set design brilliantly convey the period (1920s Ireland), drawing you into the entire act.Martin McDonagh has created an exceptional film in many respects, beginning with the brilliant theatrical writing and performances by all the main actors. It's one of the best pieces of writing you'll ever witness. There is an excellent balance of comedy and sadness.It is a truly masterful film and an absolute joy to watch.

This was such an amazing film to experience at the movie theater, a total joy! The synchronicity of laughter was just so much fun. I imagine that most of the audience were In Bruges fans and were there to see Gleeson and Farrell together again. Such AMAZING chemistry between those two! This was a beautiful, beautiful film. The cinematography of the Irish landscape was awe inspiring. I loved all of the images of Celtic crosses, high sea cliffs, green rolling hills, etc. All accompanied by a heavenly score. The acting was phenomenal on all levels. I think this was Farrell's best role to date. He was simply amazing in this film. I would have to say the same for Gleeson. What a duo! I can't wait to give this a second look. Like In Bruges, I will be visiting The Banshees of Inisherin again and again. Classic!

reviews.review_title: Funny and heartbreaking in equal measures
reviews.content: A visually beautiful movie; as an Irish person living in Western Canada this movie tugged at my heart strings. It's your typical Irish story, a backdrop of hardship, isolation and challenging times heavily sprinkled with a naive type innocence and humour. I loved the storyline with Jenny the donkey and how the movie portrays the loyalty and devotion of animals; on an island with little potential to find love, the animals provided some degree of hope. It's the kind of movie that you can't stop thinking about once it's finished. I thoroughly enjoyed it and would highly recommend it. It's a wonderful movie.

I just realized a Female Donkey is called Jenny, and not just a random name.A typical oscar bait, with some nice sceneries shot. With this type of film, the story has to be intrigued in order to capture the audience, and it's not the worst. Certainly a movie I can get through if to watch it in a theater. To be honest, I thought it was another gay film, and thank goodness we get nothing of that. Just one crazy guy endless disturbance to a poor man, which I think he deserved the consequences. And yet, they go through the pity route. Brendan character should stick to his value instead of feeling empathy.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful and rich but very sad
reviews.content: It blows my mind how few people know about Irish history, the occupation by the British for 800 years, their cruel oppression of Irish culture, the famine that killed a million people, and the ensuing struggles for self-determination.The Irish Civil War (early 1920s) provides the backdrop for this film, even though the conflict is disconnected from the mythical island Inisherin, off the coast of Galway. The islanders do not really know what the war is about, but they can hear bombs and what could be executions taking place on the distant mainland. I took the Banshees of Inisherin as a painful allegory of the Irish Civil War, when the nation cut its own nose off to spite its face. The story follows a refined man, Colm, who one day decides he does not want to be friends with Padraic, a sweet man who lives with his sister and loves his animals, because the latter is too dull. The film is almost Shakespearean, as it lurches from farce to heartbreak, as Colm's depression manifests as a desperate need to be left alone. The plot's underlying themes portray the boredom and frustration of island life, a man's yearning to leave something important behind, and the sadness of broken dreams. Banshees is quite a beautiful film, but bleak. I did not come out of the cinema feeling uplifted. However, it is McDonagh's most mature work and another of his odes to the Irish people. I feel some people will 'get' this film and other's will not, as evidenced by some of the scathing and inaccurate reviews here, which portray the film as empty, patently untrue. Maybe my knowledge of Irish history gives this film personal meaning. The cast is terrific, I have always thought of Colin Farrell as an astonishing actor who has made dodgy film choices. I hope he follows his gut instinct to be a character actor, and avoids more Hollywood blockbusters.To be honest I cannot see this film garnering a swag of Oscars (I hope I am wrong) because the Academy loves sentimentality too much.

Beautiful scenery of a fictional Irish island. I've been to Ireland and this was very real to me.Well acted; the characters were developed very well. I could almost feel what each of them were feeling as the storyline slowly unfolded. This is key. It unfolded very slowly. Two or more of these actors were In Bruge, which is much faster paced and more comedic. Don't go to watch this expecting something like In Bruge. If you do, you will be disappointed. This movie is all about relationships of the villagers on this tiny island, mostly cut off from the rest of the world.It is more of a Shakespearean tragedy. It has a few comedic lines, but not enough to warrant calling it a comedy.A lonely island in Ireland, period piece set in 1923 during the Irish civil war.I loved the cute miniature donkey and the border collie.You will hold your animal closer after this movie.

reviews.review_title: A quiet and compelling modern folk-tale from a master storyteller.
reviews.content: In Bruges is one of my favourite films ever so I was very excited for McDonagh's next story.I don't think it's as rewatchable as In Bruges. But I don't mean that as a slight. Banshees of Inisherin is a modern folk-tale, and it does everything so well. The ending left me thinking-a feat in itself-for days, possibly longer (it's nearly been a week, wish me luck).This film is masterful in how controlled it is. Like the people, the camera barely moves. This is a quiet, quaint town in 1920s Ireland, and the civil war in the background is just a blown up version of what's happening within the lens.The beautifully mundane setting has so much to do with character motivations.Why does monotony often conjure up animosity?What's the role of kindness in legacy?Watching these two characters work their way through such ideas is compelling fiction, and results in one of the years best films.

Mcdonagh got something with arson. In addition in this film, one's disallowing himself to the practice of art is interesting because Colm doesnt seem to be happy playing the fiddle rather when he has no finger he is joyful orchestrating the group. Padrick, has lost all of his friends, colm, his sister and the donkey so he is furious. What started as a joke turned into and existantial crisis.Colm does not want to be insignificant and Padrick wants no longer to be nice. But Colm also doesnt want to play the fiddle and Padrick doesnt want to give up being nice.What about Dominic? What happened to him, he took his own life maybe, he was way too troubled to begin with, he had no friends at all. His father abused him, sexually and physically, and the girl he loved refused him and what did he have left. The hook on a stick was to pull him to the shore, so it turns out.Shibon maybe she is the only true survivor of this stroy, but it is interesting that when she left the island, the war seemed to stop. What did this signify? Why Shibon's departure coincides with the end of the war. Or is it that by burning Colm's house the war between Padrick and Colm ended... For Padrick as long as Colm is alive the war wont be over but shall we take his word for it, does he not love his friend more than anything else or did he really change as sa person, gone over the ege and no longer can love Colm, even if Colm wants to love him, I doublt Padrick will be able to love him, so its a loss for the both sides JUST like the civil war. It was better when we were both killing enlishmen.

I had to drive over 100 miles to see this gem of a movie in a theater. I love a movie that requires some thinking. The metaphors, analogy and story stakes are just phenomenal. From the birds fighting in the first scene juxtaposed with the rainbow in a perfectly happy town; to the ever present Civil War in the background creates so many relationships with a war going on inside each character. Dark Comedy for sure but isn't life a dark comedy? The notable actors and writer/director have all been praised rightfully. So I will bring up the brilliant portrayal of Dominique by Barry Keoghan a tragic character that had more humanity than most in town.

reviews.review_title: Life's Story told in an Irish accent
reviews.content:
The Banshees of Inisherin is so beautiful in how it captures the reality of so many situations in a somewhat irrational way. Everyone of us can relate to every character presented and it creates such a fun and enjoyable viewing experience even when the movie takes a darker approach.The plot of this movie is so much because it takes so many turns that I truly did not expect to go down. The baseline plot is very basic and very easy to follow. But the little indirections the movie takes makes it so much fun to watch and truly gives you the experience of not knowing what is going to happen next
Plot:1.75/2It is incredibly challenging to find an MVP in this movie because every acting performance is absolutely superb. Every character from the main character banter between Farrell and Gleason to the cheekiness of Condom and Keoghan; every character feels important and every character gets their chance to shine in the absolute best way possible
Acting:2/2As mentioned previously, the direction this film takes is so much fun even if there is some incredibly dark themes. However, what is so effective is the ability for Mcdonah to take these dark themes and still use the humor so incredibly effectively to convey that. There is never a moment of boring and you truly want to continue to take a ride with these people
Storytelling:2/2The most creative thing about this film is how the characters do things that you don't expect them to do. You expect them to take a different approach to a situation and when it doesn't it can take you off guard and makes for a much more enjoyable story. It is a rollercoaster that you are riding blind which can be such a fun film to watch
Creativity:1.75/2This movie is shot so well and it truly makes you feel like you are in a quaint town in Ireland. The casting was perfection and that along with the subtle camera angles and use of the beautiful landscape make for a amazing film for the eyes
Other Factors:1.75/2Overall, this film was incredible. It was funny witty memorable moments with memorable characters but also moments of reflection and thought on some of the most fundamental parts of human nature such as friendship, envy and revenge
Overall:9.25/10.

This is why I think Martin McDonagh is one of the best writer-director living today, with In Bruges, Seven Psychopaths, Three Billboards Outside Ebbing Missouri, and now The Banshees of Inisherin. McDonagh has established himself to be a master of a world builder. There is something about McDonagh's writing that will make you want to live and experience the world he created. With Banshees of Inisherin, it talks about death, comfort, parallelism, existential despair, and oblivion, and people are yet afraid to talk about these things, but it's inevitable. One day we realize that we don't have much time left and all we wanted is to make sure that we will be remembered, and Martin McDonagh has captured the beauty and sadness of all these things in a hilarious and melancholic way as possible. The film is shocking and poignant but also guaranteed to make you laugh out loud.When people ask why I love to watch movies, aside from escapism, movies will also help me to view the world we are in right now from a different perspective, and this is what 'The Banshees of Inisherin' made me feel. There is a lot of meaning when you dive deep into the movie, but even on the surface, "The Banshees of Inisherin" is a crowd-pleasing and underneath all the black comedy is a sense of deep sadness that these people will now have to share the small island without talking to each other and it is painful. It's pure isolation and the anxiety of platonic loss, as nothing is more painful than losing the people you once valued. The film is a reminder that people do change, and want something different. We should not invalidate how they want to live their life just because it's different from how we live ours. One wanted to live the moment and be nice, while one wanted to make his life remembered, and both of these reasons are valid---you just have to respect their choices.Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson, and Kerry Condon combine for a sublime look at isolation and friendship and deliver something special. However, Barry Keoghan was fantastic. He was hilarious and charming, and yet you feel sad for him. The performances are just sincere and feel authentic which made the humor hit the nail without being forced. It was hard to take your eyes off the screen because of their performances which is a testament to their talent and the quality of the script. Just when you thought you knew where the film was going, it went in a very over-the-top, unexpected twist. My only concern with the movie is the ending, I just wished it did not end that way, I was asking for closure.The Banshees of Inisherin is a bleak and melancholy work that also manages to find many ways to emphasize the beauty of the location and individuals, but it's also a story about despair, relationship, and pain. Friend against friend, brother against brother, family against family, love lost, and grudges; all are in this little fable. This film will have a special place in my heart, and I will continue to remember this.

Among the Oscar nominees for best film of 2023, this film was definitely one of the big positive surprises for me.If it were possible I would give all the awards to the main actors of the plot, they all deliver an impeccable performance. The film's script is wonderful, which in turn is uniquely peculiar, it even seems like something scripted by Yorgos Lanthimos.However, it is not just the script that the film is based on, the entire production and photography direction of the film is impeccable, taking us on a wonderful journey to, until then unknown to me, the wonderful island of Inisherin.

Just a bunch of conversation that seemed like it was about nothing. Very slow moving which put me to sleep several times. Good acting which had plenty of emotional outbursts but not about anything I would have cared about, had I been there. I cannot understand how this could be nominated for so many awards. In my opinion, if the story is boring and no amount of scenery or photography can make it palatable. My question is, who is the target audience that might be interested in this babble? Glad I was watching it for free on HBO Max and not in a theater where I was paying for it. Definitely a movie to skip.

reviews.review_title: "It was all going fine 'till he chopped off all his fingers."
reviews.content: The Banshees of Inisherin wonderfully reunites the trio of McDonagh, Gleeson and Farrell, for a film that's not only deeply funny, deeply sad and disturbing, but most importantly one that knows its audience. By the latter specifically I mean that for those who enjoyed In Bruges (2008) - and I refer to myself in this generalisation - you feel for Farrell's character as you along with him are caught off guard and share in his despair at the loss of his friendship because we've seen the chemistry that both leads have, how - ultimately - they work as friends. It's a cleverly constructed film in that sense (one that I feel I can say wouldn't be effective without Gleeson and Farrell), you laugh when you're supposed to laugh and you feel when you're supposed to feel.The dialogue is beautiful and instantly quotable, the setting is idyllic in how beautifully shot it is, the costuming - especially Gleeson's worn out spaghetti western-esque lawman getup is a delight to watch him strut around in - with each piece suiting each character aptly, the musical score which acts as a bitter sweet death nell that things aren't going to be fine is the cherry on top. And while admittedly the symbolism and foreshadowing isn't always perfect, this is a film that stands on its cast, acting and dialogue and the three easily compensate for the films flaws as they make this picture stand on its own.While Gleeson and Farrell unsurprisingly steal the show, the supporting cast cannot be understated. The quippy barman, the dodgy copper and the busy body old biddies perfectly construct a believable Irish locale - even if the location shooting wasn't a factor - the setting is believable and it really helps with the doom and gloom that essentially every member of the island feels - whether they choose to acknowledge it or not. The best of the supporting cast is by far Barry Keoghan - having only briefly been introduced to this young actor through his agonisingly short portrayal of the Joker in Matt Reeves's The Batman earlier this year I was delighted to finally see him act and I wasn't disappointed in the slightest. His character is the most endearing aspect of the film, the hopelessness that all residents feel is exemplified in his character despite his efforts to drown it out with Poitín and the hopes for love. Dominic is by far the most upbeat character you'll find on Inisherin yet is arguably also the saddest; despite the main plot line I found myself feeling for him the most, the issues he faces are bigger than the petty squabbles of Pádraic and Colm, and significantly, one that has the biggest consequence: a death foreshadowed by the island's lone banshee Mrs. McCormick. There is something to be said for real problems being overlooked selfishly by everyone around you - since your own problems however big or small are always more important to you personally. Everyone on the island is a victim of circumstance but none more so than the film's tragedy case. You just want to reach through the screen and give him a hug, or keep him as a pet. But I'm willing to bet the latter may be just me.The main plot does feel like a joke that goes too far between two very bored friends who can't get past the mundanity of their lives - one more so than the other of course. There is a danger to deviating from the comfort of your life and spicing things up. Who's really in the wrong out of Pádraic and Colm? For me it was hard to tell. Even after lost fingers, dead donkeys, and burnt down houses, when the two part on the beach and Colm thanks Pádraic for looking after his dog, there's the unmistakable hint of a smile on his face and the feeling for the viewer that everything might just go back to normal tomorrow.The kicker is we never find out what the resolution of this sick joke is. In that sense the joke is on us. Would we be surprised if they became friends again after this? I don't think so. Where do you go from here if you remain enemies? Only those two nutters would know. But either option is fun and enticing, but ultimately, the answer is as nihilistically delightful as the film: it doesn't matter. Nothing really does.I enjoyed every second of this film and wish I had been able to come around to it sooner. I feel right now that this'll be the last film released in 2022 that I'll really enjoy and I'm more than okay with that. If this is the last time this trio get together then what a film to go out on. I can happily say in future I'll be making significantly more visits to Inisherin than Bruges.

One review I heard called the film 'inaccessible' and upon hearing this I immediately could tell what type of movie this was going to be.It's certainly charming, and at times, particularly toward the end of the film, it is deeply sad. It's what you'd expect from an Irish comedy film. Set on the island of Inisherin, it has that British-isle sense of open fields and rocky shores, which are all beautiful on film. You become accustomed to all of around five buildings the film takes place within, giving a sense of closeness with the small cast onscreen. They often had me wondering how bloody cold it must have been to live by the shore in the 1920s.Brendan Gleeson does a great job of flipping from his usual mild-mannered and solemn self, to extremes that are intentionally baffling and jarring. Colin Farrell is his ideal foil and driving point of the movie, and is consistantly asking questions and sparking trouble despite knowing better (or maybe from lack thereof). From each of their interactions you wait in anticipation of what will happen. Farrell is consistently itching for answers, and of Gleeson you wait on every word. The movie is ultimately about them, and about friendship between two weirdos.There are other personalities on the island that stick their noses perhaps where they don't belong, but they are under utilised - or atleast, the human characters are. The farm animals are like silent, sympathetic onlookers, relatable on the island to only the audience.The comedy is there, but it is even-tempered and peculiar - worlds away from the bombastic insanity of McDonagh's Seven Psychopaths. The movie is most akin to In Brughes, mostly for the modest, unique setting and the two main characters, but also the strange, intriguing commentary the storyline puts forward. Should you leave your best friend if they are impeding your life's dreams? Is a man valued at what the future remembers him for, or by the ones who love him in his lifetime?Whilst these questions are prominently asked, average viewers will dislike the lack of conclusion from the story. There are no answers here, only incessant pondering and perplexity. This might not be bothersome to fans of Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri, but no scene here is anywhere near as tense. There are no action scenes against a loud and tragic soundtrack, although there is atleast one scene of police brutality, which McDonagh seems to be a fan of.Worth the watch and the odd giggle throughout, but ultimately it felt just short of fulfilling. I think I'll rewatch one of McDonagh's others to satsiate my want for more.

Very dark, gruesome, sickening. Started out with characters, scene and interesting, then fell off the cliff. Would not recommend to anyone. I am supposed to add to this review, so if you like cute animals ruthlessly killed and fingers cut off, then you will like this. Otherwise, characters and scenery could better be written in another script. Whatever I point was trying to be made about the brother's relationship was beyond the beyond. Not cool or something to be watched. It was sadistic. Why not watch something that promotes positive content. It is one thing to see hardship, but another to highlight mental illness in a sick way.

There is a struggle inside me. Is this a good movie or is this show worthless?But the middle opinion prevails in me.Conclusion This movie has its pros and consThe first positive thing lies in Martin McDonagh's handling of a story that does not even amount to a short story, with all the perfection he made of a feature film.Another beautiful thing is the performance of all the actors, headed by the creative Colin Farrell. I am in love with Colin Farrell's style in all his roles, and I believe that he will compete strongly through this movie for the Oscar.Something I did not like about the movie is some boredom at the beginning. Also, when watching, you feel that there is something missing in this show. I do not know what it is. You feel as if there are few tools to make a movie. It could be, for example, in the number of characters.But I also think that the small number of characters expresses the loneliness of the gloomy island.

Without Giving away any spoilers, leave it to say this movie is incredibly weird in every way! It's dark and also slow paced and may not be everyone's cup of tea but it's incredibly well acted and produced. The characters are strange. The humor is beyond dark, but I did find myself laughing often.If you're down for strange and an ending that doesn't actually end anything, and leaving all your questions unanswered, and you're down for dark and dreary, then this would be the movie foe you.There's not a single solitary uplifting thing in this movie whatsoever, yet I find it strangely satisfying.

reviews.review_title: The In Bruges trio at it again.
reviews.content: McDonagh is back with his Bruge pals and his unique aesthetic.A movie about the 'break up' of two longtime friends,after a drastic and sudden decision of one. Brendan Gleeson(Colm) is impressive and as always at his best with his great performance and perfect chemsitry with Farrell(Pádraic) as the spark of the movie's fuse ,as impressive are Condon(Siobhán), one of the greatest controlled supporting preformances I've seen, as the sister of Pádraic and the big fish in the small pond of the incredibly beautiful fictional Isle of Inisherin and Keoghan(Dominic) delivering a intricate and brilliant performance as the town fool and abused son of the town's guard ,but most of the credit must go to Collin Farell's Pádraic. Farrell's performance and particularly his facial expressions letting us slightly into his exact silent contemplation in those moments regarding his situation is at times mesmerizing. There's a lot of McDonagh's witty, excellently crafted dialogue holding and guiding us through this tale, but the contradiction of the beautifuly shot backround of this picturesque Irish island and it's simple and lonely everyday lifestyle paired with the humourous dialogue balancing each other out is an uncomfortable joy to behold.

The movie is a roller coater of emotions. Starts off with being a intellectual comedy, then move to being serious, also has the social message that you cannot please everyone. There is tragicness and then finally suspense. Some movies try to make a comedy and fail at it miserably well as some such as this one, takes humour to a new level, indeed there is humour but after that no one could predict what was to come , its a great movie but perhaps could have preferred a happier ending. Thought that the movie will end on a happier note , though was hard to fathom how that could be brought about, still the movie is well worthy of your time and is sure to provide good entertainment. Definitely a gem.

reviews.review_title: A small film about how we hurt each other
reviews.content: And probably the greatest movie about depression, real depression, ever made. I don't use the term "real depression" to minimise anyone's experiences, rather to point out the fact that depression in movies is so often drinking too much, getting behind the wheel and screaming, fighting with your loved ones and screaming or drunkenly fighting a stranger (and screaming).Depression looks like a dramatic argument between Bradley Cooper and Jennifer Lawrence in these films, in an LA mansion, reaching its climax as J-Law wades into the mansion's swimming pool with a Lana Del Rey song playing, a far-away look in her eye, and still wearing her $20,000 ballgown. These are the tropes we recognise for mental health issues when used to move a plot forward but, on a human level, what does this kind of stuff really communicate to anyone beyond "sadness is temporary but here comes the happy ending"? And, be honest with your own experiences here, is any of that even true? Really, if you ask me, it reduces our ability to cope with the real, boring, day-to-day grind of sadness that can hang about like a bad, wet fart. It hurts to be in this place, and more for seeing that, in fact, the glamour and drama of these situations which we thought we'd recognise, we actually don't. The sad places we go alone are completely unfamiliar, unstructured and totally alienating. For us non-movie characters it's just ugly, dirty, unsanitary pain sometimes with no climax, apex or resolution and, if you're incredibly unlucky, no end. When was the last time you were rescued by a wise, benevolent old person of infinite wisdom who delivered in a few punchy sentences the exact re-evaluation you needed to bring your life forward? Not many times, I'd warrant, if ever. Perhaps it's because you're not sexy, or rich enough. Perhaps it's because you're dull.This is what I read into 'The Banshees of Inisherin'. In lieu of this wise old friend who aids you are more people who hurt you and in different ways. And what's more, these same people are people you might hurt, both of you without even realising it most of the time. Sometimes when we really need help it's not unusual at all to realise that we are fighting this fight completely alone, even if we are not alone in our lives. There may be people around you with their own problems who can't afford the time to spend with yours, or people with their own experiences and pains who do not understand yours at all. There may even be people who share your experiences and are hurting just like you, but are in too much pain to avoid hurting you and others around them.This is Martin McDonagh's great tragedy of the human condition with 'Banshees', when there's a world full of people who are spoiling to hurt others on purpose, we all sometimes end up in the same place as them, no matter how good we may try to be. Pain, however, is ubiquitous and unites us all.To quote the film: "From some things there's no moving on, and I think that's a good thing."

reviews.review_title: I really liked this movie, and it's okay that I don't know exactly why.
reviews.content: I watched this movie based on the positive reviews and literally nothing else. I had no idea what its premise was, or what it was about, and I think that it was for this exact reason that I enjoyed it so much.I finished the movie feeling, "What did I just watch? What was the meaning behind all of that?", and perhaps I'm just not enough of a cinephile to truly understand the nuances of the film, but I really don't care.The acting was superb - every one of the characters had their own lovable quirkiness and chemistry, and the dry Irish humour made me laugh inside on numerous occasions. The location was also fantastic. Aside from the acting, props should also be given to the writing and directing - I felt like I truly did watch a work of art.In the end I was left smiling inside, but also very sad. It made me feel like I think any good movie should make you feel.Go into this one with no preconceived ideas, and you should be pleasantly surprised.

A tragicomic poem, that's how I would describe this movie, a beautiful poem made of stunning landscapes, peculiar characters, eviscerated in all their simple complexities, and extravagant dialogues that even in their repetitiveness are never tiring and always sparkling.The simple and monotone existence of a small village in a remote Irish island is shaken by the sudden end of a lifelong friendship, a situation that escalates towards a dreadful and drastic aftermath.I loved every single character, from the town's fool to the evil policeman, from the innocent sister to the "twin" bartenders... and the perfection of Jenny the miniature donkey.Colin's and Brendan's characters are absolutely perfect, and to those who have seen In Bruges, Pádraig and Colm are the seamless evolution of Ray and Ken.Last but not least, the movie is made even more poetic by its title, completing its overall spirit made of legends, mystery and a sense of finality and, at the same time, of indefiniteness.

This film is just so good. I'm a big fan of Martin McDonagh anyway. Have loved all his movies but this is his best work. It is quirky,dark and funny. The cinematography is just stunning. The performances are just brilliant. Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson are wonderful as always but Barry Keoghan stole the limelight. His performance is stunning. The story is about 2 friends Padraic and Colm. Colm decides one day he doesn't want to be friends with Padraic again. And what follows is funny,sad and just mesmerizing. You are transported back to 1920s Ireland. And you can feel the frustrations of small Island life. Apart from Barry Keoghan,the other scene stealer was Jenny the donkey. Loved this movie and am planning on going back to the cinema to see it a couple more times before it leaves theaters.

... but not worth the rave reviews. I mean, what is the problem? A man getting tired of his long time friend. Yeah, that happens, often with no dramatic reasons, and I do not ask for an explanation like "14 years ago you slept with my wife you a**hole!". But it's is a bit of a problem in this film. OK so the old man is plain tired of the younger one. But then he cuts off his fingers? It's just strange and somehow stupid. It makes no sense. Sometimes it is also like a tourist office film for Ireland. I mean, it is stunning there, but I got enough of all the panoramic views of windy cliffs and green pastures... So for me this is a solid 7. Good acting.

reviews.review_title: Glad I watched it, you should too
reviews.content: Imagine you're a potato eating, miniature donkey loving, beer drinking Irishman. Then imagine you're not the brightest bulb in your village. That is the role Colin Farrell played in this movie, and he did great. I had no idea what to expect, I saw it was 8/10 at the time of watching and figured I'd give it a shot.Well I'm glad I did. It wasn't an epic storyline, but those are a bit boring at this point, let's actually think a bit wouldn't you say? This movie is about death, friends, and our ambitions, and how they sometimes conflict with each other. If you've lived in this world long enough you'll appreciate the subtle drama this movie presents.I won't give away the end, but it's understandable from an emotional perspective.

I always wondered; Is it a coincidence that the beautiful photography, the distinctive story, the poignant dialogue, the directing and the soundtrack all come together in one movie? Or is it story and dialogue that attract a good director, cameraman and musician? I don't really know the answer. While watching this movie, I sometimes laughed involuntarily, not at a joke in the movie or a comic scene, but sometimes the creative performance of the actors, the distinguished dialogue, or the exciting ideas made me laugh. In terms of the story, there is the unconventional idea, and there are the characters. Each character in the film is an independent world that can be a movie in itself. The photography made me feel at times that I was watching beautiful postal cards. The soundtrack sails you into a mystical world, and the directing is like a skilled weaver holding all threads are crafted to weave in the end a very beautiful piece. We need more of this cinematic beauty to quench our endless thirst.

This is not a bittersweet comedy but more psychological drama...it is a good movie, beautiful, the island depected in the movie makes for gorgeous sites where the action take place. The story is slowly developed, a little like the life on this island then, we get quickly now living there is like living in a fishbowl, where small simple pleasure take an importance beyond our existence...Colin Farrell is great and believable in his character...but I had difficulty believing in the character of Brendan Gleeson in the later part of the movie...still a day later after having seen it ..this movie leave me with a bitterness feeling but I think it helps me understanding part of the irish psych, history and written culture.

reviews.review_title: Every minute of the movie is beautiful
reviews.content: Great dark comedy. Beautiful acting, amazing scenes . Powerful absurdity . And great storytelling.Desperate times in Ireland, hopes destroyed, poverty , relations with church , nature and animals . All told in a great cinematography with wonderful music and atmosphere.I enjoyed the movie with my son ( i am 60 he is 22) a lot . For my opinion the movie is as good as In Brugges maybe better. Even after finishing the movie we both were still emotionally bound . Heartbreaking, funny and entertaining in all aspects. The law raters surely missed the point , the movie is simply brillant and beautiful!

reviews.review_title: As a nice good lad I felt this!
reviews.content: You get what you expect from the director! Comedy mixed with bleak dark tragedy, and wonderfully mixed to that! A simple plot and premise, no complications or plot twists. Just a story about two friends not being friends any-more. But that is the sign of great movie-making and trusting your audience!The story is intentionally slow-moving but the random scenes of village people crossing paths with each-other and holding absurd dialogues about trivial issues is what builds the plot up, leading to a endng where all tension meet up!But beyond all the weirdness there is actually a very human story and that is the greatness of it all. It has something to tell about male friendship, lonelyness, depression and existence! Who are we really? What do people think of us! Is this really what life is about? All served with a big dose of warmth and humanity!

reviews.review_title: A film that made me feel ways I didn't expect
reviews.content: To be honest, I had this film on my 'to see' list from the moment I watched the trailer but for some reason I kept putting off watching it.Luckily I finally did and boy, I wasn't prepared for the feelings this movie made me expierence. I genuinely laught quite a bit and every time I didn't see it coming. This could well be the funniest movie I have seen this year!Besides the humor I cried like a baby in a certain scene. Imagine, me a full grown 28 year old man that could hold his tears in movies like the notebook and the green mile wept while watching this scene.There was a mysterious factor to it. A kind of cloak of double meaning.Finally, the acting was truly amazing. This could very well be one of collin farrel's best performance yet. Barry Keoghan knocked it out of the park for me! Brendan Gleeson and Kerry Condon amazed me as well.A must see!

The Banshees of Inisherin is beautifully shot and superbly acted. This film is apparently an allegory for the civil war in Ireland, which is running through the background the whole time. Once you understand that, it makes so much more sense. I didn't know that when I watched it, so I searched for articles about it afterwards to try and make it make sense, and I found an article on Vox dot com which explained it well. Once I read that and understood, I was able to appreciate the story and not just the scenery and acting. I'd love to read more about what the writer intended. I definitely recommend watching once you understand that.

I have not seen any other films by Martin McDonagh so I have nothing much to compare this film to. All I can say is that its an excellently-shot, well-written and brilliantly-acted film.The dialogue in this film is excellent. The film brilliantly strikes a balance between comedic and serious. Conversations between characters are always insightful and the comedy is used to great effect to make the audience care about the characters. The leading performances by Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell are top-tier. Absolutely excellent. Farrell truly shines in this film, injecting his character with subtle emotion and charisma and he excellently illustrates his character's mental decline. Barry Keoghan was also a standout, mainly serving as a more cheery, upbeat character with a dark background of abuse.This film is quite bleak and depressing. While the film is incredibly colourful and wonderfully shot, the story only gets more depressing as it goes on. This is elevated by the score which really emphasises the importance of less is more. By the end of the film, the viewer is left with nothing which works for and against the film since you're left with a feeling of wasted time. Yet this is the situation the characters find themselves in and it is up to the audience's interpretation about what the film is trying to say.Overall, The Banshees of Inisherin is not going to make you feel good by the end but it is going to give you a lot to think about. The acting, writing, directing and score are all excellent. This film will either profoundly affect you or disappoint you but you cannot deny where it succeeds with flying colours.

One you have to be in a mood for, luckily I was and thus found it to be beautiful but heartbreaking. Overall the movie had a very eerie atmosphere which I tend to like and the mix between comedy and dreary atmosphere was rewarding. Characters were extremely well performed by the main actors but it would be silly not to mention other actors, they were all very good. It's one of those movies that will leave you a little bit empty at the end. Some would consider this a criticism, I personally think it's brave writing. We always seek happy endings because they leave us with that full belly satisfaction but unfortunately life isn't that. Life is much more nuanced and grey. There were some things I wanted out of this movie that didn't manifest but overall it was a worthy experience.

reviews.review_title: One Small Flaw in this Masterpiece
reviews.content: I won't attempt to gild the lily. This is a masterpiece of a film that I didn't want to end, so engrossed was I in the island, the people, the time.But as a native Irishman, I have a couple of small quibbles with the dialogue in places."He doesn't like you no more". That isn't how Irish people would say it. A south Londoner (like the great Martin McDonagh) might use that expression, but in Ireland....."He doesn't like you ANYmore" - now we're talkin'."Maybe he's just depressed". Depression is not something you'd hear much about in the rural Ireland of 2022, let alone 1922! What we'd tend to say is "He isn't himself" or "He's bad with his nerves" or "He's taken to his bed".Not major faults by any means, just moments when the authenticity wavered slightly.

reviews.review_title: A masterclass of how funny quiet Irish dread can be
reviews.content: The film is a mastery of quiet dread. The slow burn of the film is so different from the onslaught of big budget franchises and extended universes. We as the audience are lead into this isolated lifestyle and are forced to watch as people walk everywhere, wait to hear the news, and only listen to live music played at the local pub.I was drawn into the world, but it was the people I watched that really broke my heart. The bare bones dialogue does not rely on sophisticated syntax or devices foreign to these people, but shows brutal reality of arguing with you best friend, sister, or abuser. I make this sound all tragic, but this same bare dialogue made me laugh out loud at their clever comebacks. The banter that happens in pubs is its own love language which is captured beautifully by the film.By the end of the film, after all that happens on this island, there is coldness. When I finished the film I had yet to see any of the aforementioned Banshees, but I witnessed how pride and anger can destroy joy. And that is just as terrifying as any herald of death.

Martin McDonough rarely disappoints whether working on stage or on film. His quirkiness is on display again. If you are familiar with his work, take him for his words here! The film is brilliantly acted across the board. Gleason and Farrell make a great pair. The film is funny, sweet, and heartbreaking- the kind of film that rarely surfaces today. It does not move like a bat out of hell ; it is leisurely paced, but it never feels slow.Gleason has a terrific speech about the ways people are remembered years after they're gone, but this is topped by Farrell's simple, beautiful response. Gorgeous writing. Wonderful acting. Simply, put a stellar film.

I have rated it a 7 , it floats between a 6.5 and a 7 for me . The cinematography was excellent and it was shot brilliantly but I cannot fathom how it has such a high score from the critics. The story was peculiar but enjoyable but the ending just left me wondering is that all ? The acting was top class from Brendan Colin and Barry but the plot ended leaving a empty void and personally I feel a film should tell a story not 3/4 of a story . But the cinematography was *chefs kiss* and that's probably a factor in many critics ratings.If your looking for a humble civilians rating it's worth a watch for movie lovers but anyone looking for a riveting viewing should look elsewhere. A 6.8 for me solely based on acting and cinematography.Jack wood a humble civilian.

...and never mind the location setting, the time frame, the conflict. These are two of the greatest English Language actors active today. Instead of charging for tickets, they oughta bill the audience for the master class in the Dramatic Arts being put on here. Reunited with their "In Bruges" director, the story unfolds slow and steady.Then things get decidedly weird.Violence flares, and escalates, and the piece ends with no promise of resolution, no easy answers. An essay on the Irish character in the early days of the struggle? A study of dementia and depression in an isolated community? Above my pay grade.Thoughtful, quiet and deeply disturbing, and highly recommended.

Something charming about characters who are so blunt and straightforward about what they think.Seemingly a straight-forward story of the disintegration of a friendship raises thought-provoking themes of how and what we value and prioritise as individuals and how that impacts on those around us, how life experiences change us and can often beat the humaneness out of us, how powerless we often are to change and influence others, how significant disagreements can come from small misunderstandings and our inability to accept what is.Beautiful scenery and cinematography, well rounded cast of characters, well acted.

I finally saw this last night and I'm so impressed! I can't find fault, really! The script, acting, editing and direction are all absolutely brilliant!I'm specially impressed with Barry Keoghan & Kerry Condon; and I'm sure Colin Farrell it's going to get the Oscar this year.Saying all of this, it's not a film for everyone. The film it's highly political, even if never mentiins politics. It is about "The Troubles", and about all it's contradictions. About friends falling out not even knowing why.It's dark, but also funny at times; violent but very sweet; beautifully shot but turns very ugly; it's about love vs hate; about simple people with complex and contradictory feelings.I don't know if it's going to win any Baftas or Oscars and who cares? It's a cinematographic triumph and an instant classic, that's what it is!

I just watched the Banshees of Inisherin. It was billed as a dark comedy. More accurately, it's a tale of agony, despair and self loathing. Being Irish, I thought it was great!Colin, Kerry and Brendon did a wonderful job capturing my imagination. Great photography as well.Though it seems to be austere and filmed on a relatively small budget, that isn't the case at all. A lot of creativity seems to have gone into making it look that way. I read that the pub (Devine's) was built just for the movie, and then disassembled afterwards so as not to spoil the local environment. You wouldn't know that the building was temporary by looking at it.

A dark comedy that perfectly balances out visceral human components with a grounded and, simultaneously, obscure story. The major themes of legacy, kindness, fulfillment, jealousy, resentment are all handled with a certain melancholic precision, that can only be followed through with two masterful actors, such as Farrell and Gleeson. The loneliness felt by many characters is palpable and the tension between the two protagonists, which starts as confusion and evolves into spite, builds with every passing encounter. In addition, the cinematography is beautifully captured, the writing is excellent, and the supporting cast, (Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan especially) do as well a job as the masterclass leads. And like many friendships, the film begins with a bright rainbow and ends with a dark raincloud; whether that's to show the cycle of nature or the dreary transpiring of events is up to the audience to decide. A-

Gorgeous locations. Fitting soundtrack. Impeccable acting. And ultimately the lack of a good conclusion negates all of this.From the very start the viewer can sympathise with and understand all characters. They are all relatable.Padraic is indeed a somewhat dull, ordinary but kind man who can't let go of the fact that his lifelong friend has begun to ignore him. This completely unfolds Padraic's small world and he is desperately trying to rebuild the friendship, but fails to understand Colm's reasons.Colm, on the other hand, is intelligent and reserved. He obviously understands that his friend is affected by what happens, but decides to proceed with his (likely futile) ambition to be remembered with works of music. At first he tries to completely ignore Padraic, hoping the latter will simply distance himself too; when that doesn't happen, he resorts to far more drastic measures, which ultimately prove both useless and devastating to his musical aspirations.When things escalate as much as they did within the story, a sensible outcome would have been to have a conclusion - reconciliation, violent/peaceful ending or whatever. Instead, we're left hanging with the assumption that this will continue. But to what end?
