The characters were excellent and the viewer could sympathise with both; the lack of closure simply ruined the rest of the story for me, leaving their actions up to that point ambiguous, and the story futile.

A truly great film - and yet, I'm not sure I can recommend it.The setup is simple: a man's friend tells him that they aren't going to be friends anymore. But it's so much more than that. Martin McDonagh is one of the best writers of his generation (or any generation); he's able to take what could've been just a silly throwaway story and turn it into something truly magical. His ability to craft language that can be both hilarious and heartbreaking is unparalleled.Combining McDonagh's brilliant writing with two great actors - Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell - is a winning combination, which we've seen before with In Bruges. In Bruges may be slightly funnier, but this is a rich film with depth and character. This movie should win every award.But - I'm not sure I can recommend it. It's brilliant, yes; but it's also truly sad and depressing in a way that very few films are (and for good reason). Someone else put it something like this: McDonagh's previous film had cancer, rape, murder, suicide, police brutality, and racism, and that was a Hallmark movie compared to Banshees.I'd only suggest watching it if you're up for a good laugh and a good cry. It's brilliant, but so, so sad.

reviews.review_title: Less so comedic, more so emotional
reviews.content: Ever since I first saw 'In Bruge' after picking it up randomly at a Blockbuster discounted DVD sale not knowing what I was really getting into, I have been a huge fan of Martin McDonagh. What I've learned from watching his movies is you never know what you're going to get (except that you know that you're getting quality). For all of the people saying that they laughed out loud at this movie, they're lying. Sure there is some funny dialogue, but what the movie knocks you on the floor with is emotion. Every performance is just superb, especially Colin Farrell and Barry Keoghan. I found myself tearing up at different points of the movie without an obvious reason why, except for the overwhelming emotion that the characters command in such subtle ways.

Something is happening on the island of Inisheran; something beyond the islanders control. Is it the legendary Banshees at work or are they just the messengers? They predict there will be one or two deaths on the island and the movie becomes a waiting game of who will it be? Brendan Gleason's character is struggling with a despair so profound he abandons his best friend (Colin Farrell) and is willing to sacrifice (by way of self-mutilation) the one thing that brings him joy - making music. He has a song inside him, a mournful dirge, that must come out, and he can't afford any distractions. As hard as he tries to find comfort and support from classic Irish institutions: the pub and the church, no one can help him. Even his stubborn, kindly, best friend who just won't take no for an answer, drives him to desperate acts.Then there are 2 supporting characters, one who escapes the tragedy unfolding before them and another who doesn't. Are we surprised by the outcome? Not really. Once the Banshee's prediction comes true the spell is broken.So what works? What doesn't work? We all wanted to see that great chemistry Farrell and Gleason had in "In Bruges" but instead we see a friendship dismantled before we believe it exists. Does the director take advantage of the audience's expectation that these two are, in fact, friends, and therefore believe how hurt one would be if that friendship ended? Gleason is so miserable throughout the film it's hard to feel a connection.Farrell's true friends, the animals, are there for him. That we believe. It's a shame it's played for laughs and that when he needs them most he stops communicating with them. The rest of the world is the opposite. When humans let us down we turn to our critters.A real let down: The song causing everyone grief, isn't memorable and not particularly original.The Banshees, dotting the island like pale Mother Theresa's, don't fit. They're not real enough or other-worldly enough to make sense.Lastly, I hate to be picky, but donkeys don't choke on a bit of food in their mouth. It gets stuck way down their esophagus which is separate from their trachea. Would a donkey even be tempted to eat a finger? Even if he bit it off? No, highly unlikely. Wouldn't be an issue if so much wasn't riding on this incident. And even a mini donkey weighs a few hundred pounds and Farrell moves it around like a teddy bear.The film doesn't resolve in a satisfying way and doesn't encourage a rewatch like "In Bruges". One viewing is more than enough.

I watched this film cold after not having read anything about it, and I have to say it's beautifully acted and I loved the depth of the characters.I went through all the emotions watching the characters go on a downward spiral on just one decision, laughter, anger, despair and upset. To watch that one decision pull apart the fabric of community and friendship was heart wrenching, all set in a stark and bleak but beautiful backdrop of West Coast Ireland. For me personally, I love observing human nature and people, and this film documents how far people can be pushed before they snap.I'm going to think about this film for a long time, tragic and brilliant.

An interesting watch, though the trailer and plot might make it seem run-of-the-mill. What seems like a trivial feud between two friends, turns into something much more serious and poignant.It's strange how much pain we hide from the world and create fantasies in our minds, making us victims of our own doing.Inisherin, a fictional place, represents any unassuming, sleepy village with the local pub being the only place where everyone congregates. What do you do when one of your only friends stops talking to you for no fault of your own? Well, I would probably stop being friends with the person. That's the sensible thing to do.Pádraic (Colin Farrell), being a simple man, does not know how to say goodbye to his friend. And this movie is about the consequences of the rift between him and his friend.Look out for the understated Banshee. It's amusing how Martin McDonagh skilfully made her presence known.As Pádraic states at the end of the movie, "Some things there's no moving on from. And I think that's a good thing."

reviews.review_title: If you don't like it, you simply don't get it.
reviews.content: I wasn't sure what to expect, my partner saw this and said it was excellent but the way he described the plot it seemed like a dark comedy and little else. Watched it yesterday and didn't expect such a strong emotional response. I suppose being Irish, this film hits hard differently and in unexpected ways. There's so many societal factors that feature heavily in this, a lot of them we still perpetuate even though they cause us and the ones close to us harm. The heartbreaking and gradual realisation that Farrell's character simply cared more about not being liked or wanted by his long term friend than by what his friend needed to be happy hit home. The care Gleesons character still had for him was evident by defending him against the Garda of the island, but by that point it was too late for Farrell's character to recognise that his friend did care for him, he just didn't want him in his life any longer. The sisters heartbreaking loneliness, desire to be liked and accepted by her community and her tremendously brave decision to leave to carve her own life rather than stay in a familiar place hit very close to home. I'm not the most articulate, and feel so especially in tying to describe what makes this film so special. I can only commiserate for those who view it as a dark comedy and little else.

reviews.review_title: You will not feel happy post script
reviews.content: I won't deny near everything from a character perspective the actors who portrayed them and a well done mix of humor, drama, dread, however the story has so few highs, everything feels low. I don't need a happy ending, but I enjoy an arc and there was not a huge one here. I just felt this movie was set out and designed solely to leave the audience with General sense of dismay and malaise. What is a mix of enjoyable and confusing is the fact there seems to be no true protagonist or antagonist, the entire cast never appeared to find their path.That said, EVERYTHING and every other aspect aside from story were well done and I NEED A PONY!!

Why did Colm suddenly reject his friend ? I think he was in love with him and in the social setting he just couldn't handle it. This gay subtext is not made explicit at all. In fact I don't know if the writer was conscious of it himself. But I felt it it made sense and it is the only reason I can think of to explain Colm's odd behavior. If it wasn't a gay tragedy at all then I just don't get it and it becomes a failure to me. I did enjoy the setting which reminds me of the brilliant J M Synge's Playboy of the Western World filmed in the 60s in an almost identical location. Just wish this one was a gay tragedy. Then I would love it.

It was a great movie, which I enjoyed watching, but it was very dark at times. I'd think it's the kind of movie you wouldn't want to see if you were depressed. To me, it was like a stereotyped Irish wedding, in that I was there for a good time, there was lots of laughs, some moments that made me want to cry, and I felt like I needed a good drink afterwards. Colin Farrell & Brendan Gleeson were great, but Kerry Condon was excellent in support, as was Shelia Flitton, as Mrs McCormack. I'm thinking that she is the Banshee of Inisherin, with her sage commentary of what she sees in the town. I would expect this to win some awards in the coming year.

"The Banshees of Inisherin" is a stage-like character drama and allegory built upon its setting and a MacGuffin. That MacGuffin might be unsatisfying for some, but every character is magnetic and sympathetic even when their actions can shift from realistic to allegorical. They keep you invested and even laughing despite the pervading themes of loneliness, despair, civil war, and isolation on the small island of Inisherin. The obvious parallel is to the Irish civil war in the background, but what each character represents has plenty of room for consideration. At the worst of times (which are few) "Banshees" can feel self-important, but the highs will have you fully invested. The confluence is a theatrical drama that keeps you entranced and leaves you with plenty to think about.

A person suddenly asks his friend to stop talking to him and gives him a dire ultimatum if he ever tries to do so!! A plot that intrigued me so much so that I decided to watch the movie.I somehow liked the name too! Maybe it's just the multiple "sh"'s which make it sound nice, like Colm would say!It wasn't a comedy all the way, the genre you think it is when you start watching the movie.Set at the time of the Irish Civil war, this movie offers a perspective on the repercussions of the war on the people living on the island of Isherin. It's an irony as the island's far off from the actual war grounds, yet the war acts like a Banshee of Isherin, heralding death. Listening to the war shots while leading their daily life, causes distress and paranoia amongst the people of Isherin, which eventually takes it's toll!"With the fear of unknown, the paranoia of time running out, what would you do?" A question that is handled by the 4 main characters in their own unique way!Like the ocean in the backdrop, the movie runs wide and deep. It takes you places! For me, it probably took me to the ocean, somewhere deep underwater where it was really dark, at times I was on the surface with the shining waters, at times the water stung my eyes, then I saw the sun, sometimes I was washed over by the waves, at times I felt calm when the water was still.To leave a viewer with such magnitude of emotions is a definite sign of a great film and a brilliant filmmaker! The actors were excellent, the screenplay was brilliant, backed up by some great music and stunning cinematography! Colin Farrell was absolutely top notch, so was all the supporting cast!A beautiful film, one that I will probably never forget!

An amazing performance from Colin Farrell. Beautiful shots of Ireland. It is set in a completely different time and place from my own experience so I didn't understand the logic of some of the characters actions. The film makes you think, and not in a comfortable way!I enjoyed all the performances, the scenic sweeps, the period detail, the language. Initially I found the story incredible, but then I reflected, what could be more incredible and bizarre than the two years this world has just lived through: witnessing mental illness, fidelity, broken relationships, isolation and loss, all major themes of this film.

reviews.review_title: An allegory is not a story, but actual character journeys are.
reviews.content: The whole movie is just an allegory for the ongoing Irish conflict. While that's a good idea for a short allegory, you can't base complex characters in a 2 hour movie solely around an allegory. This unnatural aspect is why the characters felt fake the whole time.Movies can be disturbing at times, yes. But setting a town up that doesn't take care of a longtime resident committing self-harm is just ludicrous. Everybody knows he's lobbing off fingers, but don't properly intervene. Yes, this is an allegory for actions from extremists, but this isn't how you write a character. Viewers shouldn't have to research your movie to make sense of the characters.

The genius of Martin McDonagh is displayed once again in Banshees of Inisherin only that this time he takes it one step further and he presents us with his best picture to date.With the help of amazing talent like Colin Farrel and Brendan Gleeson, Banshees of a Inisherin will make you laugh and cry within the first hour and it will leave a long-lasting, indescribable feeling by the end of the second. A simple but powerful film that uses it's beautiful setting perfectly in conjunction with the script and uses it's calming soundtrack flawlessly with its meticulous cinematography.Touching upon subjects like hope, belonging, depression and conflict, This thought-provoking tragicomedy will resonate with anybody who's willing to contemplate its real meaning. A rare film that will not only keep you entertained but will also make you reflect long after you leave the theater. This is most certainly a must watch!

I cried so much with this movie. I loved that it has a really simple narration and storyline, but still manages to connect with you and make you reflect about deep subjects such as life, purpose, loneliness, friendship and crisis. The imagery is incredible. Also, Colin farrels' character is so well developed. The whole movie is a big metaphor about life. It also has a really unique story, with its dark humor which I liked. When I read the sinopsis of the movie I didn't expect this masterpiece; I was intrigued by the acting due to its oscar's nominations but it was a great surprise. Will think about this movie a lot these following weeks, Im sure!

Sometimes it's nice to see a film like this where you can sit back and watch what unfolds. The people who give this a 1 to 6 out of ten simply do not understand film. More films like this should be made, original films. I think people expect all these giant blockbuster movies nowadays and forget what true film is.I loved seeing Colin Farrell and Brendon Gleeson in 'In Bruges' and this film definitely didn't disappoint. The cinematography was beautiful, the acting was incredible and the whole feel of the film was just relaxing even if the plot didn't seem it at times in the final third.This film is a great example of a dark comedy, one that you can watch multiple times and not get bored because every scene is either meaningful or entertaining. I can just listen to the characters talk all day.

The Banshees of Insherin is a beautiful master piece, overwhelmed with emotion and drive.This film is so simple and yet it has more layers than these giant visual effects money makers. To kick it off the scenery is beautiful. It really shows you the beauty of Ireland. Everything is filmed incredibly well and it feels like you're one of the locals in the village.Two friends have an impasse when one decides to end their relationship.That is it. Thats it! But it works so well and Martin Mcdougnah is incredibly skilled to have been able to adapt such a simple sentence into an amazing spectacle. I have to say I enjoyed watching every minute of this film.Colin Farrell plays the sweet Padric who is the nicest guy in the village. Every minute he is on screen your behind him all the way. He is really funny as well even though he is intending not to be. I really do think this is Colins best performance and he really does shine.Brendan Gleeson plays the depressed Colm (maybe a bit psychopathic ) who abrubtly ends his friendship with Colin because he simply doesn't like him. I have to admit they both act like children but it works so well. Brendan is amazing as always and shows perfectly is characters emotion.The story is incredible and deeply moving. It's a large bowl of humor and wit chucked into a pot of emotion and judgement and then served with a glass full of tragedy. I think Colin Farrell deserves every award he gets. Same with Brendan.Directors and writers alike should learn from The Banshees of Insherin that you don't need giant spectacles or big plot twists to make a good film.You just need Colin Farrell:)

There are no banshees in Inisherin, says one of the principal characters. But then as a viewer you do feel there is one metaphorically howling silently in the air of this dark comedy, portending dread and death. If you're looking for another In Bruges or Three Billboards from the talented Martin McDonagh you are in for a darker surprise.The story is set on an idyllic island in Ireland during their civil war time (1920's) but the populace is seemingly unaffected by it except for a sporadic reference in the local pub or when a bomb goes off on the mainland.The story is of two long time friends that sets off when the older of the two, Colm (Brendan Gleeson) abruptly announces to the other Padraic (Colin Farrell) that he longer wishes to speak with him and any attempts to do so by Padraic will be met by some dire, irreparable actions on Colm's part. Padraic being nice and all, doesn't believe his buddy so tries to play the threat down while brooding over why Colm decided to be so. At one point in the narrative he realises it is no longer a bluff but Colm is serious about what he said. In the midst of these bizarre developments we have townspeople who are equally baffled including Padraic's sister Siobhan (Kerry Condon), Dominic (Barry Keoghan) who try their best to adapt to the situation, while dealing with their own personal issues.The explanation when demanded given by Colm to Padraic isn't very plausible so he continues the pursuit of making the relationship work and the emanating actions thereafter become even more darker. The genuine efforts put forward by Padraic to mend the situation are only met with Colm "truly" honouring his dire promises to his and everyone's aghastness.The behaviour of the lead characters definitely requires some 21st century psychiatric treatment but this being set in 1920's on a remote island amidst conflict doesn't allow a psych intervention, but one of the lead characters in an exasperated state does call the actions taken by the other qualifies to be called mental. Without giving too much away the story veers onto unexpected (and sometimes inexplicable) roads with some tragic developments. Gleeson and Farrell are brilliant as usual, getting into the skin of their characters and are brilliantly supported by Condon and Keoghan.The climax though, can be unfulfilling if one is expecting a neat tie-off of the events that have unfolded during the course of the narration.

reviews.review_title: Two sides of the same coin
reviews.content: The reunion not only of the duo, but of the trio that did something magical in In Bruges, returning a decade and a half later not to recreate a previous experience but to transport us to another setting, another relationship.While Collin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson's characters started off physically and emotionally distant in the previous work, here in Banshees they start from the ordinary and become different, faces of the same coin, but who can no longer see each other as equals.They begin to hate what is different about them and fail to recognise what brought them together, the essence of their friendship.In a masterly way, McDonagh directs the film permeating the theme of the Irish Civil War, without ever making superficial the conflict that split families, separated couples and destroyed homes, but also does not diminish the core of the problem between two soul brothers. In a mix of depression and nihilism, we see the desperation of one side wanting at all costs to get away, focusing on marking its name in history, while the other tries to enjoy every minute of its day, in the most banal and everyday way.Reflections of their animals, the Donkey and the Dog, victims and partners of this petty human conflict, full of pride, ego and ignorance, while a small town living on a coastal island, shouts together without ever listening to what their fellow human beings are saying on their side. If only the animal-like silence were used for reflection, it would exist for even a minute...

reviews.review_title: Everything you need for a great movie but I did not care for the allegorical story line
reviews.content: I was so excited when I began watching this. Tremendous cast. Brendan Gleeson, Colin Farrell. Kerry Condon. And then the setting. A remote island off of the mainland of Ireland. This movie drips with Irishness. And then the story begins. Colm (Gleeson) and Pádraic (Farrell) are longtime friends when suddenly Colm decides he wants no part of his friend. He does not give much reason other than he is old and hopes to make some lasting musical legacy with his remaining years. He feels spending time with the kind but dim witted Pádraic will only slow him. Pádraic of course does not like this at all and refuses to honor his friend's request to stop speaking to him (even though are in the same pub together every day). Eventually Colm ups the stakes and says he will cut off his own fingers if Pádraic won't leave him alone. All in all this makes for a somewhat dreary film. It is taking place during the Irish Civil War of 1923. This Civil War was over the acceptance of the treaty of independence with England. Clearly the relationship between Colm and Pádraic, where they are destroying each other and themselves, serves as an allegory for the Irish Civil War. I would just greatly prefer a story based on some kind of realistic relationships rather than a metaphor. The incredible cast, setting and genuine window into the Irish culture probably still make it worth watching.

The Banshees of Inisherin stars Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan, and is directed by Martin McDonagh
Set during the Irish Civil War in 1923 on a remote island in Ireland, it's the story of two long time friends, wherein one of them, Colm, played by Brendan Gleeson, decides he's not interested in being friends with the other, Padraic, played by Colin Farrell. On such a remote community, gossip spreads like wildfire, and the island residents all deal with this falling out between two men differently. It affects Padraic's sister, played by Kerry Condon, the town "fool", Dominic, played by Barry Keoghan, his abusive cop father, played by Gary Lydon, a mysterious old woman, Mrs McCormick, played by Sheila Flitton, and more throughout the town.This is a movie that upon reviewing it, you want to talk about what happens, and really go into it video essay-style, where you might spoil it, assuming your viewership has already seen the film. But I also want to talk about the themes and feelings it gives you without literalising it, and try and get down to why it's so good, and so heartbreaking, even though all of its central characters are as simple as can be, their lifestyles uneventful, their generation and background vastly different from mine, their environment sleepy and quiet (minus the distant bombing going on as part of the Irish Civil War, which is parallel in a way with what's happening between Colm and Padraic).It's almost like a macabre Irish folk tale, or fairytale even, that could be passed down and shown to different generations to come as an example of the dark side of friendship. The odd thing is however, it came out in 2022, rather than hundreds or even thousands of years ago. Yet it's an entirely original film, not based on a previous text, or classical piece of literature. It also feels modern and relevant, because close friendship is something we can all relate to and understand. Maybe it's McDonagh's background as a playwright, and writing theatre that this film has that classical tale vibe to it.You could almost decipher this movie as an exploration on a cycle of revenge. Once one act of the macabre is committed against another, is it possible to ever go back to the status quo? From that point on, is it an endless cycle of retaliation? Acts of revenge committed against acts of revenge.This film is bitingly hilarious, often due to the chemistry between Farrell and Gleeson, established wonderfully in In Bruges. Overall this could be better reviewed by really spoiling it and going through events, details and character motivations thoroughly, and I've chosen not to do that in this review, as it's one where I think the best way to watch it is to know as absolutely little as possible. Which puts me in a tricky position really. But go see The Banshees of Inisherin, it's a hilarious dark comedy, it's macabre, it tackles themes of loneliness, isolation, even self-mutilation, in an emotionally brutal way. So trigger warning for all of those things. It will rip your heart out, but it's an amazing piece of "feel bad cinema".

First off the movie is beautiful to watch, great photography and beautiful settings. The acting is suburb. Story wise its kind of a head scratcher.Two long time friends have a falling out. Evidently one now finds the other dull and simply wants nothing to do with him. I found this a bit strange, and never really explained to any level of satisfaction, but he wants nothing to do with his former friend. So the friend can not accept this and continues to approach him, which evidently inspired the former friend to threaten him with cutting of his own finger every time he comes to him. Once again this is a tad peculiar, but the friend ignores this and keep coming and the other friend starts cutting off fingers to spite him. I think the only place this sort of behavior exists is in a mental hospital, but went along with it in hopes that it would lead to a dramatic and satisfying conclusion. Sadly this movie lumbers along, a few other quirky characters show up and do quirky things, and ultimately the 'nice' friend--the one who refuses to leave the finger chopper alone--learns that his beloved donkey died while eating one of the finger choppers cut off fingers. Just a FYI donkeys are herbavors and don't eat meat so this wouldn't have happened, but again ignoring this also now the nice guy friend is determined to kill his former friend for getting his donkey killed so he tries to burn down finger choppers house. All that this leads to is a house burned down and the now feuding friends to evidently continue their feud. The ending is pretty abrupt, no dramatic conclusion to conflict, just more of a "no country for old men" weird ending where nothing is resolved and I realized I just spend some two hours waiting for a conclusion to a movie and finding nothing. Very unsatisfying. So acting is wonderful, Colin Farrell and Brandon Gleeson are great, scenery is beautiful, but actual story wasn't worth their efforts.

The acting is superb, the story puzzling, the scenery immersive. This Irish tale is captivating, Perhaps like it's name, a Banshee. That being said, at the risk of sounding like a Hollywood brainwashed consumer I wished for a more satisfying end of the film. It's an odd tale, that in my opinion would benefit greatly by even a sconse attempt at to it's aim or meaning. To me that what separates this film from being timeless, instead of excellent. The longing. It lingers throughout the film and lingers still. Is that the point? This longing to understand? If that is the case I am saddened by this artistic choice. Only a mere hint as to WHY, would have, in my humble opinion, been a welcomed revelation no matter how forelonged. Still it cannot be denied this is a captivating film in terms of performance, dialogue, location, and direction.

reviews.review_title: Watch it. embrace it and reflect it.
reviews.content: Poignant, wonderful narrative of two souls at a crossroads in their life. Both are correct in their own way, but they want quite different things. It's a simple and lovely way of demonstrating how you may grow together, be together for years, and still fall apart. The film makes you think about your life, your surroundings, and the people around you. It might be frightening at times to recognise what you want from your life going forward and what ties and connections you need to break in order to go on the rest of your life.The acting is Outstanding. Despite the dense Irish lingo, the talks are so real and basic that anyone from anywhere may relate to them. This is aimed at the more mature, older generation, someone who has lived through and experienced various stages of life and events.The film is set in a time before social media and dopamine, yet it speaks to a generation that is always looking to make a mark and leave a legacy.

(Update: If you can't appreciate this movie, do us all a favor and stop pretending like you understand a thing about cinema, cause you clearly are clueless)If you know Martin McDonagh then you are familiar with his plays, you know how he enjoys twisting facts and creating human conditions where right or wrong lose their meanings, McDonagh is one of the most important and Famous Writers of 21st Century and he never cease to amaze us with his dark comedies.Cripple of Inishmaan , The Lieutenant of Inishmore and The Banshees of Inisherin are the names of one of the MacDonagh's legendry Trilogies, and the Banshees? He never made that book published, said it was not any good at the time, I always wondered what kind of Dark messed up story he was hiding from us, that Book was the only Hidden piece he never shared with us, at the time I would have never imagined I end up watching it as a movie!I love how he is creating a new genre or one that's been missing from the cinemas for quite some time, this precisely feels like reading one of his plays, he is bringing theater into a live action movie in cinema, and I admire his work and I'm sure he will be remembered as a genius director that changed cinema just like how he changed theaters!Brilliant movie, amazing acting, lovely visuals!

Give them all of the Oscars. All of them. That's all. I'm having to write more words than is necessary for some unknown reason. Have you always had to do this? What a terrible waste of time. God do I need to elaborate more. This is a dark drama with moments of dry humour. It's cast perfectly, both leads deserve an Oscar as does both supporting actors (not the donkey - really struggling to flush this out, still 191 to go). Eh, what else. Set during the Irish civil war (thanks again England love your work). Every man lives a life of quiet desperation or something like this. This shows what the means. In all seriousness Barry keoghan is phenomenonal. Defo give him an Oscar aswell please. Again all of them. Except the witch.

Phenomenal performances from everyone in this movie. Reading some reviews I think it's one of those movies that just maybe you might have to be from at least the British Isles to truly appreciate it. The acting is nothing short of wonderful, sometimes looks and pauses mean more than words. It's funny, it's sad, it tugs at your heart and then bang you laugh again. The scene at the river is simply wonderful. It's not surprising to hear it got a fifteen minute standing ovation at Cannes, watch some of the interviews with the cast and the director, truly wonderful. I'll be buying this and watching again and again. Outstanding!!

The setting of the movie was beautiful, the cinematography knew how to capture the characters emotions and the mood of every situation. The story talks about loneliness and it's dangers. What it is like to feel like an outsider, almost every character in the movie tasted the bitterness of loneliness. Although in my opinion colm's wishes to be left alone were reasonable and should have been respected by the main character even though it was a harsh thing to hear. I didn't agree with most of the protagonist's choices, I think that he completely disregarded his friend's wishes even after he cut his own fingers off to show him how serious he is about the matter; the protagonist did not obey and only stopped persuading him after his donkey died after eating one of the friend's fingers (come to think of it, colm wouldn't have cut his fingers off in the first place if the protagonist respected his decision and didn't bother him). Brendan's acting was really good and Barry's acting was amazing. Cinematography: 8.5. Acting: 9. Screenplay:8.

I can't believe all the negative reviews. It's an amazingly unique story, with incredible acting and cinematography. Rightly nominated for so many accolades. I was expecting disappointment but it lived up to the hype. An excellent watch and a deserved 8/10..... I'm Irish so definitely biased. It's always great to see Irish acting and filmmaking getting attention. I think "My Left Foot" was the last Irish movie to get the same recognition, and it's on the same level.It's taken Colin Farrell 20 years of acting, and 10 years of sobriety for people to see how good an actor he actually is. There's more to come from him. Barry Keoghan is one of the brightest young actors in Hollywood. Kerrie Condon and Brendan Gleason superb as usual.

If I take off my rational-thinker cap and just consider the acting, the eerie but beautiful pastoral backdrop, and the artful cinematography, there is a lot to appreciate here. The issue I have is the struggle to understand the reasons behind any of the characters' actions and the overall nonchalance of the townspeople with the horrifying events that take place during the film (all done in a dark comedy fashion). Clearly the civil war looms in the background but it's never clear (at least to me) what meaning we are meant to derive from it, as even the townsfolk don't seem to be bothered too much that it's happening. My husband and I watched this film and we both had plenty of giggles throughout as the main characters plod through the plot with funny little witticisms in their charming Irish lilts, but the overarching story was incredibly unpleasant and the ending was frustrating. Barry Keoghan (Dominic), Kerry Condon, and a miniature donkey named Jenny stole the show. I would have rather seen a larger story about the island or town than this sordid tale about untreated mental illness.

reviews.review_title: Intermittently nice and not nice, but never dull
reviews.content: Laugh, cry, squirm a little, it is all just part of being human. A brutally honest romp, which dares to dance with the unpleasant, yet hilarious awkwardness in begging the question "why can't people just be nice?" The Banshees of Inisherin made me want to cry because it made me realize how long it has been since I have seen an actual film. One with compelling performances, especially by Colin Farrell and Barry Keoghan, and a captivating story with no hint of an agenda outside of wanting to feed one's soul. Whether or not it rightfully sweeps the Oscars, this McDonagh masterpiece is an utter triumph.Grade: A-

I loved this. Such a simple film yet it had strong connections, great acting and real tensions.Rural Ireland in the 1920's was a land of gossip and talking about the neighbours, in know this because of my ancestry. In a small world with no TV or electricity family is all, friends are important and news travels by talk.How stories escalate may have parallels to social media, where the world has become small and full of gossip.The relationship between the two main characters is powerful, perfectly acted, surely there will be Oscars in this,This is my favourite film of 2022. I hope you enjoy too!

The Banshees of Inisherin" is a triumph of filmmaking that is not to be missed. Collin Farrell at its best, not to mention the absolute chemistry that he has with Brendan Gleeson, Barry Keoghan and the rest of the cast add to the already stunning cinematography.With a not so expected storyline the movie ends up mixing a dark sense of humor with a gut wrenching friend feud that seems childish but is the perfect backdrop of war, and the way that Martin McDonagh subtly blends the macro with the micro is just brilliant.Oscar worthy for movie, director, actor, original script. It's a must watch.

reviews.review_title: "Let's make a movie based on the (bankable) chemistry between Colin and Brendan"
reviews.content: "I have just the vehicle, not much of a story but the Irish American market will love this - I'm thinking Oscars"I mean c'mon, the very title itself "The Banshees of Inisherin" is a marketing ploy,if not downright disingenous. Don't get me going on the plot - "Talented musician resorts to chopping fingers off in order to stop boring neighbour contacting him"Producers: "Hang on a minute, modern audiences do like a bit of blood and gore - no problem, we have 10 fingers to play with - but in a funny way, remember it's a comedy!"Doesn't the story feel a little unauthentic to you?So in it's defence I hear it's allegorical, fair enough but next time write better allegorically ok?Pretty rural landscapes though and the sea is mighty fine.

I so love the screenplay, cinematography & performances in McDonagh's film. I had seen two of his plays years ago, one off & one on-Broadway. The script has echoes of the clipped, witty phrases of his "Cripple of Inishman" with a bit of "Waiting for Godot" (McDonagh is a major admirer of Beckett) ... And the photography, sigh--easy to expect great, sprawling vistas of Achill Island & Inishmore (the West Coast of Ireland, where my grandparents were raised, is awash with rough waves, steep cliffs, treeless plains)- but Ben Davis uses them as background without milking it. It's the interiors, the painterly use of natural light-the soft whites & golds through windows, a la Vermeer, and the splashes of candlelight on faces against dark brown, earthen walls, the chiaroscuro bringing out the isolation and well worn visages of characters looking for meaning in their existence. But with all this seriousness, there is also humor, the music of Colin Farrell's exasperation, the charm of animals always in the house... Such a quiet, wonderful film.

reviews.review_title: Classic McDonagh, but more John Michael then Martin
reviews.content: This film reminds me most of Calvary in tone, the film written and directed by John Michael McDonagh, Martin's brother.Probably the setting and the atmosphere of dispair but the companion piece has to be Ken Loach. Ken Loachs' The Wind that. Shakes the Barley, a wonderful and heart wrenching film in it's own right but it also provides context the Banshees which is allegorical or a parable for the internicine strife caused by the Irish Civil War.This pitted friend against friend, Father's against children and siblings against each other.Therefore Bansees mirrors this but on a much smaller more intimate scale.A population self mutilating for no good reason and innocent people caught in the crossfire.The acting by all parties is excellent, as expects with Barry Keoghan the stand out and another actor to team up with Colin Farrell once again.That said, this is Farrells film and it shows what a fine and versitile actor he has become. Gleeson and Kerry Condon provide wonderful support but the island and the smaller characters along with Carter Burwells unobtrusive score that stick in your mind long after the smoke has settled.

Having Irish heritage I do like a good Irish movie but I found nothing new in this movie.i know a movie doesn't always need a twist ,and all twist guesses were taken out in the script halfway through,but the film needed something more at the end to make it a good film from a ok film.my review has to be longer by all accounts so I'd just like to say the acting was good all round. But I thought Barry keoghan was exceptional and if any awards are giving to this film and he doesn't get one it's a joke far and away best actor on show. Watch the guard or the wind that shakes the barley if you are looking for a good Irish movie.

Thoroughly incapacitating Irish people and Ireland, deeper than any one of us gombeens could express and comprehend. This film was so good people talked to each other after the screening, people who did not know each other. I could not speak due to emotion. Irish theater breathes through this film on screen. Visually perfect. Emotionally cutting. I cried for the majority of the film, laughed genuinely and deeply. Every sentence and every word, every tut is worth the listen. I won't try to explain the dept and multitude of depictions of humans and Irish humans but you should comprehend what is being said and not said. Smile and take it all in. This is a masterpiece.

Watching 'The Beauty Queen of Leenane' being performed on stage in writer Martin McDonagh's home city of London's West End a few decades ago was stirring enough. I and two friends had seats in the second row, just out of range of the occasional splatters of fake blood from the stage, which were reaching those in front of us. A good few walked out of what they must have presumed would be a titillating Oirish play. Instead, they got J. B. Keane crossed with Tarantino. That approach - folky scene employed as Trojan Horse - has been a common enough formula: Flann O'Brien set the precedent, Shane McGowan had a touch of it, the Father Ted series played with same. McDonagh's film The Banshees of Inisherin loses that power, partly as an insightful nephew (and filmmaking undergraduate in Dublin) says, because it still feels like a stage-play. But it isn't a stage play. Thinking out loud, realistic amputated fingers being thrown into the audience could have done the trick, like something from Joe Dante's movie Matinee or to have expected in the famous all-night Scala Cinema, Kings Cross back in the 1980s.What interested me about the film, whether McDonagh intended it or not, were all the allusions to social media. In the 1960s many had misunderstood media theorist Marshall McLuhan's use of the phrase Global Village. In fact, it was meant as stark warning. Whilst village life (of the past) had its charms, and involved mutually supporting networks, normalised sharing, open doors; the reality also meant everyone knowing your business, the imposition of a uniform oppressive morality, collusion and covering-up of horror, and various forms of entrapment. Lars von Trier's Dogville hits the mark in portraying small town niceness masking pure evil. Each platform is different to the next - arguably Twitter was/is too hostile a place and Instagram is sickeningly 'nice' - but the social media landscape which emerged two decades ago has many village characteristics. Long in advance of the internet, that is what McLuhan was hinting at. If it was hard to leave communal village communities, then detaching from social media platforms is as trying. Pubs, bars, shebeens and cafés preceded online communities; people are not only addicted to alcohol, caffeine and to social media, but to socialising itself, to conversation and to each other, in ways which can be pleasing but also - overused term alert - toxic. McDonagh's play/film unpacks the question of Likes and Liking in amusing ways, illustrating how things can get out of hand. That is surely a referencing of today's new-media world where adults behave like 'twelve-year olds', bitter disputes unfold, and even the fact, that dexterity with fingers is a vital aspect of smart-screen and device use, appears linked. And a sick joke I heard once seems pertinent. What have online chat rooms and confession got in common? Both involve talking secretly with someone you can't see who is probably a paedophile.McDonagh goes to great trouble to signify that the bucolic historical scene is exaggeration. He throws everything in: the Virgin Mary statue, one of those household Jesus pictures, a Celtic cross, priest, policeman, there's the perfectly twee clothing, an uncanny lack of rain, and highly saturated imagery adds to the effect. The intended irony seemed lost on the cinema audience I was part of (not in Ireland): a lot of people were laughing at perfectly ordinary turns of phrase, but not at other, presumably meant-to-be funny, aspects of the film. The dog licking Colm's wound made perfect sense in my mind because of the purported healing effects of same but amused many there.Though language use is hammed up in McDonagh's signature style, interestingly other terminology slips in: today's fixation on depression is given attention. There is a lot more going on in this McDonagh flick, for example a reactionary message about the inevitably of conflict, including civil war, hinting at a pointlessness in revolutions. Women seem capable of rising above all this, observing, escaping the madness but are idealised. The relationship with animals, the attempt to tease out tensions between cultural drives and the apparent artistic mindset versus everyday pressures, low versus high culture - eating with your mouth closed is associated with being French, use of the word 'yet', English etc. - the significance of the island as metaphor (a platform?), nostalgia for war, belief versus nihilistic attitudes, the concern with stupidity and being a gom versus cultured, interesting, intelligent all deserve attention maybe.The storytelling may be seductive but I'm so tired of these kinds of overall framing. Others must be too. The intended irony is easily lost on many, as stated. Irish directors like Leonard Abrahamson have been doing more interesting things. McDonagh ends up exploiting too much of what artist and filmmaker Mick Holly calls 'the notion of "Irishness" as fictitious unity developed for profitable export', and ' the tourist industry's production and management of Irish fantasy'

reviews.review_title: Colin and Brendan again a wonderful combination.
reviews.content: It's difficult to find the words to describe just how powerful and emotionally charged this movie is. From the very first scene, I was drawn in and completely immersed in the story, unable to look away for even a moment. The performances of the actors are nothing short of astounding, and the script is nothing short of brilliant.One of the things that really stood out to me was the way that the movie tackled some of the most sensitive and controversial issues. It was never preachy or heavy-handed, but rather used subtlety and nuance to explore these complex themes in a way that felt authentic and raw.Overall, this is a movie that will stay with me for a long time to come. It's the kind of film that will leave you thinking and feeling long after the credits have rolled. If you're in the mood for something that will truly move you, this is a movie that you absolutely must see.

reviews.review_title: As you watch a Greek tragedy unfold
reviews.content: Beyond the violence of the civil war on the mainland in 1923s Ireland, lies a piece of land that seems to be frozen in time. It is a perfectly written setting to start unveiling the littlest of tragedies to the outside world - a friendship ending.I found the poetry in the loneliness of the island to be exquisite and gut-wrenching, the space between the dwellings adding to the overall feeling of scarce feelings, for, in those time, stubbornly bridging the distance for human comfort was yet to be instilled in people.Then there is Padraic - doing just so.Brilliantly acted, making you burst into short laughter fits, followed by a quick realization of what is actually beneath that humor.It's hard to watch because of it, but it's impossible to stop watching exactly because of it.

Decided to watch after the critical acclaim. The acting is excellent but it's so slow and meandering. Quite dreary and not a pleasant watch. It's supposed to be a black comedy and although there are one or two funny moments the whole story is just depressing and pointless. The reason for the two main characters falling out is never really explained and in my opinion the story never get's going. I was expecting so much more and consider it a missed opportunity. I am familiar with this beautiful part of Ireland and I think they could have made more of the lovely surroundings. Three Billboards was a much better film, which although also dark deserved the awards it received..The Banshees doesn't.

reviews.review_title: When leave me means go away
reviews.content: "The Banshees of Inisherin" is a movie for all little things which are in friendship. The love, the fun, the emotional talkings, the sad nights, everything. As a theme the movie talk about the important meaning of communication. People need to be honest, need to talk each other nowadays.Martin create very simple history with very emotional level of empathy. And of course this Martin's thin line of humour. It is interested how the line of plot is like horizon but with some little accumulations the fire burn houses. More important is that although everything the friendship never end.The cast is amazing. Brilliant Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson. Must watch!

This is a weird movie to review, yet I know I loved it. I don't know if others feel the same but it's almost like witnessing a public event, one which you don't see the beginning or the end, yet it is interesting enough to talk about later with friends. Like getting on a bus and there is an argument between a couple and as you get off it is still going on. You will never know what started it or how they normally are and you will never see the end.This movie doesn't show the past of this friendship, just that it the moment where it stops and you don't get a satisfying ending to the drama, instead you witness a part of the characters lives, and if you go in, as I did, knowing this then it's an enjoyable, beautifully shot and scripted affair that has you reflecting on life.

Listen, I don't know what Colin Farrell did to go from a handsome mediocre actor to this thespian powerhouse but I'm really glad he did it. His performance as Padraic, a simple man wanting nothing more than to live a simple life, is so nuanced and so heartbreaking one almost drowns in its subtleties and Farrell's prowess with deftly delivering levity within the dramatic.Balanced against Brendan Gleeson's tightly bound Colm, a man who wants and needs more than his life has to offer, Padraic's optimism seems almost obscene. They are strange bedfellows and when Colm suddenly ends the friendship the only person surprised by it is Padraic.So begins their descent into enmity (that includes self-mutilation, accidental death, exposed secrets, escape, and tragic realizations) driven first by Colm disparaging Padraic's "dullness" and sustained by Padraic's ever-diminishing idealism.Comedy my arse. I cried through 80% of this film. It's beautiful and tragic.

1923, in a small village on an imaginary island off the coast of Ireland. Colm ends his lifelong friendship with Padric abruptly and with little explanation. Padric is heartbroken and makes multiple attempts to reconcile with Colm. Colm fears his own death, his aging and his existential despair. Padric unaware of his loneliness, his jealousy and his anger, accelerates the conflict beyond repair. Stunning green countryside, shear rock sea cliffs, humble thatch roof houses and austere island vistas. There is no transformation of these characters but only a tragic ending of revenge. McDough could have been more imaginative.

A film you 'appreciate' perhaps more than you 'enjoy'. This is a story of struggle against change. With one man wanting to break free of what he fears he's become whilst the other fights to keep things the way he feels most comfortable and you can't help but empathise with both, and the credit there lies in the performances of both Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson who reprise their "In Bruge" chemistry. Yes, the pacing is a little slow in places, but then I'm sure life was in Ireland in the 1920's but the journey is worth it. A stand-out performance by Barry Keoghan as the affable "slow coach" on the island deserves the credit it's receiving, likewise Kerry Condon as the put-upon sister so desperate to be seen.

reviews.review_title: A film to make your heart swell
reviews.content: Wow. There are not enough adjectives to do this film justice! With its setting on an Irish island in 1923, it is visually stunning, evocative and atmospheric. The pacing is perfect, with a lean script and gradual build that makes you both fall in love with and fear for all the main characters. The acting is just amazing all round - Colin Farrell is yet again a revelation (his eyebrows alone deserve an Oscar for the inner turmoil they convey) and Barry Keoghan blew me away with his nuanced portrayal of the troubled young Dominic whose sweet nature and hopefulness are at odds with the bleak island life he was born into. The undercurrent of darkness and foreboding grows throughout the film, despite the light relief from some sharply funny moments and some bittersweet scenes that are almost too poignant to bear, and the ending leaves you wanting much more more. Utterly brilliant.

reviews.review_title: A Delightful Slow Burn With A+ Performances
reviews.content: I've very much anticipated this film since seeing the trailers, I found the basic concept fascinating and was excited to see where the film would go on such a simple premise.Firstly, the acting is fantastic across the board, Colin Ferrell and Brendan Gleeson are excellent in the film, but Barry Keoghan stood out in particular with a great performance as the village screw-up, he adds so much to his character.The concept for this film starts out with the simple premise of a man who decides he no longer wants to be friends with another man, and throughout it escalates, it becomes more intense and even a bit unsettling, that is no doubt in part due to the setting. Living on a very small island (Inisherin) where everyone knows everyone and word travels quickly can make change very awkward for everyone. One small slip, one bad encounter and suddenly the entire village will hear of it. But the build up is very well done and you really feel for Colin Ferrell's character as he comes to grips with his best friend suddenly deciding he no longer wants to be a part of his life and the entire town having their own opinions on the matter. The ending is not quite what I expected, and perhaps not what I was hoping for as far as the resloution goes, but an interesting ending nevertheless, I certainly didn't dislike it.My two gripes with this film would be that there are decisions made by a certain character that feel a bit extreme and even counterintuitive to their supposed goal, so it was a bit odd when they make those decisions, but I won't spoil it.The second is that the film feels too quiet. There's very little ambient sound, meaning the ocean, the wind, animals, people in a crowded pub, it was missing or very faintly there for almost all of the movie. All of the audio is focused on what the main speaking characters were saying and all the rest of the surrounding sound is turned down, which I felt took the realism out of it to a degree. I want to hear what's around the characters, what they would be hearing to be immersed in their environment, and unfortunately that was a bit lost, which is a shame, because the film looks beautiful.Overall I would highly recommend the film, it's a very engaging, wonderfully performed & beautifully shot, well worth watching.

reviews.review_title: An Excellent Short Story Trying to be a Novel
reviews.content: I agree with Mark Feeny of the Boston Globe that the Banshees of Inisherin feels like a short story trying to be a novel; that said, this is a story that held me from start to finish.The Banshees of Inisherin follows the sudden breakdown of a lifelong friendship. Pádraic (Colin Farrell), though nice and well liked by everyone on the island of Inisherin, is a little too "dull" for his old friend Colm (Brendan Gleeson) who wants to spend the rest of his life composing music and doing things so he may be remembered for generations to come. Colm is resistant to his old friend's attempts to make amends for his unknown offence, so he makes a promise to cut off one of the fingers on his left hand each time Pádraic tries to talk with him. Though Pádraic's sister Siobhán (Kerry Condon) and the troubled son of a local policeman (Barry Keoghan) try to defuse the pair's escalating quarrel their attempts prove futile.Both Farrell and Gleeson command attention shen on screen. Farrell's bewilderment turned fury towards his old friend is matched by Gleeson's resolute will to make his life that appears to be slipping away count. The cast is further filled out by a surprisingly tender performance by Barry Keoghan, who's confession of love towards Siobhán is a strikingly sincere highlight of the second act. (Sheila Flitton also delivers a tempered performance as Mrs. McCormick, the Bergman-esque figure of death crone that spreads the island's gossip.Achill Island off the western coast of County Mayo in northwestern Ireland plays the fictional Inisherin. The homely setting is a strongpoint of the film, though the excellent art direction leaves something to be desired of the cinematography. Ireland's natural beauty isn't quite enough to save this film from looking flat I'm afraid.The Civil war metaphor also falls flat on it's face because not much happens to support it. Everything feels relatively timeless on the island. Though the far off booms of the guns on the mainland hint at another senseless conflict very little ties Pádraic and Colm's feud to the wider world.The soundtrack was a strongpoint, considering it's importance to the plot. Carter Burwell, Martin McDonagh's frequent collaborator, succeeds in circumventing the expectations of the film's setting lending a subtle yet provocative underscore to the film's plot. It was also nice to see Brendan Gleeson get to play the fiddle (with four fingers no less).Apart from notable performances fro its leads and an intriguing premise I fear Banshees will come and go like so many projects in the post-Covid "prestige film" boom. I'd recommend this film to anybody who's interested in watching it because of its setting or its leads. I'm definitely not going to say "stay away" due to a few minor gripes. Come for the performance, stay for the setting and enjoy your night out.

reviews.review_title: Highly Nuanced - (SPOILER) It's a Metaphor And It's Not About The War - One of the Best Films of 2022
reviews.content: This movie is seemingly, on the surface, a delightful weirdly quirky comedy drama about the drama that ensues as a man suddenly stops talking to his friend (Padraic) one day. The setting is on a small, remote, sparsely populated island off the coast of ireland where the accent is thick and everyones pastime seems to be spending time at the one pub, which adds to the quirkiness. The entire movie is about the other man trying to get his friend to talk to him again, and it ends more or less without much of an ending, neither resolution nor tragedy, leaving you a bit wanting for a more satisfying conclusion.But the real joy of this film comes after the fact, or maybe during for some keen viewers. You start to realize that the everything in the movie is a metaphor and that it all surrounds Padraic's relationship with his sister (Siobhan). Their relationships with the other two main characters in the story, Colm and Dominic, represent their inward feelings toward each other and other characters.Padraic is known on the island to be simple, and somewhat dull, spending much of his days drinking at the pub and talking about simple things. His friend Colm decides one day that he wants more out of life and that he must leave Padraic behind, lest he be held back as well. His relationship with Colm is his inward relationship with his sister Siobhan. She , sentimental to Colm, is contemplating leaving the island to work as a librarian on the mainland, having to leave her brother behind on the island to pursue her dreams. (Colm even hints at Siobhan that she must be able to relate to how he feels. The film is filled to the brim with hints and clues like this).The metaphors don't stop there, they abound in this film. The donkey also represents Padraic, just wanting company, much in the same way Padraic wants that of his sister. The cops relationship with his son Dominic represents his relationship with Padraic and Siobahn. He bullies them and pressures them to do things for him, otherwise beating them. (He is also saddened when he finds out Siobhan has finally fled the island and his advances, represented by his sons death soon after). Dominics relationship to Siobhan also represents Padraic's feelings toward his sister, wanting her care and love. When she rejects him, she symbolically rejects her brother, and this is the first death foretold by the banshee (Dominic in the lake).One day when Padraic drunkenly stands up to Colm, alongside claiming he will never forget his sister because she is kind, Siobahn seeming has a bit of a change of heart, and contemplates staying for her brother (Colm also contemplates befriending him again). Padraic, having sent one of Colm's music students back home to the mainland, represented by him reading his sister job offer letter and withholding it from his sister, later confesses to it, which for better or worse, makes Colm once again change his mind (as does his sister).This final resolve, Colm cutting off the rest of his fingers, representing Siobhans final decision to leave the island, results in the second and final death: that of the donkey, representing Padraic's broken heart and his yearning turned toward anger toward Colm and Siobhan. He burns Colm's house, symbolizing wanting to tell his sister she is no longer welcome, and the next day, Colm is unexpectedly wanting to keep the relationship, as his sister's letter also does. But Padraic's heart has now been hurt too much, it has turned sour toward both of them, yet he still has a soft spot for them. He offers to watch Colm's dog for him "anytime".

McDonagh has a wealth of films he's directed under his repertoire that are simply outstanding.I watched this over Christmas and as a fellow Irishman it's so good to see the Irish lads do well during award season. Colin, Brendan and Barry you couldn't split them on their performances. Kudos to them.We get to bask in the beauty that his rural Ireland in a very somber period of our history under British rule, rural Ireland villages haven't really changed and it's really a good picture of their landscape as a whole. Alchill Island wouldn't look out of place in the Mediterranean on a warm Summers day.However the appreciation of this film is and difference of opinions is worth noting but you will get that will all films. Worthy of the plaudits and make sure you give it your full attention to basque in it's glory.BRAVO.

This is NOT a good film. There are some well acted performances but the film itself is depressing, weird and melancholy. Good performances don't make a good movie and this is by far the worst movie I've seen this year.Some people have remarked that this film is funny, it's not. There are some mildly amusing facial expressions here and there and the most interesting thing about the movie is a miniature donkey.The casting of the film is right. The place the film is made and the look and feel of the time are all done very well. The story itself is trying too hard to be original and in the end absolutely nothing happens.

reviews.review_title: Think Brando and Steiger on a Connemara Waterfront
reviews.content: Acting. Atmosphere. Alcohol. Apathy. Art. Alternativism...??? A true cinematic masterpiece that will age like all the great works of art - it shall be remembered. Colin The Farrell and Brendan Gleeson in career high performances; Barry Keoghan still threatening to steal the screen right out from under them entirely sure and Kerry Condon bewitchingly bould and beautiful. The few moments of violence snap us out of our trance and wash us with the wildness of Ireland's West. The boredom of their existence demands savagery and subterfuge to summon vitality. Yes, no ordinary movie and maybe for dreamers but ... music and beauty and art are eternal - two o'clock baby!

Brilliant tale and visual treat. Has the small island community thing down to a T. With only a few dozen folk in a limited space, every relationship and happening gets magnified, so, depending on the isolation, feuds often develop. I've been to Aran only a couple of times, but only detected friendship. The nearest to Inisherin I've found is one of the Shetland Islands, north of Scotland (not saying which, but it is remote!). The islanders there have divided themselves into two bitterly-feuding families, seemingly for decades, and nothing can bring them together. They hide their mutual animosity from most visitors, but after a few visits in company with other folk from Shetland & Orkney (who somehow demonstrate island street-cred) they let the mask slip, and opposing family members walk past each other on the road in silence.Back to the film, I wasn't keen on the way two islands with obviously different geologies were used. So you get a track winding between the limestone walls & tiny fields of Inis Mor, switching suddenly to the open hill-country of Achill. Perhaps good for variety, but there are plenty of possible locations on the two inner Aran Isles, especially the middle one, Inis Maun, where you can still see the odd local woman in traditional costume on Sundays (or you could 20 years ago).If you are thinking of going to Aran, don't hesitate! In May & June the wild flowers are fantastic, though July & August are better for pub music. Inisheer has some wonderful guest-houses. Don't expect to slim while you are there.

A brilliantly beautiful harrowingly sad film that lays out the agonising pain, frustration and sadness of the civil war in a personal intimate way through the relationship between the two leads.One striving for something better, a legacy of music...the other struggling to understand a broken relationship. Ultimately Gleeson destroys his musical gift ..his ambitions...his dream..by cutting away his friendship with Farrell and mutilating himself so that he cannot play music anymore.It's a deeply disturbing act that aligns with the Irish Civil war which essentially became a body attacking itself and leaving itself damaged and broken.Farrells character develops from innocent and kind with a deep love for his animals...to the realisation that his friend no longer wants to know him. He strives to understand but when his beloved donkey chokes on Gleeson amputated fingers he is thrown into the depths of bitterness and despair. The kind that seeks retribution. And he does seek it.The film is set in the west of Ireland. Beiatiful scenery that serves to highlight even more poignantly the utter despair that the characters live through. The Valley of the Squinting windows is alive and well.Keoghegan as Dominic is unbelievably brilliant. The scene by the lake is heart stoppingly sad as his simple thought processes realise without any bitterness that his dream will never be realised.This is an extremely nuanced film. To take it at face value as a black comedy is to do it an injustice. Its a Shakespearean tragedy meets Dostoyevskian manipulation.

reviews.review_title: A contrast between beauty and cruelty
reviews.content: These are the stories that make cinema stay and transcend, a simple script without many pretensions, such as a trivial event ( the conflict of two friends on a lonely island), but with a background framed in philosophy and society. The island, the best scenario chosen to record, a photograph that impacts (each frame is a magnificent photo), the vintage color of the background that inspires nostalgia (as in the film "the Irishman"). And to top off Farrel's performances, Gleeson. Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan to rent the balcony. The costumes are also impressive, especially because of the colors that stand out in the actors.

This movie has some incredible acting with stunning natural scenes and exceptionally realistic reconstruction of Ireland in the 1930s. The attention to detail is incredible. The humour is very dry and subtle. Definitely Irish people will identify a lot with this type of humour but I wonder will it travel internationally. I just would've preferred the movie to have a happy ending. It was a long movie at just under two hours but it is compulsive viewing. It reminds me of the famous Irish play Waiting for Godot. In summary, this movie is pure quality and my only reservation is, the sadness that visited so many of the characters.

I was hypnotized since the very first scene. When I started it, I knew something outstanding was coming. Two inseparable friends (supposedly) have become enemies. It's mind-blowing by itself. Everything was so capturing in every detail, scene, directing stuff, and the acting. Collen was able to reflect every single requirements his rule needed as if he was absorbed with this character. No wonder it was nominated for 9 Oscars and loads of others. How could the friends change? How was Colm (Brendan Gleeson) able to just igonre his (close) friend. Everyone on the island knew their friendship. How could he sleep and be happy with the achievement he claimed he was seeking? A friend endures a lot from his friend. Padraic (Collin Farrell) didn't believe him and tried what he could and a bit more to reconnect what he has lost. It was his soul and life that he missed. At the beginning of the movie the island used to be sunny, unlike it was when the grief started taking place. The weather was gloomy in a way that enforces your feeling to feel himself. "When it rains, it pours down". His friend was "not nice" as he used to be, or he never used to be. While he was struggling with his friend and thought he could reconnect the friendship rope, he was burdened with his sister leaving."She is nice, I'll always remember her ". He doesn't have anyone one now to talk to or wit with except for "Jenny", yet he was gone too. Since then, Padraic didn't care anymore about any apology from his ex-friend. Here it comes the change of his personality in the movie. It hit me hard. The last scene where he was leaving him shooting the old lady between them was the toughest thing. He didn't hesitate this time to leave him or look back. He wanted to say a lot when his "friend" thanked him, he couldn't say but "any time". He couldn't talk to him as he used to do. What a lifeless life the both lived later on. They both lost the essence of life because his friend wanted to stay away from his friend to seek for forever-last-living thing (music) but he obtained neither at the end.

This is the first Martin McDonagh film that I wasn't a fan of. Colin Ferrell was amazing as he always is in McDonagh films but the whole premise of the film seems pointless. It's a very slow burn filled with uninteresting characters and boring dialogue. Three Billboards was slow too but was clever and interesting, im just really confused by all the great reviews. This film has the same rating as In Bruges (which also stars Ferrell and Gleeson, written and directed by McDonagh) and that movie is amazing, Ive rewatched it multiple times. I can't honestly say I would ever watch this film again, it wasnt terrible but I'll never sit through it for a second time.

reviews.review_title: Impressive, thought provoking work of art
reviews.content: I will not reiterate the story of this movie, as other reviews will suffice in that task, but let me say that this movie will stay with you for days. I was left with the question "Is it more important WHAT you want to do (with one's life) or is it more important HOW you want to be as a human?" Obviously, many people who have left lasting legacies in the form of music or literary masterpieces, inventions, art, etc. Were not "nice" people and have actually caused great harm during their time on the Earth. Other, "nice" people with average talents are not remembered except for those who knew and loved them while they were alive. Is one way of being exclusive of the other? This movie dives deep into such issues. The scenery is gorgeous, the acting extraordinary, and the story simple on the surface but actually quite deep. I loved it. Make sure you have closed caption as the accent is difficult to understand.

reviews.review_title: Funny, tense, sad, moving, dark - unmissable
reviews.content: The performances are exceptional, the story is simple at face value but compelling due to its hidden complexity, humour and contrasting darkness.It's hard to describe the full emotional range you will experience when watching this film but it keeps you fully engaged to the end.The setting is beautiful and the depiction of rural island life in the 1920s is both magical and austere.But you keep coming back to the story telling and the amazing performances of the cast - to watch them deliver the full range of emotion from humour and menace to sadness and love is something to behold. The awards hype that surrounds this film is not misplaced - not to be missed!

Outstanding performance from the three lads, and the director. I am not a big Colin Farrell's fan but he was absolutely amazing. Brendan Gleeson is always a guarantee and Barry Keoghan gave a strong and very nuanced performance. Really great acting. Flawless setting without any major effects, over production etc. "Just" the beautiful Irish landscape and the simple houses and pub. Loved it.Great direction and story. It's not a light hearted story - can be heavy because of the themes but this was a very needed film, especially after rubbish like Avatar. This film will probably be a staged production in theatres, no doubt.

The Banshees of Inisherin is Martin McDonagh's most refined piece of work. The story follows the deteriorating friendship between Pàdraic (Colin Farell) and Colm (Brendal Gleeson). It achieves a perfect equilibrium between humour and heartfelt. McDonagh takes aim at the pointlessness war through the metaphor of his charaters petty conflict. With Farell and Gleeson once again proving that their on screen chemistry is of the highest calibre. The two leads are also supported by great performance from Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan. The donkey was pretty good as well.The island of Achill provides a stunning backdrop for the film and the beauty is enhanced by a rather enchanting score. Easily one of the best films of the year. 9/10.

reviews.review_title: It's a tragic conflict between art and humanity
reviews.content: There's no breath of fresher air than Martin McDonagh's films in the creatively bankrupt wasteland that has been cinema in the last 5-10 years. Ever since I first saw In Bruges, I've held my breath for all of his releases and when I found out he is doing something with Gleeson and Farrell again, I was counting the days.First of all, The Banshees of Inisherin is one of his least inviting films. But in a good way! It will refuse to hold your hand. Martin McDonagh has proven to be pretty straightforward in his stories and his dialogue. Inisherin is no different and it doesn't hold back for a second.There is a conflict at the center of this story that is a simple and an intense one. And the conflict is mostly the result of a certain fear all of us have known throughout our lives - the fear that the good times are a waste. The fear that history only remembers the martyrs and especially the fear that to be happy just might as well mean to be stupid. In my opinion, if you've ever had a true real friend in your life - this movie is either a great consolation or a serious warning for you.Beautiful scenery, great performances, heartbreaking dialogue, great pacing. To all the reviewers in here who said they didn't get it - please give it another chance! I found myself relating to all sides of this conflict and I think it is an incredibly important subject. We sacrifice humanity in the search of meaning and we sacrifice meaning in the search of contentment.

One of the more interesting reviews I heard about this identified it as a fable-like or a fairytale and you can see it throughout the film. Two friends who fall out, one promises to cut his own fingers off if the other talks to him, the ever-present watcher in the 'ghoul' of a woman who to me felt like death or the grim reaper watching them and saying things like there shall be two deaths. This was thoroughly enjoyable, the laughs in the cinema couldn't be stopped, the humour is so Irish and brilliant that performances like Barry Keoghan's really shone through. However, for me Kerry Condon was without doubt the stand out performance. Wow what a great film!

I thoroughly enjoyed this film from start to finish. In fact I was disappointed to see it end. Not because I think it should have kept going, but because I wasn't ready to see the last of the characters I had been watching for the last two hours. Farrell and Gleeson both give great performances with some genuine laugh out loud moments in this black comedy. No punches were pulled or fingers...My take on what it was all about:I think Colm had clearly decided he wanted his life to have meaning and to leave a legacy as he wound down his last years of life. This meant he resented Padraic, his dull, simple friend as he was clearly content with their lives doing nothing but being drinking buddies and chatting absolute nonsense all day, everyday. This means Colm ditches his old friend for a chance to focus on his goal of achieving immortality through his music. The only problem is that their friendship had, unbeknownst to him, been giving Padraic's life purpose. This meant that once Padraic realises he can't win him back, much like his friend, he turns to unapologetic, bizarre, specific violence (Colm cutting his own left handed fingers off when Padraic bothers him and Padraic burning Colm's house down at 2 for killing his pony). The civil war in Ireland, like many wars, was fought between two sides who had far more reasons to love each other than hate each other. But as the movie says "somethings there is no moving on from". This in my opinion is what the movie is about. The violence both men have done has meant they can no longer go back. The only way forward now is with more hate and violence.
