Padraic knows he's lost his friend but also knows that he'd rather be his enemy than no one at all. They both end up with nothing even though you can see in their eyes during their last interaction that it is only pride that is keeping them from happiness and friendship once more.

reviews.review_title: Samuel Beckett is Back in a Bloody Way
reviews.content: This movie is almost beyond description. It is funny in the most deadpan way. Much that happens to the characters is not really believable. (That, I guess, is what makes it a comedy.) But the overall impact is existential. This movie questions the meaning of life in a profound way.I think the author wrote this as a parable of the Irish Civil War in the 1920's. But it goes way beyond that into universal territory. I keep thinking of Samuel Beckett's "Waiting for Godot." Like "Godot" it is funny but bleak. Unlike "Godot" it has some shocking violence and raw emotion. But again, like "Godot," the overall impact is devastating.I think that Beckett had Laurel and Hardy in mind when he wrote "Godot." And the two main characters in this film are also L&H-esque. One is dimwitted and the other thinks he's more important that he is. Whatever!This film is heads and tails better than anything else released this year.

This film was not what I was expecting but I loved it. It has beautifully captured the quirkiness of Island life on the West Coast of Ireland but also has much deeper meaning. Having holidayed on Achill Island earlier this year the landscape is wonderfully captured, especially the spectacular Keem Bay.The Banshee in Irish mythology is a spirit that wails at night to warn of the impending death of a loved one and the theme of the film, to me, focuses strongly on mortality and inner turmoil.Gleeson's character who early in the film shuns his old friend Farrell makes initially for dark comedic watching as he no longer wants to waste his time on banal conversation, realising that his time on earth is limited. He claims to want to achieve greater things and create a lasting legacy through art and musical composition.It is sad to watch Farrells reaction (brilliantly portrayed) to this brutal rejection, essentially losing his only friend on the island overnight. Kerry Condon plays a fantastic character in Farrells sister. She is the voice of reason and sense but she too is also impacted heavily by the isolation of island life - her most firey moment being questioned why she never had children (which obviously touched a deep nerve). For me she is the most complex character in the film and I especially enjoyed a scene where she calls out Gleeson on incorrectly naming the century in which Mozart lived - which at that time makes his arrogance on looking down on Farrell as being dull seem very hypocritical indeed.Overall this film had me thinking about it for a few days after, which I imagine is the whole point. It is fine for casual watching but there are fewer laugh out loud moments compared to something like In Bruges. I think the acting and script are on a whole other level in this though and when I get round to watching it again I might take something else away from it altogether. On first watch though I was left feeling sad afterwards and it seems like this emotion successfully washed off from both the island and the characters on to me.

This film, taking place against the backdrop of the Northern Ireland conflict, is a deeply affecting metaphor for the sad futility of war. The lifelong friendship of two men begins to disintegrate when one depressed half decides he needs more quiet to create something lasting in the form of his music. Like war, this disintegration couldn't have a more apt description than cutting off your nose to spite your face. This film is cinematically gorgeous and haunting, simultaneously. It's subject matter is provocative as it explores the themes of death and dying, the fragility of life, and dreams unrealized.

The problem I find with movies like this is that they're too often viewed at face value.This is a film of symbolism, there are specific messages it portrays and if you can identify the intent of the messages early enough then you can enjoy the film as it's supposed to be enjoyed.It does provoke thought and meaning if you allow yourself to truly invest in it. There is an absurdity to the actions of the characters throughout the film. This is where it can shut some viewers off, but if you allow yourself to think a bit bigger, you will understand and enjoy it.If you watch the film expecting to find sense and closure from the story then you'll be disappointed, this film is more than the story.Finally, the acting and cinematography are wonderful and deserve many plaudits.

reviews.review_title: Got Twice Chuckles out of me
reviews.content: We follow our main character Pádraic, played by Colin Farrell, in this dive into broken relationships. The movie opens up with Pádraic confused as to why Colm, played by Brendan Gleeson, is giving him the cold shoulder.As with any relationships, any number of things can go awry, sometimes with no satisfactory explanation as to why. As Pádraic tries to recover his friendship, he is oblivious to Colm's need for solitude away from him.This got two laughs out of me, as the tension rises and Pádraic's attitude towards the situation is "this is fine" as everything seems to be bursting into flames.For me, the movie starts to drag in the middle, where Pádraic is obsessed with recovering Colm's attention. This incessant need for Colm even drove me mad as a viewer, along with the rest of the supporting characters surprised that Pádraic still does not get the message Colm is putting out. I tuned out at that point. Only to regain interest again on the final act, the conclusion to the strife between the two.

This absolutely breathtaking masterpiece of a film, with carefully perfect balance of everything I can think of at the moment.I was floored and captivated in a state of immense feelings and it made me laugh because I wanted to cry so much.Its depth is unlike many things I have seen as of late and that includes the other two movies I saw during the Christmas holidays with my family: Violent Night & Glass Onion. The Banshees of Inisherin is beyond comparable in quality.Last time I felt a masterpiece in such an incredibly cold but heartwarming way was when I watched the Norwegian, French, Swedish and Polish film: "King of Devil's Island".If you have any sense of heart and beauty, give this a watch.

reviews.review_title: Colin Farrell does it again... but not how you think.
reviews.content: Ok I've seen most of McDonagh's plays and I've always really enjoyed them, even when they get clobbered to bits by Ireland's Am. Dram. Circuit. Loved "3 Billboards". I enjoyed both "7 Psycopaths" and "Banshees of Inisherin" - hence the 7 stars..... but these last two films suffered from the same thing..... Colin Farrell.Farrell seems to have the ability to just completely miss the character that's written down on the page. In both films he failed to create the empathy needed with the character to bring the entire concept of each story together.In Banshees I kept being surprised by expositions by minor characters that explain what has just happened, suddenly making sense of the previous scenes. At one of the key moments in the film, Gleeson (playing Colm) tells Farrell that he can't spend the rest of his life listening to conversations like the one where Farrell spent two hours talking about things he'd found in his donkey's poo. ...... THAT was a revelation. For the first time the relationship between the two men made sense. Up until that point nothing suggested that he was one of the most boring men in the world. But the way Farrell plays it you just can't believe it. Farrell spends most of the film just being angry and occasionally shouting like a hard man. Gleason does a great job despite having to play against Farrell who spends most of the film fighting against his dialogue and doing lots of "stare into the distance" acting. Farrell creates no empathy for his character. I found myself feeling sorry for Gleeson's character.The biggest tragedy is when Gleeson's character starts cutting off his fingers. It should be the funniest moment of the film, partly because it's so absurd, but it actually kind of makes sense..... how else do you stop the relentless, angry barrage of nonsense coming from Farrell? If Farrell had only played his character as a simpler, less angry man, then Gleeson's actions become crazy. His actions Madness! The bizarre lengths a man will go to to avoid a nice, boring friend.At one point Farrell tells the audience that he's a "nice" man, he then reacts with a shout as if he could rip Gleeson's throat out. And that one scream goes to the nub of the problem with Farrell's performance and sadly the film. That scream should be the best try of Padraic NOT to be nice, to be angry.... and it should fail.....it should be just enough for Gleeson's Colm to find it "the most interesting he's ever been" (even funnier it ISN'T very interesting) but Farrell actually looks threatening. Menacing. It looks like he's about to take down the entire pub.Look, overall the film is still fun and, as with 7 Psychopaths, I enjoyed the writing/story and Gleeson was fabulous.The one stand out performance was from Barry Keoghan playing the character of Dominic Kearney. An unsubtle character played with as much subtlety to make him the most fascinating character in the film. Some of his moments are heart breaking.I understand why McDonagh brings Farrell back: Global "star" credentials. But I can't help wondering how brilliant this film could have been with a different actor playing the character of Padraic.

reviews.review_title: You have to watch beyond the movie
reviews.content: If you try to see this movie as a simple story line and wonder why characters behave a certain way, then you'll absolutely hate it. If you're able to disconnect from your phone, concentrate on the beautiful scenery, analyze the why and why not of each scene, each spoken word, each gesture, then you'll truly see what this movie is a metaphor for.Also, don't expect to watch something similar to in Bruges. It's nothing like it. Although, a case could be made that this is the life of those two same characters but in the past, in the future or in a completely different realm.I sincerely enjoyed watching this movie and I also caught on to the true meaning of it when there was 20 min. Left. Almost immediately, I wanted to re watch it. The acting, the costume design, the cinematography, the text, it's all absolutely great cinema.So why a 7? It's inexplicable. It's probably more of an 8, but there's just a little something missing. I can't put my finger on it (no pun intended). If you love cinema and are willing to concentrate on the movie, I absolutely recommend it. If not, if it's just background noise or if you're not willing to see beyond the movie, I'd recommend skipping this until you find yourself in the mood for a dark/comedy flick.

reviews.review_title: Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson engage in a painful quarrel throughout this Martin McDonagh black-comedy/drama.
reviews.content: "The Banshees of Inisherin" shares at least one great quality with "In Bruges" - Martin McDonagh's previous collaboration with Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson: both films tackle weighty concepts using sardonicism and sarcasm. Striking the proper tone in this brand of storytelling is challenging, but McDonagh has mastered the art form. His talent as a writer/director speaks for itself, but I'm certain he would be the first to admit his work is elevated by Farrell and Gleeson. Though the years may have etched away at the actors' faces since they last shared top billing, their craft has only improved.In 1923, on the isle of Inisherin - a fictitious location not far off mainland Ireland - life is quiet and simple. The local church is filled every Sunday morning. The pub is frequented by many townsfolk throughout the rest of the week (and Sunday afternoons). Two of the most common visitors to the public house are Pádraic (Farrell) and Colm (Gleeson). They can almost always be found having a couple of pints when the two o'clock bell chimes. Unbeknownst to Pádraic, though, their days of drinking and chatting together are at an end.Pádraic received no warning for the sudden termination of their friendship, so he confronts Colm about it. Colm plainly informs him that he no longer enjoys his company. It's an unsatisfactory answer, so Colm is pushed into admitting that he finds Pádraic dull. That response also brings no sense of comfort to Pádraic. As a result, he continues searching for the deeper meaning behind his friend's evasiveness. At home, he talks with his sister Siobhán (Kerry Condon), who has no idea why he's being ignored. Later, Pádraic speaks with a simple-minded local lad named Dominic (Barry Keoghan). He also has no clue why Colm is acting the way he is, though Dominic points out that Colm's behavior resembles that of a schoolboy.After some thought, Pádraic resolves to confront Colm again. It doesn't go well. Colm begs Pádraic never to speak to him again, promising to start cutting off his own fingers one by one if Pádraic refuses to comply. Beyond the obvious horror of self-maiming, this would be damaging to Colm's hopes of crafting a memorable song with his fiddle. Pádraic is shocked by Colm's threat, but he remains determined to restore their friendship. He will just have to find a way to break through Colm's hardened shell without speaking to him. Unfortunately, for a talkative man like Pádraic, it will be a significant challenge.The gloomy narrative of "The Banshees of Inisherin" contrasts starkly with the gorgeous surrounding scenery. Whether indoors or out, cinematographer Ben Davis captures what beauty can be found in each moment, even if it's melancholic. The visual imagery of separation he presents is particularly striking. Davis' efforts are accentuated by Carter Burwell's emotional score. His music conjures up a rare set of feelings.It would be a shame to ignore the effort of the performers in this devastating story. Farrell is as remarkable as ever, playing Pádraic to perfection. He brings a unique vulnerability to the character, conveying just how dedicated and polite a man Pádraic is. Gleeson is icy-cold and sometimes cruel as Colm but doesn't open the door to feel apathetic towards him. Kerry Condon is terrific as Siobhán, who is the voice of reason whenever present. Barry Keoghan plays his role exceedingly well, putting on a nuanced and impactful display despite having little screen time. Dominic is perhaps the most profound individual in Inisherein despite his lack of intellectualism. The remaining cast members are also superb, but I don't have room to go into detail here. Suffice to say they make Inisherin feel lived in and complete.There were many times I was in total awe of the cinematic craftsmanship of "The Banshees of Inisherin." Black comedy/drama films rarely receive genuine, uninterrupted engagement from an audience. I was amazed that I did not hear a single rustle of movement from anyone around me as I sat before the cinema screen. All eyes were glued, and every ear was tuned in to each moment of the story. That is a definitive marker of powerful cinema.What I personally found most interesting about "The Banshees of Inisherin" is how it has a different impact than McDonagh's other films. It's both sobering and funny, which isn't new, but the questions the movie asks are more biting and demand introspection. Not only are the queries daunting, but they are posed in such a way that they cannot be brushed off. McDonagh's ponderings are genuine in a way that few films manage to communicate. Most directors would be laughed off or met with eye-rolls if they tried telling this story. "The Banshees of Inisherin" has hung in my mind ever since I left the cinema, and I've faced more introspection than I have in a long time. That's one of the great gifts movies give us if we let them.

reviews.review_title: A Deep Dive into Human Nature with 'The Banshees of Inisherin'
reviews.content: The film "The Banshees of Inisherin" is set in the 1920s in Ireland and follows the relationship between two friends, Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson. After a falling out, Gleeson's character becomes increasingly extreme and unwell, while Farrell's character is revealed to be more selfish in his actions. Kerry Condon, as Farrell's sister, is a standout in the cast and provides a contrast to the male characters. The humor is Martin McDonagh-style dry, dark and subtle. The film is best appreciated by a patient audience who can appreciate its subtleties and dark humor. It is not a light-hearted comedy and has a slow-burn plot that is a commentary on human nature and isolation. The film explores themes of friendship, loneliness, isolation and mortality, and the four main performances are outstanding, with Barry Keoghan particularly impressive.My personal rating for this movie is 6.6/10.

reviews.review_title: A slow decent into civil war
reviews.content: Once someone told me it was a metaphor about the civil war at that time it made a lot more sense. People who liked each other one day falling on two sides of a divide and no longer getting on. One side wants to get back to normality but the other is resistent to this. The loss of things they loved because of conflict served only to deepen their divisions and eventually to escalate the violence and disagreement. The conflict also highlights the waste of staying in a divided state causing people to leave and seek a better life across the sea. Throw in a bit of police brutality and religion and we've covered it all.

reviews.review_title: If you want to end friendship, then you need a lot of blood
reviews.content: Many people thought this film was long, but it didn't seem so to me, because it's not only about the fact that friends can stop communicating at one point. And also about how boring life was before, especially on the distant islands of Ireland. People had nothing to do, every day they went to the pub and that's how their years flew by. This is confirmed by the character of Kerry Condon, who simply escapes from this life into something new, something interesting for her.You can be friends with your friend for years, tell him a story about a goat for 2 hours, and after a day he doesn't want to see you anymore. This movie answers the question: "Should you be friends with a friend who drags you down?" , "How not to lose your friend?" , "What will be the consequences after you stop communicating with him?", "How can friendship die?" And what the end of friendship will cost?The masterful performance of Colin Farrell, Kerry Condon and Brendan Gleeson under the direction of Martin McDonagh, the incredible cinematography of Ben Davis and the gorgeous shots of the coast of Ireland borrowed from his brother Michael McDonagh: All this complements this film.P.s : Sorry for my english:)

Not Shush Padraic, it's more of a shush England. Leave Ireland alone. Do you want all of our people (fingers) dead? You shall have it but not our freedom. Whatever you do, no matter how you try, we will stick to want of freedom.What a movie! What a movie! " In Bruges " was the movie that made me a Colin Farrell fan. I find that calmness in this movie too but the story is deeper. It's more of a contextual movie rather than only entertainment. This is the kind of movie that will stay in your thought for a long time. Every time, whenever you think, you will find new meaning, and new aspects.If you even think, about the movie, on the surface level then also it will make you sad. It will show you the ways to connect your thoughts with the characters' thoughts. You will be able to blend yourself with either of the characters. Either you are trying to be friendly with someone or you are trying to avoid someone. You will find these two aspects in two characters separately.But this movie is more enjoyable when you can connect it with the Irish civil war. Though you won't get many references in the movie hey it's the way of the goodies.I generally don't write movie reviews but this one made me think twice before not considering writing one. So, here it is.

Martin Mcdonagh what a wonderful filmmaker. Every few years he provides another gem of a movie from In Bruges (2008) to Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri(2017) and now The Banshess of Inisherin(2022). One of the best pieces of writing we have seen the past few years. There is a wonderful balance of humour and pathos, just like in 3 Billboards. The cinematography is amazing while the sets and locations are beautiful which further enhance the majestic and tragic nature of the movie.Moving on with the cast.. what can I even begin to describe about the superb acting happening in this film. Bringing back together Colin Farell and Brendan Gleeson truly showed what a beautiful chemistry these two have. Colin Farell gave us one of his best performances, the actor has unquestionable depth and he portrays the majority of his roles masterfully. The supporting cast was top notch as well, with Barry Keoghan giving as subtle, powerful and tragic performance of his character!!Why satisfyingly unsatisfying you might be wondering by now... The reason behind this is that the movie ends in a way that I feel unsatisfied. We never get the big payoff we are waiting for!! Maybe that was a conscious choice, maybe that's exactly what they wanted to do.. maybe so.. but nonetheless it leaves me with a bitter taste in an otherwise masterful film. Maybe the struggle of the characters is the same as the futile civil war across the pond.

reviews.review_title: A heartfelt mixture of Drama And Comedy
reviews.content: From the getgo your are drawn into the island culture and nuances of the town at an intimate level.Excellent performances from Farrell ,Gleeson and Keoghan among others bring this simple, sad and funny story to light. You are taken on a journey of emotion and growth / maturity of the central character. There is a nice balance between comedy and tragedy. Enjoyable and emotional leaving the viewer pondering with questions. Featuring Irish trad music, pubs , a banshee with the Irish civil war as a far backdrop it isn't often we get to throw ourselves back in time of rural Ireland. An insightful cultural timepiece to be enjoyed by many.

reviews.review_title: Your single act of stubboness change the world.
reviews.content: This is a gut wrenching film.This is the saddest movie I have ever seen.Everyone should see it.This film is so moving and show the repercussions of depression and despair. That mental illness and loneliness can have devastating consequences.The performances of every actor in the film was brilliant.The scenery is gorgeous.There is so much feeling in this film.The Summary "Two lifelong friends find themselves at an impasse when one abruptly ends their relationship, with alarming consequences for both of them." is short and to the point as to not spoil the real meaning of the film.Watch it and wait for it to sit with you for days if your are truly human.Your single act of kindness can change the world. I wish Colm Doherty was well enough to accept his help before he changed a man for the worse.

This movie begins with the seemingly inexplicable decision of Colm (Gleeson), to suddenly unfriend his mate of many years, Padraic (Farrell). The movie is set on the Island of Inisherin, which feels like a beautiful but isolated and rudimentary place. The characters both behaved in ways that I found maddening and frustrating, but because the acting was so flawless I began to understand each one's point of view.The unexpected part of the movie for me, was the dynamic between Padraic's sister, Siobhan (Condon) and the son of the local police officer, Dominic (Keoghan). The scene between the two of them by the lake felt like the climax of the movie- with my heart absolutely shattering for Dominic. I wanted to reach through the screen and give him a hug and tell him how he deserved to be loved.I think it's worth a watch, even for the acting alone. It left me thinking about it, long after the ending credits.

It was such a pleasant watch and definitely a penetrating one.The actors were absolutely a blast to watch.Some parts were predictable but only in such a humane way you have felt them in your course of life.The smooth flow of the story leads you to a timid silence at the end, which is something to admire in this film. The psyches portrayed in the movie are the kind of struggle easily missed in usual life, yet you see them almost in every interaction.Overall I think it needs to pick up as much as a blockbuster movie,
It talks about such subtle human aspects and in such short screen time too!Kudos to the writers and the director for that.Such an adaptive change in psyche.

reviews.review_title: A quiet, soft, horror film about the breakdown of male friendship
reviews.content: The premise of this movie is simple: two men (Colm and Padraic) who were best friends experience a drastic change in their lives when one of the men suddenly don't want to be friends anymore.I'm honestly quite surprised at how much I ended up enjoying this movie, it felt like watching a train wreck in slow motion that gradually speeds up until everything ends in an explosive ball of fire. All of the actors and actresses in this were wonderful, and it really touched on how self-destructive male loneliness and the unwillingness to compromise can be. We watch as a man who is known for his niceness turn into a monster because he has little else to sustain himself on outside of this single friendship.Padriac's sister Siobhan was a huge highlight for me. Often playing the mediator between these two men's petty squabbles, she is often the only source of vibrant colour that you can see in the film, and makes for a great contrast with the rest of this dreary Irish island.Throw in a little bit of mysticism, and this movie had me captivated for its entire duration.

This is a great film. To me, this film is about a battle of ideologies. Colm is a realist. Worrying about his legacy, he pushes away his friend to chase immortality through the composition of fiddle tunes. He wants to be like Mozart, remembered not for his personality, but for his accomplishments. He sees life not as a journey, but as a destination.On the other hand, Padraic is a dreamer. Even after Colm demands him to stop speaking to him, claiming that he wastes his time on dull, meaningless conversation, Padraic keeps returning. Not because he thinks he can change his mind, but because he hopes he can change his mind. Although it can be seen as stupidity-I mean, Colm told him that if he kept trying to talk to him, he would cut off the rest of his fingers-he can't stand to lose a friend and hopes he can change him.Padraic isn't really concerned with his legacy, but rather the connections he forms with the people around him. For him, life is about the journey, not the destination. He isn't worried about being immortal or remembered forever, but with being a nice, kind, likable guy.Throughout the film, Colm cuts of his fingers whenever Padraic tries to talk to him as a way to deter him from speaking with him. This is interesting an interesting method, because he essentially relies on Padraic's kindness and his desire to not hurt him. Padraic isn't the one physically cutting them off, but he is inadvertently causing Colm pain.However, once Jenny the donkey chokes on Colm's severed fingers, it switches. Now, Colm has inadvertently caused Padraic pain. As a result, Padraic is forced to see the reality of the situation. Colm is cruel, and his cruelty caused the death of a loved one. We see a switch. The narrative is flipped-now, Padraic doesn't care if Colm gets hurt. He actually wants to hurt him. Now, Padraic is the violent, pessimistic cruel one and Colm feels regret. Thus, Padraic burns his house down, even though Colm was inside.It is important to note that Colm chose to escape. You would think that Colm would be at peace with dying because he cut off his fingers, ending his fiddling career and destroying his chance to create a lasting legacy. However, he chooses to live. This exemplifies the change in him: now, he is no longer obsessed with the destination, but he is willing to live for the journey of life.Don't forget about Dominic's death, which is definitely a suicide. Before his death, Padraic and Siobhan were his only "friends." The town saw him as weird, the odd one out, but Padraic and Siobhan were kind to him. In fact, when he needed to leave home for a bit after his father beat him, he asked Padraic to stay the night. Desperate for a human connection, he even asks Siobhan if she could ever love him. However, after Padraic revealed to Dominic that he made the fiddler go away by telling him that his dad died, Dominic sees the cruel person Padraic is becoming. He no longer wants to be friends with him, and after Siobhan went away, he has no more friends in town. Dominic has an abusive father, no friends, no future, so it's no wonder he killed himself. The fact that the townspeople thought it was an accidental fall shows how no one in town even thought about how he felt, and even in death, the town does not care about Dominic at all.This is a great movie about philosophy, friendship, and the human connections that run our society, and I'd recommend watching it to everyone.

I walked into the movie theater while very upset with work stuff. The movie started and i immediately felt grounded. The movie sucked me in completely.It felt like all of a sudden i connected with the characters very deeply. Especially with Farrell's character and the boy Dominic.You get such a close look to the essence of relationships between different people.The small details of looks, pauses, touches, sarcastic comments etc, all made for a great experience.The scenery provides such depth as well to the whole narrative.A very moving performance from Farrell.Makes you appreciate human relationships.Makes you somewhat hopeful.Would definitely recommend! I'm.

If you enjoyed in bruges then I definitely recommend giving this a go. I say this because you will get an idea of the fantastic chemistry that Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrel have with one another.It's an odd film but that's definitely not a criticism and if I'm being honest it was a breath of fresh air from the over the top Hollywood style flicks we are constantly having shoved down our throatsI can certainly understand why people won't like this film, its not for everyone but the 2 star reviews are not warranted. You have the appreciate it's existence.If you have a dry sense of humour and do not mind slow paced then this will be right up your street.

Banshees of Inisherin is definitely not bad. It's got great writing, good acting and near to perfect mise-en-scene.What it fails at though is going beyond these and communicate key plot elements through moving pictures (which is what cinema artform's all about after all).Evidently, the author is aware of this shortcoming as he (assuming it is) repeatedly throws footage of beautiful natural features such as landscapes and animals with little to no relevance to the plot development.Character development suffers from inconsistencies. They resonate between dumb and smart, ill and sane, real and cartoonish!

reviews.review_title: This might top "In Bruges" for me.
reviews.content: I love the chemistry between Farrell and Gleeson, which is why I adored "In Bruges". While not as zany as "In Bruges", Banshees of Inisherin delivers that McDonagh humor and a beautifully structured story to drip feed you more and more information to keep you invested with a few Impactful moments that shake everything up. There's enough comedy to keep you chuckling while not distracting from the story and themes, as I believe happens in "In Bruges", which is why I believe this now tops it, for me personally.Impeccable writing and direction from McDonagh. I love how the mildly claustrophobic indoor shots contrast with the wide open outdoor shots. Very fitting for the location.It might seem like an odd thing to focus on, but I really appreciated how "real" the livestock and buildings were. They weren't prettied up for the camera. It just felt very honest. Fabulous set design.Great movie. Definitely worth your time.

reviews.review_title: An Extended Metaphor That Goes a Little Too Far
reviews.content: Terrific acting and a wonderful gloomy and lonely depiction of isolated island life in poverty. The story - nominally about a falling out between friends - is really a metaphor for several things, including alienation, depression, dependency ... even the Irish Civil War (I kid you not). It pretty much works, except that the plot goes to a non-believable extreme when Brendan Gleeson's character resorts to cutting his fingers off to prove that he's serious about no longer wishing Colin Farrell's companionship. More serious repercussions follow that ...Kerry Condon gives a strong performance as Colin Farrell's sister and presents a dose of reality among the rest of the characters, each of whom carry their own versions of damage and odd obsessions.Barry Keoghan's performance as Dominic is at once bizarre and wistful and Gary Lydon's as his constable father Paeder gives a strong depiction of suppressed rage and violence that crops up throughout.I would have rated this a 10 as an art-house film but for the less believable aspects. More conventional interpersonal rejection and even violence would have improved the movie without changing anything else at all.

reviews.review_title: A small ordinary people story with universal reach
reviews.content: It is very unusual for a movie to allow you to identify yourself with both the protagonist and the antagonist. But how could we not? Colm (Brendan Gleeson) is also suffering... How do we know? He discloses it at the confessionary. And despite the story being driven by the friendship (or lack of it) between Colm and Pádraic (Colin Farrell), it is the small characters, the priest, the sister, the policeman, his son, the post office lady, and the bartender, that fill the gaps deliberately left in the plot and make the script both compelling and solid. Even the ominous presence of Mrs. McCormick offers us a touch of magical realism and it works; Éire Folklore is full of it.Set in small village in a seemingly parochial islet, off the coast of Ireland, The Banshees of Inisherin deals with ordinary themes such as comradeship, tittle-tattle, farming, daily chores, as well as despair, isolation, hardship, and war. It does it in such a way that makes them universal and relatable to every human being; all of this while we chuckle about the mundane and guiltily giggle, however cruel is what we are witnessing on the screen. But what is dark comedy for anyway, Martin McDonagh the master of it.The breathtaking landscape of the West Coast of Ireland is captured by a crafted camera work. The score by Cart Burwell is eerie and melancholic but used sparsely. The performance by the main actors and supporting roles is prominent. The period costume design blends in smoothly with the landscape and the set decoration. Martin MacDonagh is at his best as scriptwriter and director. The film would be a strong contender in each category at the Oscars but given that Disney-owned Fox gave the film a limited release in most markets and a quick streaming launch The Banshees will probably not get all the recognition it is worth.The film has a baffling end, could it have been any different, do we need to know what happened in the end? Probably not, it would have been too graphic and full of unnecessary exposure. And that is probably what we can take away from the film, it is not the end that matters, but the journey. It is when Colm became all too philosophical about purpose, end and goals that comedy turned into tragedy.This is one of the best films of 2022 the work McDonagh will be ultimately remembered for.

reviews.review_title: So dull you will cut off a finger!
reviews.content: Haaa Great acting beautiful scenery. A bit unsure about my understanding that they were so bored they made their own drama. This movie shows a lifestyle that would drive someone mad from boredom. Its why many who live this way have a hobby or they have a huge family or something to occupy their time. This is beautiful place to film so for that and the acting it is worth watching if you are in the mood for a slow paced story. Well done by all involved. Would love to see a part two. This movie is not for everyone as it is so different from most. I would recommend overall that people watch the movie as it is a peek into a way different life than most of us live.

It's set in 1923. That's right after during the Irish War for Independence, lasting about 1-2 years. Of course, later there's the terrible fighting in Northern Ireland. Lasted 1968-1998.The movie is a reflection of the human condition as is related to the continual violence. I think that's why we hear the gunshots from the mainland and a couple of references to it.The human condition is our failure to empathize with others, including sorrow, show compassion, share in joy or grief, an unwillingness to move on to better our lives. People can get so wrapped up in their own feelings of loneliness and hopelessness, the don't understand others and start a tit-for-tat escalation of events that ultimately "destroy" everyone.These lack of emotions basically reflects the troubles in Ireland in the 20th century.Only until humans learn to rise above their own selfishness can fighting stop.Notes- beautiful landscape, music, and cast. Also, so much is symbolic, not literal.

reviews.review_title: Amazing scenario, great cast, just spectacular!
reviews.content: I nominate The Banshees of Inisherin for a lot of awards but the best scenario award is an award that is earned by this film. I do not know I think films that talk about friendship have a special place in my heart. This is a movie that talks about loneliness, kindness and many more ethical things. It really tocuhed my heart. Such a simple story is written and turned into a movie with a great effort.Also the acting is just awesome. Especially Collin Farell was really great in this film. The supporting actors were amazing too. Also the views were really well placed abd they were like paintings made my a really talented painter.I really want this film to win The Best Scenario Award at the Oscars.

Martin Mcdonagh directs yet another brilliant film. His selection of Farrell and Gleeson was inspired. Two already fantastic actors in their own right, but when their together they feed off of each others' quality.It's a dark comedy, not a Will Ferrell comedy. The tragedy and heartbreak is all too real. Cordon and Keoghan's storylines are immersive and they all come together in the end.The landscape is ravishing, but island life is tough. The isolation. The cabin/island fever. The harshness of life back then was tough enough, but to be on an island just makes it tougher. You need a good spirit to get on in life, and I guess this is why Irish are great linguists and always upbeat. You have to be.One thing to note. I thought it was a contemporary film but it's actually set in the relatively near past.

This is not a comedy, black or otherwise. It is a slow, interesting, bizarre movie with a few chuckles.After reading other reviews regarding the metaphor for the Irish civil war, it makes a lot more sense to me. Life long friends having a falling out. Neither of them seem to fully understand why. The horrible consequence of one of them not listening to the other.I have a great affinity for the Irish and maybe that is why I really enjoyed this movie. The acting was great and the scenery beautiful.This is one of the best movies I have seen in a long time. It is not for everyone, but you might want to give it a chance.

reviews.review_title: You don't know why you like it
reviews.content: I found myself fascinated by this slow paced, somewhat pointless plot. This is a fantastic movie. I wish I knew how to explain why or how it is fantastic. The performances, of course, are great. Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson were...fantastic. But Kerry Condon wasn't fantastic; she was amazing.Watching this film and being drawn to this film reminded me of watching "The Station Agent".If you like "The Station Agent", you will love this movie.The websites state that the plot is some sort of analogy of the Irish-British relationship over the decades.I don't think it is. But that doesn't matter.It's just very, very good.

The Banshees of Insherin is a period Irish film set in 1923 during the Irish civil war centering around the friendship of the two principle characters played brilliantly by Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleason. The story evolves gradually exploring the themes of loneliness, dreams, conflict , and alienation . It speaks to the soul of humanity. The drama is laced with contrary Irish humour and engaging characters. Colin Farrell gives a nuanced performance of a lifetime. He deserves the Academy Award for Best Actor. The supporting cast is outstanding. Kerry Condon plays Colin's sister and Barry Keoghan plays the naive young man who has a crush on her. The cinematography is enchanting. It is film that lingers in both the heart znc thr mind.

The Banshees of Inisherin is an Irish film based entirely in Ireland which is rare to see nowadays, this is one of the many factors that make the movie so popular and appealing. The acting is phenomenal and the cast deserve all the nominations for the respective awards. I think the movie has an interesting and intense deeper meaning that some people may not catch. On the face it's just two lifelong friends who suddenly split due to the attitude of one. The movie has great aspects of comedic relief while it tells a heavy and depressing story. The film has incredible cinematography including breathtaking shots of the Irish landscape. It also tells a very different story than most films, including films about this time in Ireland. Films about this time period in Ireland usually focus on the fighting on the mainland while The Banshees of Inisherin focuses on the isolation of a small island that is clearly dying out with lack of people to replenish the dwindling population. Overall it tells an excellent tale and has great cinematography therefore delivering an excellent claim for the best movie of 2022.

I saw all the award season buzz around this movie, came to IMDB, and saw it had mixed reviews. So I went from high expectations to low expectations. People who have reviewed this as dark comedy are right. I was laughing at the beginning. And then, my laughter turned to tears. My heart just started breaking slowly for Colin Farrell's character, as he tries to negotiate how to keep on living when his friendship has ended. His acting is truly incredible, and he deserves the recognition he is getting. Everyone else does a brilliant job, too. I think this is just one of those movies that if you get it, you get it, and it stays with you. I like dark humor-so maybe that's why I think I got it. And I know this is the sort of movie that will stick with me. Will I ever watch it again? No, probably not, because I don't like to feel sad. But I definitely recommend this movie. Definitely.

reviews.review_title: I think some folks missed the point
reviews.content: The more I read the bad reviews on this movie, the more I began to really love it. Watched it twice so far, and it is still growing on me as probably one of the most unique movies I've seen in a while. Sometimes in life things just happen and there is no reason behind it other than someone made a decision that obviously impacts another party quite deeply. It doesn't have to make sense. And sometimes things don't get resolved. That's just life. I loved the ending of this movie simply because there was no coming back from the situation at hand. I think you'll life thus movie if you've ever lost a good friend or gone through a depression.

reviews.review_title: Everyone got it wrong? It's a Metaphor, a cynical allegory to Irish Civil War
reviews.content:
I'm surprised none has called the great Metaphor, the allegory to this Great Movie:
* Padraic & Colm are *definitely* a metaphor of the 2 Irish fractions Provisional Government of Ireland and the Irish Republican Army (IRA) that were on a civil war between them over the Anglo-Irish Treaty, during 1922 & 23. These previously close friends were now attacking, damaging and killing each other. It make no sense, watching the story unfolding, to be around those specific characters. The reasons are deliberately vague, unexplained, idiotic, persistent and stubborn. There is never a real discussion about it, only hopstility. Just like during a bloody civil war. I'll let you choose which one is which ;-)* Siobhán (Padraic's sister) maybe represents Reason or Wisdom. She's the most educated, wise and tries to resolve conflicts. Despite being strict her self with matters in general. In the end, se departs cause she can't stand the madness. Maybe she represents England or the UK? I leave that all to you!

reviews.review_title: I lost my thumbs from laughter
reviews.content: This is a brilliant film, one that Martin Mcdonagh wrote beautifully. The cast did an amazing job, especially Colin Farrell, Kerry Condon, and Barry Keoghan, all deserving of Oscars. This movie reminded me of why Martin is one of favorites and best working writer/director today.It is truly a hilarious film, but incredibly sad. It became quite unpredictable and honestly the ending is something I didn't expect, but it was fitting for it. The cinematography and score are incredible and also deserve some recognition themselves. It really is a film that makes you start questioning your own everyday life. I really hope that Mcdonagh wins best screenplay for this, if he doesn't for this what will he? If I were to ever make a movie, I want it to be like this.

I've read a few negative reviews calling the film dull and I respect that decision and like any medium there is a certain projection when it comes to a piece of art but all said I loved this film.I wont trad old ground as even the negative reviews acknowledge that the acting and characters are on top of their game (and like many I thought Barry Keoghan was the stand out amongst stand outs) but it's more than that. The beauty of the setting both geographically and temporal hit me in a way no others have this year but ultimately the story that can be read as an examination of mortality, relationship between people, animals and their environment, good and evil, the merits of a simple life, the heartbreak of a break up, the joy and love of family, the positivity of community and faith, the love for friends and family (both human and not human) and why being nice is sometimes enough is what made it for me.Many bemoan the ending and the lack of clear closure and on one hand I agree (though I could argue like many others that that's life for you) but on the other hand a strong part of me read into the ending a clear (or at the very least a hopeful) conclusion that pointed to a future resolution between the main characters that didn't need any more than what was said...."Thanks for looking after my Dog""Anytime"..

The Banshees of Inisherin.This is a proper film. The funniest and saddest I've seen for some time. It summarises the absurdity and conundrum of Irish idealism and violence. I should know, I've lived through it.Humour:- much of it local, many may not catch its hilarity; I bust a gut several times watching this.Acting:- Farrell, Gleeson & Condon all give flawless performances. I'm convinced Brendon Gleeson plays the fiddle here, I always look for acted playing and I can't see it (I play the fiddle myself).Pathos:- so clear. Why do we hate? The Irish are so used to violence (e.g. Ulster's bloody red hand in their flag). For a time we became immune to it. It's worth noting that the number lost during the the recent troubles of Northern Ireland over 30 years was just around twice those lost at sea in the Titanic disaster (a ship built in Belfast). So few. Yet so tragic and pointless.This film is Marmite. Those who hate it will happily watch bubblegum requiring no intellect. We need more thoughtful filmmaking like The Banshees of Inisherin to challenge and spark us.

Scenery 10/10; acting 10/10; story 7/10; film overall 8/10To say why 8/10 might stray into spoiler territory so before that let me mention one goof:.., in addition to all those already spotted by eagle-eyed goof trackers .. I am not one of those but when something just hits me it is difficult to ignore ... the only ones that came into this category were the beer ones plus :
The 2023 roads clearly had to be covered with grit for the filming but then the only tracks that can be seen are the ones the cart has just made .... in every scene ... . A bit like one track of footprints in the snow.Now for the story and possible spoiler :
it is not a very uplifting story (heavy irony)it does not end wellI did not leave the cinema either up-lifted or thoughtful .. and not even miserable ... just "well OK"What I did think throughout but emphasised in the last scene was that it was an allegory for what was going on over on the mainland and that this would never get resolved as stated by Padraic about his situation with Colm ... and in a way this is reflected in current (Feb 2023) negotiations still going on... my other thought was that nothing else got resolved either - not even the policeman's brutality until I remembered the old lady (banshee without the wailing?) said there would be two deaths and she beckoned two people towards her at two different times .. we saw one after he had died .... the other one beckoned near the end was the policeman .. so I guess that did get resolved.

reviews.review_title: Good film but parts are not credible
reviews.content: The action of this film takes place on a remote,craggy island off the west coast of Ireland; so we are in "Father Ted" territory. I was waiting for him to turn up and in fact a priest does arrive on the island and turns out to be quite comical but in a different way.I found the film funny and entertaining until the finger chopping after which it was horrible and unbelievable. I appreciate a parallel was being drawn between the private quarrel on the island and the civil war on the mainland. A country which fights a civil war mutilates itself - yes, but the parallel is not very exact. Both sides are mutilated in civil war but only one party was in the island quarrel and the civil war ended pretty soon but the quarrel was set to drag on endlessly.The incredible parts: 1. Someone whose main interest seems to be playing the fiddle would not mutilate themselves so they could not do so. Vincent Van Gogh cut off his ear not the fingers he used to paint with.2. A donkey would not eat a severed finger and even if it did to choke to death it would have to be stuck in its craw, not its mouth where Padraic finds it.3. No priest (apart perhaps from Father Jack) would say "God does not care for donkeys" as they would know God cares for all his creation.As I write this the Bafta awards are due tonight and I hope this film wins an award for acting or cinematography which were both superb- but not best film or script.

Mild Spoiler alertA fabulous story and very comical. Both main actors play this to the hilt and a massive twist at the end. A clear play on the Irish psyche. Both played it so well, best Colin Farnell film since winters tale, no correction better. A clear play on the southern Irish psyche that isn't over played but so well acted. The filming down played and so real. Ups and lows on so many different levels. Watch it and just adsorb the Irish attitude and the way of life. So way it was acted so poignant that builds throughout the movie, starting with humour and ending with despair and sorrow don't think it will an Oscar but it should.

reviews.review_title: A movie about being rotten by the very life you're living
reviews.content: First of, this movie is a superb combination of cinematography, fantastic acting performances, a very wild sense of storytelling and inevitability of conflicts in human lives.An aging musician in a small Irisih village, realises his life is ending without meaning, purpose or drive, and he tries to put blame on his clueless, gullible life long friend who basically adores their friendship and reacts poorly to the shifting reality.Colm appears to be harsh and very uptight snob at first. But with time, it's quite clear that he's been dealing with Podraic's gullible nature, he's being Podraic's friend for Podraic's own benefit. Podraic is an ignorant villager, who really doesn't accept Colm's new decision. He feels abandoned and discarded, and no matter how clear he's been warned about the situation, he's just trying to lure Colm into conversing with him.But, even though there are other folk than Colm, only person who's getting along with Podraic is the village idiot, Dominic. Whom Podraic doesn't particularly like either.And with this ridicilous cause, the two literally destroy each other's lives. Just like Ireland, with a meaningless squabble starting a never ending disdain, Colm and Podraic, just are making eachother perpetually miserable.

reviews.review_title: You need to be really idle to watch this film
reviews.content: The movie's theme has been set in a way that you will find it interesting for some time due to its scenical beauty and the walls, but later into the movie if you are not enjoying it firsthand then you should probably close it as you are not going to find something in the story.I dont think that this film has been made while keeping a clear message evident...it just shows the strangeness and different personalities of people around us while also highlighting the fickleness of human attitude.If it had not been the excellent acting many of us would have not liked the progression of the plot.SOME PEOPLE JUST LIKE TO LIVE IT BY OTHERS JUST CANT GET ENOUGHT TO TRY.... BOTH CAN BE THE HAPPIEST IF NOT THE STATE OF MIND.

I question if lifelong friendships exist. This was how I sat down with no expectations to watch another weird but fun piece from the trio. I was curious and it did blow me away how Martin McDonagh made it cut through the curtains of our daily apathy.Colm (Brendan Gleeson) could have portrayed us all. Pádraic (Colin Farrell) is adorable and not-at-all-simple character. Dark comedy, it is. Brotherhood is sensitive and painful. Irish way of life and civil war history as a perfect background.Siobhán (Kerry Condon) made every second caring and daring, I love how she's written and played. Dominic's (Barry Keoghan) facial expressions and lines are priceless, the Priest (David Pearse) made confessions tempting again! I enjoyed the dynamics between each character. Casting was an A+.It was absolute pleasure to wonder about those eye-watering green landscapes. The animals melt my warrior heart right at the bottom. Poor Jenny's death was stupid and made me fairly lethal with reckless Colm, putting him on my imaginery death row for sure.Cutting those fingers off and still playing music - that was quite manly. Dancing with the dog - one of the heartwarming moments of the film. Siobhán getting out of Inisherin was like the euphoric point of no return to me.My reason for not giving it a 10 is because it made me sad. I was shouting from the inside. I sweared to myself I won't watch it ever again. I like Colin and Brendan when they can laugh or get weird together. I felt uncomfortable a tiny bit to see them apart. Unnatural to a certain degree.Otherwise, I highly recommend to watch it at least once in your lifetime. Good lesson about human nature. Great glimpse of Éire.

reviews.review_title: Colin Farrell & Brendan Gleeson a Match Made in Heaven
reviews.content: This movie is fantastic. Taking place on a remote Island off of Ireland, in 1923 during the Irish Civil War. We are introduced to two friends in this very small town where word travels fast. Once the conflict of between Colm and Padraic starts, you can truly feel their uncomfortableness for each other. Colin Farrell's worrying about his friend and what has happened is wonderfully done. Also Brendan Gleeson's commit to try to avoid his ex friend is a sight to see. The supporting cast are very well balanced, adding to the unorthodox nature of the friendship's chaos. Also the very traditional Irish slang and conversations are such a delight to behold that keeps you engaged throughout the whole film.

The Banshees of Inisherin is fantastic. Set in Ireland in 1923, during the Irish civil war. This tale tells of two friends who in their own way are having their own civil war. Martin McDonagh lures you in with great shots, amazing actors and humorous and relatable Irish humor.There's something poetic, or Shakespearean about Martin McDonagh's story telling and this story is exactly that. The cast are exceptional, especially Barry Keoghan. In a time of superheros and bad CGI, The Banshees of Inisherin brings cinema back to its best and reminds us that cinema is about storytelling, and not about big budget save-the-day predictable stories.

reviews.review_title: Colin Farrell should literally win an Oscar for this performance!
reviews.content: I also enjoyed the plot, it was quiet nice but not much of a comedy tho. I usually tend not to be that much excited for new movies, but I watched this one as soon as it released because I was kinda hyped for the acting performances!. Also, I would like to talk about how incredible was the cinematography, it got me speechles tbh cuz I was not expecting an 2022 movie to have that great cinematography, color effects and much more!Shortly, this movie gave me back the hypes for other upcoming movies, we want more of these HOLLYWOOD! My opinion is that this movie should AT LEAST win Best Actor, Best Picture, Best Cinematography, and Best Director!

reviews.review_title: "Let's make a movie based on the (bankable) chemistry between Colin and Brendan"
reviews.content: "I have just the vehicle, not much of a story but the Irish American market will love this - I'm thinking Oscars"I mean c'mon, the very title itself "The Banshees of Inisherin" is a marketing ploy if not downright disingenous. Don't get me going on the plot - "Talented musician resorts to chopping fingers off in order to stop boring neighbour contacting him"Producers: hang on a minute, modern audiences do like a bit of blood and gore - no problem, we have 10 fingers to play with - but in a funny way, remember it's a comedy!Doesn't the story feel a little unauthentic to you?OK, in it's defence I hear it's allegorical, so next time write better allegorically. Pretty rural landscapes though.

I know what am going to get when I watch McDonagh. Its not going to be wrapped up in a package with bow. Ultimately I thought the film was about depression. The damage it can do not only to the person but the people around them. They isolate themselves from meaningful relationships. Was he trying to spare his friend in some way from his pain?In the end it causes his friend to change himself from a the nice guy to a spiteful, vengeful and angry person. I guess it touches on depression specifically in men. They don't talk or open up as much. It just grows and festers and causes pain.I really loved the film. Also if you're ever around Mayo in the summer time the island is beautiful.

This is my first review on imdb and I'm happy its this one. The characters and actors were perfectly cast and written. Though I believe the island is the most important cast member. The story of a failed friendship that loses control in this isolated part of the world is one of the best I've seen. Colm is hard to like and Padraic is a loveable simple man, they are polar opposites. Films like this don't come along to often. The theatre laughed throughout and clapped at the end. Thank you Martin McDonagh for this masterpiece, if you are reading this Martin just know you've made a wonderful film. A proper treat.

Visually, the scenery is amazing. It was recorded on the Aran Islands and also on Achill Island. Most of the filming done at Keem Bay. I believe the pub was created for the movie and doesn't exist but the houses are real. It's a shame too because it's a pub you'd love to have a few pints in while looking out at the sea contemplating.Full of humour with some dark parts, I think this movie had it all. It's clear the two main characters are an allegory for the Irish civil war. Beautifully done.It captures how contrary, bleak and depressing living on an island off the west coast of Ireland can be.Well worth seeing.

reviews.review_title: A film that lives up to the hype
reviews.content: Given that I wasn't as enamoured with In Bruges as I probably should've been, I went into this film with some reservations. However early on I realised this film would be a different story.The two lead actors clearly have great chemistry together and this is reflected in some of the non verbal acting that takes place throughout the film. Barry Keoghan's slightly unhinged role gives me great expectation for his role as The Joker in the upcoming Batman sequel.Beautifully shot, the cinematography really lends itself to demonstrating what rural life is really like.Set against the backdrop of the Irish Civil War (which I believe is a metaphor for the entire film) this is a must watch black comedy.

Top-tier acting, yet a dull storyline. Both colin and brendan outdid themselves, honestly all the cast were quite good.However i was waiting for something to happen, but it didnt.2 hours of runtime could ve been so much better. No buildup, just 2 mental friends, also i dont get padraic suddenly didnt become a nice person no more? Like he woke up and choose to be a different person? I was really hooked on the movie yet the flow of events did disappoint.I know its character development but it cant come out of the blue and we would clap after.Dont waste your time if you r looking for something intriguing, better watch anything else.

Nothing really happens. From the moment I sat down to watch this movie in a half empty cinema- I knew this would be the case. But I also knew that I would never be bored. The cinematography alone was captivating and the recurrent feature of animals as almost part of the cast was at times amusing and also heartbreaking.This was never going to be a feel good Hollywood style romantic portrayal of Ireland
Yet it managed to convey subtly the historical period in which it was set whilst focusing on the personal stories of the main characters with a dark humour. The dialogue being at times hilarious and hilariously tragic.Barry Keoghns Dominic is eerily reminiscent of John Mills Michael in Ryan's daughter but gets some show stealing jokes despite being the ultimate victim- in the personification of loneliness and desperation of the lives of the islanders which the film conveys almost painfully at times
A great cast, superior acting and a witty and moving script makes for a thought provoking, funny and poignant watch and I would highly recommend it.

Utterly pointless film in which nothing happens and even less makes sense.Unless you are interested in the scenery and the odd funny line you'll find nothing in the film.You can relish the absolute misery that seems to exist on the island in everything except when a resident amputates their own fingers which is pain free and results in minimal blood loss.You'll be confused by the way that everyone treats seriously troubling behaviour as though it's normal and how they fail to respond to emergency situations.Don't bother waiting for the end for an explanation, the film just gives up having barely moved on from the first 15 minutes.AVOID AVOID AVOID.

Thinking this to be the usual tale of endearing Irish characters in a charming Irish tale, I tuned in to this movie with those expectations. Impressed as I was by the actors' performances, five minutes into the story, I was thrown instead into an intense experience of relationships tossed by the wind into torrents of dispair. Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan impressed me with their portrayals of people wrangling with emotions and unfulfilled wishes. Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrel had drawn my attention before by remarkable roles wherein they slipped effortlessly it seemed into Regional American dialects, especially Gleeson in "Cold Mountain." Their chracters' actions and motives in "Banshees" defied analysis time and time again, though Condon's character brought a note of triumph into the story.I've never been to Ireland and am not familiar with true Irish English speech. What held me transfixed was the dialogue here: unlike anything I had heard before. Even when I lost patience and sympathy with the characters' behavior, my ears remained tuned to sound of it. I'll definitely be watching (and listening) to "Banshees of Inisherin" again.

reviews.review_title: A Good Play Captured On Film
reviews.content: This was a haunting movie with great performances by the entire cast. The scenery was as much a palpable character as the people, captured incredibly well by meticulous cinematography.I liked the off-beat plot, the unusual setting, the dark humor, and the film being OK with itself eschewing the traditional Hollywood fare.I am by no means a movie snob, but do enjoy a film that stays with me long after I've watched it. Banshees is one of those movies where I want to talk with others who have seen it and discuss their points of view.The title of my review captures the feel - It's like a play captured expertly on a rugged and beautiful landscape.This may not be for everyone, but I recommend giving it a try and experiencing it for what it is!

The Banshees of Inisherin is equal parts fascinating, hilarious, and brutally dark. A provocative story acted by the best in the business in one of the most beautiful settings in the world cannot disappoint. The idyllic setting is a stunning contrast to the hellish behavior of the characters. Blue waves crash on the rocky cliffs of the Irish shoreline. The characters walk between rock walls to cozy cottages warmed by fireplaces. If nothing else I would've enjoyed this film for the scenery.Like its setting, the world class cast is 100% Irish. Colin Ferrell and Brendan Gleeson team up again and are joined by Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan in this tragicomedy. While Colin Ferrell is outstanding, Barry Keoghan (playing Dominic) was my favorite performance. The way he constantly sways and moves like an ocean bay perfectly represents the innocence and impulse of a young boy. He couldn't help but wear his feelings on his sleeve like a child answering to a cookie theft accusation. Just watch him move in this scene with Kerry's character, Siobhan. You can tell he's making it all up as he goes. And when he washes up on shore, it's thought he must've slipped in as he was an unloved and abused boy who couldn't avoid the rocks wherever he ventured.My favorite part of the film is the plot. It takes the viewer through the darkest caves of the human psyche. The two main characters, Colm and Padraic, each illustrate fascinating psychology.A feud breaks out between the two inseparable men on a remote island. Largely due to no better option, a simpleton who connects suspiciously well with his farm animals and a thinker and musician who idealizes the great artists of history find friendship and enact a routine of heading to the pub to waste away time. One day, Colm abruptly decides he doesn't want to be friends with Padraic because "he's too dull" and "talks for hours about animal poop." Padraic, along with the entire gossipy town, are in disbelief and suspect a jest. But when Colm proves his sincerity by threatening, and then following through with, cutting off his fiddle-playing fingers, the audience joins the characters in sheer bewilderment.Why would an old man suddenly reject his long-time best friend? Colm admits Padraic hadn't done anything and was the same person he'd always been. But while the audience searches for an understandable motive, the answer hides in Colm's existential mentality.Colm describes his desire to publish music that generations to come will remember him by. "Everyone knows Mozarts name." He destroys his closest relationship seeking everlasting connection. In an Irish halcyon, Colm's wandering mind conjures up an existential fear of death and loneliness. "I just have the tremendous sense that time is slipping away from me Padraic. And I think I need to spend the time I have left thinking and composing." Like his existence, his cherished friendship with Padraic would also be coming to an end soon. He decides to dedicate himself to music in a last ditch attempt to be loved after he passes.But why the finger? Perhaps his tendency for the abstract, symbolic, and historic drove him to self-mutilate like Vincent Van Gogh. He did what he wanted to become: a famous artist edging on insanity. The gruesome act also materializes his belief that Padraic is preventing him from pursuing music: by cutting the fingers of his playing hand whenever Padraic talks to him proves his point that he must end the relationship in order to play.Padraic illustrates a more relatable human tendency: revenge. A man revered as "one of life's good guys'' highlights how easily corruptible people are when subjected to emotional pain. As Colm softly but directly tells Padraic he has other interests and no longer wants to be friends, the pain of abandonment slowly deteriorates Padraic into a deceptive, angry murderer. Hurt people hurt people.

If you a looking for a remake of In Bruge this is not it. Deeper more disturbing than 3 Billboards or 7 psychopaths - a slow burn with some brilliant comic moments. One man Colm (Brendan Gleeson) does not want to be friends anymore with Padraic - (Colin Farrell) both sad and funny this film delivers - slowly.Great performances, a ravishing landscape and a plot that, it seems to me, is about mental health, isolation and escape. Not an easy watch but, I think, you would be very hard hearted not to be moved and be left thinking about the story long after the final credits have rolled.The supporting cast is superb, as is the score.Martin McDonagh proves himself once again to be a cinematic tour de force.

reviews.review_title: Superb once the melancholy wore off
reviews.content: A cold and windy island by the atlantic ocean, is a perfect setting for this heartfelt story.In its essence, its a story of lonliness and depression during war times. I imagine being there during a time without civil unrest would have been rought as it is.Despite it being a period drama, the themes are still relevant to modern times. I also like that it's something different to the usual "message" that's pushed out by Hollywood studios these days.I personally love films with a "message" if it's one that would be tricky to engage mass audiences. Not to say this isn't inclusive because I really believe that every human on earth can relate to this message. It's new and refreshing to our screens, yet nothing new in reality.I understand this won't be everybody's cup of tea, but if you are going into this expecting major comedy like 'In Bruges', you may be disappointed, although that's not to say it isn't funny. At times, I'm laughing to myself at the subtle humour embedded in conversations, almost like a relief from the seriousness of the subject matter.Even though it's an absurd portrayal of a common friendship, it's very easy to believe this is how things really are in any dynamic between people, especailyl when faced with death and lonliness. These feelings make us do crazy things, and even though it's funny, it's also quite sad.

Prior to watching "The Banshees of Inisherin" with my wife I had few preconceptions concerning it. All I knew wass that it had been pretty heavily advertised and that there was some generally positive "buzz."We watched it partly due to having been exposed to the advertising and the actors making the rounds of the talk shows....But even more so, we watched it because when we ran across it on Hulu, it was listed as a "Comedy."So, we settled in for some lighthearted "Irish Comedy" entertainment. With "Banshee" in the title, I was figuring it would have to do with Irish myths/fables/folklore. I figured it might be a little like "Darby O'Gill and the Little People" but perhaps less "stereotypical" and more aimed at modern audiences than Darby O'Gill which was made back in 1959.I don't think my wife or I laughed even once. It is possible that a nervous giggle may have escaped our lips, but no genuine laughs.After watching it, I finally read some reviews to see what others had to say. I was dumbfounded when one review actually talked about the movie having several "laugh out loud moments."
What movie were those reviewers watching?They all agreed that "The Banshees of Inisherin" was a "Dark Comedy" and I'll agree wholeheartedly that it was "Dark." Period.I like a lot of Dark Comedies. "Dr, Strangelove" is perhaps my favorite. Nuclear Armageddon is certainly a dark topic, but there were many, many laugh out loud moments in "Dr. Strangelove." In recent years, "Knives Out" was certainly funny, though "dark."Then there are movies that really push the envelope, like the South Korean movie "Parasite." It is incredibly funny until it spirals into complete tragedy and bloody mayhem. But the entirety of "Parasite" is a social commentary on income inequality and related issues.. Everyone should probably watch it once... and that is likely enough for anyone.So, I really can enjoy a dark comedy, but for me "The Banshees of Inisherin" was NOT a dark comedy.To its great credit, "The Banshees of Inisherin" is superbly acted, beautifully filmed and highly evocative of its setting on an Irish island during the war for independence in the 1920's. It might have worked as a travelogue of an Ireland now past, but all the action takes place in so few locations that it would've felt like a play if they hadn't occasionally had exterior panoramic shots. Aside from the panoramas, the entirety of the movie takes place in or near 3 houses and a pub, with one of the houses shown only briefly once.But, the houses and the pub are beautifully rendered and filmed!!Unfortunately, all the action at these four locations could've been done in maybe 50 minutes of screen time, leaving over an hour of runtime to brood about how not funny it really is.But the acting is GREAT!!!For those that enjoy the movie, the script would also be a highlight.Intellectually, I can enjoy the film as a character study involving friendship and growing old as well as a commentary on the dynamics of a small village. To some extent the film can be viewed as a metaphor for the Irish "troubles", which are marked in the film occasionally by the sounds of distant gunfire on the mainland. But that metaphor is limited and doesn't do justice to the centuries long conflict in Ireland. So, in the end the movie is mainly a character study concerning friendship and growing old.Since the end of the friendship occurs early in the movie, I don't think it is much of a spoiler to mention it here. But it does mean that the "friendship" part of the movie is really concerning the tragedy of friendship lost.The part about growing old is mainly about one of the many tragedies of age. Since it would be a spoiler to mention the exact element, I won't explain it here. But, the movie does a fair job of examining it.So, for me the movie was more of a tragedy than any form of comedy, dark or otherwise.Perhaps I find no humor in the film because I am old enough to directly understand and empathize with the specific problems the movie discuss.The fact that so many reviewers talked about it as a "dark comedy" makes me think that there has been a substantial change, for the worse, in modern sensibilities.In my view, even a young person should be able to view a movie like this and empathize with the characters and the problems they face. If so, their view of the movie would likely be similar to my own, though perhaps with slightly less pathos due to their distance from old age. But nonetheless, the movie should be dark for anyone with empathy.Being able to laugh at this movie seems to me to be a level of disconnectedness bordering on the sociopathic. But in an era where a Presidential candidate can mock the physical disability of a reporter "in good clean fun" for many of his supporters, perhaps I should not be surprised.I can understand laughing to keep from crying: I often look for a hidden comedic element in the tragedies of my own life. But when it is someone else's life, I'm only going to laugh at their affliction if and when they do so.... and only if they seem to want me to do so.So, for me "The Banshees of Inisherin" is one of a number of movies I can appreciate intellectually as a incredible work of art, but one I would not care to view again. This CAN be a high accolade. I'd put "Parasite" and "Grave of the Fireflies" both in this category. I think EVERYONE should watch and discuss those movies, not DESPITE them being absolutely emotionally devastating, but because they are. "The Banshees of Inisherin" does not rise to that level. But if you are willing to watch a depressing movie to appreciate fine acting, beautiful cinematography and overall craftsmanship, then have at it.If it provokes belly laughs, or laugh out loud moments... please explain it to me. But, don't expect me to agree.

reviews.review_title: An introspective examination of friendship in isolation
reviews.content: The Banshees of Inisherin, directed by Martin McDonagh, explores the complex dynamics of friendship set against the backdrop of a remote Irish island. The film follows the relationship between two men, Padraig and Colm, as it deteriorates due to their differing personalities and expectations. Padraig is portrayed as a simple-minded individual, while Colm is depicted as a introspective and talented fiddle player.The film delves into the themes of loneliness, repressed emotions, and the difficulty of communication, themes that are also explored in other works such as Kelly Reichardt's "Old Joy" and Yorgos Lanthimos' "The Lobster". Despite a lack of typical filmic spectacle, such as chase scenes or grand speeches, The Banshees of Inisherin effectively employs a slow and deliberate pace to create a sense of isolation and tension. A particularly striking scene in the film sees Colm taking drastic measures to sever ties with Padraig, even at the cost of his own musical abilities.In conclusion, The Banshees of Inisherin is a thought-provoking examination of the fragility of friendship, offering a unique perspective on the difficulties of adult relationships.

Powerfully written and powerfully performed by a cast without the faintest hint of fear as they go for broke even when they stand still. Beautifully filmed, with a musical score that deserves an Oscar, so quiet and laconic it penetrates your skin so stealthily you never notice until it threatens to kill you.Its story of despair on an Irish island and the break in a long friendship builds inexorably, if minutely, to a devastating climax in which pain and grief must exact, with the Irish troubles as a distant but insistent background.
