The need for human connection battles with the desire for artistic space in one instance and the hope for a fulfilling life in another.

reviews.review_title: Excellent- What REAL movies are all about.
reviews.content: One of the best movies I've seen in a very long time. There's a reason people are saying they say they love it but they don't tell you much about it- and you shouldn't read about it before hand.If you remember and love what Hollywood movies used to be like before Marvel ruled, this is what you've been looking for. I've read reviews by a lot of young people and they just don't get it. And that's a shame. I highly recommend and hope you enjoy it as much as I did.The story, the writing, the characters are all perfect as are the actors portraying them.It's the type of movie you will want to talk to someone about afterward, It's that good and meaningful.

I don't remember watching a film with so many outstanding acting in the recent years. All of them deserves their nominations for the Academy Awards and all the other awards, and some of them deserves to win in their categories, specially Colin Farrell (I didn't see "The Whale" yet). The screenplay is also mind blowing, very sensitive, with a lot of unexpected turn of events. The score, written by the great Carter Burwell, is wonderful. And technically, the film is really really well produced. Concluding, it's a true masterpiece, a superb work of art. Now, if your thing is more the classic american/hollywoodian/pasteurized movies, you'll probably prefer something like EEAAO, Avatar or the new Top Gun.

reviews.review_title: A clever way to make feel for
reviews.content: I watched the film at a small cinema in Cesis, Latvia.Expecting to see a funny and intelligent play of opposites like "In Brouges", I was lured into the beautiful world of clear and strong emotions of what I perceived as two men with the autistic spectrum and one without it. The latter wants to cut ties with what he sees as his drinking buddy being too dull for him.I loved the Irish accent and culture in the film. The nature and historic setting is truly a charm and an instant relief from the modern urban-centered way of live.Being an English teacher, I especially enjoyed the way everyone talks - their speech melody, choice of words, when arguing. A the silence - the nice times before radios and music records arrived.A must see, to my mind.

Read the reviews with ratings of 6 and below, and you have my take on this movie. For me, the acting and cinematography are what made it worthwhile, I join those who single out Barry Keoghan for special praise, and that says a lot, given the company he's in. But the story line left me cold. There simply is no there, there. Just a lot of episodes that ultimately lead nowhere, and leve you with a hollow feeling at the end.What I find striking is how the reviews avoid noting the specifically horrifying act that certainly rivets your attention but is so outlandish and incapable of being committed in real life, it reinforces the sense that the movie is wandering down dead ends, never reaching a climax.

reviews.review_title: Great acting of interesting characters with beautiful sceneries
reviews.content: Acting is good from all actors and actresses with the backdrop of a beautiful Irish landscape looks. The characters are mysterious and interesting. The film does manage to keep you interested despite not much happening at glance. I love how the movie shows also how important animals can be for people. There's a layer to the movie that is not very obvious, perhaps referring to domestic political troubles. I'd say it is different and a good movie, but I certainly wouldn't classify it as a "must watch" or "mind blowing". Yet I understand why some may or may not like this movie, I'd suggest to watch it with no expectations and you will enjoy it.

Gleeson & Farrell are superb. Kerry Condon and the supporting cast were perfect. Even the donkey played a blinder!A wonderful film punctuated with dark, Irish humour and sharp observation. It studies the complexities of human interaction around a very simple conflict. Many laugh out loud moments show what a great script can do. The cinematography portrays both a bleak and beautiful setting that help to bring out the best of the characters.Before I watched it I wondered how they were going to fill 2 hours with what seemed a disagreement between 2 grouchy men. How wrong I was - the time flew by and at the end I wanted more.

The film was filled with every range of emotion and there was a sense of connection to the characters. And while the acting by Martin McDonagh and Colin Farrell is brilliant, the ending feels abrupt and chaotic. Perhaps it is a good sign that I wanted more out of the story!I also did feel that the scenes did have interesting transitions. The transitions were frequently filled with scenery of the Irish landscape with Irish folk music playing. Although the scenery and the music were beautiful, it made the scenes feel somewhat disconnected from each other.Overall, the actors/actresses did a wonderful job with their roles, but I felt that the ending didn't fully satisfy what I had hoped for.

reviews.review_title: Powerful, effective, thoughtful and interesting cinema
reviews.content: A film with deeper meaning that, on the surface level, serves as a powerful and effective metaphor for the Irish Civil War that provides it's backdrop but also seems to ruminate on the concept of loneliness, identity (of oneself and how we're viewed by others) and the general idea of "being a (good) man". The slow-burn plot does come off as a little "artsy-fartsy" but a pair of outstanding lead performances by Colin Farrell and Kerry Condon power it towards it's compelling directions in the second hour, with extremely good support from Barry Keoghan and a captivating, if unlikeable, character performance from Brendan Gleeson. The direction is full of lots of little moments that I could analyse for hours (when entering Colm's house Padraic places his face in a mask seemingly symbolising the mask the men have been putting on masking true feelings and deeper sadness at their core). I really came to care for the characters (Padraic & Siobhan in particular) and was very moved in some emotional moments with them that I wouldn't want to spoil. Weirdly despite Siobhan's assertion that men's foibles are boring the movie itself didn't seem that way to me, though it does reinforce her view in other, deeper ways ("You don't care who's being executed?"). A thing of visual beauty that hides the oppression of the island (another mask?) whilst being a very interesting, well-acted and thoughtful meditation that's certainly not a feel-good movie but doesn't leave me at least feeling depressed or angry, more appreciative and understanding with a sense of wanting to talk more about what I've seen.

WHAT AN AMAZING MASTERPIECE! I REALLY ADMIRED THIS MOVIE.We know the directors and leading actors from the movie " in Bruges". So both movies are really powerful, admirable movies.I want to write my some opinions, this movie is for everybody but at the same time not for everyone. Because everyone can understand the story, but for seeing special details, you must be film-lover, real one!This movie contains lots of deep, meaningful messages. For example we must care all creatures. The other one is don't break a heart with toughness, rude words. Because you can't imagine how she(he) can affect by these words.So thanks a lot for this movie, dear Martin Mcdonagh!

Cinematography is incredible. I would expect as such for a film taking place in coastal Ireland.That being said, the storyline is tedious, repetitive, and frustrating. It feels like you're watching two toddlers argue, seemingly resolve their conflict, then start the same argument up again. The issue is that they aren't able to communicate and explain themselves without one walking away or yelling over the other.The protagonist's sister offers the only meaningful character development and growth. The rest of the characters are static, plain, and simple minded.Albeit entertaining portions, I would not rewatch or recommend. There's better things to do with your time, like count blades of grass.

reviews.review_title: Friend v. Friend. An Uncivil War.
reviews.content: To like this movie, you don't have to be Irish. You don't need to have visited Connemara or the Aran islands. You don't need to have seen Becket's Godot or read Synge. A knowledge of The Seventh Seal might help, or an appreciation of Carter Burwell's efforts on Coen bros. Films. You don't need to know that in real life Brendan Gleeson is an accomplished traditional musician (fiddle). Perhaps the biggest drawback will be a total ignorance of the existence in history of The Irish Civil War 1922-23.I watched The Banshees Of Inisherin with a friend who was oblivious to most of the above; they enjoyed it.This film is about island life. It's parochial in the extreme and wastes no time in exposing the darkest sides of a compressed, incestuous lifestyle on a remote island, off a remote island on the western fringe of Europe.This film is about rejection by one of two very close friends of the other. It's about the reaction and development of that reaction by the spurned party. It leads to a complete and irreconcilable split and reveals in the final scenes the allegory that has been hinted at throughout. On the little island they are re-enacting what is happening across the water. Friend v friend; brother v brother. The Civil war is entering its last stages in 1923 and The Free State army are rounding up the last of the '' irregulars'' in Galway. The war hasn't touched Inisherin but the RIC man turned Civic Guard is happy to take money to attend a firing squad, no matter who was shooting whom.I've studied this period in history extensively ( my dad took part in both The War of Independence and The Civil War in Cork).In my opinion this movie is a masterpiece. I long ago gave up on the Academy as a trustworthy arbiter of cinematic quality. Their list of poor decisions is extensive. Nevertheless, I would love to see the cast and crew rewarded with global recognition for a project that brought me much enjoyment, food for thought and reflection.

reviews.review_title: "If All You Have is Something Nice to Say, Then Don't Say Anything At All"
reviews.content: Changes the old adage into something rare and powerful - truth, art, freedom of expression, individuality, honesty and autonomy ought to be valued over politeness, pleasantries and meaningless chatter.Then again, unless you're a "Mozart," why not just have a pint and enjoy the ride with those around you?Brilliantly shot and performed. Colin Farrell is to McDonagh as DiCaprio and De Niro are to Scorsese, and rightfully so. From Penguin to this, Farrell can do it all.I'm not Irish, but I used to live next to two authentic Irish pubs in NYC and the dialogue definitely brought me back "like."Fantastic flick.

This film is a masterpiece.But why?First of all, of course, you have to mention the cinematic aspects. The camera shots of the landscape of the Irish village, the incredibly good acting performances, especially by Colin Farell and Brendan Gleeson (what else could you expect), but also the supporting roles. Barry Keoghan, who plays the role of Dominic Kearney, an insecure, naïve character broken by his environment, is particularly noteworthy.But all this was to be expected in a film by Martin McDonagh anyway.What makes the film so powerful, however, is the unique story and the messages that are so suptily and creatively delivered. Of course, it's about friendship. And the meaning that friendship and the loss of friendship can do to you. But this is only the surface and serves as the basic structure to drive the story forward. Rather more, the story is about what the isolation from the outside world is doing with the character of a human being. A small village, isolated from the outside world. Each citizen is marked by loneliness and by the lack of human relationships and diversity. What happens to a person when he is "trapped" in his wasteland all his life without any prospect of love, variety, events. I do not want to reveal too much. But when the only person in the village who still has the desire and openness to the world in her, leaves the village, everything collapses. The people are broken and this is so subtly and incidentally communicated by Martin McDonagh. Be it through the big emotional importance that animals play ( hints of bestiality, the donkey's name is Jenny,...), incredibly funny dialogues and characters that are on the verge of complete madness (the old woman, is she a clairvoyant, a witch or just gone mad?).The great thing about the film is that it has so many interpretations and makes you think, while, by the way, is incredibly funny. It is a must see for everyone who wants to witness a more than clever and funny movie!

reviews.review_title: A perfect of example of the power of a Writer/Director
reviews.content: "Once there were two friends. Suddenly, one of them stopped talking to the other and needs silence between them. His friend is perplexed and dosen't know what to do to gain him back."Consider this the major theme of a story. Can anyone make a full movie of it? If yes, how good can anyone make a movie out of this? Yet writer/director Martin McDonagh has converted this simplest storyline into an brilliant movie.The performances of each and every actor in the movie is commendable. Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson and Kerry Condon are impeccable. Moreover, the character of a young boy portrayed by Berry Keoghan is marvellous.

What an amazing movie!!!!! It is very sad and funny. Takes you through so many emotions. Touches so many important subjects like mental health (especially in men) , loneliness, friendships, domestic abuse, families, animals, dreams, death and meaning of life. I can't recommand this movie enough. Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson is just phenomenal!!!!!Acting is very good. Movie which definitely worth watching again.Really hope the movie will gets loads of recognition for acting, directing, writing and cinema photography!The views are spectacular and obviously the Irish accent I just love.

Martin McDonagh's The Banshees of Inisherin is an existential black comedy about male friendship and loneliness, which begins with a seemingly trivial plot and absurd situations, but develops in dark tones, towards a violent end and tragedy. The film opened the Auteur Film Festival in Belgrade, where it came after two awards in Venice and critical acclaim. Nevertheless, it is a step backwards for McDonagh.When compared to his previous film Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri, McDonagh went back to the themes and atmosphere of his early stage plays, such as The Cripple of Inishmaan and The Lieutenant of Inishmore. The Banshees of Inisherin clearly continues this line, taking place on the undeveloped, fictional island of Inisherin during the Irish Civil War.While cannons thunder on land, Inisherin lives its primitive rural life by the ocean. Simple island lad Pádraic Súilleabháin (Farrell) can't come to terms with the fact that his best friend Colm (Gleeson) no longer likes him and won't sit with him in the local pub. The violinist Colm realized that his time was running out and that in his old age he wanted to dedicate himself to composing, in order to leave a mark behind him, and not to useless chatting with boring Padraic. Padraic's sister Siobhan, played brilliantly by Kerry Condon, is aware of the backwardness of the island and her education, self-awareness and resolute nature emphasize the problems of rural and male stubbornness that do not allow progress and improvement of life.Besides the masterful way in which Farrell, Gleeson and Condon play silly scenes and utterly impossible and absurd dialogue, the atmosphere of rural Ireland in the 1920s is the best element of the film.Director of photography Ben Davis captured the beauty of the landscape of the Irish island in dynamic totals, tracking and crane shots, while we get a sense that under the greenery and rocks and the apparent calm of the ocean live the dark forces of loneliness, cruelty, restlessness and dark banshee demons that herald death. The music is excellent, but not Carter Burwell's original score, too illustrative and ambient, but diegetic Irish folk music performed by Colm or his music students in a pub. This authentic depiction of the music of the Irish countryside during the Civil War is a burst of kinesthesia and life in an otherwise overconstructed film.That's why for McDonagh, at least in my eyes, Banshees of Inisherin is a film of mannerism: this is his In Bruges in the space of his theater. Those who don't mind that mannerism will certainly enjoy the film more.

reviews.review_title: sorry to crash the party, movie blows
reviews.content: This movie was worse than Quintet which I saw in the 70s. I want to warn anyone thinking of watching this that the theme and story are retold in a much more realistic manner even given its circa 1923 in many other great and average movies out there. The use of odd plot events attempt to shock the extent of someone at their true wits end. Remove that utter nonsense and recast as what we would see as personal sabotage or whatever all of the great reviews here in imdb and there is nothing there. You will be disappointed. The way the movie ends, you feel ripped off. Great cast but they couldn't salvage a poor storyline.

I love a dark comedies! And this is a superbly made and beautifully shot film. But I honestly feel a little emotionally traumatised after watching this. If you are expecting anthe In Bruges, then think again. This is one of the darkest and most bleak films i have seen in a long time. It's definitely not for the faint hearted. But it is still a fantastic movie. The acting on all sides was superb. The scenery was breathtaking. The story line was heart breaking and authentic. It definitely takes you on an emotional rollercoaster. But I may have to go watch a little Disney now before I go to bed!!

The movie starts with Pàdraic a man living with his sister on an island off the west coast of Ireland. When one day he apprehend that his long last friend Colm wants to cut their friendship. Although we only know one perspective from the side of Pàdriac it seems that Colm and his kindness are no longer in touch with him. As the movie unfolds things get more disturbingly violently from both of them. Colm is willing to harm himself in order to make Pàdriac stay out of his life but Pàdriac wants explications. A movie about the realism of the world we are living How someone can change jerkily from a day to another and how tragically far can people's mind go to implement this kind of vicious behavior.

This is a masterpiece, but I am afraid if you haven't lived in UK or Ireland you won't get it or appreciate it.The acting is Oscar worthy, the scenery and costumes are immaculate.Humour is incredibly witty, dialogue extremely well written.I could watch another three hours of this film, I wouldn't mind if it was ten hours long.But as I said earlier if you havent grown up in Great Britain, Ireland Scotland or England you really wont enjoy this film half as much.I feel most of the negative reviews are from Americans that simply cant grasp this film or its humour, which is understandable.I loved it!

I started to watch this thinking I wouldn't finish. I kept getting pulled in by the dark comedic lines. The acting was wonderful, every actor was perfectly chosen, now one of my favorite movies with Colin. My husband normally wouldn't like a movie like this, and falls asleep even with action films; this wasn't the case here. I didn't find this depressing at all as some say, a bit sad at times, but most movies are. The storyline is a bit odd, but I'm not from the 20's living on an isolated island.Amazing location, I recognized several areas in Ireland. The animals were also a nice plus to this movie.

Banshees of inisherin packs a solitude punch, rare these days how beautifully iceland atlantic is portrayed with environment sour due to friendship wrecking emotions, humans and animals alike caused by emotions weighing equal to straws engulfing nein's🌾
it is indeed a unique experience embodying solitude, heartbreak, unfulfillment, friendship or the lack of it, in the backdrop of a beautiful yet melancholic landscape. Do checkout martin mcdonagh earlier work. Way he uses colin and brendan is phenomenal, in all the roles. Defines a fine line in all his movies which i would say are digital plays. Need to make a endless thread on all his pieces.

Beautiful as all Irish movies are. Some fantastic performances and some really goofy ones to move things along.Awareness of the metaphor intended is really necessary to understand the movie. Fine, I can look it up. Perhaps if the Irish Civil War was of more immediate interest to me the metaphor would have been more riveting. I wasn't moved to go do a deep dive on a singular event in order to more fully enjoy the film.Brendan Gleason was amazing, But the Colm character was still incomprehensible. The character wasn't a very fully realized human being to have such deep conviction that necessitated such gross violence. So the weird self mutilation, to make clear what wasn't even clear to him, was just jarring. I think more can be said about futility than, "it's futile," or that crazy people do destructive acts.

Padraic on his way to burn down Colms house. The policeman, drunk and blind with rage and sadness over the loss of his son (of which he blames Padraic, even though it's his own fault), stops him and confronts him.Cop: "You. You killed my son."
Padraic: "I think that was yourself, like." "Now go out of my way."Padraic wants to drive on with his wagon, but gets pulled off by the cop, who starts beating him up badly.The horse cart drives on without Padraic on it.Outside of Colms house, his dog (who is left outside so he wouln't burn when Padraic sets fire to the house) notices the commotion and runs up to the fight. He gets kicked by the policeman and runs off again.He goes to Colm at the house and tries to get his attention. But he's not interested.Finally Colm goes up the road. Padraic is on the ground in a bad shape and the policeman is still kicking him.The Cop notices Colm and tells him to go away. Colm looks at the bleeding, half dead Padraic and takes a hit at the policeman. He knocks him over. Accidently he falls badly, hits his head open on a rock and dies.-- cut --next scene:Colm and Padraic are standing next to eather other, blindfolded and ready to be executed.Colm: "What was it again?"
Padraic: "What was what again?"
Colm: "What was it again, you found in your pony's sh*te?"pause,
fade to darkthe end.

Most of the movies that coming out now a day I don't know what's happening in the cinema, but most of the films are weak, cliche and don't worth watching, but Banshees of inisherin have something to say.Banshees of inisherin is an amazing movie with great performances of actors.It's a sad, funny, mysterious and... movie you gonna love it, I recommend it to you.I think after watching
Banshees of inisherin you need to give yourself time and think about it and try to understand the movie.It's a masterpiece and this could be a great choice for weakened to watch with your friends, I recommend it to you.

reviews.review_title: A fine film in the greatest Irish tradition
reviews.content: This is a great film because the acting is brilliant, the cinematography is glorious, the dialogue is deliciously Irish, and, most of all, the story is utterly believable. A friendship unravels following an utterance between friends, which, in turn, envelopes a small remote island community, ending in tragedy.The screenplay, and the journey this film takes us on is what makes the film great. This is a film that goes through every emotion from disbelief and frustration, to anger and despair following Colm's decision not to talk to his former friend Padraic, for seemingly no reason at all. The journey is interlaced with some hilariously comical moments, mostly provided by the island simpleton, Dominic, who has experienced an awful childhood himself.Every character from the bar-keep to the island vicar are beautifully portrayed and totally believable, with a special shout-out to Padraic's miniature donkey, Jenny, a role only the Irish would think of.I'm not a believer in fairytale endings and this film would not benefit from an ending where everyone comes up smelling of roses. Sometimes issues don't get resolved, they just linger, and, this film is better for the ending it delivers, than for one, blatantly manufactured.Kudos to everyone involved. This is a fine film and it sits comfortably alongside the great Irish films of all time.

This was a very interesting concept for a movie, yet, I can't explain it. I found myself hooked almost instantly due to the characters. I found myself not being able to look away but at the same time asking "what am I watching?" I say this to say I think it's a great movie. Definitely a character piece that pulls you in and keeps you so invested that when it starts to get weird, you just can't quit the story.Give this one a chance and you'll probably be left dumbfounded and wishing the story would go on. Colin F blew me away with his ability to play such a humble and lovable character. I've never seen him be so vulnerable.

The film is something greater than the sum of it's parts. It is brilliantly written and masterfully directed. It is visually stunning and the actors embody their characters perfectly. It leaves you with a feeling of loss, resentment, betrayed, abandonment and last but not the least nostalgia. You can't help but feel that the movie is an allegory for the crisis that the world is battling currently. The immigration crisis, the climate disaster and the political instability, even though the island of inisherin is isolated from the world we see the impact of the external forces. All in all a true masterpiece by Martin McDonagh.

reviews.review_title: The story is really just a tuning fork for your moral compass.
reviews.content: The story is really just a tuning fork for your moral compass. Everything is reduced down to its core essence, then they proceed to strip away whatever is left in the environment until all that remains is just a chief feature of each character. That's when it hits you - "nice" is just a euphemism for "dull evil" really. The "nice" well meaning folks are there to prevent any sort of possibility of the soul shining through and realizing its potential and so the soul has to resort to some seriously drastic measures and is forced to pass through some fairly extreme tests for a chance to leave that lasting mark. This is real art.

reviews.review_title: Wonderful film overall, but not a masterpiece
reviews.content: There are so many things to love about 'The Banshees of Inisherin': It has a premise which is both ludicrous and viscerally captivating, much like a classic folktale. The wide-ranging themes underlying the narrative hold great promise. Its sensory world is crafted by a combination of stunning, STUNNING music and cinematography. And then there's Brendan Gleeson, who shines as Colm, at once formidable and sympathetic... But the film falls just short of excellence, largely due to an uneven tone and lack of clarity as to what it wants to say.Others have already written in detail about the film's merits. So I'm going to limit my review to a discussion of what I think keeps it from really soaring.A quick survey of critics' reviews after watching the film informed me that I was in the minority with my opinion of the tone. The consensus seems to be that writer and director Martin McDonagh has hit upon the perfect balance between comedy and tragedy, which is just baffling to me. I thought a lot of the jokes were tired and the delivery often sitcom-like; both jarred with the sublime atmospherics and the truly thought-provoking motifs. Not only that, but the comedy often serves to demean Pádraic by reducing him to a buffoonish caricature, and to undermine, as a result, the pathos around the character.Deriving humour from a main character's lack of intelligence by having him act like a 50-year-old child does not really work when the entire plot stems from his abandonment by a longtime friend for being "dull", a fact that is played for tragic effect at other points in the film. It takes the dignity out of his situation and renders the more poignant scenes ineffective. I think the film, which so often appears to aim at profundity, calls for a different kind and handling of humour.This is not the best comparison, but consider the show 'Fleabag' (its creator Phoebe Waller-Bridge is McDonagh's partner, which is probably why I thought of it). It also mixes comedy and drama but manages to flow much more seamlessly between the two than 'Banshees'. 'Fleabag' may not make claims to the kind of depth that the film does, but it certainly aims to be moving in an authentic and compelling way. Despite its flaws, the show is able to accomplish this with ease, while also being riotously funny, precisely because its humour never undermines the main character, our sympathy for whom drives the tragedy. Granted, she's supposed to be whip-smart (so nothing like Pádraic) but she has other qualities that make her vulnerable to a similar kind of authorial treatment: she sleeps around, plays the clown to her sister's straight man and is kind of a failure in the conventional sense at the point in her life that we know her. Despite all this, the humour never, never turns her into any kind of caricature. No amount of laughing at Fleabag takes away our sense of her as a full human being worthy of respect. What could've been left at the writer gently ribbing Pádraic for his intellectual deficiencies, is taken to a rather crass and shallow place. The film's moments of low humour undercut the tragedy instead of complementing it, while the tragedy, being so effectively wrought, makes the humour genuinely uncomfortable at times.In its two hours, 'The Banshees of Inisherin' brings up an array of interesting ideas. There's the old-as-time fear of one's own mortality, embodied in Colm, who claims to want to focus on his music to have something to be remembered by. There's the question of whether being kind is 'enough' though it can't bring one the immortality that artistic brilliance can. There's also a strong sense of God's abandonment of man, mainly seen through Colm, who has a longstanding problem with "despair". The constant picturing of crucifixes, statues of Mary and portraits of Jesus on an island aching with loneliness heightens this sense throughout the film. Colm's self-mutilation has religious echoes as well; self-mutilation used to be a form of penance, but what is Colm punishing himself for? Apart from this, there is an overarching critique of men's emotional incontinence (for which the Civil War serves as a parallel), and how it is not just self-destructive but harmful to everyone around them as well. The only person who gets something of a happy ending is Siobhán, Pádraic's brilliant sister, who refuses to bottle up her misery and sit around letting it fester like the men of the film (although Pádraic is a glaring exception there, because he is as expressive as can be).As you can probably tell, the film's intellectual landscape is rich. But, unfortunately, it comes to nought in the end. I've seen the film twice, but I still couldn't tell you what the film has to say about the many ideas it brings up. The best I could think of was: Despair (and not necessarily the religious kind) causes a kind of spiritual death which is contagious. Colm 'infects' Pádraic slowly through the course of the film, ending in the near-complete loss of his humanity as he attempts to burn his former friend alive. But Pádraic's moral turn is unconvincing; when he shows up cheerily to Colm's home the morning after and is genuinely surprised and disappointed to find him alive, you wonder, did he really come here expecting to find Colm's charred body? It just doesn't ring true at all. The open ending that follows only adds to the thematic fuzziness. So many people understood the final scene as giving hope for Colm and Pádraic's friendship, and if that's really the case, my reading's clearly wrong.When a story's threads fail to come together in a satisfying finish, it ends up feeling less like a story than an experience. This is often acceptable in cinema and literature, but the lack of a distinct message or meaning in this film stands out all the more because of its folktale-like structure and premise.So 'The Banshees of Inisherin', on balance, makes for an incredibly exhilarating but far from flawless experience.

reviews.review_title: Missing music from the soundtrack list
reviews.content: There is a lot of beautiful music in this fantastic movie. Listening to these, looking at the beautifully photographed landscape, and at the same time seeing people living in complete hopelessness creates a very dramatic effect. And again, Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson are brilliant.And when it comes to music: Does anyone know the source of the music at 5:13? I can't find it in the soundtrack list. This is a Tchaikovsky song "Legend" (Russian: Legenda), which was published as part of Tchaikovsky's Songs for Children, Op. 54, in 1884. (also known as "The Crown of Roses" in some English-language sources). This is what Colm listens to on an old record - a tenor singing with piano accompaniment - when Pádriack first visits to take him to the pub.

Felt compelled to write a few words. Just blown away. In many ways this feels genre-busting. One minute I was laughing out loud, the next my mouth was wide open. Unexpected shocks that I put down to Ben Davis' come terrific cinematography. And Colin Farrell. Oh my goodness. I didnt think I could genuinely like a Colin Farrell performance but Padraic is surely his best character by a million miles. And Kerry Condon and Brendan Gleeson, wow. Captivating. Haunting. Funny. Bleak. Insidious. Character-driven brilliance. Martin McDonaugh take a bow, you have created a work of genius, intelligence, frailty and beauty.

reviews.review_title: Visually Exquisite, Narratively Intriguing, Profoundly Moving
reviews.content: This film is gorgeous to watch - as every scene is composed beautifully and then woven together with other scenes melodically.This story is a simple tale of profound consequences, with dramatic twists and comedic turns. Every actor in the movie is terrific. I watched it twice in a row and I cannot get it out of my head... The story, the characters, the history, the visuals... all are god awful beautiful and will resonate inside your head for weeks. Amazing screenplay, amazing direction and cinematography. Amazing performances.Colin Farrell turns in the best role of his life and you will find yourself yelling at the screen and talking to characters, I promise you. You will laugh and cry in equal measures.

I could say a lot of things about this movie and why I think it is a masterpiece, but no words can really explain it.From the start I felt a knot in my throat and at first, I couldn't really understand why, but as the movie progresses it all became clear.I was so mad at the characters at times, and yet I could see each other's point of view.And I think that unless you have felt real loneliness, despair or heartbreak in your life, you won't get it. And if you did, you will get it. Simple as that.It is a tuff movie to watch, but I am glad I did. Wonderful performances, cinematography, loved the bits of dark humor.It is a true work of art really and deserves every award that it gets.

reviews.review_title: An Example of critics getting together to promote rubbish
reviews.content: The film was recommended to me. I saw the Rotten Tomatoes rating. I am Irish. How could this not be a great film to watch. My goodness, this was like watching paint dry slowly. I was waiting for something to happen in the movie, something that created the great reviews. I love the actors. Unless you get some satisfaction trying to find the nugget that created the nonsense reviews by the critics, spend your time more wisely - drive 6 inch nails in to your fingers. Absolutely a joke of a movie. Just one man's opinion vs all of the nonsense reviews giving it a score that will make people watch the movie.

reviews.review_title: Kind of a World Wildlife Fund warning: Don't drink, compose and cut your fingers on the same small green island!
reviews.content: In short, this is how you can sum it up: cultural emancipation in isolated communities from green coastal lands tends to inflate weird social conflicts and (more tragically) the extermination of small animals.The trailer is a bit misleading (at least, the one that I saw). You may think that's a comedy, but it is actually a rural drama. A very well played rural drama. You know the type: small, limited aspirations, disproportionately giant conflicts.Colin Farell and Brendan Gleeson are just great, but also impressive are Barry Keoghan and Kerry Condon. The dog and the donkey are doing a good job, also, kudos to them.

reviews.review_title: A 10/10 in the modern cinema wastelands
reviews.content: The power duo from In Bruges once again gives us some of cinemas much needed art and storytelling. A somewhat believable story set in 1923's Irish island of Inisherin depicting the downward spiral of two people connected in time and place. This film shows the depravity the human spirit can face when one man decides he's done with another. This is very good storytelling and one which surprised me while also saddening me because of the friendship and despair can take us. This was a human story, not filled with allegory, but with a certain flair of realism tucked behind a curtain of humor. A good watch, and one that may make you hug your dog or pet for comfort. Thank you Martin McDonagh, we need more of this from our studios.

Trying to be open minded and having loved the movie "In Bruges", we went to watch this movie. What a total waste of time!Desperately slow, complete absence of plot and in the end what on earth happened ?Did the movie just finish with no escalation of events ?Leaves you cold in the water.The Banshees of Inisherin just killed In Bruges.With a bang !The exact opposite.If you liked In Bruges, DO NOT watch The Banshees of Inisherin.It will destroy whatever good memories you had about it and the chemistry the existed between those 2 characters.Do yourself a favor. Watch anything else.

On a remote island off the coast of Ireland, Pádraic is devastated when his buddy Colm suddenly puts an end to their lifelong friendship. With help from his sister and a troubled young islander, Pádraic sets out to repair the damaged relationship by any means necessary. However, as Colm's resolve only strengthens, he soon delivers an ultimatum that leads to shocking consequences.On a remote island off the coast of Ireland, Pádraic is devastated when his buddy Colm suddenly puts an end to their lifelong friendship. With help from his sister and a troubled young islander, Pádraic sets out to repair the damaged relationship by any means necessary. However, as Colm's resolve only strengthens, he soon delivers an ultimatum that leads to shocking consequences.

The film immediately launches into the relationship conflicts, without any time to develop the characters, who they are, what they want, or why I should care about them. The way the characters deal with their conflict only gets more absurd as the film progresses. This goes on for 2 hours until the film just sort of ends.
Beautifully filmed and great acting but I didn't like the story. It isn't entertaining when people do stupid things and they cannot resolve their problems.
It might be directionally great. But I guess one has to be in the mindset to enjoy this kind of film. It just dragged on building intrigue but never delivering it.
a great film, wonderful performances, incredible photography, and the story is beautiful despite being sad, a film that brings several important reflections on life.
Listed as a dark comedy.  I agree with the dark.  Comedy?  No.  Self-mutilation to prove a point is a sign of mental illness and should never be celebrated.

Brilliant acting. If a movie is slow and sad then only top performances can save it. This movie had that in spades. Yes the scenery is spectacular but that is a backdrop. Every emotion is brought out to be observed. There is some dark humor but the depth of despair grows till the movie shows the mental slide of all the main characters. Truely deserving of several acadamy awards
Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan diserve Oscars, I realy thought if Colin will kill the dog, I realy shocked, the film was Great.

Martin McDonagh writes and directs a great movie. The script is near perfect for most of the journey but tends to drift just a touch towards the end. Perhaps a little dramatic in a couple of scenes, but that doesn't detract from what is a serious story of life, connections, love and loneliness. A gripping tale. 
Gleeson and Farrell shine out with their understanding and portrayal of the two main characters. They are well supported by an outstanding cast with Barry Keoghan memorable. The scene stealer though is the donkey Jenny, one you will never forget. 
This is a movie that demands to be seen by all serious movie buffs.
The movie drags on at a snails pace and ends up going nowhere. I didn't enjoy it at all.

If film companies are going to slap "tobacco use" and "harsh language" labels on movies, perhaps they could consider "animal abuse" too? I was scarred, and turned it off. The film violated rules of allowing--even encouraging--the audience to become enamored of a lovely, vulnerable creature, only to.....If you want to be a horror film, fine, but don't violate genre conventions and inflict psychological harm on your viewers.
Like Love Island, but sad and enthralling.
This was a disgusting awful boring story with no redeeming value
Weird but two stars for scenery

A dark comedy that really lives up to the genre. It makes the audience question what's more important, being liked or being remembered.Both Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson personify these two choices in fantastic Oscar worthy performances. With not having directed a film since Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri, which I also loved, Martin McDonagh does a fantastic job.The cinematography and camera work is not to be overlooked here. The backgrounds were all just exquisite and the camera shots were at times mesmerizing. This is the time of year when most Oscar nominated films come out and this is a huge contender in many categories. Definitely one I recommend checking out. It's incredibly well made, tackles some incredibly deep themes and is a truly amazing viewing experience.

Slow sad story that had little in the way of a smile, chuckle or a laugh. I had great expectations as I have seen the chemistry between the actors work very well in previous dark humour films. Its possibly the portraying the average person in the film as an idiot whilst a few are normal is where the humour is supposed to emanate from, but I did not find that amusing, really just very sad
The acting and the scenery were amazing. The story was a bit hard to figure out for me. I am not sure I truly "got it" in the end.
Academy award worthy. Artsy and all acting/dialogue. Great casting. Takes you through many emotions and discomfort. Not predictable at all. If you like this type of film it is a must see.

Even without knowing the background of the Irish Civil War, this movie is still deeply moving. The film profoundly portrays various characters' personalities in life (especially those as "uninteresting" as the protagonist) and their emotions when facing conflicts, which are magnified in this closed-off island. The ending ultimately highlights the protagonist's foolishness, but it also evokes sympathy for him.
A little weird and maybe too artsy for me but I thought it was funny and good acting

A bit slow and dull.  Great acting and scenery but the stupid fingers stuff made it so unbelievable.  Yes, I know it was a metaphor, but so what?  That doesn't make it make sense, and no one knew it was a metaphor until they read the reviews.

This is a good film. It's slow and quiet throughout but there is a lot of dark humor and a few surprising moments that keep the film interesting. It's one of those films that gets better as it goes on. The acting is great, with strong performances by Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson. This film won't be for everyone, if you're looking for action or laugh out loud comedy then give this a skip. However if you enjoy quiet, dark comedic dramas then you should enjoy this.

Excellent piece about two friends estranged by philosophical differences about how they want to spend their "last" days and time. Driven to dark comedic madness, the performances of the lead actors and actresses were spot on! Recommended.

In my humble opinion the best movie of 2022, everything everywhere may have deserved its oscar but i would have been so much happier with this. I kind of think that it's underrated no one talks about it except when it apperead in the oscars, this is with out a doubt a masterpiece, it's also the most irish thing ever. Goodnight Tri state area.
Amazing cinematography! I enjoyed this movie and thought the plot was funny
Did not know what to expect... unusual story but relatable, great acting and stunning scenery... kerry condon should have got an Oscar for her performance

To start off, the cinematography in this movie is phenomenal. Some of the scenes were breathtaking. The movie is set in the 1920s on an island off the coast of Ireland. Ireland is a beautiful place, and being able to capture so much beauty in one shot is remarkable. 
I thought this movie was witty and wholehearted, but I will admit it was also strange and absurd at times. The acting from each character was great. While I do have some personal issues with this movie (ones I won't say in order to keep this spoiler free), I think this was a great movie regardless and I would definitely recommend it.

Seeing as I am only 14 (supervised by an adult)- I was not analysing the more serious subject behind this film (the civil war) However, i found The Banshees of Inisherin a very interesting film. This film explores many different genres; comedy, horror, drama, and many more. The casting is excellent- including BAFTA nominee ‘Barry Keoghan‘ and ‘Brendan Gleeson' (best known for his performance in the Harry Potter franchise as Mad Eye Moody) The film is a metaphor of the troubles of the Irish throughout the civil war hence the slight references used throughout the film. Overall an amazing film which I highly recommend to anyone over 15 (I wouldn't have wanted to watch it any younger!!)
WOW!!!  Life on an island can mess u up!!!  Sad but intriguing.

Still laughing.

Great actors, original script, comedy based the value of friends.

This is the worst movie I have seen in the past 20 years. It is a perfect storm of pointless, depressing, banal, and smug. There's literally no way they could've made it more terrible. Is there an Oscar for terrible? Well, this is a contender.
Superb cinema. Story seems rather simple but there are so many layers to discover in movie itself but mostly in yourself. Loved it!!!
Bruh.. dude cuts all fingers and the friendship in the film just kept on derailing.. also, the ending seemed random..

Scenery alone is worth five stars, the performances are grand, but the story is absolutely insane, literally. No character but the sister Siobhán Súilleabháin (Kerry Condon) and the donkey are remotely likable or remotely sane. Colm (Brandan Gleeson) is severely mentally ill, wait, everyone but the sister is that. Imagine if Van Gogh had cut off fingers rather than his ear, i.e. what he needs to keep painting. SAF. Ridiculous. Reminds me of urine-poor attempt at a Flannery O'Connor short story which talks about a brooding young girl who learns to be jaded and not care and the swindler comes and says that he was born not caring-paraphrase. Skip this train, er, finger wreck and read the amazing Flannery O'Connor for more eloquent way to tell and put forth a lesson.
Well played by Colin Farrell. Unusual, grotesque humor.
This is a perfect film. Every aspect of it was incredible. Please watch it. PLEASE.
Beautifully constructed tale of fall into despair acting by all incredibly impressive very sad but then falling outs are like that
Very slow, very odd and very enjoyable. What a strange story of remote Irish life and adult friendship. Absolutely fascinating.

Metaphoric of the Irish civil wars or not, this is a dull and dark experience that I do not seek out for pleasure watching.  Beyond assigning students essays to uncover parallels between it and the civil wars, I find it unworthy of the actors therein and the award nominations it received.
Good acting doesn't make up for it's hopelessly unbelievable plot.
I saw nothing funny and was sorely disappointed.
This is the only film worth watching among the oscar's coterie.
Best movie I've seen in a long time. Should have won the Oscar for best film

I didn't like it at all, the whole story line was absurd, I did like the location, the actors/actresses were good, but felt they were wasted on the crazy storyline, I give it out of 10 fingers, only a 5 .

I thought I would like this more than I did. I mean, it is not bad, but it's so slow and it just didn't please me that much. Although it's very smart and has a very rich dialogue, I thought it had more potencial.
This movie is a Masterpiece!

The stars are for the scenery and the accents, but the story is horrifying, cruel and unrealistic. There is no history. It does not make sense -allegory to civil war is a stretch. Really old life style with animals inside ok but since there are so few on the island -it would only make sense that they would hang out as they seem to have done before. Irish feuds are legendary, but there is no context or disagreement there. The idea that he would cut off his fingers to spite a young man he has mentored is just macabre. There are no banshees, no one dies -no plot, action or meaningful family interactions -nothing to mourn or be sad about -just a cranky old man who is into hurting others and self-harm. Even Ibsen is more cheerful. Nothing like the soulful tales of Ireland old and new. No real appeal. Next time make an actual story with actual heart and maybe even a soul with lots of interesting detail –then and only then an award may come your way…
Slow-paced, but beautifully filmed and great acting. The story is simple yet original and with a subtle humour which I thoroughly enjoyed.

Won't get that time back. Bit of a "King with no clothes on" movie - lots saying it's good when it isn't. Personally don't see how acting out tosh can be classed as great acting, and this was a front runner for the Oscars…..! Scenery lovely.
God awful movie. Seriously can't believe some people like it.
Tremendous acting, artful and clever screenplay, with a backdrop of traditional Irish culture, myths, history and coastal scenery.

Sometimes I think we've forgotten how to let a plot unfold. Not the case in this story. This is brilliant filmmaking in every 
aspect of the movie and Colin's character Padraic will stay with you days after you leave the theater. A masterpiece!
Another sad Irish movie about sad people with sad lives feeling sad.  No redeeming moments in this film.

Such an odd concept but it's executed with a lot of dedication. The small island community explored feel authentic and it's an impressive period piece. The accents and small-scale conflicts are a breath of fresh air after so many movies take place in cities with higher stakes. It's a testament to the writing that this is interesting at all. Martin McDonagh's signature humor is present in full force here, and the movie is funnier than it has any right to be. The performances are also stellar all the main characters are played to perfection. The film spells out little of its actual meaning, there's a lot to read into but also answers to find that feel satisfying. I'm unfamiliar with the actual conflict the movie references but it didn't hamper my enjoyment. It's always a joy to see a creative project with true passion behind it come to life.

This is one of the most Irish things I've ever seen. Petty Squabbles about one's pint, the beautiful music, Donkey named Jennifer and the gorgeous scenery. However behind it all is a sad story about a falling out between two close friends who deep down don't want to hurt each other, but still do so anyways. The performances in this film are deeply moving with Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell delivering the best performances of their careers. This movie is one fine Tragicomedy.
This is a ridiculous movie with great scenery.  Don't unfriend anybody or you may end up cutting off your fingers and having your house burned down.
It is bleak and claustrophobic, as it openly admits in its playing. There are humorous lines, but ultimately it was, for me, fairly pointless.
Extremely tedious, lacking real purpose.
This was depressing. Great acting but nothing about the story is uplifting.
The story is uncanny and that's what makes it so good.
Shakespearean level of tragedy. You'll leave sad but rewarded.
It was actually a good movie that brings out a little bit of tears. The acting was great but the plot was a blurry and hard to pin-point. Overall, solid movie!
Amazing acting and cinematography.
So unique and keeps surprising throughout
Breathtaking Aran Island scenery, some wonderful performances (including from a miniature donkey) and the complex, sad death of a friendship make this movie well worth watching.

A grounded, hilarious, heartbreaking tale of a guy who doesn't wanted to be friends with another guy. 

This film is FLAWLESS. So simple yet so beautiful.

Really boring.
To me at least.

I loved this movie. The simple dramatic premise, of one friend telling another friend that he didn't want to be friends any more, with devastating consequences, is pure McDonagh. It is a play disguised as a movie and because it is set on an incredibly beautiful Irish island, Mc D gets away with it. Colin F breaks my heart. Brendan G makes that tough love seem like truth. The sister, the bartender, animals, the sea, the sky itself weave the story with mythic fibers. I had to see it again right away. Big screen is best, for the scenery, though my second time was on the small screen. Good both ways.

As EngineEddie put it (on reddit):

In Bruges is a hilarious movie with great moments of darkness. Banshee is a dark movie with great moments of hilarity.
Good lord, what are 75% of you thinking? This was the most depressing, horrible movie I have ever seen. Not a single redeeming quality about this movie. Absolutely awful.
It's weird but in a good way. The acting is sublime and so is the scenery and the music. Jenny the Donkey steals the show.
A situation we've all been in

It's a movie about the desire of explanation, the need to understand. It's as much about the inexplicability of life and conflict on large scales, as it is about the awkward, ill-suited attempts of one person's mind to force itself to change to bring back the comfort zone, and failing nonetheless. Powerful and hauting both allegorically and literally.
Good movie, beautiful scenery, simple story and great acting. Loved it.

I see reviews that refer to this movie's balancing of humor and tragedy, comedy and pathos, etc. This is not a comedy. There are a couple of chuckles here and there. But this is a sad, brutal story propelled by one man's abandonment of a friendship, an action that, justifiable or not (the viewer can decide), is undeniably cruel.
Beautiful scenes and costumes, talented acting, sad and moving story - 4/5
I found nothing funny about this dark and depressing movie.  The acting was excellent, but not a story I would want to see again.
Fantastic movie with an innovative story line. Its absurdity and comedy points are just amazing.
Total and utter rubbish. To think these guys were all in the excellent 'In Bruges' defies description. How on earth could Rotten Tomatoes give it a 96% mark - are you out of your minds?
What the hell!!! What was the meaning of this flick? Glad I watched it, but once is enough.
Beautiful and darkly funny.
Slow, bizarre story. Not sure I understood the turning point correctly, because what appears to be the obvious implication didn't make sense. Pretty scenery though.

I will always be a fan of Colin; the acting great, the camera work beautiful. But..a comedy? In an age when depression and suicide is supposedly key this is a very sad and shocking movie. If you are depressed, do avoid.
The main character tells the priest a number of times he is sad and lonely.
He cuts off all the fingers on one hand. He rejects company. He never smiles or laughs and seems permanently depressed. his compositions morose. He needed major help, and we called this a tragic comedy.
It's lost on me. Very very VERY confusing and sad movie and I'm sorry to go against the grain. In the end its one man's opinion who often sees around him mentally illness go untreated or recognized.
Tried to like it as I'm a big fan of indie movies and international films but I simply didn't care about the characters, the plot, or the conclusion.
On a remote island, a man wants to end a years-long friendship with another while the Irish Civil War occurs in the mainland. A simple, moving, and sometimes funny parable.

Very unpleasant experience. References to the Irish civil war went over my head. Without that context the movie feels very depressing and left me feeling empty. I think maybe film is not the right medium for this story?
I couldnt tell you why but i realy loved this movie. Its dark, slow and at times funny.
So well done! I never thought such a simple plot....man defriends a friend....could capture my attention. It added suspense also and a realistic ending!
Possibly the worst movie I have ever seen
Really bad. Loved the scenery, but the storyline was just sad, slow and very hard to watch.

It was to be a Comedy/Drama but there was maybe 3 lines that were sort of humorous. It was very depressing. I knew the story line & love the actors so was terribly surprised at the sadness. Had I known I would never have watched. 👎🏻
Overrated and slow….I have no clue what the hype about this movie is……

Bar none the worst movie I have ever seen!!!! I want my time back- do not watch this! Go look up beautiful scenery around Ireland or anywhere if your choice! 

Most people watch movies for the following reasons: relax, get out of your head from a long day or week, inspiration, history, fun, laughter, 
date night, scary thriller, ….. anything but this!!!!

I can't say enough about how horrible it is - negative zero stars! If you want to question why life exists and goodness and purpose… and then want to cry about the lack of any trust inhumanity or loyalty…. This movie brings out the worst in everything you want to believe! 

Whomever wrote it- go get therapy and friends help you!

Seemed like a rather vapid metaphor. Relatable as a premise and that’s where it ends. Fails to explore either the literal metaphor or historical subject of interest deeper than an incredibly superficial level.
Loved it, great performances all round.

This film is absurd yet real in its portrayal of a friendship that just isn't working. It is set a century in the past in a small irish island. It has beautiful vistas with mundane, yet compelling, conversations among friends, family, and neighbors. Strongly recommend.

It is hard to imagine how such excellent acting, beautiful cinematography, and interesting story line could total a viewing experience that I would sum up in one word - torture.

We all have differing motivations, but for me the despair and removal of "hope" just became too much.  

Again, the acting across the board had me all in.  And Jenny.  Ooooooooh Jenny!
Well-defined characters against the backdrop of the Irish civil war. It's sad, but poetic and smart.

This movie was hard to watch, but resonated deeply with me at this stage of life.  I can't stop thinking about it.  I have been that idiot who cut off my fingers (metaphorically) to try to leave a legacy that transcends my mortality.  I have lost a best friend or lover because I wasn't capable of giving them what they needed and felt bereft.  If you live long enough you experience the emotions of the characters in this movie.  At another level, the self-inflicted violence (Colum) and unintended consequences (the donkey's death) resonate with the terrible self-inflicted pain and tragedy of the Irish civil war.  God bless Padraic's sister who had the sense to get off the island.  Most of us stay with the familiar, no matter how painful it gets.  If you have fully lived this terrible and beautiful life we have been given you may be able to fully appreciate this movie.  It's not for those who avoid the dark side of life.  It will only make sense to those who have muddled through this life imperfectly and see themselves refracted through the lens of the film maker.
another incredible diverse and imaginative movie complete in its everything lights pictures actors and all. BRAVO!!! should have won all prizes!!!!!!!

As a viewer I felt like an invisible time traveler who got to witness a slice of the idiosyncratic "craziness" of the residents on this isolated Irish Island at the beginning of the 20th century. As viewers we are there.
It may not be up my usual street of movies, but you have to appreciate the amazing performances and the extremely saddening story.
This is a dreary mess. I was hoping for a little Irish charm and interest. Boring, slow, unlikable main characters, and a truly stupid plot.
Billed as a dark comedy.....there is absolutely nothing comedic about this movie.  I was disappointed that the cinematography was dull considering where they filmed.
Not fast-paced, but definitely poignant
Loved it. A deep movie about music, friendship, and loneliness.
What a slog. Pretty to look at but umm, yeah.
Spectacular film from Martin McDonagh exploring the end of a friendship and the foolish futility of the Irish Civil War.

If you are looking for entertainment, look elsewhere. What begins with a little humor (the trailers drew us in) descends into a depressing story of emotional and physical abuse, including self-mutilation for no apparent reason. It is a tragic, cautionary tale about settling for the inertia of a sad life you've only ever known. (I'm glad the sister escaped.) The cinematography was gorgeous, though, thanks to Ireland's pastoral landscape.

Entertain and a little difficult to watch in places. Initial reaction was confusion, but then I couldn't stop thinking about the movie for days trying to make sense of it. Ultimately really enjoying it and would recommend.
I get that it was supposed to be a metaphor, but it was really just stupid people doing stupid unbelievable things.

As the utter insanity of the Irish Civil War rages on the mainland, an island community is subtly affected by the pathological violence that has seized Ireland.  When the normal is pathological, the pathological is normal.

During the Civil War murder and violence became so normalised that the pathological became normal, which was one reason the Irish Garda Siochana was created as an unarmed force, to use its moral authority in the first, rather than force of arms, to delegitimise the use of the gun to settle all disputes, and to grab land, as happened wholesale for example in Co. Kerry, where brothers slew brothers and father sons, in an orgy of insane and vicious violence, each side driven to out-do the other in a game of rock paper scissors; where vendetta and revenge was tempered with piety and the innate compassion also of the Irish, that even when committing acts of atrocity there is still space for morality; where cruelty and the innate ability to turn a blind eye to it that characterises Ireland in the 20th and other centuries, was institutionalised and affected every aspect of life right down to the treatment of the most vulnerable.  

This film encapsulates the madness in its narrative, as two friends take it to the bridge in increasing games and levels of obduracy, bloody-mindedness, hurt, personal offence, and by the end, the sheer hell of it, wrecking not just their own lives but those of others around them. A great and indirect metaphor for the Irish Civil War, which like just about anything inconvenient and likely to 'rock the boat' is traditionally brushed under the carpet in Ireland, in line with what Michael Davitt called one of the twin curses of Ireland, the national Moral Cowardice.  

Everything just works in this film. The light (of course, it's Irish light which is unique in its magical luminescence) and the use of reflection; which is what this film is very subtly all about; the dramatic scenery, the beautiful backdrop to literally centuries of horror, exploitation, starvation, emigration, depopulation, mercilessness, viciousness, and all crammed under a veneer of piety with its roots in a religious ceremony that is meaningless in the incomprehensibility of language and ritual, once so much it had to be partially concealed behind a rood screen as were the crimes of myriad child abusers in clerical garb likewise concealed in plain sight.  As Christy Moore once sang ''Everybody knew/  But nobody said.''  Ireland's problems in a nutshell.  AND of course the acting, which is uniformly excellent.

Drink, religion, sexual frustration and abuse, combined with two-facedness, cruelty, bloody-mindedness, all the usual and well founded tropes, serve to convey a sort of logical descent into madness that echoes the Civil War seizing the country generally, in an Atlantean outpost of eccentricity and conformity, where power is abused by Church and State to maintain the population in a general state of infantilism and idiocy just as it was on the mainland, ''Christ'' ferried across on a Galway Hooker in the form of the prieshteen, fat complacent and resplendent in the power of his dog-collar, embraced by ''Caesar'': the corrupt local Garda sergeant, a former member of ''the national movement'' who was brutalised by the killing he did during the War of Independence and now brutalises in turn his son and those whom incur his displeasure..hand in glove.  

So it goes, and so it is today as well, so long as the Irish keep telling themselves and everyone who will listen convenient lies to avoid the pain of confronting the truth.  I write this as a former/ex-Irish Citizen, so if my criticism is harsh, it is also just and this film reflects better than any I've ever seen, the problems that beset this country and which only the Irish themselves can ever fix, but that won't be today nor tomorrow.  See 'moral cowardice' above.

It is a thought provoking view to the ending of a friendship by one man's decision to do away with a dull friend in order to leave a musical legacy and the other being a simple man that can't comprehend or accept the break.  The level of devastation the plot reaches is a metaphor for the real Irish Civil War that is taking place.  The cinematography/scenery is breathtaking and the acting impeccable.
Original, unexpected story, great acting, beautiful shots and scenery. Definitely worth watching, noting that it's very depressing and sad.

The brilliance was in the simplicity of the quippy and blunt script. Nothing but excellence in this all-irish cast and the roles and responsibilities of each one was understood perfectly whilst juggling the idea that their characters live in such a boring time and space of Ireland. I love this film.

I loved this movie. I had to watch with captions on so I could catch what they were saying. It was humorous and dramatic all in one. And you can't deny that the scenery added so much to it! What a beautiful Island!
Cannot believe this lost to other movies for the Oscars. Politics at play….
Hated it… content is really not funny, dark, painful and no reason to put people through this. Could've made the point in a better way. Depressing
Was not sure what to expect going in but I thoroughly enjoyed this solid and straight forward dark comedy.
Absolute rubbish. Not even the talented acting could gloss over the abysmal plot.

If I could give it a zero I would. The story started off well enough and went downhill quickly with a very depressing storyline, that did NOT make me look at friendship or life in a different way. Instead, it made me think HBO must have spent a lot of money advertising this for an Oscar. This discouraging story did have my colleagues talking around the water cooler, one said they canceled their HBO subscription after wanting 2 hours of their back. If you want to walk away from a movie disheartened about life and friendship this is the movie for you. Seriously bad movie.
Interesting movie. Funny. Intriguing. Dissects human emotion. Good performances but wouldn't say great - although all the awards seem to feel differently.
Enjoyed the film. It was very unique but not much happened. I would have liked if the meaning behind the film was more obvious (Irish civil war)
It was not what I expected. The beginning starts out a little slow, but stick with it. The movie becomes interesting and intense. Plus, the actors are phenomenal.
Its greatness lies in its simplicity and the characters.
Beautifully shot but it was a bit silly.
It was not a happy movie very depressing.  I couldn't recommend it to anyone.
One of the bleakest and most depressing movies I've ever seen. 10/10
Contrary to popular reviews, I thought this film wasn't what it was recognised for and to be.  Great cinematography, interesting location, but a bit silly.

Really enjoyed this one!  Acting is great... and the whole concept really keeps you intrigued.  I am glad I watched this movie. 👍🏻  However, I removed one star because the last 1/3 didn't feel as magical as the first 2/3 of the movie.  I would still recommend it though.

It staggers me that apparently this movie is in contention to win an oscar for Best Picture. Frankly it was boring and the entertainment value was close to zero. I didn't think the acting was anything special and there is essentially no plot to speak of.

The cutting off of fingers does not a movie make. The writer-director who normally makes terrific movies fails in this one by using a contrived metaphor that is not only patently weird but also lacking in imaginative and emotional force. Great scenery, though, and engaging subplots of love and loneliness. Overall suffers from an enervated aesthetic.

My husband and I were torn on this one.  Yes, the cinematography was beautiful.  The actors were very, very good.  The story???  After cutting off one finger a mental healthy eval would have been helpful.  OK, so it's secluded.  People who so desperately wish to play a violin don't cut off their fingers!!!
Absurd, so disappointed with both actors for accepting any part in this dismal, sad movie
The only good thing about this movie besides the scenery was the little donkey and they decided to remove that bit of good too. Didn't like it.
Erm..... a 2 hour movie where nothing really happens. Oscar winning? Not for me thanks. Battled through to the end but not worth it.
Wonderful and heartbreaking. Acting is terrific.
It's no In Bruges but it's a good movie. It's motivations are not clear but the oddity of it and great acting keeps the movie going
Awestrucking! Finally a creative, impecable movie from beginning to end. The balance between every element fully transports us to that awkwardly captivating time and story.

Way too slow..yes, I know life was slower in those times but this was really like pulling teeth. A great story, don't get me wrong but I feel it could have been done a tiny bit quicker, more fluid. This has the whole 'art film' vibe.
If you're hugely chill, patient and into historical Irish history, this is the movie for you.
Excellent fil making with two great actors. A slow moving but powerful story. I would watch it again.

This was advertised as a dark comic view of a friendship. Unfortunately the comic part missed the mark. The one star was for the acting of the donkey- the rest was just tedious and depressing. We seemed to have entered an era where good writing, acting and film making has gone. Instead the shock value of depressive and torturous relationships is celebrated as art.
My daughter says it's Rubbish, she knows what I like that will do for me.
Not enjoyable. Don't ever want to see it again.

Made NO sense.  Maddening, cuz nothing was explained.
Also inexplicable is why so many praised this stupid movie.
Giving it an irritated 1 1/2 RT stars... 'oof, rotten'
Saw it in 'lerton, AMC, Dec 3,2922
Too symbolic for its own good. In order to be a dark comedy. You need to have some comedy.

Good acting, but stupid plot: an aging man wants to achieve a measure of immortality via his music, and he considers his best friend to be "dull" and therefore somehow inimical to his desire to reach immortal greatness, so he cuts off his own fingers to separate himself from his erstwhile friend but in doing so makes it impossible for himself to play his fiddle. Really??
Fantastic acting. The storyline takes a bit to get going and then BOOM and then it ends. An unfulfilling ending.
Acting was great. The film was very dark. Scenery was very good.
I rarely don't finish movies but this was one that I was happy to not watch and it's not a comedy. There's nothing funny about it. Stop calling it a comedy

One of the worst oscar nominated films for this year.  Who would think someone cutting off fingers to break up a friendship would be nominated for an oscar.  Who are these people that pick these films and vote for them. Really, really bad film done with good actors.  Don't spend any money on this one. Stinks bad
"Stink, Stank, Stunk"   If I were a suicidal person and seeing a bad movie could trigger me, I would not have made it alive out of that theatre seat. This movie went nowhere.
I thought the actors were good and the  scenery was  beautiful,  but the story  was   too bizarre for me, like it was in the other Colin Farrrell movie The Lobster.  The subtle plot was lost on me.
Quirky, original, dark. Loved it.

This would have to be one of my favorites in the list of movies nominated by the Academy for best picture of the year. The world-building is simple and direct. The characters are believably nuanced. I loved the humor sprinkled into the dialogue.
I couldn't really get into it, but will give it another try.  I found it rather dull and boring, but we all have different opinions.
as dull and boring a movie as you will see, the two quality actors could not save this
Unusual story told through exceptional acting.

A quirky low budget movie that delivers with cinematography, great acting and a strong story line that has you enthralled till the closing credits.   Ironically we watched the history / myths of the ireland banshee   Without understanding the backdrop of this myth you would find it difficult to understand the full background/character of the myth of the Irish banshee.  An absolute must see movie.
I don't understand what the fuss was about. It was too dark and not comedic.  Couldn't finish it.

So this is what passes in Hollywood as an Oscar contender? Hollywood has not only alienated it's fanbase, it's completely detached itself from reality. I'd rather have a tooth pulled without freezing than ever subject myself to a movie like this again. The tooth being pulled would be far less painful...
So many funny one liners and so dark in places. Loved the acting and absolutely loved the movie.

It is not for everyday or for everyone but if you don't mind a slow burn and a dark story this is one of the most atmospherically dense and well acted movies of all times, with some very strong themes.

I found this really painful to watch.  The characters are stupid and act that way.  The movie should have been the story of the protagonist's sister, the only person in the cast with a brain: she leaves the worthless island to find a life.  It is reasonable to speculate that the story is intended to be a metaphor for the silly conflicts occurring in the Ireland of the time (and continuing), but that doesn't make it worth seeing.

This black tragicomedy directed, written, and co-produced by Martin Mcdonagh is set on a remote island off the west coast of Ireland, and follows two lifelong friends who find themselves at an impasse when one abruptly ends their relationship, with shocking consequences for both of them. It is a unique story with an original rare screenplay that invites to think about the sudden terrible changes a war can cause on a group of people, although the war itself is not seen. Themes such as friendship, ambition and loneliness are present in the story, which might feel slow at times, but it is elevated by the incredible cast performances: Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan are just outstanding. Some scenes are plain funny, while others are quite melodramatic, which makes it a nice balance. Also, Carter Burwell's score is hauntingly beautiful! The gorgeous cinematography and the compelling screenplay will surely make it a memorable and unpredictable movie.
Xcellent setting and good acting but depressing plot.

trying to catch up on the Oscar nominees.  Hard to believe I've watched two of the worst movies ever that are top picks.  Watched "Everything, Everywhere..." a few nights ago and could barely sit through to the finish.  Now, hoping for something better, watched Banshees.  Just awful.  Can't believe the reviews that say "excellent acting"..."beautiful scenery" and rate the movie highly.  At the end of the day the story has to be interesting and the movie should entertain...this was plain, mind numbingly stupid.

I'd give it -5 stars!
Waste of everyone's time tbh.
Not even worth 1 star and definitely not a comedy.

I don't understand how this film can be categorized as a comedy?  From the very beginning, you know that it's going to be one of those deeply despairing, dread-filled Irish movies, like "Calvary," "Lamb," "In the Name of the Father" & others ~ involving a confluence of the Catholic Church, alcohol, a suppressed & unemployed people, and music/poetry/dance, and animals.  I was filled with similar despair by the end of it. Yes, beautiful scenery & acting.  And an interesting metaphor for the Irish civil war when the Irish Free State was established, separating Northern Ireland to remain in the UK.  Just so, so, so bleak ~ for numerous reasons.
Superb acting and incredible scenery for a quite slow storytelling half comic and half tragedy.
Amazing all around. Great writing, acting and directing.

No-one would ever do the fingers thing - even less a fiddler!!!
Totally spoilt the movie!!!
I really liked the film, and the performances are great.  It's a weird film with over the top characters.   This is not a negative.   The characters are interesting and endearing.

A decent into madness, in a breathtaking setting. First off, the cinematography is gorgeous, highlighting the beauty, loneliness, and mystery of living in a coastal Irish village.
