The acting is superb. Not only the two main characters, Padraic and Colm, played by Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson, but the supporting cast as well. What I really appreciate about this flick, is a totally original take on a friendship taking a turn for the worst. This is not your mama's Lifetime movie, this is a twisted and disturbing trip down the rabbit hole,  which decent into madness only goes deeper and deeper. The only reason I did not give this five stars is how unbelievable and crazy Colm reacts in Padraic's refusal to believe their friendship is ending. Veered a bit too much on the deep end, to make it a believable scenario.
Fantastic cinematography. Good acting. I guess it is supposed to be some form of noir relationship movie. Too weird of a storyline for my taste.
I wanted something on par with in Bruges but I think I was asking too much.

Not sure how anyone can stay awake through this snoozefest.  Also, couldn't get past the age difference between the two main characters who are supposed to be lifelong friends.  I mean Gleeson is 67 and Farrel is 46.  At the very least better casting should've been considered.
The Banshees Of Inisherin = fucking masterpiece
Fantastic acting, but dark.  Once the donkey died, I was upset. Don't like animals being killed off as a plot device.
Well written and acted. Irish countryside was magnificent! Sad story with moments of offbeat humor.

It was an odd movie for sure.  What the Brandon Gleason character did midway thru was quite inconceivable for sure.  Makes you wonder about when you or someone wishes to end a friendship/relationship and the other person doesn't get it or doesn't want it to end.  The cast was great.  Loved the little black donkey.  Colin Farrell was great in a very different role for him.  Gleeson was great as usual in a very unusual role.  Love his fiddle playing, he is quite talented.  Kerry Condon was superb as Pádraic's sister.  And Barry Keoghan was quite the surprise and did a great job.  It wasn't the happiest of movies and my wife and friends who watched it with me, were like, 'this is so weird'!! But we talked about it for two days after, so it had an impact.

Another ‘23 film looking to make a point, or teach a lesson, or something. The film takes you on a boring emotional rollercoaster that eventually leads to gut-wrenching sensations of "why?!?" It doesn't take the entirety of the movie to make its point, but does take the entirety to make you rethink why you expected the movie to pick up at any point. Its clear that Gleeson and Farrell continue to be a match made in movie heaven, I just hope they go on to collaborate in a film that isn't as dreary as the Inisherin countryside.

Visually stunning. A must see on a bigger screen, if you can do so. Acting is outstanding. At first I was frustrated by what seemed like a slow "art film". Then I realized that this whole story is a multilayered metaphor for the Irish Conflict. Then you realize that it is really the story of so much of the fracturing of society. It can just as easily be about the division of American society. Hey people…..what are we doing???
Wonderful, unique movie due to great acting demonstrating the juxtaposition of Irish tragedy and humor, all in a gorgeous physical setting. I'm not feckin' jokin'.
It’s a critic’s movie. Great acting. Comedy? Maybe if it’d been a cartoon. No, not then either. Is absurd a genre? Two hours of my life I’ll never get back.
Worst movie ever. Chopping off fingers, killing a donkey .

i ended up liking this much more than i thought i was going to - i don't think i'd call it a comedy, but it *is* quite funny. maybe "dark comedy" suits it. it's an interesting combination of sad/silly & heavy/light-hearted. great cast & good performances from all - i was pleasantly surprised. if you like quirky, you might like this too.

In Bruges is slightly better.
Feels like there is some greater symbolism that we're supposed to pick up on, but don't. Even if there isn't, it's a simple if unrealistic story that strikes with biting emotion.

One of those artistically beautiful works with tour de force acting that critics go gaga about, but at the end of the day is a depressing tale about what happens when only ten people and a donkey live on a remote island, and then you go bonkers and cut off your fingers because you suddenly realise you loathe your ex-best friend. Art, they say.
This film was excellent 👍🏼
The first half of the movie isn't bc but then they really cross a line. Couldn't get through the last 20 minutes and deeply regret what I did see. Do not watch this movie.
Top level acting by the entire ensemble. The story moves at a pace that some won't enjoy but the funny moments, the heartfelt moments carry and shine through.
Wonderful movie, really gets you thinking about the sad nature of people.
A story of a dreary life in Ireland. Kind of a weird movie centered around two ex friends and one having fewer fingers as the movie progresses.

Magnificent acting, scenery, music though I found it annoying how Colm's mental overreaction did not get called out but was treated as quite well, normal. A dark comedy that's both a lesson in rejection and a study in friendship
The scenery was gorgeous and the acting was good- but the story/plot was seriously lacking. Tempted to give a third star for animal actors 🤔
Unfortunately, nothing happens in this movie that's entirely devoid of plot.
wow. so many great reviews for an absolutely horrible movie. could not sit through it. unbelievable and full of cruelty. the 'critic' reviews are just pandering. avoid this like the plague.

Well it gets half a star for the location and the acting, but calling it a comedy is miss- selling in the extreme.  A few comedic lines do not make this into any sort of comedy. Great for those with a decapitation fetish I suppose. A  long winded tragedy more like.  Do not go to see if you at all depressed it might tip you over into the suicidal,  especially if you like donkeys.

I must be uncultured cause honestly this went over my head. I waited and waited and waited for something to happen. Then it did, the rolling credits. Now fair play, good acting from the main characters but otherwise I was so bored I took up knitting and now I have a really nice scarf, its red and it will go with the jumper I am going to do. Exciting stuff, well worth the investment on thread and knitting books. Overall I give knitting a 8/10....oh and the movie, emmm it gets like a bare 5/10.

I could truly feel the sorrow and despair of the characters as well as the loneliness. Despite the sadness of the movie there was a lot of lightness and comedic elements to the story. I recommend it and would watch it again.

Only reason I gave more than 1 star is that the acting is good and nice history lesson of Ireland. But I don't like a movie where I have to look up what it's about to understand it. It's an "allegory of the Irish Civil War". As an American I didn't know what they were talking about! I gather the Irish Civil War is different than the "Troubles". OK, well how about a movie that's educational about that, not allegorical! It's depressing, sad with a muddy point.

Didn't know what to expect. What I got was certainly not a comedy. I was very happy to have watched it. It was a long time ago I saw this sort of quality movie. I hate spoilers, so I won't get into the story, but I would highly recommend it. And as always... don't read anything in advance. It diminishes every movie.

Impecable acting and extremely original.
Must see!

Touched me deeply! An incredible storytelling on human struggle to remain relevant and liked. If the filmmaker had chosen to tell the same story in current social environment , most probably I would have kept my ears shut. Yet he chose to place his narrative 100 years ago, only to realise that human nature evolves with a remarkably slow pace. When the movie finished I was left in deep thinking, full of emotions. Amazing screenplay, exquisite acting MUST see! A great thank you to all contributors!

As a human drama, it's not worth a single star. It's terrible. Pointless, tragic and pointlessly tragic.

As a metaphor for the pointlessly tragic Irish civil war, it's still not worth watching for two hours. The entire film boils down to two points: one is a conversation wherein Gleeson's character says "you've not said anything, you've not done anything, I just reckon I don't actually like you." The other is both characters losing something they love to prove a self-destructive point. The dark humour doesn't serve a purpose beyond trying to make the film palatable...and then it beats you about the room by addressing actual cannonfire from the mainland. Rubbish.

and stark beauty of this film.

Great scenery of an Irish island (the scenery itself makes the movie worth watching). Taking friendship and isolation to the extreme, but weirdly resonating. Acting is of-depth, loved every single character in this movie.

As a huge Brendan Gleeson fan, I may be a touch biased but this film will entertain and haunt you in equal measure. Barry Keoghan was outstanding as Dominic, and deserves his Oscar nomination. His costars Colin Farrell and Kerry Condon are equally brilliant! The scenery which is filmed in Ireland and not CGI is enough of a reason in itself to go watch this film. Enjoy!

Not impressed - and I'm usually into stuff with interesting characters and good stories. It's supposed to be a dark comedy, but it's not at all funny, or even particularly dark. Farrell plays a not-very-bright rural Irishman who sleeps in the same room as his sister and connects with his animals far more than the also not-very-bright, often cruel, occasionally violent people around him. Gleeson is his really not-much-brighter mate, who thinks he's going to leave a musical legacy to rival Mozart if only he can get away from his dim mate. It would all need to be saying something much more worthwhile, or perhaps just be a lot funnier, in order to rise above the obvious and awful stereotyping. The scenery is stunning, of course.
Definitely not an action film, but I did find myself shouting at the tv. I really liked the show, everyone was great, no bad actors or miss casting.
Fecking confusing. The guy really doesn't like fingers.

Worst funking ending to a movie ive ever seen. A lunatic who cuts his fingers off, they kill a man's best friend and then this pile of shite just ends. I hope whoever made this shite dies in a house fire.
Definetly a "must-see" movie. Great performance by leading and supporting actors, all wrapped in stunning views of Ireland.
It was slow and sad. The acting was great and the scenery was beautiful.
So odd at times it's great.  CF should get the oscar

This dark story with compelling characters, expertly embodied, is set against the beautiful and bleak landscape of a remote island off early 20th c. Ireland.  A sure mark of a good movie, the film stays with you. You will be thinking about it and talking about it for weeks. A few amusing scenes, one in a confessional, allow the viewer to forge on despite the pain and darkness, the bewildering and heartbreaking actions of the two main characters, Pádraic and Colm.

Would love to see Kerry Condon and Collin Farrell win Oscars for their roles here. I thought they were incredible and wouldn't mind seeing them pull off an upset. Great writing too. Oh and loved Gleeson and Keoghan!
Had some funny moments but if one of the characters was willing to go to such extremes he needs help it ain't funny. Sad

The acting, scenery and music are all superb. The telling of this spellbinding story becomes unbelievable when Colm goes to the lengths he does  as a result of Padraic's repeated attempts to repair their friendships.  And there's a few other scenes that just don't ring true.  A good idea gone a bit wrong.

Yes, it is beautifully filmed and acted.  Why is this considered a comedy when my only smile was at the kindness of Farrell's character fawning over Jenny, the small and adorable donkey who follows him around and prefers to be in the house. Irrational darkness does not a comedy make.  I was not buying one bit the entire premise of this movie; the interest of the main character's friendship feud,  the eternally sunny Ireland, the lack of shock by the locals seeing Colm's self mutilations, a donkey chocking on a human finger (aren't they herbivories?). Yes, we all get the story's allegory of the Irish Civil War, but come on.  man.  I kept looking at my watch multiple times wondering when it would even get interesting. Or when it would be over. Dreary and dull.  Will anyone tell their friends they just have to see this movie?  Will anyone ever watch this movie a second time?  I doubt it.

Overall, Banshees of Inisherin is a well made and acted movie. It wasn't particularly enjoyable to watch and my biggest beef with it is that it IS NOT a comedy and yet it's being heralded as one, even winning Best Motion Picture- Comedy at the Golden Globes. A tragedy with a few funny lines does not become a dark comedy. It was a wonderful metaphor for the pointlessness of the Irish war but don't go into it thinking you're going to walk away feeling anything but upset.
The irony of watching a man cut off his fingers because the lead character is so boring has not been lost on me.  Wear gloves when you watch this film!

I don't want to spoil anything for people who haven't seen the movie yet, so I'll speak in generalities here. 

On the face of it, this is a story of two men, one-time friends, who take actions that sabotage the very things they each want most in the world: connection, respect, peace, acceptance. 

Exaggerated to the point of shocking, this story points to something universal in humans: we can be our own worst enemies, undermining the possibility of mutually caring relationships, which we all need.

Colm and Pádraic's fighting has been called a metaphor for the Irish Civil War that's going on on the mainland. Gunshots are within hearing across the water throughout the movie. As one reviewer sums it up, "Through their in-fighting, they destroyed themselves." We've all seen and maybe even been in relationships like that between people and between peoples. A visitor from another planet at any era in our history might shake its head at our folly with dismay—"you all make no sense"—just as we do while watching this movie. 

Watching with compassion for the characters—and the excellent acting does invite empathy—I'm left longing for all such stupidity and unnecessary misery to end once and for all. 

Any great tragedy has a similar impact. I'm left looking into my own heart. In this case, I might ask, Where do I sabotage myself? Where do I undermine my own chances to experience happiness and contribute to the well-being of others? In what ways have I been blind to being my own worst enemy, and what has the impact been on others?

If even a few people come away from the movie with that kind of soul-searching, it deserves whatever prizes it may get.
Great acting, slow and sad at times, funny at others, must watch.
While it certainly is a sad movie, the acting is terrific and there are some incredible visuals of the scenery. It does a good job of keeping you hooked throughout the entire  movie.

Terrible movie, just awful. Do not see this. Incredibly boring and pointless. Acting was okay and definitely not as awesome as all of these "critics" say. Are there really people this dumb? I don't believe anyone would act this way. No redemptive value. Terrible ending. My wife and I absolutely hated this and want our 2 hours back. The Irish accents and dialogue was fun in maybe threes scenes, that's all tge good I can say about this movie.
Such a weird film!!! I watched it because collin pharrell is nominated for an Oscar, but honestly, this was really bad.

Something about the slow pace of a small island place people's story that turns for the worse with, still, humor aspects in it makes this a great movie to me. Not to mention the mesmerizing sceneries which fit perfectly to the sequence of events that build up in the movie. Very refreshing with astonishing acting!

I never found it interesting. I was never able to finish watching this movie. I'm saddened by the fact I couldn't like a movie liked by most, but I guess that is what happens when you watch a Bri'ish movie.
I DO NOT CARE WHAT AWARDS BANSHEE GOT OR GETS, IT WAS EXCRUCIATING TO SIT THROUGH. MY WIFE AND I EMERGED FROM THIS FILM WITH INTENSE HEADACHES.
So much of this film is a metaphor and the more you think about it it is a very philosophical film.
Very slow and fairly boring it's just about two guys having a pointless argument that barely goes anywhere. Acting was good though with some pretty cinematography.

Two of the most basic human desires are the desire for meaning and the desire for belonging. In The Banshees of Inisherin, these desires are personified by two of Ireland's best actors: Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell, respectively.

But these desires, real and present in everyone, can kill us if they take over. And they do take over here. Every character in this movie is somewhat of an island (ironic, because they are living on a small, isolated island!), left to search for meaning and belonging on their own, and some fare better than others.

It's a dark comedy, emphasis on dark, with plenty of tragedy thrown in for balance. Gleeson's and Farrell's characters resolve for the paths they have chosen are well balanced by more hopeful characters placed around them, played by Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan.

The conflict feels like an eternal human conflict, yet also feels timely and pressing for today, as isolation is so present in our searches for meaning and belonging.

The fictional isle of Inisherin provides a beautiful, threatening, lonely backdrop for this story, heightening the emotions our characters feel. And the banshees - well, they're not real. But their presence looms large regardless.
Excellent acting performances and beautiful scenery counterbalance the slow pace. Thoughtful graphic depictions of mutilation and painful mental struggles kept me immersed in this film. Well done!
Was it beautifully painful or painfully beautiful?

Slow moving, quirky, and darkly humorous, this movie wouldn't be for everyone, but I personally enjoyed it. There's even a moral lesson in it - don't waste your life with people who do nothing to enrich it when you have other more productive things to do.
Miserable, slow pace, awkward and boring movie that critics love.
An absolute must seen. Incredible scenery and outstanding performances. I simply love it.
A friend of mine couldn't watch it saying it was too sad. Yes, life is tough. Friendships, siblings, love, death can be sad. But beautifully portrayed, shot and acted. Loved it

Contains spoilers - Brendon G. is one of my favorite actors and I try to watch most things he is in.  I won't be watching this again.  The premise is completely ridiculous. One of two long time friends decides the other is boring and taking up too much of his time that he would rather use to write violin music.  Instead of doing the reasonable thing, telling his friend he needs to give him some time to write music, he tells his friend to never talk to him again or else he'll start severing his own appendages.  When his heart broken friend can't stay away, fingers start flying.

It takes place in a make believe world where someone can chop off all their fingers on one hand without much pain, bleeding to death or getting a life threatening infection.  Its a crazy place where people exist that think chopping fingers off of their violin playing hand is the best way to end a friendship.  Its also a place where townspeople aren't really shocked by self-mutilation.
Absolutely brilliant! Great movie. Funny but yet emotional.

The acting is top notch throughout the entire cast.  The movie was a letdown considering the critics rave reviews.  Overall, a film worthy a viewing but probably not two.  Check out "In Bruges" for a more enjoyable dark comedy.

A truly depressing movie.  The cinematography was good, the acting was good, but I just felt sad for everyone  involved.  Kept hoping for a ray of sunshine in this storyline but there just wasn't one.

Yes the scenery is beautiful and the film is charming and intriguing all at once but I found myself waiting for something to happen, which I guess is kind of the point of this film, nothing much happens, so then when something does it seems more tragic and shocking than it might have been in other movies.  A Sunday afternoon rainy day watch.

I thought it was awful. Dark, gruesome and depressing. The 5 of us walked out after 4 fingers were cut off.
The part star is for the scenery of Ireland.

The day i've started watching the movie my friend called me to say that her bf left her for a younger girl & i was thinking that i can't think of a single good book or movie about when it happens to a woman & her perspective on it.
Watching this movie that evening it was very close to the situation- what happens when your best friend just decides to drop all communication with you? How do you feel about it, what are the thoughts that are going through your mind & what 'stories' do you tell yourself to make sure you preserve your self esteem?
All of these questions are really well dealt with here (not to say they are solves as if the director would solve them it'll be a shit movie). Another very interesting aspect of this movie is that all of this happens in a very small community. It's very common for us to live in big cities today & if we don't like someone or he/she involves painful memories we can easily not see that person anymore but in that place & in that time one has to deal with who they have around them & it's not much to say the least. Beautiful movie about friendship, loss, loneliness & relationships

While the performances were exceptional, what the actors were performing was rotten. Dark, bleak, a few weird laughs, and while you wait for some growth in the characters and a positive message from the story, it never comes. In fact the opposite is true. The characters regress and the message is just more bleakness. The movie leaves you feeling like crap. The actors deserve praise for their performances, the movie is awful.
Outstanding acting. Beautiful filmography. But unfortunately the story doesn't work…at all.

The script is really well written and the acting is fantastic. I really loved this movie. It made me feel like I did back in school sitting in the library and listening to the librarian read a very exciting fable out loud. You'll get pulled in to this story.

Let's not get carried away by scenery, actors and all things Irish. It was okay but wasn't 97 out of 100 great. The story started with an interesting premise but ended up in the most ridiculous end of folktale horror. Don't expect Citizen Kane; this is a movie about some daft people living on a small island.
One of those slow movies you can't turn off, it was great dark humor with great acting!

It was a lot funnier than the synopsis suggests. Down to excellent dialogue and outstanding acting from not only the main characters but also the minor characters. Cant understand why it didn't do better in the BAFTAs. Definitely go and see it

It's well-made. It's a stream of consciousness film without any real idea, other than the exchange of angst between a few folks on an island. Not to mention, there's some  spectacularly unpleasant sequences thrown in with very little cause. The idea that THIS ever beat "Everything at Once" in any award show is ridiculous.

This film is not for everyone (as with most best movie nominees). It is slow and features a lot of talking and Irish slang. But I appreciated the humor in this dark comedy. Not laugh-out-loud funny, but smiling every 10 minutes sort of funny. More importantly, the 2 main characters played great opposite each other. It's not easy to make "not wanting to be friends anymore" become a dramatic story. And most clever of all was how this fight between best friends over nothing was symbolic of the Irish civil war going on in the background.
A nice blend of sad humor, angst, and thought provoking parable. Performances were all great and the cinematography was good.
Banshees is a miserable but well filmed movie. It is not entertaining and is quite sad with mental distress and self harm and suicide.
I thought I would hate it....I didn't. it is one of the best this past year
Sucked. Would rather watch people drown themselves. Stupid.
Good movie. I can understand why it was nominated for an Oscar as it's your typical dark comedy and drama. However, I am glad that I streamed it at home, rather than paying for a movie ticket.

As said by many others, great acting and scenery. The story line of Barry Keoghan  made some sense. The rest was utter rubbish and made no sense whatsoever to me, even with the nod to the civil war. I will remember it for the mutilation and for the reaction it's caused among those who enjoyed it and those who didn't!
Brilliant acting, moody scenery, dry humour...one of the best films I've seen in a long while ! Farrell and Gleeson are totally believable and a great pairing.

I am stunned that this movie got so many great reviews I can understand why the actors themselves would get reviews I guess but what a horrific movie. My daughter said I wouldn't like it but I wanted to watch it anyhow because I love the actors but she was right don't watch it

Great actors and beautiful scenery.  A numbingly pointless and absurd script.  The dramatic premise driving the storyline is stupid.  Overrated film made by excellent filmmakers and cast who are capable of so much more.

Such a bad story all about toxic masculinity, who needs it. The big movement/tension release is when the only smart one, the sister, moves away. I checked with my son to see if I am too much of a feminist for this movie;  and he said no, he felt exactly the same way, a waste of his time.

Set on an idyllic island off Ireland, Martin McDonough's black tragicomedy opens with an abrupt end to a long-standing friendship, proceeds to intrigue with a development hinted at existential crisis and closes with an esoteric ending coming to grips with the vicious cycle of loneliness and depression.

Original, beautifully filmed, powerfully acted masterpiece with an extraordinary screenplay! Colin Ferrell, Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan give powerful performances! There is so much greatness and layers to this story! Another winner for our very best writer, Martin McDonagh.
A strange movie that kept me on my toes. Can't say it is my favorite but it was something new with amazing points.

This is a perfect film. We don't think Ben Davis cinematography or Carter Burwell score get enough credit. But the awards keep  pouring in for Best Picture, Best Actors, Best Screenplay and Best director, so I think that tells you why we think Banshees is a perfect film. It's certainly McDonagh's perfect screenplay. The master of dark comedy takes it deeper into tragicomedy with this one. The story is profound. One viewing only takes away one layer.  The dissolution of both men comes  to a gut punch at the end. Fans have filled YouTube with debates for weeks now about the layers of meaning here. The metaphors, the foreshadowing, the symbolism. It's wonderful to read all the interpretations.
If the tragedy of the story gets you down, you are not seeing the gallows humor peppered throughout. We saw it twice in a theater and the audience 😆 as the hilarious scenes were weaved into the sorrowful ones. This really is a masterpiece. And the 4 performances are absolutely extraordinary. All four nominated by every awards groups. As is McDonagh for directing and screenplay. This is truly a must-see. At least twice. The Irish brogue is much clearer too.☺️ We've streamed it four more times since November and are still chewing on it.  Best film of 2022.
Another fantastic film from Martin McDonagh
I hated this movie with a passion. With the world as it is, no one needs invented misery. I wish it had never been made and I want those hours of my life back.
Not the jolliest film you will see, nor the most uplifting, but an original, very believable script, beautifully performed. This is what stood out for me.
A film that will be remembered for a long time. People have so hidden who they are inside. 1923 and 2023 and it doesn't matter.

I honestly cannot believe that this movie has garnered so many award nominations. It made absolutely no sense to me. The plot line is so dumb and to think anybody would cut off all of his fingers because he doesn’t want to be friends with somebody is ludicrous.

Many people will recognize the scenery or the performances, and idk. I just kinda feel like a compelling story is a pretty compelling ingredient when it comes to making a good movie. Was is strange and different? Sure. Were there scenes that made you think or feel? A few of them. But fundamentally, at the core of this story, one man decides he no longer wants to be friends with the other. It just doesn't hook me. And it takes so long to escalate the conflict and advance the story, that by the time you get to any sort of payoff, I just don't care. It's a boring story.

It is disturbing that this movie has received critical acclaim.  Nothing remotely humourous about the mentally ill characters in this story, nor the self-mutilation by the lead character.  Anyone who finds this entertaining is also disturbed and needs psychiatric help.  This movie is sick and pointless.

A bizarre one for sure.  I did appreciate the slowly moving story that showed me a part of Ireland I hadn't seen.  Despite the fiction, it still was great acting and engaging a story.  Is it best picture material, prolly not.  It was on HBO.

Possibly the worst film I have ever seen.........Truly horrid.........cannot believe it would be up for any awards.........Every sentence from every person is mean ,sick and/or distorted literally!!!!...............Also violent in a wierd distorted way.........we were told there was no violence and that was not true............my ancestors are from the Islands of Ireland and this film is an insult to them..............we stayed thinking there would be a lift up or a spark of kindness but never happened.........read the other 1 star reviews to get more info...........One guy says his wife got physically ill and I can understand...........This is not art......................

Good acting and gorgeous cinematography is not enough to keep one awake in a slow moving plot. I think the metaphor of the film is quite interesting, but the execution of it all is so tedious that it leads to an underwhelming build up. Definitely a film that I strongly disagree with critics. It should be 71-74% on rotten tomatoes, not in the high 90s.

Not what I expected. The hillside villagers provided many twists and turns. GREAT cast! Some have this listed under a 'comedy' film, I disagree. Not so much a psychological drama, but a psychological dilemma.

Good acting, locations and cinematography do not automatically combine to make a good film! I laughed a few times, I winced a lot more but ultimately this seems to be "The Kings New Clothes" of films at the moment.

To be fair, my friend thought this was a comedy. When I heard the term "Irish" and "dark," I should have guessed it would be bloody depressing. I don't tend to find a lot of belly laughs in stupidity but an extra star for the scenery. I'm sure it will get a bunch of Oscars, leaving us feeling even more confused and depressed.

If I was to compare this film to a light bulb it would be a 1 watt bulb very little light to shed I would dare to suggest that it is a film that would help severe cases of insomnia to fall asleep
This film is not for me
Boring movie about 2 psychopaths posing as normal human beings
Very boring, good acting but boring overall.

It's a superb film with a ton of layers and meanings. The acting, script and subtlety arev a joy to behold. However, anyone expecting Father Ted will be shocked. This is very adult material and it's increasingly dark. But, what a film.

Acclaimed playwright and director Martin McDonagh delivers another masterful ensemble piece to audiences with his latest film "The Banshees of Inisherin". The black comedy reunites leads Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson with McDonagh, who directed them both in his 2008 Oscar-nominated film "In Bruges". After it's world premiere at this year's Venice International Film Festival, the film went on to receive a rapturous 15-minute standing ovation, five minutes longer than McDonagh's previous film "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri". 

The film takes place in 1920s Ireland, against the backdrop of the Irish Civil War, on the fictional island of Inisherin and tells the story of two friends Pádraic (Farrell) and Colm (Gleeson). One day, Colm decides to abruptly end his long-running friendship with Pádraic, claiming the man is ‘too dull' for him to spend the rest of his life around. An escalating battle then begins between the two friends, and it soon becomes the talk of the village, with many just as confused as Pádraic with Colm's decision. As the growing tensions between the two grow, it's not long before it boils over and results in devastating consequences for both feuding men. 

Colin Farrell leads an uber-talented cast comprised of some of Ireland's greatest talents like Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon, and Barry Keoghan, all delivering knockout performances. Farrell's work is almost certain to land him a spot in this year's Best Actor line-up as he plays Pádraic, the harmless easy-going farmer, until he finally snaps and becomes a ruthless man out for revenge, and perhaps that's what makes his performance so fascinating to watch unfold on the big screen. The friendship Farrell shares with his co-star Brendan Gleeson elevates both performances making them feel much more authentic and believable. The pair share a hilarious back and forth that's embellished by McDonagh's screenplay. Gleeson's role as Colm, a man who finds himself in the later years of his life wishing to be more creative, and have more interesting conversations with those around him, is terrific and perfectly compliments Farrell's performance. The film's other standout performance, alongside Farrell's, comes from Kerry Condon. The Irish actress, probably best known for voicing ‘Friday' in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, gives a marvellous turn as Pádraic's sister, Siobhan. Condon ends up acting as a mediator between the two men, trying to keep them apart to prevent Colm from resorting to drastic action. Condon boosts every scene she's in to a whole other level and she ends up being one of the best parts of the film. 

Director Martin McDonagh pens a screenplay that balances side-splitting hilarity with tear-jerking emotion and reminds you exactly why he has two Oscar-nominations for writing under his belt. It's sharp, witty, and brilliantly tells the story of what happens when a friendship turns sour. McDonagh does a skilful job blending the comedic tones at the start of the film with the tragedy and drama that becomes more dominant towards the end. This balance, combined with McDonagh's sensational directorial effort, makes "The Banshees of Inisherin" such a unique and entertaining film. Perhaps what else makes the film so good, and sets it apart from a large majority of this year's awards contenders, is that it isn't an intricate biopic about a famous figure or some overbearing think piece, but is instead a rich, amusing film about friendship. 

"The Banshees of Inisherin" brings some delightful visuals to the screen alongside the engaging narrative and likeable characters. Cinematographer Ben Davis, who worked with McDonagh on "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri", uses the scenic Irish coastlines to his advantage to effortlessly enhance the natural beauty of the film.

Not even close to "In Bruges".  It could have been a well made film with superb acting, photography, scenery.  But what was the point in that plot? Was there an allegory that I may have missed? Don't know.  Coulda, woulda, shoulda...
Beautiful cinematography and great soundtrack. Also nice acting. Just not my cup of tea for a story.

This film has a gentle pace and pleasantly ambles through a pretty odd tale of two, hitherto friends. The acting from all the cast members is amazing and the setting is beautifully simple. I'd describe it as enjoyable overall. For some it may miss the mark and be a bit of a head-scratcher, for others it will be a master-class.

If you were a fan of In Bruges, then this is an absolute must watch. Gleeson and Farrell hit the freaking bell with their chemistry again and it's so good!!! 

Kerry Kondan delivers a masterful performance which commands every scene she is in. Barry Keoghan likewise sends it in this movie. He will wrench your heart out and you'll thank him for it. 

Every bit of dialogue, let alone conversation, is expertly crafted to extract the most out of what needs to happen. Expect laughs and tears in equal numbers. 

The setting will also have you wide eyed the whole way through. The stark expanses of the Irish islands are breathtaking. 

All in all it might not be for everyone if you aren't looking for a dialogue heavy dark comedic drama, but if that's your thing.... watch it yesterday.

It's a boring movie, about the boring life of boring people in a small boring island in 1923.....Simply the most pointless movie I have ever watched. It's shocking that, with so many great stories waiting to be told, such a numb tale ever got made into a movie. Even worse is the fact it got many Oscar nominations. It's not brilliant, it's not insightful, it's not touching, it's does not make you go into deep personal reflection... it's just plain boring!
The acting was superb, beautiful scenery.
Wonderful movie, great acting, beautiful scenery. Plot twist I didn't see coming - wonderful resolution at the end of the movie.
Beautiful to behold and beautifully acted, this film doesn't reveal itself to you unless you really sit and let it wash over you. If you do, you will be rewarded.
Amazing scenery, a little strange plot, captivating characters,  a few wtf moments, maybe even a few tears.

I'm guessing the negative fan reviews come from people that bailed within 30 mins because of the pace. The movie builds like a steam train. Starts off at a stall and by the end it's off the rails. One the best Collin Ferrel films. Go Movies!
Macabre story. Stark and bleak scenery. Not my cup of tea.
Some of the best actors in the world, depicting the remotenrss,madness, community & clanish nature of island life 100yrs ago in ireland.
Super depressing film. Kept waiting for there to be more to the story. Cutting off fingers? Stupid. Very disappointed, Academy Award worthy? Maybe that's why I don't watch the awards anymore.
I honestly do not understand the positive rating of this movie.  It had very little story, was dark, disturbing and needlessly tragic.

While the story isn't very exciting my attention was kept the whole movie. Likely for two reasons - the acting was as good as it was and there were a lot of funny moments. Speaking of which Barry Keoghan was fantastic. He's proved to be an amazing actor. Someone I'd watch a movie for the main reason of him being in it. Closed captions were a must, which I don't really mind but if I had watched this in theatres I would have missed half of what was said. Solid story but it didn't flesh out how I would have wanted it to.

People who did not like the movie perhaps did not get the allegory presented here.  It's about the Irish Civil War.  The pointless nature of cutting off friends and relatives for religion.  In the truest sense it's a different spin on 'cutting off your nose to spite your face.'  It's NOT a comedy - it's a dark dramedy.  Colin Farrell is heartbreaking, Barry Keoghan is a revelation as the town 'gom'.  Kerri Condon is the perfect sister/foil to Padraic and Brendon Gleeson is amazing as the no-longer-friend.  Cinematography is first rate, beautiful.

I couldn't finish it. It was really well made, but some stories don't bear telling. The plot was so dark that I kept hoping it would brighten up, and was continually disappointed. It started out with some potential, but by the time self-mutilation happened, it got to the point where it was unpalatable.
Absolutely a genius piece of art.
Definitely thought it would be better then what it actually is, slow and monotonous.

We decided to watch this based on the high reviews and cast. We were very disappointed in everything about this film.  Very slow paced, dismal storyline and bleak ending.  There are a few cleaver lines throughout but not enough to offset the negative vibe. Felt very pointless when we finished watching and have difficulty understanding the rave reviews given so far.
Great acting, wonderful photography, but the story is sad and also strange and not satisfying at all, even if you understand the parallell of the friendship with the Irish Civil War.
Excellent movie with a phenomenal cast playing interesting characters.
Oscar worthy! Fantastic!
Despite its depressing  features the banshees of Inisherin delivers with a great cast, good humor and  a great lead performance  this is film is a success in many ways.

This was one of the saddest movies I have ever seen. I didn't find it humorous at all. The acting was brilliant. Love Brendan Gleason and Colin Farrell,but it was sooo depressing.  I do not recommend this movie.
Great acting but the story is crazy - and not really believable
Dark, dismal, beautiful cinematography & disturbingly humorous at times. The acting is superb.

I'm not a fan of the ubiquitous CGI/action/Marvel drivel that has been spewing from Hollywood for the past 5 - 10 years now, and love a well written, compelling, drama performed by great actors. This movie was neither. Don't misunderstand. The acting from all involved was amazing. But the story wend from pointless, to monotonous, to boring, and finally disturbing... not your classic story arch. At an hour and a half in, my wife stood up and walked away.  Since I didn't see it in the theater, I can't ask for my money back.  So maybe I should write a letter and demand those two wasted hours of my life back. 

PS those husk-brained, echo-chamber critics are wrong AGAIN.

Actors were great. However, the movie was the worst I've ever seen. 2 hours of misery. I kept expecting something to happen, but just more of the same. I didn't expect very much, but I was still disappointed. Do yourself a favour and give it a miss. Really can't understanding the good audience rating.  By the way, this is definitely NOT a comedy as listed in the movie details, it is a very sad, miserable story likely to leave you feeling a little depressed.

Thank you Martin Macdonah for the best film I have watched in a very long time. Great to see Farrell and Gleeson re-united after the In Bruges triumph. At some point in your life you reach a moment when you enjoy nothing much happening slowly. Car chases and shoot outs make me reach for the "clicker" but this ticked all my my boxes; though sometimes I thought the donkey was moving a bit too quickly!! Another triumph with a fantastic supporting cast in Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan and a perfectly written screenplay. I hope to see more from Gleeson and Farrell in a similar vein. A fall-out between two mates, in an island community, with unimaginable consequences.

As "The Banchees of Inisherin" (2022 release from Ireland; 114 min) opens, the Colin Farrell character, a guy named Padriac, stops by the Breandon Gleeson character, a guy named Colm who is Padriac's best friend. That is, until that moment. For reasons unknown, Colm wants nothing more to do with Padriac. "I just don't like you anymore" Colm offers. The calendar shows "April 1, 1923", and Padriac doesn't take this unexplained change of behavior by Colm very well... At this point we are 10 min into the movie.

Couple of comments: this is the highly anticipated reunion of writer-director Martin McDonagh, and lead performers Farrell and Gleeson, 14 years after the now classic "In Bruges". I too was eager to see how this reunion would play out, but then something completely unexpected happened: I found the Colin Farrell character to be irritating and off-putting, to the point where it was almost too much to bear or see. Without spoiling anything, I will say that things are somewhat better in the movie's second hour. But I could never get into the proper flow of the movie, let alone rave about it as many others have done. I completely understand that my viewpoint is definitely in the minority. And that this film has been hailed critically (it's currently rated 97% Certified Fresh on Rotten Tomatoes). The most striking thing about the movie for me was the strong performance of Barry Keoghan (who starred in "Dunkirk" a few years back). This is a subjective opinion of course.

"The Banchees of Inisherin" premiered at this year's Venice Film Festival to universal acclaim, and opened in theaters in November. The Sunday early evening screening where I saw this at my local art-house theater here in Cincinnati was attended okay (I counted about 15 people). If you are a fan of Martin McDonagh's earlier work of or Colin Farrell or Brendon Gleeson, I'd readily suggest you check this out, and draw your own conclusion.
It's advertised as a comedy but it's not funny it's more of a drama and when I finally got invested it ended not bad but in my opinion the pretty mid 5/10
The acting is superb and carried the movie. Plot is a bit aimless, but very original. Overall is a bit depressing, but a good watch.
Movie made absolutely no sense whatsoever
An awful pointless depressive movie. People don't behave so cruelly and pointlessly, even not the more disturbed of us.

What a well-crafted film. It film manages to combine a rich sense of humour with the reality of a failing friendship. The ending might not be for everyone, but everything leading up to it is more than satisfying.
Very strange premise and plot - but amazing performances and gorgeous scenery.
I can see why folks may like this film. I just didn’t.
Amazing tale of how friendship can tear you apart any second. 4.7/5
Crushing yet hilarious.  And what scenery.

Banshees completely lacks the savage charm of In Bruges !
What is left is sad and ultimately unfulfilling to me, but clearly this is a matter of taste.

Beautifully shot and surprisingly moving film. The two leads are phenomenal and while the plot itself gets a bit ridiculous, it's amazing how often it hits a raw nerve. 
Recommended.

These, Oscar nominated films, do not live up to the excitement of what the award was created for. These films are aren't based, and more of a low budget miss for the audience. We not only as an audience member want to see the movies we love on the big screen, but we also enjoy the chances that the film industry take on these type of films. I feel like this film was just good for Collin, and maybe Barry as well. But the rest of the film just fell flat for me. It felt like a very long drawn out boring time in the theater.

I want to watch this movie everyday, but I also don't like to cry and have my heart ripped out on the daily so I won't.  But oh my gosh, this touched me in so many ways, along with being well woven with metaphor and symbolism, making is satisfying in emotional and intellectual ways.

A movie with clear award aspirations. I'd submit it succeeded. 
The essential ingredients of this movie are excellent. A fantastic and interesting screenplay. Top caliber acting throughout from the leads to smaller side characters. Beautifully shot and wonderfully composed. Atmospheric and engaging. It is difficult to fault any of those classic ingredients. Uniformly of high-quality top to bottom. 
The second piece is how well do the essential parts come together. Sometimes a movie is less than the sum of its parts, or an Oscar winning performance is all a piece really offers amongst other flaws. I think this movie attains the cliché of being more than the sum of its great pieces. The movie has a simple and, in some ways, predictable narrative start and end. The meat of this journey though is built on a deeply strange turn and a bit of a quirky premise. The main characters, we are led to believe, were once good friends, or at least spent much time together.   One day the smarmy tortured genius (Gleeson, born to be that character) decides his time is better spent not hanging around the dim-witted nice fellow (Farrell). He wants to be remembered with his music, not the friendships of people who will die. The genius let's the dullard know as much, and he takes the news not well , with confusion and hurt. Our dull man, you see, just strives to get along. The genius' plan, creative and full of that smarm, is to mutilate himself every time our nice dull person offends his decision to be left alone. It is extreme and seems remarkably odd for our supposed once great friends.
I do not profess to know enough about the nitty gritty details of the Irish Civil War, which is the period, setting and backdrop of this film. I am not sure you need to know a lot to surmise that a civil war about how to settle a treaty, where the past allies of an independence war turn on one another, has many parallels to this story. I am not sure the point of the movie is that. I think the theme is more universal and emotional. In Irish tradition, I think the point is exploring people surrounded, consumed, and trapped by their grief and loneliness. 
You never get the full details of the main characters backgrounds, except for Dominic, played with a measured and wonderful performance by Barry Keoghan. We know the sources of Dominic's pain rooted in abuse and torment. The other characters we can guess, but it's clear no one here has a healthy life path. Only one character, Siobhan (a brilliant performance by Kerry Condon), the dull man's sister escapes the trappings of the island. Even that act of escaping, helps bring about the ruin of those still inside. 
The great trick of the movie, at least in my view, is how the measured actions of the characters lead to their unravelling without them intending it to happen.  There is some element of dessert in the result, but the end here lacks the usual trapping of karma. The end isn't poetic justice of obvious choices leading to that end, but relatable mistakes rooted in grief. In my mind, that is why it is so incredibly fascinating to watch. 
The things we discover post break up is the flaws of our characters, revealed, or maybe caused by the split. We discover that our genius, as revealed in a bar scene with the dull man's truly brilliant sister, might not be the Mozart in waiting he hopes. Our dull nice man might also not be so nice when pushed by confusion, guilt and isolation. Our dullard lies to a man, with a splash of comedic innocence, as part of a plan to win back his smart friend. The ripple effects of the two sides respective choices become vast, dark and lead to deep lasting scars in the community of Inisherin. The dull man's choices dissolution his vulnerable friend, Dominic and speed about his own consumption by grief. The smart man's disregard for feelings or normal social concern has disastrous results when he, without any overt malice, kills Farrell's last remaining companion, Jenny, the donkey. This is the last straw from the hurt dull man who thereafter escalates the feud past the point of return. Whose fault is all this pain? Hard to say, probably no one and everyone. 
Maybe that is the nature of grief and stubborn isolation. It consumes and destroys everything around it, even if you don't mean it to, maybe even if you mean the opposite. I am not sure the smart man's hope to be left alone was all that sinister. Nor were the dull man's hopes to keep his friend all that wrong. The irony being both characters complemented each other in so many ways.

I love the humor in this film, the way it cuts through all the pathos and sadness. That's human nature in a nutshell. I slightly prefer "In Bruges," a film I've seen 5 or 6 times. But this one is just as rewatchable.
I really enjoyed this which says a lot considering how bleak it is. I mean that in all the best ways. This is Oscar level film making. No flaws. Hilairious and heartbreaking.

Each year, I try to watch most of the movies nominated for an Oscar. Prior to the Oscar list, I had never heard of this movie, so I watched it. I don't know if I even understand the plot, at this point! I guess my questions begin with, "Why?!" 
* Why was this movie made?
* Why is it so engaging when the plot is so….outlandish?
* Why is it nominated for an Oscar? 
I'm going to recommend watching it so you can come to your own conclusions. This movie has me perplexed.

Very absorbing. Outstanding performances from the cast to bring to life a sad, often witty but emotional tale about the mundane life on a small island where nothing much happens. What holds your attention is not the subject matter itself so much as the intensity of the feelings of these ordinary folk as they are forced to confront the truth about themselves.

Martin McDonagh missed the mark on this one for me. Great supporting cast, especially Barry Keoghan, but in my opinion a wildly overrated performance from Farrell. The storyline, while original, doesn't quite come together in time.

One of the worst movies I have ever seen with one bleak scene after another with depressing sick mind states and no trace of saving grace at all........none of humanities higher inherent goodness.........just sad and a bunch of depressed people that spend their time attacking one another and themselves........If this movie wins best picture as a culture we are in trouble

My favorite movie of 2022. It’s dry…and if that’s your kind of humor you will enjoy this dark comedy. If you don’t like dry European humor….you won’t understand what the hype is all about. My recommendation watch it and enjoy great acting. Ultimately it’s a story about the inner societal conflicts of Ireland. Worth full price
The acting is fantastic, the music and scenery is beautiful and the clothes make me reassess my style. The story is a bit grim but challenges the mind.

Wow

I haven't felt so completely absorbed and thought provoked in a cinema, in a very, very long time, perhaps ever. The Banshees of Inisherin delivers a mind blowing analysis on the breaking of a friendship and the war between two personalities, that is a tragic and brilliant metaphor for the war between enemies, in this case specifically the Irish civil war. 
Outstandingly performed by the lead roles, the characters in Banshees are all so complex and powerful, that you completely forget that you have seen the talented actors who play them before, and feel convinced you are looking at authentic people in real life. I did not see Brendan Gleeson for most of the movie, after about 10 seconds of him on screen, I only saw Colm. 
In praise of subtle performance I was while watching this movie. Pauses between lines and full ranges of emotions expressed in silent facial expressions transform the simplest of conversation topics in the movie, into full blown literary scenes.
Even side characters like the priest, the cop, and Dominic, are all in there own, such crucial and full people, despite how little time they might share next to the leads Glesson, Farrel, and Condon.

What an incredible effect this comedic and dramatic writing had on the audience. While feeling tense and petrified throughout the movie, you also find yourself laughing at moments right through until the end. It is one of the many aspects that makes it feel jarring, and it somehow lightens the load of the story, which makes what is happening feel somewhat normal. The leads, while committing and observing such disturbing acts, stay civil. It brings it back from a horrific violent tragedy, and makes it feel like a simple fight between friends again. It allows us to observe the breakup of this friendship in a more sound way, despite the gruesome undertones and imagery.

I hope I am making sense, but the movie, in doing this, becomes a perfect metaphor for war. For example, in a war, one hundred people could die in a battle, and then the war can end the next day, and suddenly everything would be alright between the two parties. The armies captains could shake hands and go their separate ways, as if no-one was killed, all sense of morality is lost. The result of the war, being a destruction of each party, because neither would stop.
That is what is mainly represented by The Banshees of Inisherin, the complete loss of morality, with the disregard of destroying ones self. Colms character has no remorse about ending the friendship and cutting off his fingers as a message, just as Padraic has no remorse over carrying on talking to Colm, despite Colms self harm.
Both parties, just like in war, will end up destroying themselves. Colm loses his ability to play music, the only reason he started this dark journey, and Padraic loses his sister. Again a synonym for what he was trying to preserve by carrying on - a loving connection. Padraic also loses his ‘niceness', another aspect of life that was important to him, which brings me to the cause of the battle, and the question asked by it.

What is more important, niceness and everyday deeds that those around you can appreciate, or leaving a mark on the world, whatever the cost, that people will appreciate for centuries? That is the question The Banshees of Inisherin asks us. What is interesting however is that we never see the desired result for either of the characters efforts, we never hear Colms song played in full, representing that it did not have an everlasting affect that Colm intended to, instead the movie focused on his grotesque self mutilation, leaving an everlasting sense of damage of himself and their friendship. That is what Colm achieved. Padraic never achieved exhibiting niceness as he intended to, instead we focus on his drive to harm, first emotionally, then physically, and the lasting theme is his angry nature.

In the end The Banshees of Inisherin is an incredible metaphor for war and battle, and it is a culmination of themes that when put together, will leave you dazed, and in awe of the human nature.

SUFFERING FOOLS

The Irish really are an island unto themselves, and that may be the point of this movie. Loved and despised in equal doses, "The Banshees of Inisherin" nevertheless is rewarding cinema. Set solely on the gloriously green rolling knolls of a cute island (sit down tourists, no such place) where the rain only sprinkles at night, the muffled sounds of revolutionary shots fired are at a safe distance on the mainland, and the locals gather daily at the local pub. All seems idyllic in the charming farming community, until a long-standing friendship is suddenly disrupted. Forget small town, this is a small island, where everyone not only knows everyone, but appear to have no will to escape. 

The break-up, abrupt, congenial, silent, eats away at a confused Padraic (Colin Farrell and his expressive eyebrows). A simple man, his confusion and childlike determination to mend matters with the stoic and complicated Colm (Brendan Gleeson) is rife with comedic tension, until, well, until things get way out of hand.

The battle of wills takes on an unsavoury, physical bent that becomes the knife twist in the film. One which tests an audiences' mettle. An allegory for the warring factions on the horizon, the odd couples' relationship runs the gamut of absurd to horrific. A tragic comedy that delivers more victims than victors. 

Farrell and Gleeson are superb, bringing plenty of grand ideas to the table - the regiment of life, the role of friendship, reinventing oneself, the cuffs of relationships, unrequited love, vengeance, and mortality. Plus a bunch more. Sunny yet dark. Do a favour with a viewing.

-	hipCRANK

I bought it on Vudu and kind of regret. If you would look at it as a cake it is wonderful, all what makes the movie is top quality. Yet, it is not clear to me what this movie wants exactly. To depict human depression in a small town.
From moment to moment, the movie touches horror elements, but then again it is not clear where it goes to. I could create a similar movie from the events that are happening in my building. They would create a similar desperate atmosphere for sure.
If you think that it has 9 Oscar nominations, you could think that is must be something, right? It is simply not. I have no desire to watch it again, and I watched it just for educational purposes to have a topic for conversation. On my own, if I knew any of it what I know now, I would not watch it.
Strange that so much creative energy is built into something that is nothing, not a comedy, not a drama, not a horror, just a blend of it that is a canvas.
Substance is missing, there is not a single scene that I will remember permanently. Maybe it would work as a theatrical performance, because in time it would develop into something more substantial. This... nothing, just a nicely done postcard from Ireland. I wish it was at least tedious, but it is not even that.
I enjoyed the acting but not so much the "grown men behaving like school children" storyline. It was saved by beautiful cinematography.

Perpetuating stereotypes only Gleeson can overcome

This was a lovely film about the hardships of growing up outcast from society and struggling with friendship. It centers around the titular islands off of Ireland, during their Civil War. Not many will realize after watching this film that Ireland boasts one of the most thriving modern economies, and that despite the border which enshrouds its legacy there are only 18% of the Irish counties within that district which rebel against the Christian doctrine. My aunt and uncle are members of a local traditional Irish music band and play at bars frequently within the area. Directly from them, I learned about Riverdance and the culture of Gaelic traditions. My uncle plays the Irish flute, and my aunt plays the fiddle. The problems with this movie are major, however. The violence with Gleeson really overshadow the meaningfulness which was intended for the film. They could have done away with some of the violent imagery. As a fan of horror movies, even I was taken aback by the scenes when they had very little payoff and even smaller plot building around them. Other parts of the movie remind me of Terrence Malick's Days of Heaven, but with even more authenticity. Also subtracting from the film were superstar Colin Farrel's spray tan. How could a man on the islands of Ireland use so much spray tan? His performance was on par, but his often-confused facial expressions did little to enhance the script. Barry Keoghan was underutilized, I thought, yet brought a lot more to the movie than Farrel and his overutilized sister. The movie perpetuates myths about Ireland which could have been chiseled away at, I thought. However, it was an enjoyable, lighthearted movie with its hands just on too many deep pockets of emotion to hold together perfectly. Had it been a little simpler with violence, and a little less overacted by Farrel, it could have been golden. Also, I thought there were supposed to be banshees? Where's the banshees?
One of the best movies I've ever seen. Tackles the vulnerabilities built into human life in really compelling and creative ways.  Everything about it was excellent.

It started out pretty well – it felt natural and unintentionally funny (but obviously that means it was well-written), and seemingly simple but powerful. However, first of all there are several trigger warnings necessary that I wish I had known. Let's just say I certainly would not categorize this as a comedy, in fact it was disturbing.

If you like a depressed Irish Steinfeld , a movie without a point , this is for you. Was waiting for the promised comedy got nothing but depression and violence , A wasted opportunity with these two great actors and beautiful scenery.

Well, it's an incredibly weird story which, I guess, can only be really appreciated by some Irish folks. As a movie it's a quite interesting insight into Irish countryfolks' mentality and if you have a knack for Black British humor, there are quite some giggles and even the occasional good laughs, but the macabre aspect of the whole script is generally perturbing making it a movie which in the end leaves you with quite a sour/bitter taste in your mouth unless you enjoy the extremely morbid. It's quite enjoyable in parts while being extremely upsetting in others. If you watch it you don't win much, and if you don't there is really nothing lost. It's surely not a flick that deserves an Oscar though Colin Farrell might actually do. 5/10

I liked the story a lot, it is so original. It had an excellent cast. The performances of Collin Farrell and Barry Keoghan are great! The score is wonderful. It has a great production design. The only thing, I didn´t like was that at sometimes it felt very slow. But it isn´t that much.
Can we get any more bbbboooorrrriiinnnnngggggg???  Pretty much put me to sleep.

The movie is about two best friends in an argument that started over, essentially, nothing, but if you dig deeper you will see the story is a reflection of the civil war taking place on the Mainland, which is also a fight that started over, essentially, nothing. On top of that, I found certain parts of this movie laugh-out-loud hilarious. And Kerry Condon steals every scene she is in. Great movie.

Barry Keoghan's performance shined. Story was dark and pacing was slow, but so well done. Different is okay, sometimes different is wonderful.
It was good until the end.  I don't even know how to explain it. It was just wrong.
Kinda weird. Kinda funny. Doesn't seem like a movie that needed to be made.
Overall, it was good. Just good. Some awesome humor and makes you think. A lot.
Great Irish humor and fantastic acting
The incredible location is brilliantly directed in a strange story that is helmed by two terrific performances in a film that manages to easily tread the line between hilarious and morose.
A masterwork of storytelling and cinematography. Loved every minute of it! Amazing performances from the entire cast!

The trailer makes you believe that this is a comedy. It's far from it!!! If you enjoy someone (SPOILER ALERT)being so pissed off at a friend that even talking to him makes him cut off his own finger, then this is your movie. And then there is the poisoned donkey. Great acting. Great scenery. But a horrific way to make an analogy to the brother-against-brother fight in Northern Ireland.  Ain't no comedy.
The Actors were superb!!!
If you'd like to spend two hours watching a slow, miserable, and pointless plot play out with no resolutions at the end for any of the characters, then this movie is for you.
Very well done and beautifully acted. Tough story

I thought it was one of the worst films I had ever seen. Characters were one dimensional and it normalised depravity . Stereotyping the Irish as mad or stupid. The good acting and scenery were not enough to warrant any good reviews .
Shite, disturbing,pointless,poor beautiful Ireland,please don't show to our happy children.

Dreck. Cruelty abounds. Stupidity. Even the beautiful scenery can't make up for this shite. Have always loved the two leads, yes, Gleeson is a great fiddle player, fine performances if you really want to see crazy ppl doing horrible, sick things. Obviously there's an audience for that, sick, horrible people, congrats all on another new low.
Just watched it and liked it. Feels like a classic Irish folk tale. With symbolisms and metaphors. Bet I’m gonna be thinking about this one for days.

This was an imaginative movie, but it was very dreary.
Good acting, good cinematography.  The plot was as dull as the perceptions of the lead character.  The human condition was full on mental patient mode.  And the Oscar goes to Jenny the Donkey!
Not that interesting really. Got bored half way thru the movie.

Compared to every other movie of the last few years, this is an absolute pearl. It has story, acting, character, morality play, good music, great scenery, and ZERO ideological lecturing.  It's enjoyable.
The ambiance is so relaxing that you feel like you are watching a painting. Acting is phenomenal, and it is a very different experience overall.

This movie is resounding in every way, delving into the existential, the absurd, and the human condition, all through a tale of two old friends. Even without the incredible performances and cinematography, the narrative could have stood alone as a desolate and powerful dark comedy.

It's a sad dark journey into the ending of a lifelong friendship. It's subtle and has moments of brilliance.  It's a dose of reality in extremes and subtleties. Very well acted and beautiful costuming and cinematography.
Sad, funny and well acted. Really liked this movie!
Totally engrossing and absorbing from the 1st minute...!! Best not to watch if you're looking for the feel good factor...!!
Don't  understand the rave. Liked the characters, but nothing happens...

Colin Farrel is fantastic. While the film is a little dark, it does a great job in evoking emotions. Highly recommend!

I liked it but didnt like the ending.  Albeit the plot does live up to its title.. Banshees of Inisherin.

This movie is an instant classic. The remarkable score is perfectly complimented by the screenplay. Martin McDonagh uses his dark humor commonly portrayed in his films to paint a vivid image of the themes in the movie. I't hilarious, dark, depressing, original, relatable and above all else, entertaining.

Took at least 3 tries to get through it. Do not feel rewarded as a result. THIS is award winning movie making? This fecking film taught me nothing. There were no smiles, no chuckles. Only a sad display of hate and misunderstanding. Reading all the positive reviews did not change anything about how useless I found this film.
Love the setting, however I found the movie extremely slow.

The cinematography is beautiful; the actors are top notch; the story, however,  is terrible. Halfway through the movie, I stopped caring about what happened to anyone because they all are determined to be miserable. Only one person makes it out alright, and we don't hear much from them.

The description calls it a "feel bad" movie, so if you like feeling bad, you might like it. I wish very much that I had not seen it. I post this review to emphasize how sick characters in the story are. Yes, the actors might have done a stellar job, and I have seen many movies where the storyline depicts dysfunctional characters, but I have rarely been left feeling so disgusted and distraught. If you are a sensitive person, don't watch this.
I felt so many emotions
brilliant camerawork and acting: makes you feel like you live on the island.

A truly heartbreaking movie. Colin Farrell's acting in particular had a grip on me I couldn't explain, and everyone else was great too. They added depth to Dominic's humourous side-character role which made it so much sadder and interesting. I feel I'd have to watch the movie a couple more times to truly understand every detail - especially the extreme escalation towards the end.

I love these movies, they're always original. The atmosphere was presented beautifully and the characters were great. Performances were excellent. It just got a bit gruesome and non-sensical at times. Would recommend

Maybe not quite the level of characterisation of In Bruges but well scripted and superbly acted dark and comedic fare with the scenes stolen by the beautifully shot sumptuous scenery and by Jenny the donkey - very, very watchable if at times, by design, excruciating
The acting, the scenery, but most of all the story were out of this world. The allegory of war is beautifully done.
I started to watched with some apprehension, it frankly looked boring, but after a little while I was totally enthralled. That donkey is the star of the movie.
The only way this film might have possibly redeemed itself, is if they busted out laughing and yucked it up in the end bantering on their mishaps with tears running down their faces.

I thought the setting was glorious and stellar performances by the cast. As an Irish person, this movie is another example of the uncommunicative culchie/countryside male, previous examples include "Philadelphia here I come" and "Normal people" where reading between the lines is required. It would have made a good leaving cert choice to study apart from the decapitation of digits and naked Garda.

Overall, this movie is objectively good. The performances are stellar, especially that of Collin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson, the direction is phenomenal, and the story, while small, is sad and melancholic. That being said, this movie was just not for me. I can see why others would rave about it and say it's one of the best movies of the year, but for me, I just didn't like it that much. The story was incredibly slow, and although I liked it more towards the end, just didn't do much for me. The humor in the movie is good though, as there were definitely moments that elicited a chuckle. And again, I liked all the performances in the movie and got upset towards the end when Jenny died. But this movie just didn't do it for me. It was too slow paced for my liking. I can definitely see myself going back and rewatching it and maybe getting a different opinion than the one I have now, but for now, I'm on the fence as to whether I liked it or not.
Great performances all around. Very funny bits. If you want to watch something original and fresh check it out. I highly recommend.

The story was bad it gave you no history of the two main characters so it was hard to age their friendship. To be honest none of the characters were given any background like why his sister was still single. How did he know the cop was molesting his son? What happened to that cop after he found his dead son? The crazy witch lady said there would be two deaths did he kill himself? Yes, the writing directing, and producing were bad but.... You had incredible acting by Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson.  These two can make even bad writing interesting their acting was A+ these two are the rare actor who can play a tough guy, a nice guy, a funny guy most actors are pigeonholed to one kind of character. I don't think there is any role these two could not only take on the role but succeed at the highest level with it. To watch two of this generation's greatest actors I would recommend this film. Again the writing won't win you over but you will believe these two are the characters they are playing and that in itself is worth watching.

Great cinematography.
I heard a lot of good things about it and I tried but it didn't grab me.  I'm sure that is my error not the films fault.  But for me, I gave up and moved on to something else.
Definitely on the dark side although it sure had moments of humor. Struggle to understand the dialogue at times.

Yes, the film it's slow. Yes, the film it's, overall, sad. I believe that was the point of this film, to portray what it's like to live in on a remote island. The characters have nowhere to go, and they are stuck with each other, even though they would rather be somewhere else or with other people. But they don't have that option. I think this is a setting where things are very likely to go wrong, and where people could slowly enter a state of lunacy. To me this is accurate but exaggerated, which is what makes this film funny and absurd. Complex emotions dealt with in a simple way. 
If you want a film that portrays human behaviour, reduced to its most elemental, I would suggest you to watch The Banshees of Inisherin.
This movie was boring sad and after almost two hours watching it I felt there was no redeeming  value to this movie. Rotten Tomatoes  let me down .
This was not sad.  It was downright depressing.  And this is going to win awards?  Sheesh!
Definitely a feel bad movie. But keeps you interested and captivated the entire time. Great acting and supporting roles with an interesting plot. Odd, but enjoyable.
It was a very dark story and rather stupid actually.
THe most depressing awful movie I have ever seen. I had to walk out.
Brilliant, beautiful but soulless.  I don't want to be suckered into watching the story of a psychopath.
Droll, depressing, lifeless... this is Hollywood's future after CV. Without question the worst movie I've seen in the last 20 years, and my family is from Co Mayo.
Very sad, but engrossing. Felt for Colin Farrell's Padraic and Kerry Condon's Siobhan. Future was brighter for Siobhan, less so for Padraic and other islanders.
Excellent ensemble acting . The implausible turn of the plot is what diminishes the overall score. I find it hard to reconcile with the maiming.

If something is original it doesn't necessarily mean that it's good. This movie seemed so set to be original and impress that it often felt artificial and pretentious. It had some good moments, but the way it ended ... And it had its share of stereotypes, too.

I don't get this. AP just voted "The Banshees of Inisherin" as the best movie of 2022. I've yet to talk to any of my friends that has seen it that agrees. Perhaps that's because there aren't any film critics in my circle of friends. 
Yes, it is beautifully filmed. Yes, the actors are brilliant. But the pace is tediously slow at times, the premise of self-mutilation ridiculous and the ending completely unfulfilling - resulting in (for me) the feeling of "why did I just waste two hours watching that?".

Very hard to understand some of the Irish brogue, and I found it very depressing.  No humor or comedy that the critics speak about.  It was all very sad and hard to watch to the end.  Yes, Colin Farrell did a great acting job, but I couldn't wait for it to be over.
Ok, great acting, scenery. But plot is thin. Story is incredibly sad, macabre, and not really believable. I wouldn't recommend it.

Beautiful cinematography boring hour and a half. I think if there was a book where you could read what they were thinking, what was in their hearts, back stories, folklore something!  Very hard to translate into a movie. Was just a movie about nothing.
Absolutely loved it. Amazing acting. The Oscar nominations are well deserved.

I'll still give it a 5 Star, because if I could have understood the Irish brogue, I surely would have liked it.  But, I had to walk out 1/2 through the movie.  Does a Moviehouse ever have Closed Captioning?  If they did, I'm sure older folks would go see a movie more.  And my hearing is not quite what it used to be.  Maybe hearing aids would help, but don't think I quite need those yet, but Closed Captioning would help in that area too.
Seriously don't get the hype. Boring, annoying, slow. Talented actors but the film was not worth the time and emotional investment.
Fantastic writing, brilliant acting, gorgeous cinematography.
Very Dark humour . Brought back memories of  Kerry
I am in awe of the story, comical moments, and beautiful location and set design.
Slow, but fascinating. Acting is excellent.
It's a sad movie, but you'd enjoy it, and even if you don't enjoy it, you'd be left thinking
Slow and sad, but beautifully shot with great dialogue and wonderful performances.
