A beautiful, intelligent, and slightly shocking movie. Human emotions and irrational behavior makes the mini donkey and border collie the true protagonists of the story. Run to the cinema for reflection and beauty.
Something to think about finally..
The acting of Colin Farrell and the cast ,the scenery

Hated it! The acting was very good but it was disturbing and dark. My husband and I watched it and I was afraid I was going to have nightmares after the witchy old lady or the chopped off fingers! Not what we were expecting at all! The finger thing was just too much!
Slow moving and depressing. Dont waste your time!
pretty bizarre..some simply sick people
Slow and the fingers were over the top. Could have had more of a story. I saw where they wanted to go but just couldn't get there.

The movie was sad, thought provoking and lovely all at the same time. The entire cast was phenomenal, whoever was in charge of wrangling the animals did a fantastic job. The island and all the scenery was breathtaking. The perfect dark Irish story, if you know you know.
If mutilation and dead animals tickle your funny bone, then go for it. Otherwise, avoid. Colin Farrell snd Brendan Gleeson are great.  The story sucked
Don't watch unless you want to be suicidal and depressed. Great acting though! Just wow.
great movie about a man who cuts off his fingers and another mans love for his donkey

So much to love about this movie but I did not understand any of the plot... it was beautifully shot, acting was incredible I was glued the screen.  But the movie was like your wife, that you love, is divorcing you because you had an affair with her sister in her dreams... You have all the emotion of a divorce but you do not understand any of it.

An allegory of war.   It is senseless and beyond understanding and rationality in the way war is.  Not pretty, but well-done.  Like Johnny Got His Gun by Dalton Trumbo or The Lottery by Shirley Jackson.  It has grusome and bloody scenes, like a horror movie, but this is necessary for the message.  You can compare it to the Irish War for Independence, the Irish Civil War or The Troubles.  Or the Russian War against Ukraine.  Beautiful scenery.  The acting, directing, and production are the best.  Go see it, but be prepared to be shocked and surprised.

No spoilers. This is a most beautiful and moving film. It moves at such a gentle pace but does so with an intensity that actually breaks your heart. The writing is sublime. The acting is on a higher level. The scenery is stunning. The cinematography is breathtaking. I cannot recommend this highly enough.

I do not mind being the odd one out here, as it looks like this is being hailed as an artistic gem.

From my vantage point this is a vacuous and pretentious film from a director who appears to be resting on his laurels. Hopefully he will not become the Salvador Dali of modern movie-making.

The story? Well, a man tells another man he does not like him any more, and that man tries to get him to change his mind. That's it. Now, if you wander through the Guggenheim with the intention of finding art in everything you see, you will find lots of art. If you wander through this movie with the intention of finding art in everything you see you will find lots of art.

There is also a negativity about humanity which says more about the director/writer than about the human condition.

Perhaps it works as a black comedy. You wish.
Top cinematography unbelievable. The acting is phenomenal in this dark comedy. You don't want the movie to end

I honestly hoped for more with this movie. The acting is good. The plot seems interesting for a time, but lost my attention after some twists and turns. I'm sure the Academy Awards will fawn over this cinematic experience, but it's a resounding "meh" for me.
A moving portrait of stupidity and stubbornness gone astray.
A put your phone down movie. Probably a little slow for some but amazing acting from everyone involved

The characters are so uninteresting that the only thing that could have saved this movie was if a bomb had been lobbed from the mainland and leveled the island and everyone on it in the first few minutes.

I typically love movies that have a quirky story line, including dark comedies.  While the cinematography and acting was top-notch, the dark story was simply not interesting and flat.  At the end, I kept searching for something that I missed, beyond the acting and photography, that gave greater validity and praises of this movie among critics.  It's been almost a day since I watched it and I still think it was a waste of time.

Incredible scenery and lots of potential to make a great Irish movie with plenty of Craic. However this is absolute depression without any resolution. It also paints life on the island as lonely and inbred.
In my books, Barry and Kerry were better than the winners. The lake scene sealed the deal for me.
Beautifully shot, well acted, and a strong film.

Expect to be disappointed with this movie which can be told in these few lines: In a small English/Irish village in the 1920s there were two dumb and demented friends. One suddenly decided he no longer wished the other spoke to him, but when the other friend continued, he threatened to mutilate his own fingers each time his friend gets in touch with him. His friend thinks that was a bluff but soon finds 5 severed fingers at his door step. One finger ends up choking up his donkey and killing it. Enraged at his dead donkey, he burns up the house of his friend who mutilated his own fingers hoping he would die there. Friend with self mutilated fingers doesn't die but suddenly seem to appreciate the guy who burnt down his house and stars talking to him again. Well that's all folks, that is the story. Something that everyone will appreciate is that Colin Ferrell is best suited for his character due to his naturally dumb looks

The story was slow, surrealistic and poor entertaining.
I agree about the good acting and the stunning photographie of the film, but that doesn't make a film good.
I'm so tired of this movies "Oscar type", only have acting and photography, and are easily forgotten a couple of years later. The kind of movies that when you said they are bad the usual reply is "It's too much intelectual". No, they are boring and slow. Period.
The reason I give only half a star (even though the actors and photography are good) it's because I'm tired of this kind of movies. One is good, 6 every year in December for the Oscars is hell (and all of this comes from a person that likes Tarkovski's Nostalghia).
No doubts why the theaters are so empty.

Somebody please give Collin Farrell  best Actor!  Oh and the film is Superb.   An emotional ride or what. I wanted to shout at the screen sometimes in an attempt to influence what the actors do next.  I laughed much more than I normally do. And was horrified loads. I left feeling ambivalent all because of friendship.   Be prepared!

Absolutely beautiful, surreal and heartbreaking depiction of the troubles in Ireland. To those saying it is slow and boring, with some historical context the story really opens up to the viewer and all on the backdrop of this incredible landscape. I would go so far as to call this one of my new favorite movies! I cannot stop thinking about it.
The slow moving plot is propped up by quirky events. The characters are intense and well balanced within the story.
Senseless movie full of unrealistic premises. Save yourself the time.
Slow,boring, pathetic story line, depressing. Very unrealistic and not great acting
Loved this film!  Every actor is wonderful.
Two really fine actors trapped in a scrip by turns boring and sad… until it turns ugly. What a waste of time.

I did not find it believable, that anyone would act the way these characters did. My favorite character was the donkey. My next favorite character was the dog. They acted much more believably than the people.

Being of irish decent and have been in Ireland recently I feel I have a valid perspective. 
In the last year I had an unexlipible and sudden end to a very long term relationship that was and continues to be bewildering.  
In my situation,  there's been no sacrificial bloodshed or symbolic "pet death", yet I am still bamboozled about the whole situation. 
Although beautifully shot, on the Aran islands I am no closer to clarity about this film or my personal life

Beautiful cinematography.  Fantastic acting.  The story took a bizarre turn midway through.   Some consider it an artistic twist.  Some believe it a statement about the Irish Civil War.  But many consider it very dark and depressing.  One thing it isn't is a comedy.  I took their marketing bait when the film first came out.  I went expecting an evening of laughter.  I was sorely disappointed
Pointless. Didn't really love any of the characters and there was really no point to the story.
I will simply say that this is a masterpiece.

The stupidest and most overrated best picture nominated film. Oscar voters love McDonagh’s films. Every time he makes a film ends up nominated for an Oscar; this time, they go all the way. Other films deserve a spot for best picture nomination. Also, the performances are not so great, not bad but not Oscar worth it. Better films that didn’t get consideration are: *The Menu *Empire of Light *The Whale *Babylon etc. You name it!!! Oscarsucks!!!

I was hoping for some of the magic and snappy dialogue from In Bruges. However, ended up with a similar experience to watching paint dry only knowing I used the wrong paint and was waiting for wife to get home and deal with your wrath.   The scenery was lovely.
One of those movies that just leave you empty and thoughtful at the end. I do like it but I can't quite put my thoughts into words. Beautiful cinematography though.
Beautifully shot, scripted and scored. Farrell and Gleason are both superb.

It would be difficult to watch for some but very interesting to me for showing how friendships and relationships can change over time and how people can grow apart.  This certainly happened in my life although I would never take such drastic acts as shown in the film. The acting was also very good.  I can see why it was nominated for an award.

The movie is magical in a way of celebrating the beauty of the Aran Islands.  The story was so surprising and demonstrates some difficulties in living with a small social group.  I loved the movie and will watch it again.  Acting was great, including the supporting actors.
Slow movie, very boring at times. didnt finish it

The most beautiful depiction of the "troubles". With Colm representing Ireland, Pádraic representing England, and Siobhan representing N Ireland. Full of funny moments, but the overall theme is laced in melancholy. 
True cinematic masterpiece, must watch!!!

A unique and original story that takes you to a time and place that appears to be dull, but that is the point. To stay on an island safe from the outside world would drive anyone to madness to extremes of emotions. You will laugh, cry and be in awe with each of the main characters as they guide you to all a climatic numbing reality, but feel emotionally fulfilled.

beautiful location and a well written screenplay with pleasing acting. this couldn't get better but for me this movie is a bit slow at start as it takes its time to introduce the characters and then also the ending seem to have no message whatsoever.
Another weird Colin Ferrel movie. Minimal plot. Spend 2hrs doing something else.
One needs to watch this comedy at the cinema to know when to laugh. Movie about nothing; miss it and you miss nothing
Depressing, but not bad. Acting was good.
The development of the relationship between the two characters is extremely engaging. Very well written characters, and the actors were up to the task.
Brilliantly acted all around,but damn. I could identify with the depression involved around aging,and our place in the world,just so damn bleak.

I wasn't expecting much and I was wowed by the acting, scenery and story. There's a scene at the pub where Colin's acting was def Oscar worthy. I was stunned by the acting and the connection with the animals. Clearly it's not a movie for the Avengers type crowd, but it's one of those movies that make you think about all the metaphors and layers it has. Barry's character was also so heartwarming. The scene at the lake with Colin's 
 sister  had me almost in tears.
It's been a while I didn't watch such a catching, amazing film. I really loved every moment.

Why the heck would anybody call it a comedy, I cannot fathom. It's "everything you've always wanted to know about existential despair but were afraid to ask". And it's gorgeous. Colin Farrell finally stopped trying to be a star and decided to try that weird concept called acting, and it proves he knows how to act! Brendan Gleeson is great as someone who just cannot live anymore with his own mortality. But who really sucks the air from the frame wherever he appears is Barry Keoghan.
I know some people say it's boring (many viewers today have the attention span of a cricket), glum, unattractive, not sufficiently funny etc. The same crap as last year with the Power of the Dog, when also there were people complaining because they were unable to watch quietly and think. But if you go to the cinema to see the films, not just the movies, you will not be disappointed.

A beautifully bleak and poignant movie, with outstanding performances all around. With moments of absurd humor, most of the film settles into a type of doomed resignation. Some of the most heart wrenching moments occur off-screen, and the viewer is left to fill in the gaps and deal with the aftermath. Everyone does a phenomenal job, and the backdrop is absolutely gorgeous.
Mad Eye accidentally kills an animal with his appendages....top tier cinema. I too would burn down his house for that.

The best thing about the movie was the beautiful landscape and photography.   But the plot line is too one dimensional.    The same theme endlessly repeated.  Any two hour movie which simply shows the escalation of an obsession, without many other plot lines, runs the risk of being boring to me.    Adding severed fingers to the mix may cause a temporary jolt, but does not make the movie more pleasant.   To be fair, I do think the acting was good, especially Siobhan and the teenager Dominick.

This was just so stupid.   Why did anyone think this was worth making. I am so glad I didn't pay to see it.   The only worthwhile thing was the donkey and it dies.  Ì wasted 2 hours of my life I can't get back.  I can only say what the feck is this for??

I was so looking forward to seeing this movie, I'm Scottish so I knew the scenery of Ireland would be spectacular and it was! However,  the movie itself is probably the worst I've ever seen, the story it terrible, pointless and it was heartbreaking to see two such great actors in such an awful movie, I kept thinking it might get better but to no avail. Horrific in parts and as I said it goes no where! Please don't waste your time!
just a quick note re the trailer -  the caption under the dialogue in the trailer says "I just don't like it no more."  No, it's actually: "I just don't like you no more." Big difference!

McDonough's best film and Colin Farrell's best performance. Barry Keoghan should get an Oscar for his. I didn't walk out of the theater as thrilled as I was after Maverick, but my heart was thoroughly filled when left this one. The most accomplished film of the year.
This movie is perfection, absolutely genius. It perfectly balances the obsurd while being genuine and sincere.

SPOILER:  If you are not bothered with a beloved animal dying for grotesque reasons, or someone chopping off their fingers to make a point, then have a watch.  I recommend watching the first 30 minutes to see the characters and amazing scenery, then turn it off and read a synopsis.  I can understand the love this movie is receiving, but I personally cannot do grisly/depressing.

I love literary analysis and the use of it to interpret movies, but in Banshees this practice goes off the rails.  About 2/3's of the way into the film, it's clear that the writer is using the plot at this point to make metaphoric comparisons to things happening in Ireland at this time in history...but at the sacrifice of any semblance of reality in the storyline.  The story becomes completely nonsense at this point and continues that way right through the final scene.  This movie was WAY over sold by the critics.  OK, not great.
All actors are amazing in their parts. Outstanding Movie
This movie was moronic and not worth watching. On a positive note, it was not as bad as Everything Everywhere All The Time.

The scenery was breathtaking. The acting was amazing. And it was the most bleak and depressing movie I've seen in a while. It left me feeling sad and hopeless. I don't need all the movies I watch to have a happy ending. But this really affected me in a bad way and I would not recommend it.

I'm astonished that this movie has gotten great reviews and it's nominated for the Oscar's. 
One of the worst movies I've ever seen in my life.

I love period pieces. I love historical fiction. I love anything that we can get a glimpse of another time place or era to learn from
This movie was by far THE worst movie my husband and I have ever seen. It was so depressing, that we went right to bed to make the biggest waste of 3 hrs of our lives go away. Then today I open the list for Academy Awards and its nominated for multiple categories. This is what is wrong with Hollywood. Another lost household rating for Oscar night👍.

Personally as an Irish person I loved the movie, the history that was brought to the screen and the actor's performances were spot on and makes you feel back at home. The movie intrigues the audience and makes them want to know more about the plot and what happens in every scene. I rate this is 9.5/10 movie and so far a really great movie to watch.
It was a darker comedy than I had expected, but actors were good and scenery is beautiful.  It's not one I'd rave about to others but I didn't feel as if I had wasted my money.
It's a very engaging film that gets incredibly dark. When it comes to movies about small town Irish folks I prefer something like Waking Ned Devine.
A beautiful analogy for depression and the impulses that try to keep us afloat. Colin Farrell has never been better...and he's been very good before.

Incredible script with fully realized, fleshed out characters. The performances are incredible, it manages to be both hilarious and sad, and there's just a level of depth here that makes the movie stay with you. Loved it.
It's both a comedic and depressing story of the loss of friendship with some amazing performances

Silly and pointlessly lugubrious. This is a contrived appeal to contemporary social dislocations at the cost of disrespecting a bygone era of Irish bucolic life, that's essentially been bastardised for a meretricious exploration of existential crisis. Assured performances and occasionally impressive (albeit repetitive) cinematography do little to resolve the as yet fundamentally mistaken approach to comedy and tragedy that McDonough has taken in his underwhelming and largely overrated filmography so far.

I truly don't understand why this snooze fest is getting such praise. Despite amazing Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson, this flick drags on… and on… and on… none of the characters are memorable and you don't even really get a chance to know them. You are left with a regret in your belly that so badly wishes to get that wasted time back. Not even worth talking about… I think I'll go watch In Bruges, a far, far better film.

What were they thinking? Where's all the CGI special effects, dragons, spells, talking donkey, blue people, guns, stunts, and death-defying action? Instead we have to make do with real actors; an authentic setting; a well-crafted, often absurb and humourous  script; superb and understated cinematography…an all round masterclass in filmmaking. Its like a refreshingly stiff breeze off the Atlantic ocean blowing across your face. Thank goodness someone still knows how to make an engaging film. Thank-you Martin McDonagh and everyone involved in making this film!

Beautiful scenery, wonderful acting, great direction. Can't go wrong with Colin, Brendan, and Kerry. But it's a very dreary and depressing movie. There is no uplifting moment. It's just not the way I want to spend my entertainment time.
Very well acted. But I just didn't like the story. Was slow and repetitive to me.

Of the movies nominated for best picture this year, this was my favorite.  Slow and dark but thought provoking on so many levels.  I thought the actors were brilliant and the setting magnificent.  It was painful to watch but oh so moving.
Original and authentic, The Banshees of Inisherin is a gripping, raw, brilliant and devastating from start to finish.

Farrell and Gleeson set the bar too high with In Bruges.  This depressing dirge has none of the rapier dialogue or quirkiness expected.  In the end it's a sad flop with no redemption.  Trust the audience on this, not the paid critics
Terrible and pointless movie.
Beautifully shot. Over acted. Over dramatic. The time of film people will say they love because they are supposed to.

Please, please DO NOT waste your time or money on this rotten motion picture!!
I am waiting for the 'class action' lawsuit with the other people who saw this 
film....this is NOT a story, this is NOT a movie, by any sense of the word........
Boring, no character development, there is nothing here to see.............!
(It's not worth the half of a star above.)
How could it possibly be a nominee for the OSCARS! No way! They paid somebody off!!

I actually went to see the movie with my wife because the ads said it was a comedy, beautifully made, etccc...
We were so appalled at the grim story, and were depressed after it.  I have spoken with friends who saw it who had the same comments.
I cannot see any way this can be a "comedy", even a dark one.  There is not a single moment in it where that label could possibly, IMHO, apply to this movie.  I can even think that people who are vulnerable could be really badly affected by it.
Sure, it was very well-made, but I would definitely warn anybody who would want to see it that it is really a serious downer.  Grim.  To be avoided.  How much pain are we willing to take?
Thanks,
Tom

Very fine cinematography and excellent performances, but a completely ridiculous storyline and very miserable from about 20 minutes in.  We left the cinema and had to debrief over a large glass of wine.  The self-harm elements stayed with me (not in a good way) for several days afterwards.

Had no idea what this movie was about… what I can tell you is that you’ll like it from the very beginning to the end. It’s surprisingly funny, super well directed, acting is phenomenal- it’s not boring (even though the name can make it feel like some boring foreign film) - it’s really really good! You’ll love it.

Some incredible performances no doubt. An amazing view into rural Irish life at the time, at least it felt realistic. Got weird near the end. Depressing and sort of pointless. Shame, as it had a lot of good things going for it and some incredible acting. The sister and the village simpleton were tremendous. But the main plot line never really went anywhere or made sense to me. I can't NOT recommend seeing it, but it didn't deliver in the way I hoped it would.
The film is an extraordinary story based on memento more and what we left behind, the cast emerges us into the story and makes you feel the emotions through the screen.

A depressing, very bleak movie. I cannot call it a dark comedy as there were too few comedic moments. Beautiful scenery and some great acting but the storyline is ultimately unfulfilling. Very disappointing.
Great acting.  Well made.  But characters do incredibly weird and mean things.  Is such a thing possible in real life?
Brilliant from start to finish. An original story, great acting.

I wasted my time watching this movie.  The plot was stupid.  I cannot figure out why this movie is getting such great reviews (and a recent Oscar nomination).  In my opinion, some people are afraid to criticize this film because so many top reviewers said they loved it.  If it's a drama, it's stupid, if it's a dark comedy, it's not funny at all or dark.  The only horror in this film is wasting 2 hours.  I hope I'm not alone in this criticism.

I get the symbolism of the pointless feud between two friends on the island, taken to extremes, as a mirror to the senselessness of the civil war taking place on the mainland (also the sister's desire to escape the island as a parallel to those who had ventured further afield to America to start a new life), I also admire the bleak scenery and cinematography, however, it is a long and dull film that I found myself dozing off to and unfortunately for me was not a patch on the film that first brought the director to my attention with the two same male leads (the cult film 'In Bruges') which I still come back to every so often: it may be for the film student that can write a pretty good essay but it is not for those looking for an escape or anything venturing on the entertaining (so will probably pick up a few awards then from those taking themselves way too seriously).

Wasn't the movie I expected.  It is slow running with no real plot, but somehow comes together. You can't stop watching. It's the weirdest movie I've ever seen, but in a good way.
Would I watch it again, no. But the acting was brilliant.
Why even bother to make this movie? it was pointless and odd. That doesn't make it a good movie.

Top notch.  I will likely never watch it again, but it’s a pretty perfectly done movie, by movie making standards. No missteps, whatsoever.  A meager storyline brilliantly crafted into a compelling watch that speaks largely to loneliness and simple joys.
An absolutely gorgeous movie. Martin McDonagh delivers another very intriguing script. And the direction and acting are perfect.

This was truly the worst movie I have ever watched. During the film it dawned on me, someone actually wrote this dialogue, reread it and thought it was good. I suggest you get some friends together, get drunk, and have a table read and film it. You will be laughing your arses off.
What a heap off shite
My favorite of 2022!! We simply loved it !

A cleverly written film (probably too clever for some casual observers) and amazingly acted. Spoke to me of the folly of some aspects of the Irish Civil War of 1922-23 (probably many civil wars for that matter). I felt the once best friend, suddenly, dramatically and aggressively turning his back on his best friend hinted at 2 parties of the Irish Civil War. The removing of a finger, and then all fingers of Colm's hand signified to me how in the war, Ireland was administering harsh and unthinkable punishments on it's own people. The way Padraic went from being the nicest, friendliest (but a little dull) to being a mean and dangerous person (but still loved animals) spoke to me on how the conflict turned some good, everyday people bad, making them do horrible things themselves. I think the fact everyone still loved animals proved they were good people, but just lost and confused by circumstances. The dreadful police office - said a lot about authority.  The publican - everyone's friend. The snoopy general store owner, the sister - smarter than the lot of them, plus comradery v's the loneliness & sadness, the need for human connection and of cause the scenery - spectacular. I love you Ireland. Great film.
Half a star for the donkey and the dog! And the donkey didn't even make the whole show! Oscars? Seriously? Give it to the old lady!
What a piece of shite of a movie!...
Beautifully shot film and excellent acting, however the dark side is very dark, perhaps too dark.
A comedy? Most boaring movie I've seen in years, when they got to cutting 3 fingers off I was done; went knowwhere.

Though there are some funny moments, I'd really doubt anybody's sanity who calls the movie a comedy. It's a well executed, very moving piece of cinema that on the one hand presents something that is very profane in the grand scheme of things, but on the other hand it provokes thoughts exactly about that - the questions about the important things in life...
Makes me want to time travel to Old Ireland and cut off my fingers. Certified feckin fresh.

A stunningly crafted and beautifully acted piece of cinematic art.  The punishing isolation of a life on a small community island, of its stunning beauty, of history being made across the sound with no day-to-day or even year-to-year impact. A tale of the confusion of a friendship illogically spurned, of brutality, of stubbornness, of despair and ennui, of dashed hopes and a flight to freedom, of the acceptance of the loneliness and drudgery of being left behind. At once funny, shocking and desperately poignant. Kerry Condon as Siobhan is a standout, but excellent performances too from Messrs Gleeson and Farrell. Best film of 2022 by a country mile.

This was billed as a comedy/drama but was more akin to a Shakespearean tragedy. While the acting by Colin Farrell, Barry Keoghan, and Brendan Gleeson was superb, the writing and general story line left much to be desired. We kept waiting for some sort of redemption but the path kept taking us to darker realms. A huge disappointment given the accolades and acting. Definitely not a date movie.
A wonderfully dark and humorous stroll through a quaint Irish village. The lead performances hold the same fantastic chemistry they did in the film In Bruge.
Those supporting actors are great.
Pointless and boring to be honest. I guess they play the parts well but I kinda wasted 2 hours of my life hoping it gets better. Weird humour if you'd call it humour.

Dark, very funny and looks amazing

Everyone does their jobs really really well, not much else needs said I think. Should win alot of awards but we will see

Was really looking forward to watching this movie. OMG it is possibly the worst thing I've ever wasted my time on. I will never get that hour and 15 minutes back. We fast forwarded through the last 15 minutes. The kid who played Dominic should win some kind of award because he was amazing. It was so excruciatingly depressing and boring and we were utterly mystified by the gore. It was absolutely nonsensical. A comedy?? Where? When???

Sensational on every level other than a compelling story. A sublime Irish poem that is concerned with state rather than action. Offering an audience descriptive vignettes but little in the way of cause or motivation for the dramatic centerpiece. So it remains oddly unemotional as it defers investigation for a film trying to find its way back to a documentary. That said, all the performances are just stunning. If you need a reason to call acting an art form, you'll find it here.
Hated this film. Great acting and scenery but stupid plot and annoying to watch.

The movie was not what I expected.  I thought it was a black comedy, which it sort of is, but is much darker than I anticipated.  Well done movie, interested story, good performances and lovely cinematography.
Stunning acting complemented with stunning scenery and a fantastic screenplay. Kudos to Martin McDonagh for assembling this amazing cast lead by Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson,
Enjoyable but a bir odd. Scenery was fantastic

I loved "In Bruges" and so I had high hopes for this film. I was extremely disappointed. Great cast and beautiful scenery couldn't make up for a horrible plot with little story arc and no point. Almost no character development either.  I've rarely felt as apathetic towards characters in a movie before.  This is not a good movie.
Gorgeous location however, story was sad, confusing, tragic and heartbreaking. Actors were brilliant but they couldn’t save the movie. If you want to be perplexed and sad, watch this movie…ugh.
Pretty location. Absurd plot. Very clunky Civil War allegory. It underperformed.
Great acting and cinematography wasted on a ridiculous plot a troubled 5th grader would have written.

Nihilism and despair take center stage on this film, along with severed fingers, sad animals, and even sadder humans. This morose two-hour slog with a minimalist plot  ends as ambiguously as it starts, leaving viewers with a pretentiousness parable on early 20th century Ireland doesn't balance the scale. Even the beautiful cinematography is ruined by the aggressive despair foisted onto the screen. Strong pass, won't return.

this is a brilliant film. It starts off with humor and satire and quickly becomes a horrific drama. The atmosphere is spot on, and the cinematography is beautiful, as well as the music. All the actors a perfectly cast and it's a movie that will haunt you for days.
Amazing movie. Makes you cry.
It's not a bad movie. But, where on earth is the humor?  I can get into dark humor.  I'm not finding it here.

Fine. Tedious. Middle School Triviality. I couldn't watch it all, turned it off when it came to the point where it seemed the dog was going to be, well you know… In Bruges was WAY better with these two.
I want that two hours back:(

I have never been so strongly in disagreement with the Tomatometer. This movie is sad, strange, and most of all boring. There are a few moments of clever writing that gave me a laugh, but otherwise, it was awful. I recommend you watch something else.

I came to the film cold, knowing little of and not knowing who directed or wrote it. I recognised Gleeson and Farrell from "In Bruges: but that was all. It absorbed me from the beginning, and was in turns, laugh out funny, shocking, gut-wrenching, and ultimately sad. The two main roles were impeccable, and there wasn't a weak performance from any - but the character I found the most poignant was Dominic - and beautifully acted by Barry Keoghan. I shall come back and watch it again, and then again and again...

Superb acting and cinematography, a lovely windswept setting and some engaging, slow-paced humor. But the dark heart of this film ultimately horrifies. While I admired this piece of cinema, I can't say that I enjoyed it.  

The plot resonates more if, as some have suggested, it is viewed as a metaphor for the Irish Civil War, which provides a distant backdrop for the on-screen action.

Know that the film's marketing and most critics' reviews overemphasize the comic notes and understate the mounting violence and tragic denouement.
Amazing scenery and acting another classic from this director an acting partnership one of the must see films.

This film proves that tension & suspense are relative, and that a storyteller can create high stakes from the spark of something isolated and small. A slow build, but appropriately so, if you stay to see it through, which I'd recommend you do.

Fantastic dialogue and great performances with wonderful cinematography.  I understand how it might not be everyone's cup of tea because it doesn't move quickly.  Be patient and appreciate the performances !

Engrossing, funny, tragic and subtle in its clever echoing of the hubris of a small village to a wider and equally inane conflict, this is a profoundly humanistic story elevated to the highest levels by acting of the highest caliber, crisp screenplay, empathic direction and sheer gut wrenching originality.

The positive publicity for this awful film is a triumph of marketing. There is some great acting, but with a dire story line, no believable depth to the characters and a ludicrous basic premise give it a miss.

One of the worst movies I've seen in a long time. While the camerawork is good and the actors gave a good performance, and it has to be said, the scenery is stunning. (That's there anyway). However, whoever wrote the storyline must have been tripping. Yes, it's dark, and I suppose it's meant to be, but it's just utter rubbish that has your eyes rolling. If this is winning all the awards then the film industry must be in trouble.

What a film! I had no idea what I was getting myself into by watching this film. A very deep, thoughtful film which I will have to watch a few times I reckon because there are many layers to it. In places it is infuriating because of the analysis of every last detail by the characters....which could very well be a small island thing. But I feel that it is an essential part of the film...even perhaps what the film maker wants is to nudge the watcher to feelings of frustration, by some stupidity of being trapped by the mundane cycle of tit for tat with no foreseeable end. Utter mindless stubbornness. A definite classic for sure.

Great acting, scenery and direction but poor pacing and character-development let's this film 
down.
not my type of comedy. the accent is hard to understand for my taste.

For a slow burn movie this definitely kept me engaged the entire time. A lot of philosophical undertones. And the acting was marvelous. Does make you question the why we are so comfortable with our reality.

The movie presents you dense emotions which you immediately relate to and think about even after the movie is over. Such an emotional rollercoaster which flexes your brain while thinking of the reasons behind certain actions taken by characters. An absolute directional master piece, an absolute acting masterpiece from all characters which im sure will be a golden star in their career. Thank you for making such awesome work.

This is a pretty tough topic, I guess the movie is all about desire. We know ourselves through someone else, what if we want to change that? Is it possible to be alone, what is the importance of the commune for humans? The movie makes you ask good questions.

A brilliant film which has one on the edge of your seat. The acting is superb and Gleeson and Farrell's eyes do much of the speaking for them.  The theme is quite traumatic and we left the cinema drained but satisfied
Yep, it's pretty good.
Deeply depressing, but an incredible movie nonetheless

This is an extremely well crafted film that portrays a universal human dilemma, and filled with amazing details such as the quality of the sound recordings (a persistent yet subtle clock ticking even when the image has left the house comes to mind as an illustration of the sort of thing I'm talking about).
Performances are convincing most of the times. Farrell sometimes oversimplifies, like when pronouncing Beethoven so wrong that it loos ridiculous, but it doesn't happen that often and it certainly doesn't kill the story. Too obvious, theatric scenes could have also been reduced in intensity, but overall I believe the film to be of exceptional quality in its ideas, and the way they are presented, which is concise, but open enough to let the viewer add their own interpretation. 
This is a film to watch with full attention. I often found myself rewinding to check a transition, or to re-appreciate and reaffirm the quality of the soundtrack, which is masterfully conceived as a feeling enhancer.
Nature, the mind of an animal, god, death, human existence, music, art, truth and justice, love and magic, are all elements present in this film. I recommend watching it.

Edit: I read some of the reviews after writing this, and certainly didn't took this film as a comedy. It does have some really good, satisfying moments that would belong to the sort of ideal world typically depicted in comedy: the moments where the policeman gets what he deserves, for instance. I think I get why this could be seen as a comedy, but that is not the way I watched. Also, I didn't know anything about it beforehand.

I guess this is not my kind of movie. Made no sense, boring as heck, dumb and unbelievable plot. I love Gleason and Firth, but I don't think this movie played to their strengths, although they do great acting. But mid-way through, I couldn't care less what happened to either character. So I'll pass.
Such a funny, insightful film. Incredible performances and interesting commentary on misunderstandings and escalation. Stunning setting too

The genre should be comedy of despairs.
The media should be play not movie.

It's a sad and doom laden film, brightened up by quirky touches of very dark humour. The relationship between the two main characters, Padraic and Colm, opens up sensitively as the film develops and the two leads are at the peak of their powers.  
There is a repeated reference to being "nice" - Padraic is declared the nicest man on the island, whereas the old hag who creeps around the edges of the story is "not trying to be nice" - as opposed to interesting.  Padraic and Colm move back and forth along the spectrum between these two qualities.
Padraic is also keen not to be the most stupid man on the island; that title is given to Dominic, the official village idiot, who is smarter than he seems, causing Padraic to worry about his own real status.
A strong stomach is required occasionally, as the trailer will warn you, but this is not a macabre film; rather, it is a story about friendship and what's important in life.  The ending is beautiful.

Anytime a film features a donkey, you know symbolism galore is to follow.  Why cant a donkey ever just be a donkey?  This film has the nerve whats more to pose as an allegory of the irish civil war.  

Pretensionsaside, the acting in the film is superb, particulary Keoghan.  I agree with a certain few others, that the film is perhaps in reality a horror movie.  Just as the title states, hiding in plain sight.
this film is frustrating and unwatchable. colin farell is just sleepwalking the entire film

Is this what you have to do to win an Oscar? 
The cinematography was amazing. Ireland is gorgeous. The story line is pithy. Such a beautiful place, and potentially interesting and wonderfully simple people, in a tortuously inane storyline. 
It is as if the author created these people w naught but utter contempt. The animals were treated w more love and respect than this author afforded the human characters. 
This is two hours of my life I will never get back. I do not know how anyone could call this a comedy. 
The only reasons it gets 3 stars is the wild beauty of the Irish landscape, the subtle and fabulous use of color in costumes and filmography. Otherwise it is a shite movie.
Terrible movie.  I can't believe it is up for an oscar.

This is like Catnip to Oscar voters. Slow, confusing, disturbing. Acting is terrific all around and Colin Farrell reached new heights here with a beautiful performance. I would never watch this twice.

I found this movie to be boring. I got a few chuckles from the monotone dialogue, but the themes and humor in this movie just didn't land for me. I couldn't empathize with the characters, who all seem ignorant. Legacy is worthless, and annoying relationships are avoidable. The dramatic actions of the characters make no sense. The whole story just seems to be nothing about a whole bunch of nobodies.

When Irish Egos are not Smiling -- This film is bleak and hilarious like a Beckett play. 
Wonderful setting and characters, and the most bizarre threat I've ever heard made by one person to another.

Another BIZARRE movie.  It is getting to be a pandemic.  It seems as if the best way to get critics to love your film is to do something bizarre or nonsensical.  This movie was both.  The acting wasn't even as good as people claim.  I miss the good old days of movies that told great (and believable) stories.

"I don't like ya anymore." This simple gut punch is the spark that accelerates the chain of events that lead to self-mutilation, arson, and a dead donkey. The setting is the verdant fictional Irish island of Inisherin during the 1923 Irish Civil War — though none of that violence makes its way to the island, it's close enough that explosions can be heard from its shores. The day-to-day is almost fantastically Gaelic-bucolic — leading animals to pasture, writing elegiac songs for the violin, downing the same dark beer in the same dark pub. Pádraic (Colin Farrell) goes to heard his (supposed) friend, Colm (Brendan Gleeson) to the pub for their 2:00pm ritual. It's only back at the pub — and only after Colm treats Pádraic like a ghost — that Colm informs Pádraic that he no longer wants to speak to him. Not even a little. The Banshees of Inisherin is ripe with wholesome one-liners that are simple, yet witty. Both characters are gems — and somehow, the two most stubborn men in all of Ireland ended up on the same little island. Colm wants to "leave something behind" in the form of a song and finds Pádraic to be an aimless distraction keeping Colm from cementing his legacy. Pádraic just enjoys "good, normal chattin" — you can tell that his little home with his sister, his animals (especially, his beloved donkey named "Jenny"), and his chats at the pub with friends is satisfying life enough. You can understand both characters and if either just gave an inch (a hint, perhaps), they could both get what they wanted from each other. There are so, so many fantastic moments in this movie, but I keep finding myself returning to Pádraic's defense of "niceness". Barry Keoghan plays Dominic, a young lad who is beaten by his abusive father (Gary Lydon), seemingly the only police officer on the island. Keoghan possesses the ability to act using solely the bottom half of his face — it's something about the jaw. I first noticed it in The Killing of a Sacred Deer and it's even more pronounced here. I'm not sure I've ever seen anything like it before. **SPOILER ALERT** If there's one screenshot that captures the film, it's Colm conducting his troupe with a fingerless left hand, blood spattering across the sheet music on the pub table, with a dejected Pádraic standing over his shoulder in the background, having just entered the establishment. I have some catching up to do with 2022 movies, but as I write this, The Banshees of Inisherin is my favorite of the year and Best Film choice for the Oscars.
beautiful tale, existencial in the core

It was a well shot movie with amazing actors but the material was a brain breaking mess they didn't need to be told. I wished I liked it Ireland is beautiful and the actors did their best to sell it but it was just a tale of a friendship that falls apart with people and mental illnesses.  Which is fine but it's not something that I want to watch.
It's ok nothing great
Gave it every chance. Not a good movie. The attempted allegory fails. On many levels. Boring. Pointless. Acting was fine but how this movie won awards will never make sense to me.

A beautiful story about friendship, family, love and the central question of how to spend one's years. I was moved by every characters fate (especially Domics, with a heartwarming performance by Barry Keoghan). And although the film appears to be gloomy, burdened with philosophical questions and therefor rife with unhappyness (just observe how Colin Farrells eyes turn sadder with every minute of the film - great acting), we are to witness a funny story of change, hope and deeply humane bonds.

A dark comedy with unique characters and an off-beat story. The beautiful cinematography is worth the price of admission alone. A thoughtful, enjoyable film that transports you to a place and time not often visited on the big screen.

It's so funny!!! Brenden Gleeson is my favourite Irish actor!! I loved the fact it was all Irish and I just lived the plot!! My parents and I went to watch it and I couldn't stop laughing. My parents say it was more of dark humour and stuff but I love dark humour!!! I highly recommend this movie!!
If I got stranded on a desert isle, yep, this would be the one.  I so loved this movie.

Thoroughly enjoyed this film. I don't immediately think of Colin as a comedic actor, let alone in an early 1900s setting. But he deserves all the recognition he's getting for this role and reminded me why I've always liked him. Perfectly cast, there are no noticeable weaknesses. Not even in the brilliant casting of Lead Donkey.
Great drama and script!

I loved every frame of this movie.  I have seen it 3 times now and each time find something new.  The acting is a masterclass. Every single cast member is a gem.  McDonough's glorious writing especially the dialogue is so refreshing.  Dark comedy at its best and could have gone very pear-shaped in the wrong hands but all elements came together beautifully.
not really my type of film but it was an interesting enough watch, though at times it was hard to stay enaged

Thoroughly miserable, no substantive plot. The thinnest of allegories. The acting was good, but could not make up for the lack of plot. The supposed time and location made the few story elements even less believable, complete with several anachronisms, and the scenery, though pleasant to look at was disjointed due to trying to blend two topographically very different islands into one.

Overall a great disappointment from a director and cast that have done so much better previously. All the prizes and rave reviews give me a distinctly emperor's new clothes feeling...
Yes!  Something different.  Great acting, funny and beautiful scenery.  I liked it and then loved it when i looked up how it is an allegory and then it all made sense.

The acting is simply superb. However there is a claustrophobic atmosphere and the dark setting is unsettling. I have seen it as comedy and expected to have some laughs but it was extremely depressing.
Excellent cast. A story that seems so simple, yet really pulls you in and makes you want to root for Colin Farrell's character
This movie offers a unique approach to comedy and how it's a subjective genre. Tragedy + Perspective + Time = Comedy and 'The Banshees of Inisherin' offers this most carefully and dynamically.
A well acted and fantastically sad and slow burn up to the very end.

I just thought the story went absolutely nowhere. Being Irish and a big fan of Brendan Gleeson I expected to really like this but in my opinion it was a story about nothing that went nowhere and by the end it left me asking what was the point?

On a positive note Barry Keoghan was really good in it and if anyone deserved an award for that film it was him. I'd probably have turned it off only for his cameos throughout.
So interesting. Characters are well-written. Barry Keoghan stole the show for me. Depressing movie tho

I loved this movie.  But I didn't mean to.  You can come at this movie from so many angles (except the comic book action/switching universes angle).  It is a laugh out loud dark comedy, but you can take it as what is the meaning of life, what is immortality, what is important, man's stupid inhumanity to man in the face of great compassion to animals.  Not to mention the superb acting of Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson and the clever, clever writing. Wonderful characters and cast. I have to see it again.
Ripping emotional story about two dumb and stubborn Irish men on a desolate island outside Ireland. It gets prety nasty.

I loved everything about this movie: the quirky story, the cinematography, the scenery, the acting, everything.  The pace is what you'd expect of life in a small town on a small island off the coast of Ireland, but it's not a tedious pacing; it fits the story perfectly. The dialogue feels so authentic and characteristic of small towns and the intimacy of living in essentially a tribal society. The main story is refreshing and philosophical, and confronts us with questions about how we find meaning in our lives. It gets a bit dark, but it's Irish, for crying out loud. With just enough of a nod to ancient Celtic myth to keep things interesting.  Brilliant movie.

Nice scenery.  Other than that, it's one of the most bizarre story lines I've ever seen, and not in a good way.  Bizarre, twisted, and disturbing.  

One last note:  It's NOT a comedy.
Bleak, funny and enchanting. A must watch.

+ Beautiful cinematography, good actors.
- this is like eating a bap and calling it a burger

"The Banshees of Isherin" comes with the fantastic writing from director/writer Martin Mcdaugh, and the scenery displayed in the films Irish backdrop also enhance the film greatly. The performances by Colin Ferrel, and all others in the film are also fantastic. The film is very slow, but depending on how much that offputs you, your enjoyment will flucuate. Still a very solid film however.
Beautiful character study that moves a bit slow. Shows the human condition with a very simple but heartbreaking story

While the acting is indelibly the part of the film that makes it enthralling and worth a great review, the film is so disturbing and nonsensical that the actors are wasted in a story that is convoluted and psychotic.

I left the film once the fingers all came off…..and I heard it got worse after that. Perhaps a sociopath or psycho may love this, but anyone with a sense of self and humanity will find it hard to stomach this insane asylum inducing antisocial plot of a film.
Extra half star for Colin Farell’s performance

Amazing movie and so very original.  A dark comedy that jumps from cringeworthy scenes to hilarity, so that your not sure whether laughing out is akin to laughing at a friends funeral, but I did so anyway.  
Colin Ferrel and Brendan Gleason shouldn't be, but they are absolute magic together.  Proving that their prior project, "In Bruge", being absolutely wonderful, was no fluke.
Banchees is the  best movie of the year in my humble opinion.

Wow... I have to think the "critics" watched a different movie from me!

First the good:  good acting, reasonable cinematography. After that, well there's nothing for me to say in the "good" column.

Now the bad:  glacial, paint drying and mind numbing story line pace with one of the weakest storylines you'll ever see in a movie.   Here's a spoiler that summarizes the movie: Irish man in the 1920's has drinking friend who decides not to talk with him. 114 minutes perfectly summed up.  I just didn't get it, and usually I'm very much in line with the critics, definitely not this time though!

Awful. Give it a miss or save your money by watching ice melt or paint dry.

I went to see the film with my wife. We both really rate Farrell and Gleeson, but were so disappointed with this film.  It is so depressingly devoid of anything of interest, so bleak and uninspiring. One to forget.
Amazing scenery good acting just lacks a plot

Slow and kinda dull.  I had to look up why this is so well regarded.  Supposedly a metaphor for Irish Civil War which I don't know anything about (may have heard of the war back in high school history).
It's an allegory, right? About the Irish Civil War, yeah? Not sure I got it, and I definitely don't get the hype about this movie.
Collin and Brendan are very reliable in nearly everything they perform in. However, this movie is a bust and unwatchable. Self-indulgent, myopic work that resonates with nearly no one.
What a beautiful film. Deliberate and purposeful. The acting is incredible, and second only to Ireland's God-given scenery.
Dull and pointless without any plot of merit.
Depressing and repetitive.
Sad and funny at the same time, fantastic performances by all the actors.
Brilliantly done Irish allegory.

Strangely, one of the best movies I've ever seen.
I'm lost for how to explain how I feel about this movie.
Weirdly wonderful in every way.
Casting and acting is actually perfect.
I was completely hooked.
Nothing at all like In Bruges but the coupling of Farrell and Gleason is diamond.

This movie was very well acted and the cinematography was stunning. The plot however was bizarre and depressing. I wish I had those two hours of my life back! As you watch the film you keep thinking that it will get better and that there will be some point to the film other than “life sucks and then you die”. I suppose it teaches us that family and friends are over rated and should be abandoned if they don’t improve our lives. I’ve seen other films about toxic relationships that were good. This movie wasn’t one of them. The film never misses a beat in introducing one depressing incident after another even when it does nothing to advance the plot. Great acting and filming couldn’t rescue this story. After watching this film I felt like the victim of an assault that I unwittingly agreed to.
I LOVED this movie. I NEEDED this movie.

What a dreadful, brutal, pointless piece of faux satire. I've seen reviewers claim it's a metaphor for the centuries long conflict between Irish Protestants and Catholics. Rubbish! However misguided, both sides made the source of their grievances crystal clear. "I just don't like you any more" is a flimsy excuse for two hours of violence, animal cruelty and graphic self mutilation.

Well this is just about the most depressing movie I've ever seen in a while. First I get taunted by a friend that I wouldn't like it. Then it wins 3 golden globes awards including best picture , best actor and best screenplay, the trifecta. Probably is going to win the oscar too. Then. Rotten Tomatoes has almost 8. Well. I hated it. I gave it a 1/10. Gets a 1 because I actually finished it. Worst movie I've ever seen in a while. Just left an awful after taste in my mouth. So depressing. Gheez On HBOMAX
First hour was very deep, beautiful landscapes, interesting characters. After that just unnecessary violence began. Very cheap tricks to capture attention of the viewers. Disappointed.

The story portrays 3 aspects of life through 3 characters. It beautifully depicts the pain, suffering of loneliness and that strong sense of ever present longings within every human being. it has some good dark humours 
and Sometimes it's sad and gloomy.sometimes it felt like a horror in the given scenario. But major problems with the film are- its slow, like dead slow. There is no motive behind the story. It has some suspense/ thriller/twist elements present in it but that's not enough. I was always left wandering with two questions "why?" and where is the going. Its an average movie experience.

This is a film which features a lot of space in both a timing and metaphorical sense. Kinda ironic considering its about two friends who have issues when one wants his own 'space'. Brilliant acting, stunning cinematography and dialogue make this a fascinating film to watch on a big screen. One of the best films in years.
I loved the doubling down on revenge and bitterness - no saccharine ending here. A wonderful study of toxic masculinity and beautifully shot too.

Oversimplistic and naive. I don't believe a movie should be just an allegory and nothing more. Some of the metaphorical details have been already used in other movies and the camera was so unoriginal that I don't remember a single frame. Even the acting is not really what I expected. I'd call this a "thin movie", not really bad, but too void of content if you love a more complex cinematography.

Original premise, incredible acting, gorgeous filmography and funny dark humor. So cool to see three Irish actors who typically play American roles in their natural form. The humor reminded me a bit of Coen Brothers, or the director's other work "In Bruges." Yes, it's "slow" for some but if you don't have the expectation for immediate gratification and action, it pays off in the end. Makes you think a lot about expectations in friendship, how you spend your time, and recurrent depression.
I don't like to have to think that hard when I go to the movies for entertainment.  Drippy, downer of a movie. Excellent acting and cinematography.
Interesting but it was too exaggerated.
Naw, not worth the effort. The idea was good, but so far over the top and with a pointless ending. Lots of talent here, but a poor direction was taken by the creators.

Horrible story!  RT should have a 'disturbing violence' rating.  
Yes, the scenery.  Yes, the acting.  But, really?!
Beautifully shot, but boring depressing storyline.

The Banshees of Inisherin is a stunning dark comedy/drama feature that stars two of the best Irish actors ever to grace our screens with their presence. And that is what this film has in abounds, presence. 

A strong character piece is what holds this film together in that the characters are so well played that you almost forget the surroundings or somewhat lack of them since the island is very barren. 

Colin and Brendan play off each other perfectly and their natural accents just went hand in hand with the vernacular of the time it was set (1923), ending half of their lines with '...so?' Was a good example of the attention to detail when it came to making the speaking parts as authentic as possible.

The most noteworthy part about this movie, for me, is Colin Farrells unexpectedly brilliant performance. Not unexpected because I don't expect brilliance from him, but he was outstanding in this role and as someone who wasn't too hot on 'In Bruges', that came as a surprise. 

Gleeson is equally great and menacing with his own peculiar intent. The whole mix gives you an idea of small island life in the time of the Irish civil war, although it doesn't play much of a part in the film.

I give this movie 91%, I'd say 95-96%, but I think I'd have gone with a slightly different ending which could have perfected it for me.
Great acting and interesting story. Started as a dark comedy, but second half turned into a dark and sad film.

Exactly the kind of strange movie that critics fall over themselves for as great "art" while the audience says, "huh?"  The behavior of the character Colm makes no sense whatsoever in context. It's an outrageous reaction to nothing to speak of and drives what began as a lovely movie down the weirdest path. The movie seemed wonderfully enchanting until it wasn't. Bad trip for all concerned. To the critics who say this is an allegory to the ongoing (circa 1919) Irish civil war, continued rule by Great Britain seems much more compelling than what Padaric did not do.

Andy Wharol'15 minutes of celebrity for everyone has been reduced to 3 minutes on Tik Tok for everyone, but no one leaves a trace of her/his existence.

This is the futile struggle of a man, Colm, isolated in an isolated tiny world, where echoes of big facts are just very far noises. 

And in this little civil war he lost all, mainly the possibility to give the joy of friendship to a simple good man.

Very good direction and acting.
I loved the film.  Almost a masterpiece.  I imagine it's not for everyone but it certainly touched me.  Wonderful cast and glorious scenery (and animals!)

Despite the sad theme, the acting and scenery were outstanding!  Collin Farrell deserves a best actor award.  The screenplay, casting, music, everything was the best I've seen in years.  Yes, it's theme is dark and brooding, but hurts so good.
Although the cinematography and scenery are incredible, it just didn't live up to the accolades being handed out.  The story was confusing and illogical.  Acting was great but the story wasn't.
Reaching for susbstance and under achieving.  Boring movie about depression, rejection aspiration and nothing.  Slow as hell.
The Golden Globes had this in the wrong category. There is nothing comedic or musical about this film. It was a beautiful film. Well acted. Donkey, heartbreaking. Watch it.
Horrifyingly slow and sad. Ruin your whole day kind of movie.

Cards on the table, I'm Irish so have a somewhat jaundiced view of how film world has often portrayed 'Oireland' in the past. Needn't have fretted though, in McDonaghs very capable and safe hands all was well with this wonderfully shot jet black film, delivered with warm comedic touches that explores so many themes quite close to Irish hearts. The scenery and cute critters aside, this was more Shakespeare or Greek tragedy than Hollywood, with Trojan performances by the 2 leads, especially Farrell and incredible supporters, particularly Barry Keoghan who should never have to audition for a part again after his astonishing playing of the village 'gom'
In short, it is beautiful, tragic, funny, sad, dark and should NOT be missed. See it with an Irish woman's blessing.
Excellent acting across the board & Assured directing and Cinematography. Won't be everyone's cup of tea but I really enjoyed it.

It started off with an interesting premise and went quickly into the toilet.
My husband wanted to turn the movie off before I did because of the gory content which seemed really unnecessary.  There were so many other ways to convey the
content than the gory method employed.  So disappointing, lazy and dim witted.

I am still thinking about this story today.  What is friendship and how does it form and remain vital?  What is one's responsibility to one's friends?   Is being nice more valuable than being important.  What is the meaning of life. What does one do when a friend is clearly depressed and is there anything that can stop it?
I loved the characters and the scenery was stunning.

Although the backdrops were stunning, i felt the film was very slow and never really got going enough to grab your interrest ! Dark comedys dont exacly grab me in general, i find them depressing ! Comedy should be funny not dark !
OMG this was hilarious! Another one I put off watching and really enjoyed it.
For Gods sake just leave the man alone!!! Like watching a riddle that’s never explained and you don’t care enough to try to figure it out.

What the heck did  I just watch and who on earth thinks this is a comedy? Just a sad slow slog. The only redeeming quality is the beauty of the country side. Just watch it with the sound off and enjoy scenery. Terrible story unless you enjoyed your close reading classes in grammar school where everything has some other hidden meaning .

The most beautiful film i have ever seen. Truly. Cried out so many tears as it is not an easy one to watch (though the funny light-hearted moments help to go through!) But in the end, it revealed such a deep, profound message about humanity; our fears, hopes, anger that leads to wars.... A masterpiece. Excellent roles, music, screenplay, pictures, EVERYTHING. You must watch it!

Banshees of inisherin is one of those movies you watch, it doesn't blow your mind or anything of the sort, but it deeply affects you in its  themes and in its perfect execution. 

Mcdonagh once again pulls off a great comedy with a deep exploration of human nature. Here we explore the fear of loneliness. Something we all fear, but something we all eventually have to experience. 

Everything flows so naturally in this film, the jokes  are well executed and balanced. The movie doesn't try to make you cry or make you feel sorry for someone.

It's far from a must watch, but It's a good piece of film that will leave you thinking about you, your relationships and leaves you wondering "Am I lonely?"
funny and sad movie, got deeper and darker as it progressed, which just gave it more impact.  Great performance from Gleeson, Farrell and the donkey.
Nah. Not for me. Too dark and actually didn't get the reasoning for some of the plot.  No character explanations. Also I felt too many Irish stereotypes going on.

I give this four stars because nearly every aspect of this movie is about as close to perfect as can be . . . it's missing a star because of the story (though not the story-telling). To say the movie is dark and depressing is an understatement. These are about a group of Irish living on there small island off the coast of Ireland, where there's not much to do except go to church, hit the pub, usually at 2 p.m. every afternoon, and talk about the same things over and over again. Or talk about trivial things over and over again . . . so much so that one character simply ends a friendship because he no longer can listen to the man's palaver. In fact, he's willing to cut off a finger at a time to convince his ex-friend (Colin Farrell) that he no longer can stand his company. These are people who are stuck in their loneliness and do not have the "inner resources" to deal with their isolation from one another as well as themselves. Even some of the farm animals, particularly a miniature donkey, get  caught up in the darkness that seems to be everywhere. (Also of note, at least in terms of the way the film uses a Bergmann-like symbol in the dress and speech of an old woman they call the Ghoul; a Fellini-like symbol comes in the occasional explosion of cannon fire to the east of a "war" or rebellion that is due to cease any day now.) I did like this move, though honestly I doubt I'll ever sit through it again. Just about every aspect, great or small, about this movie rings true in most of our lives. Loneliness, the inarticulation of isolation that leads to rage--or the quiet moment where you either go mad and harm yourself . . . or take it out on anything you can get your hands on in the moment.

Not funny, slow, morose and ultimately a depressing outing. At the end of the day, entertainment should be at the forefront of art, and Banshees failed to provide the opening that spurs interest in seeking hidden meanings. Sad to see this from such a brilliant cast and director.
I do not understand the buzz for this movie. It was not funny and it was not entertaining. It was depressing and tragic in a bad way.
It's long past time that Colin Ferrell was awarded with an Oscar.
Boring and just a bit pointless

I kept waiting and waiting for something to happen. The storyline is wish wash pointless. Grey, sad characters with very low IQ's. Odd yet intriguing just wished for more emotion and intensity and even conversation between characters. Overall feeling of ‘this is odd'. Hmmmm

A sad tale told through amazing writing by Martin McDonagh and the masterful acting performances of Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson and (IMHO the show stealer) Barry Keoghan all taking place on the small Irish island of Inisherin. An amazingly beautiful location to shoot, and the cinematographers do well to show you it all from the cliffs to the beaches, to the small town square, to our 2 best friends local watering hole. All taking place in the early 1920s on the outskirts of the Irish Civil War, that can be seen raging just over on the mainland.

This film has a bit of Irish folk music throughout, as the story is partly centered around Gleeson's character writing a new song, as well as some of the fecking drama that 'potentially' could encompass the people of such a small Island community, told in a dark comedic way.
Hit my soul to be honest. Every word is worth thinking. Beautiful scenes.

Or a perfect movie, but a really, really good one. Excellent acting. Original story. Beautifully shot. Good, complex characters that develop and change. This won't be for everyone. There's no action, but there is some dark comic relief. It's mostly a slowly developing drama about people living on an island off the coast of Ireland at the end of the civil war there in 1929 (?). There's a lot of sadness. it's gripping and dark. If you like this sorta thing, you'll definitely like this movie.

As an irishman i can't help but think I am biased in my review but this movie tells such a genuine story. I am no patriot to my country nor do i even agree with half of it but this story feels so distinctly irish, an absolute must watch in my opinion a truely beautiful film with an incredible cast easily one of my favourite movies of the year
Beautiful scenery, great acting, slow very sad story. Not sure what the message was. Respect boundaries, loneliness can kill you?

I know that humor is subjective, but calling this grim tale a "comedy" astounds me. Critics called it "remarkably hilarious" ; "often very funny";  "shot through with bristling humor"  Really? What part? The bleak island life part? The loneliness part? The self-mutilation part? That sad soul washing up dead part? The ending (spoiler alert) when you realize that it's not over until one of the two is dead?

The LOL incident with Colm and the priest going at it in the confessional is entirely out of character with the movie. About as jarring as a stand-up comedian on the train in "Schindler's List" would have been.

Though, as for that, if people can see "Banshees" as a comedy, it wouldn't shock me to find out people somehow found humor in THAT movie . . .
Great performances but too preach. This is like one of those bad ‘Christian movies’ with its blatant metaphors and boring speeches.
Wickedly funny, dark and bleak. The countryside is morose and beautiful and you're left feeling empty in the best way.
fakey cutie deedle-dye leprechaun Lucky Charms Irish -- overacted, overwrought, patronizing -- faux-gritty -- couldn't stand this cartoonish tomfoolery and buffoonery
A fantastic movie, the Irish countryside looks incredible.

Absolutely terrible!  Wasted time I can never have back. This year has been the worst year in movies. Tell the writers and producers to pull their heads out of each others asses and make something worth our time
How! Why? Remember, just one man's opinion..but that was bloody awful!! (Pun intended)

Well it's not a comedy. It's one of the saddest movies I have ever seen. Pure heartbreak and just makes you feel lost. It touches a part of every person who just wants to be loved. Well written, great acting, but not uplifting. Watch it and forget it or you will end up eating a bullet.

Visually engaging and Farrell is kind of funny in parts. What really amazes me is how something like this can gain so many positive, praising reviews. Did they watch a different film from me? Don't these people have capacity for boredom? I was bored out of my mind. I think it was trying so hard to be clever and funny. You could see all the seams real well. So much better out there. Watch 20 mins then snap-decide if you want to dedicate 2 hours of your only life to this.

Went in expecting a light-hearted slice of soap, but it's so much more. Brilliantly funny to begin with, then heartbreakingly sad as it goes on. Wonderful performances from all, and although I had to read up on the allegory, it works just as well without knowing it. Recommended.

Story of imagination.  Start with one friend who won't talk to his former friend.  Add in his rage because his friend continues to want his friendship .  Rage becomes his self mutilation. Even worse because he destroys his ability to play music.  Then make it sad by having the guys pet die.  Throw in a witch that predicts everything because after all it is Ireland.  Next have a fire.  Save the lovely dog . Yea!  Add in magnificent scenery!  Interesting but I could have written it.  No maybe not.  I don't think I would have thought  of the self mutilation part.  That was unique!  But not realistic because if you did that I'm sure the pain would be out of this world pain.
Amazingly dark but funny film. Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson are so good. One of my favorites of the year, and I hope it does well in all the awards shows later this year.

A VERY VERY DARK comedy, beautifully acted. It's worth watching just to see an incredible acting job of Barry Keoghan....it's so nuanced and beautifully acted it's worth watching just for him. But really all of the actors are brilliant. It is a bit squeamish in a few parts...the build up is very tense too.

I have to give this movie all 5 stars.  The script... omg so good.  It feels like the movie would be slow but no, every scene is so great and fun to watch.  Amazing film.  Stellar acting and such an interesting story.

Love all McDonagh's movies with the exception of this movie. Bewilderingly, RT gives this movie McDonagh's highest score. It is watchable and gets just a passing grade from me. It moved along far too slow. After the first 10 minutes you find out Gleeson's character no longer wants to be friends with Farrell 's and an hour later that is still about all you know. Dark humour that is one of McDonagh's strengths as a writer seems absent here. The symbolism of the broken friendship and the war on the mainland is weakly connected. It is the type of movie critics give best picture to but less enjoyed by general audiences.

Banshees of Inisherin is definitely not bad. It's got good writing. Let me rephrase; it's got great writing! It's the writer's ability that creates a two-hour drama out of such limited cast and locations. However, it fails to go beyond its great script and become a great motion picture as it fails to convey the greatness of its story (assuming it is) through meaningful cinematography. Evidently, the author is aware of this shortcoming as he (assuming it is) repeatedly throws footage of beautiful natural features such as landscapes and animals with little to no relevance to the plot development.

Apart from that, good acting and mise-en-scene are top two contributing factors to the enjoyability of the experience of watching this movie.
Loved the actors but hated the tale.  Too weird, too disgusting, too sad.
What was the point of this movie?

Charming. Whimsical. Metaphorical. Timeless. Hilarious in places but terribly sad in others. A tale of friendship, relationships, aging, and broken dreams with the canons of a civil war across the water punctuating. Wonderful performances from everyone in the cast but a brilliant, heartbreaking turn from Barry Keoghan and Colin Farrell at his very best sit atop a cream filled crop. Martin McDonagh is an excellent and prolific writer who never strays too far from the simplicity of "you killed my cat, so I'm a kill yours" although "You can choose your friends but can't choose your family" seems to be the major theme here, (with a little of the former). Loved it.

Always interesting to see lifestyles and this film certainly did a good job in showcasing the Irish island regime. Additionally it is a pleasure to see the fine cast of assembled do their work. However unlike "In Bruges" where Gleeson & Farrell clicked so wonderfully, the characters they portray in this movie are so pathetic it is hard to watch. Makes anyone with a backbone want to do some punching.

It for me was in 3D: 
Dull, depressing, and demented. 
So much so I think I need to wash out my brain.
The smart one got off that forsaken island, 
the rest were a bunch of "nut bags."
How does that make a good movie.
They say it was at least scenic, 
but even the island itself was depressing:
Who was the sad soul that had to pile all those rocks.
A superb film. The writing, the performances, the cinematography, the setting are sublime.

Watched most of the movie with a friend. We got tired and called it a night. He told me to let him know if the movie got good. I finished and sadly, it didn't. Great acting and setting! Although, a 97% on rotten tomatoes is baffling. Makes me wonder how some of these critics have a job. Extremely misleading score. It's a slow burn, doesn't leave a lasting impression, the hidden meanings they weren't very obvious to the average viewer, overall not worth the watch. You're not missing much other than Collin Farrell's versatility when it comes to acting.

I understand the low audience score...but I agree with the critics: this is a very good movie.  Tired of the same plots being used over and over again in Hollywood?  THIS is definitely a unique story!  You must remember: this is a comedy.  Well, it's a comedy, a tragedy, a drama.   I did laugh several times throughout the movie...it's so...ridiculous!  And of course, I felt the heavy dramatic feelings as well.
